Small bowel polyps showing malignant cells located at the lamina propria and submucosa. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at × 4 magnification.

Histopathology of small bowel polyps showing malignant cells arranged in diffuse sheets with the presence of intracytoplasmic and extracellular pigments. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at × 20 magnification.
Small bowel polyps showing malignant cells located at the lamina propria and submucosa. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at × 4 magnification.

Histopathology showing spindle cell uveal melanoma from a left eye choroidal pigmented malignant melanoma, classified as invasive in the ciliary body and cornea (stage IIIB, pT4bN0M0). The microscopic examination reveals a dense cell proliferation composed of small and medium fusiform (spindle) cells, along with evident pigment production. The tissue fragments were embedded in paraffin for this histopathological examination. Staining is Hematoxylin–Eosin (HE), magnified ×100.
Histopathology showing spindle cell uveal melanoma with corneal invasion. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (HE) at ×100 magnification.
Histopathology showing spindle cell uveal melanoma with invasion of the ciliary processes. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (HE) at ×100 magnification.

Histopathology at ×20 magnification, illustrating amelanotic variants of melanoma cells. These cells lack melanin, making them challenging to diagnose in routine hematoxylin and eosin (H&E)-stained specimens and potentially leading to misidentification with non-melanocytic tumors. The scale bar represents 50 μm.

Histopathology at ×20 magnification, illustrating amelanotic variants of melanoma cells. These cells lack melanin, making them challenging to diagnose in routine hematoxylin and eosin (H&E)-stained specimens and potentially leading to misidentification with non-melanocytic tumors. The scale bar represents 50 μm.

Histopathology at ×20 magnification, illustrating amelanotic variants of melanoma cells. These cells lack melanin, making them challenging to diagnose in routine hematoxylin and eosin (H&E)-stained specimens and potentially leading to misidentification with non-melanocytic tumors. The scale bar represents 50 μm.

Histopathology at ×20 magnification, illustrating amelanotic variants of melanoma cells. These cells lack melanin, making them challenging to diagnose in routine hematoxylin and eosin (H&E)-stained specimens and potentially leading to misidentification with non-melanocytic tumors. The scale bar represents 50 μm.

Histopathological evaluation showing a relatively uniform medium-sized polyhedral-epithelioid and spindle cell neoplastic proliferation with a zonal discohesive pattern, massive and focal fasciculated architecture (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, 10× magnification). Microscopically, the malignant population is observed to be confined predominantly to the submucosa, exhibiting a dissecting effect on the muscular and serosal layer of the jejunal wall, with extrinsic colonic invasion up to the mucosa level. Scattered multinucleated osteoclast-like giant cells are evident. Areas of necrosis are obviously apparent in approximately 50% of the tumoral volume, and the stroma exposes broad areas of fibrohyalinization. Lymphovascular invasion (LVI) with the presence of neoplastic emboli and perineural infiltration (PNI) is identifiable.

Histopathological evaluation revealing moderate cito-nuclear pleomorphism, with coarse chromatin and conspicuous nucleoli (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, 20× magnification). High mitotic activity is present, noted as 30 mitoses per 10 high-power fields (HPFs) with atypical mitotic figures.

Histopathology from a skin biopsy of a 35-year-old woman presenting with a pigmented patch on the right breast, demonstrating epidermal acanthosis and hyperpigmentation of basal cells, particularly pronounced at the rete pegs of the epidermis. The biopsy findings also included hyperpigmentation of the basement membrane associated with numerous melanophages, with no cytonuclear atypia or melanocytic hyperplasia, which helped to exclude cutaneous melanoma and pigmented Paget's disease. This image supports the retained diagnosis of MAN. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 200x magnification.

Histopathological examination demonstrating orthokeratosis, mild epidermal spongiosis, and perivascular infiltration of lymphocytes in the upper dermis. The image is stained with hematoxylin-eosin at an original magnification of ×400.
Histopathological examination showing a high magnification view of the dermal infiltrate, consisting of lymphocytes. The image is stained with hematoxylin-eosin at an original magnification of ×1000.

Histopathology from a blackish-brown plaque on the right sole of a 49-year-old diabetic female, diagnosed as talon noir (black heel) and a benign lesion due to repeated microtrauma. This panel (A) shows intraepidermal collections of degenerated red cells (black arrow), which are characteristic findings in this condition. Microscopic examination also revealed severe hyperkeratosis, parakeratosis, and acanthosis, with multiple foci of acute inflammatory exudates in the epidermis, and large areas of hemorrhage in the dermal papillae. (Hematoxylin and eosin, 20× magnification).

Histopathology from a blackish-brown plaque on the right sole of a 49-year-old diabetic female, diagnosed as talon noir (black heel) and a benign lesion due to repeated microtrauma. This panel (B) shows intraepidermal collections of degenerated red cells (black arrow), which are characteristic findings in this condition. Microscopic examination also revealed severe hyperkeratosis, parakeratosis, and acanthosis, with multiple foci of acute inflammatory exudates in the epidermis, and large areas of hemorrhage in the dermal papillae. (Hematoxylin and eosin, 20× magnification).

Histopathology from a blackish-brown plaque on the right sole of a 49-year-old diabetic female, diagnosed as talon noir (black heel) and a benign lesion due to repeated microtrauma. This panel (C) shows a focal acute inflammatory exudate (black arrow) within the epidermis, a characteristic finding in this condition. Microscopic examination also revealed severe hyperkeratosis, parakeratosis, and acanthosis, with intraepidermal collections of degenerated red cells also present, and large areas of hemorrhage in the dermal papillae. (Hematoxylin and eosin, 20× magnification).

Histopathology from a blackish-brown plaque on the right sole of a 49-year-old diabetic female, diagnosed as talon noir (black heel) and a benign lesion due to repeated microtrauma. This panel (D) shows an intraepidermal inflammatory exudate, a characteristic finding in this condition. Microscopic examination also revealed severe hyperkeratosis, parakeratosis, and acanthosis, with intraepidermal collections of degenerated red cells also present, and large areas of hemorrhage in the dermal papillae. (Hematoxylin and eosin, 40× magnification).

Whole-slide image (WSI) stained with PHH3 and counterstained with H&E at 40× magnification, showing two identified mitotic figures (yellow circles). This panel illustrates the initial microscopic view from which PHH3-stained mitotic figures are identified, a process for which good agreement has been observed between QuPath, ImageJ, and pathologist eye in subsequent analyses.

Histopathological image showing hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining of tumor cells from Case 1, magnified 400x. These tumor cells tested positive for estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR), with expression observed in their nuclei. This melanoma developed and spread rapidly during pregnancy.

Histopathological image showing hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining of nevus cells from Case 1, magnified 400x. The presence of these nevus cells near the melanoma was histopathologically confirmed in this case, where melanoma developed and spread rapidly during pregnancy.

Histopathological image showing hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining of tumor cells from Case 2, magnified 400x. These tumor cells tested positive for estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR), with expression observed in their nuclei. This melanoma developed and spread rapidly during pregnancy.

Histopathological image showing hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining of nevus cells from Case 2, magnified 400x. The presence of these nevus cells near the melanoma was histopathologically confirmed in this case, where melanoma developed and spread rapidly during pregnancy.

Histopathological image showing hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining of tumor cells from Case 3, magnified 400x. These tumor cells tested positive for estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR), with expression observed in their nuclei. This melanoma developed and spread rapidly after childbirth.

Histopathological image showing hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining of nevus cells from Case 3, magnified 400x. The presence of these nevus cells near the melanoma was histopathologically confirmed in this case, where melanoma developed and spread rapidly after childbirth.

Thyroid histology showing melanoma metastasis. This image depicts one of the multiple bilateral cancer foci found in the thyroid, confirming a diagnosis of multinodular goiter. The metastatic melanoma displays characteristics overlapping with the primary nasal mucosa neoplasm and showed immunoreactivity for HMB-45. (H&E staining, x200 magnification).

Thyroid histology showing neoplastic cells, identified as melanoma metastasis, infiltrating the parenchyma without destroying the thyroid follicles. These epithelioid or spindle cells exhibit granular chromatin and scant cytoplasm. This image represents one of the multiple bilateral cancer foci found in the thyroid, confirming a diagnosis of multinodular goiter. The tumor's characteristics overlap with the primary nasal mucosa neoplasm and it showed immunoreactivity for HMB-45. (H&E staining, x400 magnification).

Histopathological image showing melanoma infiltrating prostate glands. The tumor cells present with round nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and moderate cytoplasm. Both intracellular and extracellular deposits of melanin pigment are visible. [H&E, 400X]

Histopathology stained with H&E, magnified x40, depicting a small, approximately 2 mm, circumscribed melanocytic matricoma located within the dermis. The tumor is described microscopically as a small round neoplasm featuring a central area of shadow cells surrounded by basaloid epithelial proliferation. Peripheral patches of melanin pigment deposition are observed in atypical epithelioid cells. Moderate pleomorphism, hyperchromatism, and increased mitotic activity (up to 6 mitoses/high power field, averaging 3-4 mitoses/high power field) are visible, predominantly in the non-pigmented epithelial cells. A clear-cut abrupt transition of basaloid cells into shadow cells is also evident. The epidermis appears unremarkable.

This hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained image, captured at 400x magnification, displays mitoses within non-pigmented cells, which are highlighted by black rings. Additionally, several shadow cells are visible, marked by pink areas.

Histopathology image stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 400x magnification. The image displays mitoses located both close to and away from pigmented cells, which are highlighted by black rings. A few shadow cells are also visible, indicated by a blue arrow.

Histopathology stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at x100 magnification, displaying distinct features including patches of pigmented cells (indicated by red arrows), blue basaloid cells (indicated by a yellow arrow), and shadow cells (indicated by blue arrows).

H&E-stained section (100x) showing histopathological features suggestive of intramucosal nevi. The image displays the proliferation of nevus cells, characterized by cohesive islands of polygonal to oval epithelioid cells with focal melanin pigment production. Nests of nevus cells are separated by a hyalinised band beneath the stratified squamous surface epithelium. The nevus cells exhibit junctional separation and differentiation, without significant cellular atypia or dysplasia. The associated fibrous connective tissue contains dense bundles of collagen fibres. A yellow arrow points to Type A cells, which are large and round, without dendritic processes, located at the periphery adjacent to the epithelium with intense melanin accumulation. A blue arrow points to Type B cells, which are uniform, round to polygonal, found in deeper layers, and show decreased melanin deposition. Lesional cells are observed close to the excision borders.

Histopathological examination of excised tissue revealing atypical fusiform and epithelioid melanocytes containing granular or dense melanin pigment. These melanocytes extended from the lower dermis to the subcutaneous layer. These findings are consistent with a malignant melanoma arising in association with PTBN. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification ×40.

Histopathology of a longitudinal nail biopsy showing benign melanocytic activation. The image, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at an original magnification of 20X, displays proliferation of melanocytes in the nail matrix and nail bed. In benign melanocytic activation, the pigmentation of the nail plate is primarily due to activated melanocytes in the distal matrix, with melanocytes typically being almost absent in the nail bed, contrasting with their normal presence mainly at the nail matrix level in physiologic conditions.

Histopathology of a longitudinal nail biopsy showing benign melanocytic activation. The image, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at an original magnification of 25X, displays proliferation of melanocytes in the nail matrix and nail bed. In benign melanocytic activation, the pigmentation of the nail plate is primarily due to activated melanocytes in the distal matrix, with melanocytes typically being almost absent in the nail bed, contrasting with their normal presence mainly at the nail matrix level in physiologic conditions.

Histopathologic aspects of a nail matrix biopsy showing nail melanoma. The image displays proliferation of atypical melanocytes in the basal and supra-basal layers of the nail matrix. Nail melanoma often presents clinically as longitudinal melanonychia, a brown to black band of the nail plate. Histologically, both melanin granules and atypical (pagetoid) melanocytes can be observed in nail melanoma. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification 10X.

Histopathologic aspects of a nail matrix biopsy showing nail melanoma. The image displays proliferation of atypical melanocytes in the basal and supra-basal layers of the nail matrix. Nail melanoma often presents clinically as longitudinal melanonychia, a brown to black band of the nail plate. Histologically, both melanin granules and atypical (pagetoid) melanocytes can be observed in nail melanoma. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification 25X.

Histopathological examination (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, original magnification 5x) of the ulcerated plaque from the left leg of a 58-year-old woman, showing irregular hyperplastic epidermis. In the dermis, large nests composed of basaloid keratinocytes are present, exhibiting palisading of cells at the periphery and clefts with the surrounding stroma, consistent with a basal cell carcinoma component. An inflammatory infiltrate is also noted in the perilesional area. These basaloid nests were identified as BerEp4-positive.

Histopathological examination (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, original magnification 5x) of the ulcerated plaque from the left leg of a 58-year-old woman, revealing irregular hyperplastic epidermis. In the dermis, large nests of BerEp4-positive basaloid cells are present, alongside a second cell population consisting of spindle cells and dendritic cells. These spindle and dendritic cells stained positive for Melan-A, S100, and HMB-45, representing a melanoma component. A heavy inflammatory infiltrate is also observed in the perilesional area.

Higher magnification (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, original magnification 20x) of the histopathological examination of the ulcerated plaque from the left leg of a 58-year-old woman. This image shows the morphology of BerEp4-positive basaloid cells, as well as atypical spindle and dendritic cells (which stained positive for Melan-A, S100, and HMB-45) with visible mitotic figures, indicating proliferation within both the basal cell carcinoma and melanoma components.

Histopathological examination (likely Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, original magnification 5x) of the ulcerated plaque from the left leg of a 58-year-old woman. The image shows a large nest composed of BerEp4-positive basaloid cells with characteristic palisading of cells at the periphery, a feature consistent with the basal cell carcinoma component of the lesion. This morphology is observed within the dermis.

Histologic image showing a lentiginous intraepidermal proliferation of melanocytes on the right (blue arrowheads) and a benign intradermal nevus on the left (yellow star). This image illustrates a case with only slight atypia upon final histologic evaluation. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at an original magnification of 40x.

Histologic image demonstrating a melanocytic proliferation arranged in a continuous lentiginous pattern. This image illustrates a case with only slight atypia upon final histologic evaluation. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at an original magnification of 100x.

Histopathology image showing hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, elongation of the rete ridges of the epidermis, and papillomatosis of the overlying epidermis. Dilated vascular spaces are observed within the papillary dermis, with no atypia. The lesion was excised under local anesthesia, fixed for 24 hours in buffered formaldehyde, and prepared for paraffin-embedded processing; serial sections were stained using ordinary hematoxylin and eosin stains and examined under a light microscope. (H&E, 100x magnification).
Histopathology showing pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia of the overlying skin, characterized by papillomatous hyperplasia of the epidermis. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin, magnification 10×.

Histopathology of the skin with dermis and subcutis showing an infiltrating neoplasm composed of large cells arranged in diffuse sheets and nests. The tumor cells are infiltrating the subcutis. These histopathological features are consistent with a granular cell tumor. Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, magnification 4×.

Histopathology showing large polygonal cells, characteristic of a granular cell tumor. The cells have abundant eosinophilic granular cytoplasm and round, uniform, to oval vesicular nuclei with clumped chromatin and a few with conspicuous nucleoli. The cell borders are indistinct. Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, magnification 40×.

Histopathology of a papular lesion stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 40x magnification, showing the separation of collagen bundles by mucin. The image displays an 'empty appearance' due to the deposition of amorphous materials, identified as mucin, which separate collagen fibers in the papillary dermis. This finding is consistent with increased mucin deposition observed in specimens from papular lesions.

Histopathology of a papular lesion stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 100x magnification, showing an increased number of fibroblasts with stellate forms. This observation supports the histological findings from papular lesions where fibroblasts were noted to be increased in number.

Histopathological overview of an excised supernumerary caruncle from patient 1, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (HE). The image shows the overall structure of the lesion, which was diagnosed as a supernumerary caruncle of the left eye (LE). Histopathological examination revealed a composition of nonkeratinizing squamous epithelium (four to six cells thick) with an admixture of goblet cells, marked subepithelial lymphoplasmacytic cellular infiltration, intervening epidermal cysts, sebaceous glands, and underlying adipose tissue. Hair follicles or sweat/lacrimal glands were not found in the tissue. The scale bar equals 200 μm.

Histopathological details of an excised supernumerary caruncle from patient 1, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (HE). This image highlights key features of the lesion, which was diagnosed as a supernumerary caruncle of the left eye (LE). Specific elements pointed out are: 1. Sebaceous glands, 2. Goblet cells, 3. Lymphoplasmacellular infiltration, and 4. Epidermal cysts. Further examination showed the lesion to be composed of nonkeratinizing squamous epithelium (four to six cells thick), an admixture of goblet cells, marked subepithelial lymphoplasmacytic cellular infiltration, and epidermal cysts (containing scattered hairs), adjacent to sebaceous glands and underlying adipose tissue. Hair follicles or sweat/lacrimal glands were not found. The scale bar equals 200 μm.

Histopathological image of the excised caruncle, revealing features consistent with a diagnosis of megacaruncle. The section, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE), shows (1) mucus, (2) non-keratinizing squamous epithelium with goblet cells, which is four to six cells thick, (3) sebaceous glands, (4) squamous epithelium with beginning keratinization in areas of more exposed tumor tissue where goblet cells are significantly fewer, and (5) adipocytes. The overall enlargement of the caruncle and reactive keratinization in exposed areas support the diagnosis of megacaruncle, rather than a dermoid. The bar represents 250 μm.

Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained section showing the tumor located in the ankle region. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) indicated that this lesion in the patient's right ankle was separate from the lesion in the right plantar region shown in panel B.

Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained section showing the tumor located in the plantar region. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) indicated that this lesion in the patient's right plantar was separate from the lesion in the right ankle region shown in panel A.

Histopathology showing an epidermal lesion with defined nests of small, round, poroid, or basaloid-shaped cells without atypia or mitosis, located in the spinous layer of the acanthotic epidermis. These cells form teak-shaped nests with regular sizes and rounded contours arranged discontinuously, characterizing the Borst-Jadassohn phenomenon. The overall histopathological findings are consistent with a diagnosis of clonal seborrheic keratosis, also showing vascular proliferation and a slight lymphocytic inflammatory infiltrate in the papillary dermis. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification 40×.

Histopathology revealing an epidermal lesion, characteristic of clonal seborrheic keratosis, with several foci of proliferating epithelial cells. These cells are basaloid, round, and small, lacking atypia or mitosis, and form teak-shaped nests with regular sizes and rounded contours arranged discontinuously. The papillary dermis shows vascular proliferation and a slight lymphocytic inflammatory infiltrate. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification 100×.

High magnification histopathology demonstrating an epidermal lesion, consistent with clonal seborrheic keratosis, where epithelial cells show proliferation. These cells are basaloid, round, and small, without atypia or mitosis, forming teak-shaped nests with regular sizes and rounded contours arranged discontinuously. Vascular proliferation and a slight lymphocytic inflammatory infiltrate are also noted in the papillary dermis. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification 400×.

Histopathology of a lesion from a 65-year-old male on his right leg, diagnosed as hidroacanthoma simplex. The image shows the epidermis with orthokeratosis, mild papillomatosis, and acanthosis. There are nests of small, round cells without atypia, poroid in appearance (blue arrow), which are smaller than the surrounding keratinocytes (*). These cells exhibit a hyperchromatic nucleus and scarce cytoplasm, forming nests with well-defined contours within the interpapillary cones. A duct is visible among the poroid-looking cells (black arrow). Hematoxylin and eosin stain, 100× magnification.

Histopathology of a lesion from a 65-year-old male on his right leg, diagnosed as hidroacanthoma simplex. The image shows the epidermis with orthokeratosis, mild papillomatosis, and acanthosis. There are nests of small, round cells without atypia, poroid in appearance (blue arrow), which are smaller than the surrounding keratinocytes (*). These cells exhibit a hyperchromatic nucleus and scarce cytoplasm, forming nests with well-defined contours within the interpapillary cones. A duct is visible among the poroid-looking cells (black arrow). Hematoxylin and eosin stain, 400× magnification.

Histopathology of an in situ melanoma on the left leg, stained with Hematoxylin & eosin (×100 magnification). The image shows intense cytological atypia and exuberant pagetoid dissemination, which is characteristic of in situ melanoma, and importantly, observed without dermal invasion.

Histopathology (Hematoxylin–Eosin stain) showing a low-power view of hyperkeratosis with horn cysts and pseudocysts. These microscopic findings, including hyperkeratosis with horn pseudocyst formation, are compatible with Seborrheic Keratosis (SK) in a 16-year-old boy who presented with a waxy, brown-black, oval-shaped lesion on his face.

Histopathology (Hematoxylin–Eosin stain) showing a high-power view of basaloid keratinocyte proliferation without dysplasia and horn pseudocyst formation. These microscopic findings, including basaloid keratinocyte proliferation without dysplasia and horn pseudocyst formation, are compatible with Seborrheic Keratosis (SK) in a 16-year-old boy who presented with a waxy, brown-black, oval-shaped lesion on his face.

Histopathology showing spindle cells with single-elongated nuclei and bipolar cytoplasm, mature adipocytes, fibromyxoid stroma, and collagen bands, which together mimic spindle cell lipoma. The lesion is located more deeply within the tissue. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (original magnification ×200).

Histopathology showing spindle cells with single-elongated nuclei and bipolar cytoplasm, mature adipocytes, fibromyxoid stroma, and collagen bands, which together mimic spindle cell lipoma. The lesion is located more deeply within the tissue. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (original magnification ×400).

Histopathology showing short nerve bundles (neural structures) embedded in the lesional stroma, along with mature adipocytes, spindle cells, and fibrous stroma. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (original magnification ×400).

Histopathology showing short nerve bundles (neural structures) embedded in the lesional stroma, along with mature adipocytes, spindle cells, and fibrous stroma. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (original magnification ×400).

Histopathology showing short nerve bundles (neural structures) embedded in the lesional stroma, along with mature adipocytes, spindle cells, and fibrous stroma. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (original magnification ×400).

Microscopic view of Cellular Schwannoma of Myxoid type (CSM) showing a primarily dermal epicenter of growth, which abuts the overlying epidermis. This non-encapsulated and non-infiltrative tumor typically displays a dome-shaped silhouette. A mild peritumoral lymphocytic infiltrate is also observed, consistent with the described mild intra-tumoral or peri-tumoral, perivascular infiltrates that can include lymphocytes, plasma cells, or histiocytes. The tumor may induce mild secondary hyperplasia of the epidermis, but no ulceration is recorded. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×40 magnification.

Microscopic view of Cellular Schwannoma of Myxoid type (CSM) demonstrating a solid sheath-like pattern of dermal growth. This proliferation is formed by uniform, monomorphic appearing ovoid and histiocytoid cells. Short fascicle formation may be present, and multinucleation is generally not seen in CSM. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×100 magnification.

Closer microscopic view of Cellular Schwannoma of Myxoid type (CSM), illustrating a solid syncytial pattern. This pattern is formed by uniform monomorphic cells, which can be ovoid, histiocytoid, or spindled, contributing to the characteristic sheath-like growth. Multinucleation is generally not seen. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×200 magnification.

High-magnification microscopic view of Cellular Schwannoma of Myxoid type (CSM) cells, showing vesicular nuclei that display fine chromatin and distinct small nucleoli. These nuclei are surrounded by eosinophilic syncytial cytoplasm. The cells are cytologically bland, typically lacking significant hyperchromasia, pleomorphism, apoptosis, or necrosis. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×400 magnification.

High-magnification microscopic view of a cellular area within a Cellular Schwannoma of Myxoid type (CSM), demonstrating mitotic activity (indicated by arrow). While the majority of CSM cases do not display mitotic activity, when present, mitoses tend to be sparse, typically ranging from 0 to 4 per 10 High Power Fields (HPF). The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×500 magnification.

Low-magnification microscopic view of Cellular Schwannoma of Myxoid type (CSM), illustrating the presence of adipocytic metaplasia, described as fat appearing entrapped within the tumor. Additionally, follicular cyst formation is observed, representing entrapped native skin adnexal elements, which are sometimes noticed in CSM. The tumor generally lacks significant other stromal elements, though chondroid–osseous differentiation is rarely seen. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×40 magnification.

Histopathology of Nodular Melanoma (NM) showing ulceration of the epidermis overlying the tumor, characterized by fibrin deposition and neutrophils. Tumor ulceration was a significant finding, present in 47 (59.5%) of the melanomas studied. (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, original magnification × 100).

Histopathology of Nodular Melanoma (NM) demonstrating a high mitotic rate. High mitotic rates, specifically ≥5 mitoses/mm², were observed in 38 cases (48.1%) of the melanomas and were frequently associated with lymph node metastases (22/34 cases with metastases had this rate). (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, original magnification × 400).

Histopathology of Superficial Spreading Melanoma (SSM) showing brisk tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes (TILs). Brisk TILs were present in 26 cases (32.9%) of the melanomas studied. (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, original magnification × 100).

Histopathology demonstrating lymph nodal metastasis of melanoma, characterized by the presence of melanic pigment deposition. Lymph node metastases were observed in 34 patients (43.1%) and were frequently associated with ulcerated primary melanomas and high mitotic rates. Loco-regional lymph node status also correlated positively with tumor thickness (pT) and Clark level. (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, original magnification × 200).

Micrometastases in the liver. Histopathology from Patient 1 shows infiltration of hepatic sinusoids in an infiltrative/replacement growth pattern (H&E, ×20 magnification). This image demonstrates micrometastases detected through histologic examination, where tumor cells are evaluated by pathologists using standard H&E staining, as part of a study investigating micrometastases detection and evaluation methods.

Micrometastases in the liver. Histopathology from Patient 1 shows infiltration of hepatic sinusoids in a nodular fashion, resembling desmoplastic and pushing growth patterns (H&E, ×20 magnification). This image demonstrates micrometastases detected through histologic examination, where tumor cells are evaluated by pathologists using standard H&E staining, as part of a study investigating micrometastases detection and evaluation methods.

Micrometastases in the myocardium. Histopathology from Patient 3 shows tumor cells growing around cardiomyocytes (H&E, ×20 magnification). This image demonstrates micrometastases detected through histologic examination, where tumor cells are evaluated by pathologists using standard H&E staining, as part of a study investigating micrometastases detection and evaluation methods.

Histopathology of a liver section from patient 1, showing micrometastases of uveal melanoma. The micrometastases predominantly display an infiltrative or replacement growth pattern. The framed area within this image is shown at higher magnification in Panel B. This image provides an example of micrometastases of uveal melanoma, a condition detected in 10 out of 11 (91%) patients in the study. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E). Magnification, ×5.

Histopathology of a liver section from patient 1, showing micrometastases of uveal melanoma. This panel shows a higher magnification (×40) view of the framed area indicated in Panel A, illustrating the predominantly infiltrative or replacement growth pattern of the micrometastases. This image provides an example of micrometastases of uveal melanoma, a condition detected in 10 out of 11 (91%) patients in the study. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E). Magnification, ×40.

Histopathology of a liver section from patient 1, showing micrometastases of uveal melanoma. A nodular growth pattern (previously described as desmoplastic and pushing growth pattern), which was less common, is displayed here. The framed area within this image is shown at higher magnification in Panel D. This image provides an example of micrometastases of uveal melanoma, a condition detected in 10 out of 11 (91%) patients in the study. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E). Magnification, ×5.

Histopathology of a liver section from patient 1, showing micrometastases of uveal melanoma. This panel shows a higher magnification (×40) view of the framed area indicated in Panel C, illustrating the less common nodular growth pattern (previously described as desmoplastic and pushing growth pattern) of the micrometastases. This image provides an example of micrometastases of uveal melanoma, a condition detected in 10 out of 11 (91%) patients in the study. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E). Magnification, ×40.

Histopathology of a myocardium section from patient 3, showing micrometastases of uveal melanoma. The tumor cells appear in sheets with an infiltrative pattern. The framed area within this image is shown at higher magnification in Panel F. This image provides an example of micrometastases of uveal melanoma, a condition detected in 10 out of 11 (91%) patients in the study. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E). Magnification, ×5.

Histopathology of a myocardium section from patient 3, showing micrometastases of uveal melanoma. This panel shows a higher magnification (×40) view of the framed area indicated in Panel E, illustrating sheets of infiltrative tumor cells. This image provides an example of micrometastases of uveal melanoma, a condition detected in 10 out of 11 (91%) patients in the study. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E). Magnification, ×40.

Histopathology image showing irregular proliferation of atypical melanocytes within the epidermis, some of them arranged in nests (haematoxylin and eosin, original magnification x20). An atypical mitosis is observed in the inset. This image corresponds to a lesion from a 51-year-old woman that was surgically removed sixteen months into a surveillance program, and histopathologically diagnosed as a melanoma with a Breslow thickness of 0.18mm (pT1a).

Histopathology image showing the extension of atypical melanocytes down adnexal structures (H&E, original magnification x20). This image corresponds to a lesion from a 51-year-old woman that was surgically removed sixteen months into a surveillance program, and histopathologically diagnosed as a melanoma with a Breslow thickness of 0.18mm (pT1a).
Histopathology (H&E, original magnification x 20) showing a new nevus-associated melanoma in situ. The extension of atypical melanocytes to an eccrine duct is easily seen.

Histopathology (H&E, original magnification x 10) showing a new nevus-associated melanoma in situ. The melanocytic proliferation is crowded, and atypical melanocytes are present above the dermal papillae.

Histopathological examination of a resected specimen from the breast, diagnosed with Bowen's disease (BD). The image shows hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining revealing hyperkeratosis, parakeratosis, epidermal pustules, irregular acanthosis, and epidermal atypia, along with inflammatory cell infiltration within the dermis. Scale bar: 100 μm.

Histological section of an endocervical mucosa, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (HE). The image reveals an endocervical mucosa lined by a regular mucosecretory columnar epithelium, overlying a chorion. The chorion contains numerous round, ovoid, or spindle-shaped cells, which contain brownish intracytoplasmic pigments without showing cytonuclear atypia or mitosis. These features are consistent with melanosis lesions, specifically indicated by red arrows.

Photomicrograph showing numerous small- to large-sized thin-walled vascular channels filled with erythrocytes and lined by endothelial cells. Also visible are mature fibrous connective tissue stroma with chronic inflammatory cell infiltration and adipose tissue (hematoxylin and eosin stain, 40x).
Histopathology showing desmoplastic melanoma, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), viewed at x100 magnification.
Histopathology showing desmoplastic melanoma, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), viewed at x400 magnification.
Histopathology showing superficial spreading melanoma at x100 magnification, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).
Histopathology showing acral lentiginous melanoma, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at x100 magnification.
Histopathology showing lentigo maligna melanoma (LMM) with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining, viewed at x100 magnification.
Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, low-power view, displaying a dermal-based tumor with no epidermal connection.

Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, high-power view, showing a tumor composed of nests of plasmacytoid cells with ovoid nuclei, open nuclear chromatin, and prominent eosinophilic nucleoli with eosinophilic cytoplasm.

Histopathological examination of a hyperpigmented lesion showing an H&E-stained section at 100x magnification. The image reveals an atypical melanocytic lesion composed of aggregates of pigmented cells (denoted by arrows) in the superficial lamina propria, located between or around benign pits. These aggregates consist of atypical melanocytes exhibiting nuclear atypia. The overall findings from such lesions were confirmatory of malignant melanoma, which also harbored a BRAF V60E mutation identified by targeted next-generation sequencing.

Histopathology of malignant melanoma metastasis showing melanoma cells forming nests of varying sizes. Some nests display a pseudoglandular pattern (arrows), a feature observed in only one of the five melanoma cases studied. The neoplastic cells in this amelanotic melanoma appear without prominent melanin pigment. Nuclear pleomorphism was detected in all cases. Original magnification, x100; Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) stain.

Histopathology of malignant melanoma metastasis, depicting neoplastic melanoma cells infiltrating the lamina propria. The neoplastic cells are small and show minimal nuclear pleomorphism, consistent with nuclear pleomorphism being detected in all five cases. This represents a diffuse/interstitial growth pattern, observed in four of the five studied melanoma cases, which also appeared amelanotic. Original magnification, x100; Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) stain.

Histopathology of malignant melanoma metastasis, illustrating melanoma cells with prominent nuclear pleomorphism and intranuclear inclusions (arrows). Intranuclear pseudoinclusions were observed in two of the five cases studied, and nuclear pleomorphism was detected in all cases. The neoplastic cells in this amelanotic melanoma appear without prominent melanin pigment. Original magnification, x400; Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) stain.

Histopathology of superficial spreading melanoma. Nests of atypical tumor cells are observed at the dermo-epidermal junction and extending into the papillary dermis. The tumor cells are typically organized in nests and exhibit marked atypia, various sizes and shapes, eosinophilic cytoplasm, and nuclear pleomorphism, with characteristic features such as prominent eosinophilic nucleoli. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining, original magnification ×100.

Histopathology of nodular melanoma, a tumor type with the worst prognosis, showing nests of tumoral cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm. The cells are typically medium or large in size, with enlarged nuclei that are sometimes irregular in shape and hyperchromic, displaying severe nuclear pleomorphism. A distinctive feature, eosinophilic nucleoli, are prominent. Stained with Hematoxylin–Eosin (HE) at ×200 magnification.

Histopathology of nodular melanoma, a tumor type with the worst prognosis. The image shows nests of tumoral cells, part of a solid tumor proliferation, occupying the dermis. The delimitation between the tumor and the epidermis can be clearly seen. The tumoral cells are typically medium or large in size, often presenting with pale or eosinophilic cytoplasm and enlarged nuclei that can be irregular in shape and hyperchromic, frequently displaying eosinophilic nucleoli. Stained with Hematoxylin–Eosin (HE) at ×100 magnification.

Histopathology of the middle part of a dermal neoplasm, from a 48-year-old male patient with widespread papular lesions, showing a striking Verocay body-like appearance. Acellular hyaline zones are lined with palisading elongated cells, where the nuclei of the tumor cells are aligned in rows or palisades, and the cell processes are fused into eosinophilic masses. This appearance is typically seen in schwannoma, but in this case, it is characteristic of a palisading dermatofibroma. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at 100x magnification.

Histopathology of the deeper part of a dermal neoplasm, from a 48-year-old male patient with widespread papular lesions, characterized by fascicles of spindle cells, scattered inflammatory cells, and foamy macrophages. These findings are typical for fibrohistiocytic tumors and, in this case, contribute to a conventional dermatofibroma appearance, supporting the diagnosis of palisading dermatofibroma. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at 100x magnification.

Histopathology of a punch biopsy from a 48-year-old male presenting with widespread papular lesions on the chest, showing a neoplasm infiltrating the dermis in a diffuse manner. At this low magnification (x10), a blend of different patterns can be seen, characteristic of a palisading dermatofibroma. These patterns include areas of storiform growth, short fascicles, collagenous stroma, fibrohistiocytic proliferation with small clusters of foamy macrophages, and zones of palisading cells forming Verocay body-like structures. The overall diagnosis is palisading dermatofibroma. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Histopathology of a punch biopsy from a 48-year-old male presenting with widespread papular lesions on the chest, showing the upper (superficial) part of a palisading dermatofibroma at higher magnification (x40). This part of the tumor is relatively cellular, composed of spindle and ovoid cells, and often contains a few multinucleated giant cells. The overlying epidermis exhibits hyperkeratotic and hyperplastic changes. The overall diagnosis is palisading dermatofibroma. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Histopathology showing subepidermal edema and dermal lymphatic invasion. Uniform basophilic tumor cells formed nests and diffuse sheets surrounding the adnexal structures, which are characteristic features observed in Merkel cell carcinoma (MCC). MCC diagnosis is primarily based on such histopathological examination. (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, magnification 40X).

Histopathology showing subepidermal edema and dermal lymphatic invasion. Uniform basophilic tumor cells formed nests and diffuse sheets surrounding the adnexal structures, which are characteristic features observed in Merkel cell carcinoma (MCC). MCC diagnosis is primarily based on such histopathological examination. (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, magnification 40X).

Histopathology showing tumor cells accompanied by dissection of collagen and some crushing artifacts, features observed in Merkel cell carcinoma (MCC). MCC diagnosis is primarily based on such histopathological examination. (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, magnification 200X).
Histopathology showing Paget disease, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E). The image displays nests of tumoral cells characterized by pale cytoplasm, which are infiltrating the vulvar dermis.

Histopathology of Paget disease (hematoxylin and eosin stain). The image shows nests of pale-staining tumor cells, also known as Paget’s cells, arranged singly or in small clusters along the vulvar epidermis. These tumor cells typically have abundant pale cytoplasm and large nuclei with a prominent, vesicular nucleus, and may display unusual mitotic figures. The tumor commonly locates in the epidermis, with occasional dermal invasion. This histopathological diagnosis is crucial as this entity can be confused with other neoplasms such as melanoma, Bowen’s disease, or sebaceous carcinoma.

Histopathology (Hematoxylin Eosin, original magnification 70x) showing Juvenile Localized Scleroderma (JLS). This panel illustrates compact fibrosis involving dermal and subcutaneous layers (long arrow) and the disappearance of skin adnexa. These features are characteristic of JLS and were key in differentiating it from Connective Tissue Nevus (CTN) during histological review of patient biopsies, some of which were initially misdiagnosed.

Histopathology (Hematoxylin Eosin, original magnification 200x) showing Juvenile Localized Scleroderma (JLS). This panel reveals perivascular inflammatory infiltrates (short arrow). The presence of significant perivascular inflammatory infiltrate is a crucial feature distinguishing JLS from Connective Tissue Nevus (CTN), where such infiltrates are typically absent, and was vital for correct diagnosis in patients initially misdiagnosed with JLS.

Histopathology (Hematoxylin Eosin, original magnification 70x) showing Non-familial collagenoma, a type of Connective Tissue Nevus (CTN). This panel demonstrates thickened collagen bundles arranged randomly in the reticular dermis (long arrow). The presence of grossly thickened collagen fibers is a most important histological feature that allowed confirmation of CTN diagnosis in all patients, many of whom were initially suspected of having Juvenile Localized Scleroderma (JLS).

Histopathology (Hematoxylin Eosin, original magnification 200x) showing Non-familial collagenoma, a type of Connective Tissue Nevus (CTN). This panel highlights preserved skin adnexa and the absence of inflammatory infiltrate (short arrow). The normal representation of skin adnexa and the absence of significant perivascular and perineural inflammatory infiltrate are crucial features that helped differentiate CTN from Juvenile Localized Scleroderma (JLS) and ultimately led to the correct diagnosis in patients undergoing deep skin biopsies and histological review.
Histopathology showing a scan power view of the excised specimen, providing an overview of the tissue architecture. This image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Histopathology illustrating a transitional zone within the tumor, demonstrating syringocystadenoma papilliferum (SCAP) on the left side and primary cutaneous apocrine carcinoma (PCAC) on the right side. The PCAC component displays multiple tumor nests located within the dermis, characterized by well-to-moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma forming distinct ductal and glandular structures with clear evidence of apocrine differentiation. This image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

High magnification histopathology view of a tumor nest from the primary cutaneous apocrine carcinoma (PCAC), showing a large cystic space. This space is lined by cuboidal cells possessing abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm and exhibiting characteristic decapitation secretion. This image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Histopathology of the penile specimen (H&E stain, 70x magnification) from a 62-year-old male patient diagnosed with mucosal melanoma of the glans penis. This low-magnification image demonstrates a highly cellular anaplastic tumor originating from the surface of the glans and invading the surrounding structures. Histopathological examination showed severe cytological atypia and numerous mitotic figures. The gross specimen was a 29 mm slightly pigmented and partially ulcerated white-brown heterogenous mass in the distal urethra.

Histopathology of the penile specimen (H&E stain, 200x magnification) from a 62-year-old male patient diagnosed with mucosal melanoma of the glans penis. The anaplastic tumor is composed of epithelioid and spindle cells, with areas displaying either dominant epithelioid or spindle cell morphology. Brown intracytoplasmic pigment is present, and bizarre tumor cells can be occasionally observed. The tumor exhibited varying amounts of extra- and intracellular pigment. The inset (SOX-10 immunohistochemistry, 200x magnification) reveals diffuse positivity of tumor cells with SOX-10, confirming the melanocytic origin.

Histopathology of the penile specimen (H&E stain, 400x magnification) from a 62-year-old male patient diagnosed with mucosal melanoma of the glans penis. Brisk mitotic activity with atypical cell divisions is evident, indicated by the yellow arrowhead. Histopathological examination revealed severe cytological atypia and numerous mitotic figures. The inset presents Ki-67-positive cells (Ki-67 immunohistochemistry, 200x magnification) with a proliferation index estimated at 80% positivity in the hot-spot areas, indicating rapid tumor growth.

Histopathology of the penile specimen (H&E stain, 200x magnification) from a 62-year-old male patient diagnosed with mucosal melanoma of the glans penis. Below the non-keratinizing squamous epithelium of the glans, an in situ component and pagetoid spread are observed, specifically found in the epithelium of the external urethral orifice. Lymphovascular invasion was also noted at the tumor’s edge. The tumor cells display diffuse PRAME expression (PRAME immunohistochemistry, 100x magnification), which is another marker for melanoma.

Histopathology of the foreskin biopsy from a 68-year-old male patient, confirming mucosal melanoma. Below the mucosa, an atypical melanocytic proliferation is visible. The melanocytes form irregular nests of various sizes and are present at multiple levels of the mucosa [black arrowheads], consistent with pagetoid spread (H&E stain, 100x).

Histopathology of the foreskin biopsy from a 68-year-old male patient, confirming mucosal melanoma. The cytological atypia is severe, with noticeable epidermal thinning. Tumor cells extend to the deeper layers of the foreskin. The Breslow thickness was measured as 1.0 mm, with one mitosis per square millimeter, classifying the tumor stage as pT1b. A moderate lymphocytic infiltrate surrounds the lesion (H&E stain, 200x).

Light micrograph (LM) showing a desmoplastic histopathological growth pattern (dHGP) in liver metastases, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E). The image displays the desmoplastic rim that separates the tumor tissue from the liver parenchyma.

Light micrograph (LM) showing a replacement histopathological growth pattern (rHGP) in liver metastases, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E). The image displays regions where cancer cells grow into the liver cell plate and replace the hepatocytes, with cancer cells in contact with the hepatocytes.

Histopathology showing a malignant melanotic nerve sheath tumor (MMNST). The image displays tumor cells with epithelioid morphology and melanin granules within their cytoplasm, as seen with H&E staining. MMNST presents a diagnostic challenge due to its histologic overlap with other conditions such as metastatic melanoma, primary leptomeningeal melanocytic neoplasms, melanocytoma, and conventional Schwannoma. An accurate diagnosis is crucial for appropriate clinical course, management, prognosis, and potential genetic counseling.

Histopathology showing a malignant melanotic nerve sheath tumor (MMNST). The image reveals a psammoma body centrally located, surrounded by heavily pigmented tumor, as seen with H&E staining. A subset of MMNST cases containing psammoma bodies is associated with Carney’s complex, a rare autosomal dominant syndrome characterized by a range of benign and malignant tumors including adrenal hyperplasia, pituitary adenomas, cardiac myxomas, and lentigines. Therefore, obtaining an accurate diagnosis of MMNST is essential given its distinct clinical course, management considerations, variable prognosis, and possible need for genetic counseling, particularly when psammoma bodies are present.

Histopathological analysis from a 12-year-old boy diagnosed with a progressively growing, dark-colored, flat lesion on the right side of his face. The image shows hyperkeratosis and hyperpigmentation of the epidermis, along with an increased number of melanocytes in the dermis. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification 40x.

Histological examination of penile tissue, stained with Haematoxylin and eosin, at original magnification x20, showing features in keeping with lichen sclerosus in a 63-year-old man with superficial spreading melanoma. This panel specifically illustrates thinning and attenuation of the surface squamous epithelium.

Histological examination of penile tissue, stained with Haematoxylin and eosin, at original magnification x20, showing features in keeping with lichen sclerosus in a 63-year-old man with superficial spreading melanoma. This panel specifically illustrates subepithelial sclerosis.

Histological examination of penile tissue, stained with Haematoxylin and eosin, at original magnification x20, showing features in keeping with lichen sclerosus in a 63-year-old man with superficial spreading melanoma. This panel specifically illustrates a lichenoid chronic inflammatory cell infiltrate.

Histological examination of the spontaneously decapitated nodule from an 81-year-old Japanese woman. The image shows proliferating atypical spindle cells, which were positive for SOX10, melan-A, and tyrosinase, covered by the epidermis, and necrotic cells around the peduncle of this nodule. Stained with hematoxylin-and-eosin; original magnification, ×40.

Histological examination of the resected specimen of the ulcerative lesion, following spontaneous decapitation of the nodule in an 81-year-old Japanese woman. The image shows no atypical cells, with an infiltration of lymphocytes observed around the ulcer. These infiltrating lymphocytes were subsequently revealed to be dominantly positive for CD3 and CD8, and partially positive for CD4. Stained with hematoxylin-and-eosin; original magnification, ×40.

Histological examination of a biopsy specimen taken from the polypoid nodule on the left cheek of an 81-year-old Japanese woman. The image shows a proliferation of atypical spindle cells and infiltrating lymphocytes on the dermis, features that contributed to the diagnosis of malignant melanoma (MM) at stage IIC. The section is stained with hematoxylin-and-eosin; original magnification, ×100.

Histological examination of a biopsy specimen taken from the polypoid nodule on the left cheek of an 81-year-old Japanese woman. The image shows a proliferation of atypical spindle cells and infiltrating lymphocytes on the dermis, features that contributed to the diagnosis of malignant melanoma (MM) at stage IIC. The section is stained with hematoxylin-and-eosin; original magnification, ×200.

Histopathological findings from the pigmented lesion of a 23-year-old female patient, referred for acral pigmentation and presenting with multiple brown lentiginous macules on her fingers. The image, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×200 magnification, shows increased basal pigmentation without atypical melanocyte proliferation. The basal pigmentation is notably more pronounced in the ridge area (indicated by a yellow line) than in the furrow area (indicated by a red line).

Histopathological appearance of malignant melanoma of the gallbladder, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (HE) at 20x magnification. The intraluminal tumor, which macroscopically appeared as a 3.9 × 2.5 × 2.0 cm yellow-brown, friable polypoid mass, is predominantly arising from the mucosa of the gallbladder.

Histopathological appearance of malignant melanoma of the gallbladder, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (HE) at 200x magnification. Dense melanin pigments, appearing as abundant granular brown pigment, are found within the cytoplasm of the neoplastic cells.

Histopathological appearance of malignant melanoma of the gallbladder, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (HE) at 200x magnification. Junctional activity is present, characterized by aggregates of malignant melanoma cells identified at the junction of the epithelium and lamina propria. The tumor was also observed to focally invade the muscularis layer.

Photomicrograph of a polypoid lesion, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 100X magnification. The image shows unremarkable anal mucosa with an underlying tumor. The tumor cells are disposed in sheets of epithelioid and balloon cells, which exhibit abundant eosinophilic to vacuolated cytoplasm and central to eccentric hyperchromatic nucleoli.

Photomicrograph of a polypoid lesion, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 200X magnification. The image shows unremarkable anal mucosa with an underlying tumor. The tumor cells are disposed in sheets of epithelioid and balloon cells, which exhibit abundant eosinophilic to vacuolated cytoplasm and central to eccentric hyperchromatic nucleoli.

Photomicrograph of a polypoid lesion, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 100X magnification. The image shows overlying rectal mucosa, with the subepithelial zone heavily infiltrated by tumor.

Histopathology of an axillary lymph node showing diffuse, cell-rich infiltration of metastatic melanoma. The melanoma cells display a trabecular arrangement with abortive gland formation in a routine H&E stain. This metastasis is from a BRAF-positive melanoma, staged as pT4aN1b (2/14) M0, stage IIIC.

Histopathology of an axillary lymph node showing diffuse, cell-rich infiltration of metastatic breast carcinoma. The breast carcinoma cells display a trabecular arrangement with abortive gland formation in a routine H&E stain. This metastasis is from an invasive breast carcinoma, NST, grade 3, which was estrogen and progesterone receptor positive, HER2 negative, and had a Ki67 of 57%. The breast cancer was re-staged to pT2N1 (1/14) M0, grade 3, stage IIb.
The luminal cells are columnar and the outer layer consists of myoepithelial cells. The stroma contains numerous plasma cells (H&E, 100x magnification).

Histopathology showing a lesion connected focally to the epidermis and composed of two layers of cells forming dilated tubular and papillary structures. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) and captured at 40x magnification.

Low power magnification (hematoxylin/eosin) of a well-circumscribed, unencapsulated nodular dermal tumor, identified as a rare melanocyte-differentiated tumor. This tumor was initially considered a melanocyte-differentiated neoplasm with local nevus cell clusters, and later concluded to be distinct from melanoma, Clear cell sarcoma (CCS), or malignant transformation of a Spitz nevus. The final diagnosis was a cutaneous melanocytic tumor with CRTC1::TRIM11 fusion.

Histopathology (×100 magnification, hematoxylin/eosin) showing the neoplasm composed of nests or sheets of epithelioid cells. This rare melanocyte-differentiated tumor was initially considered a melanocyte-differentiated neoplasm, distinct from melanoma, Clear cell sarcoma (CCS), or malignant transformation of a Spitz nevus. The final diagnosis was a cutaneous melanocytic tumor with CRTC1::TRIM11 fusion.

Histopathology (×200 magnification, hematoxylin/eosin) showing the morphological characteristics of local nevus cell clusters within the tumor. This finding contributed to the initial consideration of a melanocyte-differentiated neoplasm, which was ultimately diagnosed as a rare melanocyte-differentiated tumor, distinct from melanoma, Clear cell sarcoma (CCS), or malignant transformation of a Spitz nevus, with a final diagnosis of a cutaneous melanocytic tumor with CRTC1::TRIM11 fusion.

High power magnification (×400, hematoxylin/eosin) of the tumor cells. The cells showed no pleomorphism, with round or oval nuclei, abundant cytoplasm, prominent nucleoli, and visible mitosis. This microscopic examination contributed to the characterization of a rare melanocyte-differentiated tumor, distinct from melanoma, Clear cell sarcoma (CCS), or malignant transformation of a Spitz nevus, with a final diagnosis of a cutaneous melanocytic tumor with CRTC1::TRIM11 fusion.

Histological examination of the resected filum terminale from a 61-year-old female patient who underwent lumbar laminectomy for spinal cord detethering. The image, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×40 magnification, reveals fatty infiltration of the entire filum terminale segment with focal hypercellularity and incidental proliferation of ependymal cell types. Clean margins were observed around the hypercellular area.

Higher power histological examination of the resected filum terminale from a 61-year-old female patient who underwent lumbar laminectomy for spinal cord detethering. This Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) stained image, at ×200 magnification, shows the incidental ependymal cell proliferation and focal hypercellularity. While an ependymoma cannot be completely ruled out due to the lack of pathognomonic features, the finding was ultimately interpreted as a focal ependymal cell infiltration and proliferation within the filum terminale.

Histopathological examination of the resected filum terminale, obtained via lumbar 2–4 laminectomy, from a 53-year-old male with lower lumbosacral back pain, bilateral leg pain and numbness, and urinary incontinence and urgency. The Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) stained image (magnification ×40) shows fatty filum terminale tissue with fragments of fibrovascular and adipose tissue, embedded and adjacent ependymal cells and peripheral nerve twigs, and notably several large, thick-walled, congested blood vessels, suggestive of venous congestion.

Microscopic examination of the resected filum terminale from a 28-year-old female patient, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at ×40 magnification. The image shows fragments of fibrovascular connective tissue with focal calcifications alongside thin-walled blood vessels. The histopathological examination also identified embedded and adjacent ependymal cells, peripheral nerves, and ganglion cells within the filum terminale. Immunohistochemistry staining on this tissue revealed scattered CD45-positive lymphocytes.

Histopathologic findings of the resected filum terminale (FT) from a 34-year-old female with tethered cord syndrome who underwent lumbar laminectomy. Hematoxylin and eosin (HE) stain, shown at ×40 magnification, reveals FT with prominent small lymphoid aggregates forming secondary lymphoid follicles infiltrating the fibro-adipose tissue structures, and focal adipose tissue.

Higher magnification histopathologic findings of the resected filum terminale (FT) from a 34-year-old female with tethered cord syndrome. Hematoxylin and eosin (HE) stain, shown at ×400 magnification, reveals a lymphoid cell population with focal germinal centers, specifically foci of secondary B-cell follicles with germinal centers, noted to have a normal phenotype.

Histopathological examination of a polypous tumor, localized in the dermis, showing a dense mesenchymal component surrounding cystic epithelial structures and irregular sebaceous glands. The epidermis is hyperkeratotic and acanthotic. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HandE) at ×12.5 magnification.

Histopathological examination of the polypous tumor showing, more deeply, smaller mature sebaceous gland lobules and a dilated follicular structure radiating into the surrounding area. The cystic cavity exhibits infundibular keratinization. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HandE) at ×50 magnification.

Histopathology showing malignant melanoma infiltrating among von Brunn's nests in the lamina propria. The diagnosis of melanoma was confirmed by immunohistochemical study for HMB-45 and Melan-A markers. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at x40 magnification.

Histopathology showing malignant melanoma. The neoplastic cells are polygonal to spindle shaped with vesicular nuclei, occasional prominent nucleoli, and exhibit mitotic activity. Conspicuous melanin pigment is seen in the cytoplasm of the tumoral cells. This image provides a high-magnification view of the cellular characteristics of the malignant melanoma, which was resected from a mass involving the distal part of the urethra, as described in the pathology report (H&E stain, x400 magnification).

Histopathology of a 6 mm punch skin biopsy from the area of a black-ink tattoo provides an overview revealing a moderate lymph–histiocytic inflammatory infiltration with an abundant proportion of blackish exogenous pigment. The image shows the pseudo-granulomatous distribution of immune cells, which are concentrated around the vessels and, sometimes, the adnexa. (Hematoxylin–eosin stain, Original Magnification 4×).

Higher magnification histopathology of a 6 mm punch skin biopsy from the area of a black-ink tattoo. The image shows a moderate lymph–histiocytic inflammatory infiltration with an abundant proportion of blackish exogenous pigment, detailing the distribution of lymphocytes and macrophages around the black exogenous pigment, consistent with the granulomatous infiltrate concentrated around vessels and adnexa. (Hematoxylin–eosin stain, Original Magnification 10×).

Histopathology of a desmoplastic Spitz nevus, showing spindled and epithelioid melanocytes arranged as fascicles or single units between sclerotic collagen bundles. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) and captured at ´200 magnification.

Histopathological examination of an invasive blue nevus, stained with hematoxylin-eosin (magnification ×100). The image shows tumor tissues with an unevenly distributed pigment, appearing without invasion of the surrounding epidermis. The morphology includes abundantly pigmented dendritic cells and slightly pigmented spindle cells. The tumor exhibits a polymorphic and unevenly distributed pattern, with cells surrounded by abundant cytoplasm containing coarse melanin granules.
Histopathology (HPE) showing features of psoriasis, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 10x magnification.
Histopathology (HPE) showing features of psoriasis, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 10x magnification.
Histopathology (HPE) showing features of Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris (PRP), stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 10x magnification.
Histopathology (HPE) showing features of Hyperkeratosis Lenticularis Perstans (HKE), stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 10x magnification.

Histopathology (HPE) figure of a patient diagnosed with psoriasis, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 100x magnification. In cases of psoriasis, clinicopathological correlation, indicating agreement between clinical and histopathological findings, was found in 17.9% of cases.

Histopathology (HPE) figure of a patient diagnosed with Lichen Planus (LP), stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 100x magnification. For Lichen Planus cases, clinicopathological correlation was observed in 56.2% of instances.

Histopathology (HPE) figure of a patient diagnosed with HKE (Hyperkeratotic Eczema or similar), stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 100x magnification. HKE was commonly misdiagnosed clinically as psoriasis in 65% of cases.

Histopathology (HPE) figure of a patient diagnosed with Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris (PRP), stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 100x magnification. In cases of PRP, a high clinicopathological correlation, indicating agreement between clinical and histopathological findings, was found in 87.5% of cases.
Histopathology (HPE) image stained with H&E at 10x magnification, showing features of Hyperkeratosis Epidermolysis (HKE), in a case where clinico-pathological correlation (CPC) was not achieved.
Histopathology (HPE) image stained with H&E at 10x magnification, showing features of Hyperkeratosis Epidermolysis (HKE), in a case where clinico-pathological correlation (CPC) was not achieved.
Histopathology (HPE) image stained with H&E at 10x magnification, showing features of Hyperkeratosis Epidermolysis (HKE), in a case where clinico-pathological correlation (CPC) was not achieved.
Histopathology (HPE) image stained with H&E at 10x magnification, showing features of Hyperkeratosis Epidermolysis (HKE), in a case where clinico-pathological correlation (CPC) was not achieved.

Histopathology of melanoma, superficial spreading type, showing nests of atypical melanocytic proliferation projecting from the basal layer of the epidermis. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 100X magnification.
Histopathology of melanoma, spindle cell variant, showing melanin pigment within spindle-shaped tumour cells. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 200X magnification.

Histopathology (H&E stain, 200X magnification) of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC), showing a moderately differentiated type with intracellular keratinization and extracellular keratinization forming keratin pearls.
Histopathology (H&E stain, 400X magnification) of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC), showing a poorly differentiated type with sheets of markedly anaplastic cells and brisk mitosis.

Histopathology (H&E, 100X) of a Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC), nodular variant, showing multiple lobules in the dermis composed of basaloid cells. The nodular variant was identified as a common morphological type of BCC in this study, observed in 17 (24.2%) patients.

Histopathology (H&E, 200X) of a Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC), infiltrative variant, showing small irregular nests of basaloid cells within a mucinous stroma. The infiltrative type was the most common morphological type of BCC in this study, observed in 23 (32.9%) patients.
Histopathology (H&E, 100X) of a Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC), morpheaform variant, showing thin strands and nests of basaloid cells embedded in a sclerotic stroma.
Histopathology (H&E, 400X) of a Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC), pigmented type, characterized by nodules containing brown coarse pigment.
Histopathology (H&E, 200X) of a Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC), keratotic type, demonstrating horn cyst formation.
Histopathology of a lesion biopsy stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E).

Histopathology of endometrial tissue stained with hematoxylin and eosin (HE staining). The image shows primary malignant melanoma of the endometrium (PMME), characterized by tumor cells with a wide cytoplasm containing melanin pigment. These tumor cells are nested and separated by fibrous vessels. This pathology was derived from a 5 × 3.5 × 2 cm melanocyte cluster-like mass found at the bottom of the uterus, which showed a swollen infiltrative growth in the mucosa without deep myometrial infiltration and extensive intravesical aneurysmal plugs in the myometrium.

Histopathology of a biopsy from the gastric fundus stained with hematoxylin and eosin (HE staining), confirming metastatic malignant melanoma (MM). The image displays approximately 15 heteromorphic cells, which are nested and contain melanin in their cytoplasm. This biopsy was performed to evaluate soft tissue nodules with increased metabolism in the gastric base, identified during a whole-body positron emission tomography-CT (PET-CT) scan, which were considered metastatic malignancy.

Histopathology showing an example of nevus depth measurement. The image is H&E stained at ×40 magnification and illustrates the histopathological measurement of infiltration depth, a method used in this work. The depth of the deepest-seated nevus cells is measured perpendicular to the skin surface, specifically, the vertical distance from the top of the epidermis granular layer (including the stratum corneum) to the deepest-seated nevus cell. This panel depicts a nevus from a 95-month-old female patient who underwent surgical excision for a 20–29.9 cm large nevus located in the proximal extremity. The thickness of the nevus at a randomly selected point was measured as 0.67 mm.

Histopathology showing an example of nevus depth measurement. The image is H&E stained at ×40 magnification and illustrates the histopathological measurement of infiltration depth, a method used in this work. The depth of the deepest-seated nevus cells is measured perpendicular to the skin surface, specifically, the vertical distance from the top of the epidermis granular layer (including the stratum corneum) to the deepest-seated nevus cell. This panel depicts a nevus from a 47-month-old male patient who underwent surgical excision for a giant nevus sized 30–39.9 cm located in the trunk. The thickness of the nevus at randomly selected points was measured as 3.79 mm.

Histopathology of amelanotic malignant melanoma (AMM) from the resected nodule of a 3-year-old girl, showing an ulcerated lesion and infiltrative growth. The lesion exhibits poor circumscription, dense cellularity, and lack of maturation, particularly in the lower bottom field. (Hematoxylin & eosin stain, original magnification ×10).

Histopathology of amelanotic malignant melanoma (AMM) from the resected nodule of a 3-year-old girl, illustrating melanocyte proliferation with angulated nuclei arranged in a lentiginous pattern at the dermal-epidermal junction. A few atypical melanocytes with pagetoid scatter are also present in the epidermis. (Hematoxylin & eosin stain, original magnification ×200).

Histopathology of amelanotic malignant melanoma (AMM) from the resected nodule of a 3-year-old girl, revealing pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia and epithelioid melanocytes forming partial nests within the upper dermal component. (Hematoxylin & eosin stain, original magnification ×40).

Histopathology of the lesion from a 3-year-old girl, confirming a diagnosis of amelanotic malignant melanoma. In the lower bottom field of the lesion, poor circumscription, dense cellularity, lack of maturation, and infiltrative growth are detected. Stained with Hematoxylin & eosina at ×40 magnification.

Histopathology of the lesion from a 3-year-old girl, confirming a diagnosis of amelanotic malignant melanoma. High magnification (×100) exhibits hyperchromatic nuclei, large irregular nuclei with prominent atypia and poor differentiation, nuclear molding in the dermal component, and tumor cells extending invasively into the deep tissues. Stained with Hematoxylin & eosina.

Histopathology showing hyperkeratosis, subepidermal protuberances fusing a network and surrounded by collagen, hyperpigmentation of the epidermal spinous layer and basal layer, and sparse perivascular lymphocytic infiltration in the papillary layer of the dermis. Stained with Hematoxylin-eosin; original magnification ×10.

Histopathology showing hyperkeratosis, subepidermal protuberances fusing a network and surrounded by collagen, hyperpigmentation of the epidermal spinous layer and basal layer, and sparse perivascular lymphocytic infiltration in the papillary layer of the dermis. Stained with Hematoxylin-eosin; original magnification ×20.

Histopathology of oral mucosa lesions from a 62-year-old woman presenting with asymptomatic chronic white lesions, characteristic of white sponge nevus. This image shows acanthosis and hyperparakeratosis of the squamous epithelium, with elongated rete ridges and scarce lymphocytic presence in the subepithelial connective tissue. The hyperkeratotic stratified squamous epithelium is covered with a thick parakeratin layer, and the surface epithelium is edematous, containing numerous superficial keratohyalin granules. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), original magnification ×10.

Histopathology of oral mucosa lesions from a 62-year-old woman presenting with asymptomatic chronic white lesions, characteristic of white sponge nevus. This image displays extensive vacuolization of suprabasal keratinocytes, a characteristic finding in white sponge nevus. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), original magnification ×40.

Histopathology of oral mucosa lesions from a 62-year-old woman presenting with asymptomatic chronic white lesions, characteristic of white sponge nevus. This image highlights keratinocytes with dense perinuclear eosinophilic condensation, which demonstrates the aggregation of intermediate filaments and is a characteristic histological finding of white sponge nevus. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), original magnification ×40.

Microscopic section (H&E stain) showing a benign mesenchymal neoplasm, specifically a Granular Cell Tumor, from the dorsal tongue of a 58-year-old woman. The image demonstrates a proliferation of large, polygonal cells with abundant eosinophilic, granular cytoplasm and vesicular nuclei, organized in unencapsulated sheets and penetrating the adjacent muscle fibers. The overlying para to orthokeratinized stratified squamous epithelium exhibits florid pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia (PEH) and keratin pearl formation (black arrow).

High magnification microscopic view (H&E stain) showcasing the characteristic granular cells of a benign mesenchymal neoplasm (Granular Cell Tumor) from the dorsal tongue. These cells are large and polygonal with abundant eosinophilic, granular cytoplasm, and vesicular nuclei, forming unencapsulated sheets. This distinct morphology is key to the diagnosis of a Granular Cell Tumor.

Microscopic view (H&E stain) highlighting keratin pearls within the overlying para to orthokeratinized stratified squamous epithelium. These keratin pearls, along with florid pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia (PEH), are associated with the underlying benign mesenchymal neoplasm (Granular Cell Tumor) located on the dorsal tongue.

Histopathology demonstrating a heavily pigmented neoplasm, excised from a right retro-mastoid craniotomy. The image shows the neoplasm with cytological features obscured by dense melanin pigment, a common challenge in microscopic examination of such lesions. This heavy pigmentation also complicated the interpretation of immunohistochemistry markers during diagnosis.
