Based on histological features and location, differential diagnoses considered included melanocytoma of intermediate grade, primary meningeal malignant melanoma, and malignant melanotic nerve sheath tumor. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification x100 (low power).

Histopathology stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 200x magnification, showing a heavily pigmented neoplasm. The tumor cells exhibit prominent nuclear pleomorphism, characterized by large, irregular, variable vesicular, and hyperchromatic nuclei with prominent eosinophilic nucleoli. In less pigmented areas, epithelioid cells are arranged in sheets and vague lobules within a focally fibro-collagenous background. The differential diagnosis for this neoplasm includes melanocytoma of intermediate grade, primary meningeal malignant melanoma, and malignant melanotic nerve sheath tumor.

Histopathology of a plaque lesion showing hair-bearing skin with sebaceous hyperplasia (thick arrow) and eccrine/apocrine changes (thin arrow). The plaque lesion exhibited large sebaceous glands, heterotopic apocrine glands, defective hair follicles, acanthosis, and epithelial papillomatosis. Haematoxylin and eosin stain, 10× magnification.

Histopathology of a plaque lesion showing hair-bearing skin with sebaceous hyperplasia (thick arrow) and eccrine/apocrine changes (thin arrow). The plaque lesion exhibited large sebaceous glands, heterotopic apocrine glands, defective hair follicles, acanthosis, and epithelial papillomatosis. Haematoxylin and eosin stain.

Histopathology of a new papular lesion showing nodular basal cell carcinoma (arrow head) arising in a background of papillomatous epidermal hyperplasia. The lesion appeared polypoid with basaloid nests in a superficial and nodular distribution extending to the superficial dermis. Haematoxylin and eosin stain, 10× magnification.

Histopathology of a new papular lesion showing nodular basal cell carcinoma (arrow head) arising in a background of papillomatous epidermal hyperplasia. The lesion appeared polypoid with basaloid nests in a superficial and nodular distribution extending to the superficial dermis. Haematoxylin and eosin stain, 20× magnification.

Histology (hematoxylin and eosin, 100×) showing a poorly circumscribed asymmetrical proliferation of melanocytes with severe cytologic atypia arranged in irregular nests and as single cells at the basal layer of the epidermis. A pagetoid scatter of melanocytes is identified. There is an underlying benign nest of melanocytes in the superficial dermis. Immediately bordering the melanoma in situ, the epidermis displays atypical melanocytic hyperplasia, which transitions to benign skin at the outer edges of the excision specimen.

Histological findings of early lentigo maligna associated with intradermal nevus. The image shows atypical melanocytes distributed in the dermal–epidermal junction, alongside intradermal melanocytic nevus cells exhibiting signs of maturation and no atypia. This finding is characteristic of nevus-associated LM/LMM (NALMM), a subtype that accounted for 42 (20%) of the 201 LM/LMM histopathologic reports analyzed in the study. (Haematoxylin-eosin stain, original magnification ×20).

Histopathology showing predominant smaller round neuroblast-like cells, characterized by scanty cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei, embedded within a collagenized and fibrillary & vascularized fibrocollagenous stroma. These findings represent the first cell population of the characteristic biphasic pattern of cellular distribution, confirming the diagnosis of MNTI. Haematoxylin & Eosin stain (H&E), ×20 magnification.

High power histopathology showing small round neuroblast-like cells, which are part of the smaller round cell population characterized by scanty cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei. These cells represent the first cell population of the characteristic biphasic pattern of cellular distribution, confirming the diagnosis of MNTI. Haematoxylin & Eosin stain (H&E), ×40 magnification.

Histopathology showing small round cells, part of the smaller round cell population characterized by scanty cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei, embedded within a neurofibrillary background, which is described as a fibrillary & vascularized fibrocollagenous background. These findings represent the first cell population of the characteristic biphasic pattern of cellular distribution, confirming the diagnosis of MNTI. This panel is likely stained with Haematoxylin & Eosin.

Histopathology showing a mixed population of smaller round cells and larger cells. The larger cells possess vesicular nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm containing brownish pigment, clustered in alveolar patterns within a collagenized stromal background. These larger pigmented cells represent the second cell population of the characteristic biphasic pattern of cellular distribution, confirming the diagnosis of MNTI. Haematoxylin & Eosin stain (H&E), ×10 magnification.

High power histopathology showing larger cells, characterized by vesicular nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm containing brownish pigment, arranged in a pseudoglandular pattern (arrow). These larger pigmented cells represent the second cell population of the characteristic biphasic pattern of cellular distribution, confirming the diagnosis of MNTI. Haematoxylin & Eosin stain (H&E), ×40 magnification.

Histopathology (H&E, ×100 magnification) of a punch biopsy taken from a follicular lesion, consistent with Becker's nevus. The image shows skin with epidermis exhibiting focal mild hyperpigmentation of basal keratinocytes, a darkly pigmented basal cell layer, mild acanthosis, and regular elongation of rete ridges. The superficial dermis shows minimal perivascular lymphoplasmacytic infiltrates.

Histopathology (H&E, ×400 magnification) of a punch biopsy taken from a follicular lesion, consistent with Becker's nevus. The image shows skin with epidermis exhibiting focal mild hyperpigmentation of basal keratinocytes, a darkly pigmented basal cell layer, mild acanthosis, and regular elongation of rete ridges. The superficial dermis shows minimal perivascular lymphoplasmacytic infiltrates.

Histopathology (H&E, ×400 magnification) of a punch biopsy taken from a follicular lesion, consistent with Becker's nevus. This panel shows the deep dermis and sweat glands appearing unremarkable, further characterizing the lesion's extent.

Microscopic examination with hematoxylin-eosin (H&E) stain of the resected specimen, shown in a panoramic view, revealing a well-defined nodular silhouette with the tumor completely excised (4× magnification).

Microscopic examination with hematoxylin-eosin (H&E) stain showing the tumor connected to the overlying epidermis and extending into the papillary and reticular epidermis. A circumscribed lobulated growth pattern is observed, characterized by thicket cords of tumor cells that surround a vascular fibrotic stroma (10× magnification).

Microscopic examination with hematoxylin-eosin (H&E) stain showing the tumor composed of a neoplastic proliferation consisting of a mass of cubic monomorphic epithelial cells. These cells originate in the epidermis and extend toward the dermis, displaying the formation of well-defined lumens (40× magnification).

Microscopic examination with hematoxylin-eosin (H&E) stain showing the tumor composed of a neoplastic proliferation consisting of a mass of cubic monomorphic epithelial cells. These cells originate in the epidermis and extend toward the dermis, displaying lumens that are covered by cuticle or contain intracytoplasmic lumens (100× magnification).

Tumor histopathology showing a hematoxylin and eosin-stained section of a heavily pigmented cellular neoplasm. The image displays spindled to oval tumor cells with limited cytologic atypia and a mitotic count under 0.5 mitoses/mm². Magnification: 100×.

Tumor histopathology showing a hematoxylin and eosin-stained section of a heavily pigmented cellular neoplasm. The image displays spindled to oval tumor cells with limited cytologic atypia and a mitotic count under 0.5 mitoses/mm². Magnification: 200×.

Histopathology from an excisional biopsy of a 0.9cm x 0.9cm indurated nodule on the right posteromedial calf, revealing a malignant proliferation of partially cohesive epithelioid cells with large nucleoli and frequent mitoses. These features are characteristic of the malignant melanoma component of a collision tumor, which also tested positive for Mart-1, HMB45, and SOX-10. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification 40x.

Histopathology from an excisional biopsy of a 0.9cm x 0.9cm indurated nodule on the right posteromedial calf, revealing a malignant proliferation of partially cohesive epithelioid cells with large nucleoli and frequent mitoses. These features are characteristic of the malignant melanoma component of a collision tumor, which also tested positive for Mart-1, HMB45, and SOX-10. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification 40x.

Histopathology from an excisional biopsy of a 0.9cm x 0.9cm indurated nodule on the right posteromedial calf, showing acantholytic large cells with abundant cytoplasm, eccentric nuclei, abundant and atypical mitoses, and papillary projections. These characteristics are consistent with the rhabdomyosarcoma component of a collision tumor, which tested positive for desmin and calponin, and exhibited lymphovascular invasion. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification 100x.

Histopathology from an excisional biopsy of a 0.9cm x 0.9cm indurated nodule on the right posteromedial calf, showing acantholytic large cells with abundant cytoplasm, eccentric nuclei, abundant and atypical mitoses, and papillary projections. These characteristics are consistent with the rhabdomyosarcoma component of a collision tumor, which tested positive for desmin and calponin, and exhibited lymphovascular invasion. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification 100x.

Histologic section of a biopsy obtained from a 0.9cm x 0.9cm indurated nodule with central ulceration and confluent erythema on the right posteromedial calf. The section shows an ulcerated malignant proliferation, which was diagnosed as a collision tumor involving malignant melanoma and rhabdomyosarcoma. The image highlights two distinct populations of malignant cells: one population consists of partially cohesive epithelioid cells with large nucleoli and frequent mitoses, consistent with malignant melanoma; this population merges with an adjacent second population of acantholytic large cells exhibiting abundant cytoplasm, eccentric nuclei, abundant and atypical mitoses, and papillary projections, characteristic of rhabdomyosarcoma. Lymphovascular invasion was identified within the rhabdomyosarcoma component. (H&E, magnification 40x).

Microscopic aspect of a primary melanoma, exhibiting an atypical epithelioid melanocytic population with a nodular, en-dome (dome-shaped) disposition. The lesion, excised from the right thigh in August 2023, measured 0.5/0.4 cm, had a Breslow index of 1 mm, and showed epidermal consumption without ulceration. Mitotic activity was greater than 1 per mm², and intra- and peritumoral brisk inflammatory infiltrate was present. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (HE) at ×10 magnification.

Microscopic aspect of a primary melanoma, showing an atypical epithelioid melanocytic population with a nodular, en-dome (dome-shaped) disposition. This excised nodule from the left foot, obtained in August 2023, measured 0.4/0.4 cm, had a Breslow index of 1.5 mm, and displayed epidermal consumption lacking ulceration. Mitotic activity was greater than 1 per mm², and intra- and peritumoral brisk inflammatory infiltrate was present. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (HE) at ×10 magnification.

Microscopic aspect of a primary melanoma, characterized by an atypical epithelioid melanocytic population with massive architecture. The lesion, located on the left shoulder, measured 0.7/0.6/0.2 cm, had a Breslow index of 2 mm, and exhibited significant pagetoid extension. It was a non-ulcerated population with a mitotic rate greater than 1 per mm². Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (HE) at ×5 magnification.

Microscopic aspect of a primary melanoma, displaying an atypical epithelioid melanocytic proliferation. This lesion, located on the left shoulder, measured 0.7/0.6/0.2 cm, had a massive architecture, a Breslow index of 2 mm, and exhibited significant pagetoid extension. It was a non-ulcerated population with a mitotic rate greater than 1 per mm². Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (HE) at ×20 magnification.
Photomicrograph stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at X10 magnification, showing areas of invasion and intra-epithelial Keratin pearl-like formation.
Photomicrograph stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at X20 magnification, showing cellular atypia and spindling of cells.
Photomicrograph stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at X20 magnification, showing areas of intermingling of both melanocytic and keratinocytic components.

Photomicrograph from a gastroesophageal junction biopsy showing gastric mucosal glands and hyperplastic stratified squamous epithelium. The basal layer of the squamous epithelium displays an increased number of pigment-laden dendritic melanocytes and an increased quantity of melanin pigment. Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) stain, magnification x200.

Histomorphological features of Alveolar Soft Part Sarcoma (ASPS) showing an alveolar pattern. This pattern, characterized by tumor cells encircled by sinusoidal capillary vasculature, was observed in 4 cases. Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification x100.

Histomorphological features of Alveolar Soft Part Sarcoma (ASPS) showing an organoid pattern with focal spindling. The organoid pattern was the most predominant architectural pattern, seen in 81.8% (18/22) of cases. Focal spindling of tumor cells was a rare architectural feature, noted in 3 cases. Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification x100.

Histomorphological features of Alveolar Soft Part Sarcoma (ASPS) showing a solid pattern. Focal solid areas without any intervening vasculature were observed in 3 cases. Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification x100.

Histomorphological features of Alveolar Soft Part Sarcoma (ASPS) showing thick fibrous septae. Thick fibrotic bands separating multilobular architecture were present in 50% (11/22) of the cases. Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification x100.

Histomorphological features of Alveolar Soft Part Sarcoma (ASPS) showing single cell infiltration in septae. This rare architectural feature, where single tumor cells infiltrate the fibrotic septa, was noted in 3 cases. Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification x100.

Cytological features of Alveolar Soft Part Sarcoma (ASPS) showing a classical vesicular nucleus with prominent eosinophilic nucleoli. While classically described, this feature (round to oval nuclei with vesicular chromatin and prominent eosinophilic nucleoli with anisonucleosis) was a major characteristic (>50% of tumor nuclei) in only 31.8% (7/22) of the cases. Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification x400.

Histopathology of Alveolar Soft Part Sarcoma (ASPS) showing crenated, crescent-shaped nuclei, often described as 'apple bite' nuclei (Hematoxylin and Eosin, x400 magnification). These nuclei, which typically exhibit wrinkling and a concave nuclear contour without nucleoli, were a major feature in 68.2% (15/22) of the cases.
Histopathology of Alveolar Soft Part Sarcoma (ASPS) showing nuclear grooves (Hematoxylin and Eosin, x400 magnification). Nuclear grooves are a rare feature observed in three cases of ASPS.

Histopathology of Alveolar Soft Part Sarcoma (ASPS) showing an intranuclear inclusion (Hematoxylin and Eosin, x400 magnification). Intranuclear inclusions are a rare feature observed in one case of ASPS.

Histopathology of Alveolar Soft Part Sarcoma (ASPS) showing a mitotic figure (Hematoxylin and Eosin, x400 magnification). Mitotic activity is generally rare in ASPS, with only 5 cases showing occasional mitoses.
Histopathology of Alveolar Soft Part Sarcoma (ASPS) showing multinucleation (Hematoxylin and Eosin, x400 magnification). Multinucleation is a rare nuclear feature observed in 8 cases of ASPS.
Histopathology of Alveolar Soft Part Sarcoma (ASPS) showing nuclear pleomorphism (Hematoxylin and Eosin, x400 magnification). Nuclear pleomorphism is a rare feature observed in 4 cases of ASPS.

Photomicrograph showing a densely cellular tumor composed of bundles of spindle-shaped, moderately atypical melanocytes. This histopathological image is consistent with a lightly pigmented choroidal spindle cell melanoma. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE staining) and captured at ×200 magnification.

Photomicrograph showing heavily pigmented conjunctival epithelioid cells melanoma. On the left, the conjunctival epithelium is visible (black solid arrow), and on the right, just below the conjunctiva, a densely cellular tumor is present (black arrowhead). The tumor cells have cytoplasm abundantly loaded with a fine granular brown pigment (melanin) which also covers the nuclei. Hematoxylin and eosin (HE) staining, ×100 magnification.

Photomicrograph showing a lightly pigmented conjunctival melanoma at higher magnification (×200). The tumor (indicated by a black arrow) is composed of atypical melanocytes. Some of these neoplastic cells contain fine granular brown pigment, identified as melanin, within their cytoplasm. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE).

Photomicrograph showing a moderately pigmented choroidal spindle cell melanoma infiltrating the surrounding sclera (black arrow). The image exhibits a densely cellular tumor, composed of bundles of cells with spindle nuclei and moderate atypia. Many tumor cells show an abundant amount of brown, fine granular pigment (melanin) in the cytoplasm. The tumor infiltrates the inner surface of the adjacent sclera. This image was stained with Hematoxylin–Eosin (HE) and captured at ×100 magnification.

Photomicrograph showing a heavily pigmented choroidal mixed melanoma (indicated by a blue arrow) that is infiltrating the surrounding sclera (indicated by a black arrow) and around its nerve fibers (indicated by a yellow arrow). The tumor is densely cellular, composed of sheets of epithelioid cells mixed with cells exhibiting spindle-shaped nuclei with moderate atypia. From place to place, tumor cells present a reduced amount of brown, fine granular pigment (melanin) in their cytoplasm. The tumor infiltrates into the inner surface of the adjacent sclera and around the nerve fibers from this level. This image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at ×100 magnification.

Photomicrograph showing a lightly pigmented conjunctival melanoma. The image displays the conjunctival epithelium (indicated by black arrows) on the right side, which overlies a densely cellular tumor (indicated by white arrows). The tumor is composed of atypical melanocytes, some of which contain granular brown pigment, identified as melanin, within their cytoplasm. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (HE staining) and captured at ×100 magnification.

Photomicrograph showing nonpigmented choroidal melanoma infiltrating in the orbit. This image represents one of three (8.33%) cases out of 36 patients that showed tumor invasion of the orbit. The densely cellular tumor is composed of sheets of neoplastic melanocytes (white arrows) infiltrating between striated muscle fibers (black arrows) from the orbit. The tissue section is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) and viewed at ×100 magnification.

Photomicrograph showing a poorly pigmented, choroidal mixed melanoma that is densely cellular. The tumor is composed of sheets of epithelioid-appearing cells mixed with cells exhibiting spindle-shaped nuclei with moderate atypia. From place to place, tumor cells present a reduced amount of brown, fine granular pigment (melanin) in the cytoplasm. The tumor is seen infiltrating the inner surface of the adjacent sclera, indicated by a black arrow. This image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) and viewed at ×200 magnification.

Photomicrograph showing a nonpigmented choroidal epithelioid cells melanoma. The image displays a densely cellular tumor composed of sheets of loosely cohesive, voluminous, epithelioid tumor cells (indicated by white arrows). These tumor cells exhibit abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm and pleomorphic nuclei. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) and viewed at ×400 magnification.
Histopathology showing a densely cellular neoplasm arranged in nests and sheets, with deposition of abundant melanin pigment. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), magnification ×100.

Histopathology showing pleomorphic ovoid, spindle, or polygonal tumor cells exhibiting significant nuclear atypia, characterized by large nuclei, a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio, and scattered mitosis. The neoplasm is densely cellular and arranged in nests and sheets with deposition of abundant melanin pigment. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), magnification ×200.

Histopathology showing representative necrosis within the tumor. The neoplasm is densely cellular and arranged in nests and sheets with deposition of abundant melanin pigment. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), magnification ×200.

Histopathology showing tumor cells with granular cytoplasmic pigmentation arranged around a vascellum. The neoplasm is densely cellular and arranged in nests and sheets with deposition of abundant melanin pigment. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), magnification ×200.

Scanner view of a hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained slide from a biopsy specimen of an infected nail, taken from the nail bed and nail matrix. The slide shows ulcerated squamous epithelium with ribbon-like hyphae noted in the epidermis, giving evidence of fungal invasion in association with the tumor. The underlying subepithelial tissue is infiltrated by a high-grade malignant tumor, which is arranged in nests, sheets, and as infiltrating single cells. Individual tumor cells display pleomorphic nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and a moderate amount of amphophilic cytoplasm, with observed mitosis. Intracytoplasmic pigment is noted within the tumor, alongside large areas of necrosis. The Breslow depth of invasion for this tumor was 2 mm.

Histopathological evaluation (hematoxylin-eosin, x12.5) of the excised surgical specimen, revealing a non-ulcerated spindle cell melanoma with desmoplastic reaction. The tumor occupies the entire dermis and subcutaneous tissue of the orbital region, remaining close to the eyeball, and shows consumption of the epidermis. It is composed of epithelioid cells with marked cellular pleomorphism, prominent cytological atypia, and abundant mitotic figures (8 per square millimeter), with a 12.2-mm Breslow thickness.

Histopathological evaluation (hematoxylin-eosin, x100) of the tumor margins, showing tumor cells interspersed with fibroepithelial cells and thick collagen bundles with a myxoid background, consistent with negative surgical margins in the skin for the non-ulcerated spindle cell melanoma.

Histopathological evaluation (hematoxylin-eosin, x200) showing bone tissue of the orbital floor with focal infiltration of melanoma cells, despite overall negative surgical margins reported for bone orbital walls.

Representative histopathologic features of malignant melanoma of the parotid duct, strongly suggesting its origin from the ductal epithelium. This image shows intraluminal masses arising from the ductal epithelium. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E).

Representative histopathologic features of malignant melanoma of the parotid duct, strongly suggesting its origin from the ductal epithelium. This image shows intraluminal masses arising from the ductal epithelium. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E).

Representative histopathologic features of malignant melanoma of the parotid duct, strongly suggesting its origin from the ductal epithelium. This image shows tumor masses (asterisk) arising directly from the ductal epithelium. The scale bar is 3mm. The inserted box area in this panel is magnified and detailed in panels F–H. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E).

Representative histopathologic features of malignant melanoma of the parotid duct, strongly suggesting its origin from the ductal epithelium. This panel shows a magnified view of the area indicated in panel E. Hyperchromatic, atypical cells are observed within the ductal epithelium. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E).
Hematoxylin and eosin staining (4X) showing loss of rete ridges and ectopic mature adipocytes among collagen fibers in the dermis.
Microscopic image of a tissue section, stained with Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at 10X magnification, illustrating tissue morphology with features described as similar.

Microscopic findings from a local excision biopsy of a skin lesion, showing a nodular melanoma within the dermis. The image displays a malignant tumor proliferation with large, polygonal tumor cells exhibiting hyperchromatic nuclei and strong nucleoli. The proliferation is partially pigmented and includes an intraepithelial component. These histological features are consistent with the diagnosis of nodular melanoma, which was further supported by immunohistochemistry showing diffuse positivity for anti-PS100, anti-HMB45, and anti-Melan A antibodies. The tumor was diagnosed with a Breslow thickness of 12 mm and Clark level V. (hematoxylin stain, x200).

Histopathology showing epidermis with hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, cords of anastomosed basaloid cells, and intraepidermal clusters of atypical epithelial cells. These features represent the proliferation of basaloid cells forming thin anastomosing cords, connected to the hyperorthokeratotic epidermis, containing lumens and areas of atypia, which contributed to the diagnosis of pigmented eccrine syringofibroadenocarcinoma. Stained with Hematoxylin & eosin, ×40 magnification.

Histopathology showing epidermis with basaloid cells forming thin anastomosing cords containing lumens and areas of atypia. The stroma contains several vessels. These findings are consistent with the proliferation of basaloid cells forming thin anastomosing cords, connected to the hyperorthokeratotic epidermis, containing lumens and areas of atypia, which was key to the diagnosis of pigmented eccrine syringofibroadenocarcinoma. Stained with Hematoxylin & eosin, ×200 magnification.

Histopathology revealing atypical basaloid cells within the epidermis, inferiorly forming anastomosing cords, and hyperorthokeratosis. These histological features are characteristic of the proliferation of basaloid cells forming thin anastomosing cords, connected to the hyperorthokeratotic epidermis, containing lumens and areas of atypia, ultimately leading to the diagnosis of pigmented eccrine syringofibroadenocarcinoma. Stained with Hematoxylin & eosin, ×200 magnification.

Histopathology showing atypical basaloid cells within the epidermis surrounded by sparse pigmented dendritic melanocytes. These melanocytes are easily visible and do not proliferate continuously or in nests. This observation, along with the proliferation of basaloid cells forming thin anastomosing cords, connected to the hyperorthokeratotic epidermis, containing lumens and areas of atypia, contributed to the diagnosis of pigmented eccrine syringofibroadenocarcinoma. Stained with Hematoxylin & eosin, ×400 magnification.

Histopathological analysis showing a neoplasm consisting of basophilic cells, forming well-developed nests and masses that infiltrate the dermis, without affecting the epidermis. This is compatible with nodular melanoma of the skin. The image is stained with Hematoxylin & eosin, shown at ×40 and ×100 magnification.

Histopathological analysis showing the cellular features of the nodular melanoma, revealing cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm and pleomorphic nuclei, vesicular chromatin (indicated by red arrow), evident nucleoli (indicated by blue arrows), and frequent atypical mitoses (indicated by black arrows). The image is stained with Hematoxylin & eosin, shown at ×40 and ×100 magnification.

Histopathological analysis of a lymph node metastasis, detected during a 9-month follow-up visit after surgical removal of a suprascapular mass. The image reveals the presence of a malignant spindle cell proliferation with a fascicular growth pattern, characteristic of a sarcomatoid tumour proliferation with spindle-shaped neoplastic cells. (Hematoxylin and eosin, 40× magnification).

Histopathological analysis of a lymph node metastasis, detected during a 9-month follow-up visit after surgical removal of a suprascapular mass. The image shows numerous ill-defined, branching vascular spaces encompassed within the sarcomatoid tumour proliferation. (Hematoxylin and eosin, 400× magnification).

Histopathology of nodular melanoma, showing a solid growth pattern with epidermal ulceration and deep invasion into the reticular dermis. The overall tumor had a Breslow depth of invasion of 3.51 mm, leading to a diagnosis of pT3b nodular melanoma. (H&E, 40× magnification).

Histopathology of nodular melanoma, displaying nests of atypical epithelioid melanocytes. These cells exhibit round, enlarged nuclei with conspicuous nucleoli, focal intracytoplasmic melanin, and frequent mitotic figures (5/mm²). This microscopic appearance is consistent with pT3b nodular melanoma. (H&E, 400× magnification).
Histopathology of a right inguinal lymph node biopsy stained with hematoxylin and eosin, showing evidence of melanoma at 100x magnification.
Hematoxylin and eosin staining of a right inguinal lymph node biopsy at 400x magnification, showing a positive result for melanoma.
Histopathology image showing a well-circumscribed tumor, sharply demarcated from the normal liver tissue in the lower left part. (H&E, x40 magnification).
Histopathology image showing tumor cells arranged in fascicles. (H&E, x100 magnification).
Histopathology image showing tumor cells that are epithelioid in shape and have clear to pale eosinophilic cytoplasm. (H&E, x200 magnification).
Histopathology image showing tumor cells arranged in a whorling pattern around blood vessels. (H&E, x200 magnification).

Histopathology of a biopsy specimen from an anorectal mass, stained with H&E at 40x magnification. The image shows multinucleated enlarged cells with conspicuous pigment within the tumor cells. The cell nuclei are prominent and exhibit vesicular chromatin, consistent with findings from a 67-year-old male patient presenting with an ulcer-proliferative, friable mass in the lower rectum. The highlighted area specifically shows these multinucleated enlarged cells with prominent nuclei and conspicuous pigment.

Hematoxylin-eosin (H&E) stained slide of the blue-grey nodule from the 58-year-old Japanese man's right upper lip. Histology reveals dilated blood vessels in the upper dermis and skin erosion. Poorly circumscribed cords and nests of basaloid cells without atypia are seen invading the dermis, subcutaneous tissue, and part of the muscle layer. Keratin-filled cysts are present in the upper dermis (indicated by a black frame), along with multiple cystic glands predominantly in the lower dermis. (Bars in the large image = 500 μm; inset, bars = 100 μm).

Histopathology of Atypical fibroxanthoma (AFX) characterized by a highly cellular dermal-based neoplasm. AFX is a dermal-based cutaneous tumor of undetermined differentiation, generally categorized within mesenchymal neoplasms, primarily arising on sun-exposed sites in the elderly, notably the head and neck. Microscopically, it is typically a highly cellular dermal tumor (H&E, ×25).

Histopathology of Atypical fibroxanthoma (AFX) showing the neoplasm confined to the dermis with no microscopic infiltration of the underlying subcutis. AFX is a dermal-based cutaneous tumor, typically highly cellular with nuclear pleomorphism and brisk mitotic activity, and its confinement to the dermis is a key feature distinguishing it from pleomorphic dermal sarcoma (PDS) (H&E, ×50).

Histopathology of Atypical fibroxanthoma (AFX) formed by atypical epithelioid cells with prominent nuclear pleomorphism. This dermal-based cutaneous tumor typically exhibits nuclear pleomorphism and brisk mitotic activity, and there is no evidence of connection or origin from the surface epidermis (H&E, ×200).

Histopathology of Atypical fibroxanthoma (AFX) displaying striking nuclear pleomorphism and brisk mitotic activity with atypical forms. AFX is a dermal-based cutaneous tumor, often found on sun-exposed sites in the elderly, and is microscopically characterized by its highly cellular nature, nuclear pleomorphism, and brisk mitotic activity (H&E, ×400).

Histopathology showing poorly differentiated clusters (PDCs) in colorectal cancer. This image contributes to a morphological comparison between PDCs and cerebroid nests of melanocytes (CNMs). PDCs demonstrate a morphology similar to CNMs and are associated with deeply infiltrating tumors (pT3 and pT4) when present in high numbers in colorectal cancers. The image is a Hematoxylin and eosin stained slide at 20x magnification, with a scale bar of 100 µm.

Histopathology showing cerebroid nests of melanocytes (CNMs) in nodular melanoma, observed during a morphological comparison between poorly differentiated clusters (PDCs) and CNMs. CNMs are readily detectable and display a morphology similar to PDCs in colorectal carcinoma. These CNMs, an active growth front of nodular melanoma, are characterized by atypical pleomorphic melanocytic cells with large cytoplasm, spindle or epithelioid shape, and prominent nucleoli, often detaching from the main mass with an infiltrative appearance. CNMs are associated with lymphatic vascular invasion, higher Clark level (Clark’s IV and V), epithelioid phenotype, aggressive growth, and clinically characterized by recurrence and metastasis. The image is a Hematoxylin and eosin stained slide at 20x magnification, with a scale bar of 100 µm.

Histopathology showing poorly differentiated clusters (PDCs) in colorectal cancer. This image contributes to a morphological comparison between PDCs and cerebroid nests of melanocytes (CNMs). PDCs demonstrate a morphology similar to CNMs and are associated with deeply infiltrating tumors (pT3 and pT4) when present in high numbers in colorectal cancers. The image is a Hematoxylin and eosin stained slide at 20x magnification, with a scale bar of 100 µm.

Histopathology showing cerebroid nests of melanocytes (CNMs) in nodular melanoma, observed during a morphological comparison between poorly differentiated clusters (PDCs) and CNMs. CNMs are readily detectable and display a morphology similar to PDCs in colorectal carcinoma. These CNMs, an active growth front of nodular melanoma, are characterized by atypical pleomorphic melanocytic cells with large cytoplasm, spindle or epithelioid shape, and prominent nucleoli, often detaching from the main mass with an infiltrative appearance. CNMs are associated with lymphatic vascular invasion, higher Clark level (Clark’s IV and V), epithelioid phenotype, aggressive growth, and clinically characterized by recurrence and metastasis. The image is a Hematoxylin and eosin stained slide at 20x magnification, with a scale bar of 100 µm.

Histopathology of nodular melanoma showing Cerebroid nests of melanocytes (CNMs) graded as G1, characterized by 0 to 4 buds. The image is a hematoxylin and eosin stained slide at 20x magnification with a 100 µm scale bar.

Histopathology of nodular melanoma showing Cerebroid nests of melanocytes (CNMs) graded as G2, characterized by 5 to 9 buds. The image is a hematoxylin and eosin stained slide at 20x magnification with a 100 µm scale bar.

Histopathology of nodular melanoma showing Cerebroid nests of melanocytes (CNMs) graded as G3, characterized by 10 or more buds. The image is a hematoxylin and eosin stained slide at 20x magnification with a 100 µm scale bar.

Histopathology showing cerebroid nests of melanocytes (CNMs) located at the periphery or growth edge of a nodular melanoma. Cerebroid nests of melanocytes were observed in the periphery of 60% of melanomas in this study, with a higher number commonly found in the peripheral zone of the tumor. The image is a hematoxylin and eosin stained slide. Magnification 4x, scale bars 200 µm.

Histopathology of a vulval excision for melanoma, specifically depicting a superficially spreading melanoma. The image shows multiple clusters of atypical melanocytes within the epidermis. The section is stained with haematoxylin and eosin at an original magnification of x40.

Histopathology of a section from the background skin of the same patient who underwent vulval excision for melanoma. This image displays features consistent with lichen sclerosus, including epidermal atrophy, loss of rete ridges, a lichenoid band of inflammation, and subepithelial sclerosis. The section is stained with haematoxylin and eosin at an original magnification of x10.
Histopathology of a vulval excision specimen, stained with haematoxylin and eosin (original magnification x2), showing infiltrating nodules of invasive melanoma extending into the dermis.

Histopathology of a vulval excision specimen, stained with haematoxylin and eosin (original magnification x2), showing the adjacent surface epithelium with epidermal atrophy, loss of skin adnexal structures, fibrosis in the superficial dermis, and a lichenoid band of chronic inflammation, consistent with lichen sclerosus.

Histopathology of an incisional biopsy from the acral skin of the palm of a 48-year-old white female patient, revealing a sparse and poorly defined proliferation of pigmented dendritic cells scattered in the upper reticular dermis. These cells contain a large amount of melanin and are distributed in perivascular and interstitial patterns, consistent with a melanocytic proliferation. (Hematoxylin & eosin, ×100 magnification).

Histopathology of an incisional biopsy from the acral skin of the palm of a 48-year-old white female patient, showing a proliferation of scarce pigmented dendritic cells amidst preserved collagen fibers in the upper reticular dermis. These cells contain a large amount of melanin and are consistent with a melanocytic proliferation. (Hematoxylin & eosin, ×400 magnification).

Histopathology from an incisional biopsy of the palm of a 48-year-old white female patient, who presented with greyish-brown macules with a lacy appearance on her right palm. The image shows a proliferation of scarce pigmented dendritic cells amidst preserved collagen fibers in the upper reticular dermis. These findings reveal a sparse and poorly defined proliferation of spindle cells containing a large amount of melanin, in perivascular and interstitial distribution in the reticular dermis, consistent with a melanocytic proliferation. Hematoxylin & eosin stain, original magnification ×400.

Histopathology of a cutaneous biopsy from a 74-year-old woman's forehead, revealing an epithelial, well-circumscribed neoformation diagnosed as Melanocytic matricoma. The tumor is arranged in lobes and is composed of basophilic cells with hyperchromatic nuclei, scarce cytoplasm, and prominent nucleoli, mixed with other cells arranged in small nests. (Hematoxylin & eosin stain, 4× magnification).

Histopathology of a cutaneous biopsy revealing features of Melanocytic matricoma. The image shows basaloid cells with hyperchromatic nuclei, scarce cytoplasm, and prominent nucleoli, alongside sparse ghost cells and areas of compact keratinization. (Hematoxylin & eosin stain, 10× magnification).

Histopathology of a cutaneous biopsy revealing features of Melanocytic matricoma. The image displays basaloid cells, characterized by basophilic nuclei, hyperchromatic nuclei, scarce cytoplasm, and prominent nucleoli, mixed with numerous dendritic melanocytes. (Hematoxylin & eosin stain, 20× magnification).

Histopathology of a cutaneous biopsy revealing features of Melanocytic matricoma. The image specifically highlights numerous dendritic pigmented melanocytes, consistent with the diagnosis. (Hematoxylin & eosin stain, 40× magnification).

Histopathology from a shave biopsy demonstrating melanocytes with severe cytologic atypia, characterized by large pleomorphic and hyperchromatic nuclei with irregular contours, prominent nucleoli, and numerous mitotic figures (black arrowheads). This dermally based proliferation of large nodules is consistent with melanoma, which showed a mitotic rate of 25 figures per mm² among other prognostic factors. (H&E, 200× magnification).

Scanning magnification photomicrograph showing an acanthotic and dark-appearing epidermis with elongated rete ridges. A band of dense lymphocytic inflammatory response is observed beneath it. (H&E stain; original magnification: 20×).

High-power photomicrograph illustrating highly atypical and multinucleated keratinocytes (arrows). The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and captured at an original magnification of 400×.

High-power photomicrograph showing two atypical mitotic figures located at a high level within the epidermis (arrows). The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and captured at an original magnification of 400×.

This image shows a low power view of metastatic melanoma. The representative section, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 4x magnification, displays sheets of discohesive neoplastic cells exhibiting pleomorphism.

Histopathology showing metastatic melanoma at high power magnification. The image displays discohesive, pleomorphic neoplastic cells with a moderate amount of cytoplasm, irregular nuclear contours, clumped chromatin, and brisk mitotic activity. (H&E, 40x magnification)

Histopathological analysis of conjunctival biopsy tissue showing conjunctival blue nevus without scleral involvement. Hematoxylin and eosin staining reveals heavily pigmented dendritic melanocytic cells in the conjunctival substantia propria, arranged as sheets, admixed with dense collagen bundles, and surrounded by melanophages (black arrows). (Original magnification: 10×).

Histopathology showing eccrine ductal differentiation within a tumor (Case 5). A small duct is lined by flat cells with conspicuous eosinophilic cytoplasm (black arrow). Eccrine differentiation was observed in 7 out of 13 cases (53.8%) in this series. The tumor consists of a variable mixture of poroid (uniform small cuboidal cells with round nuclei) and cuticular cells (larger cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm), without cellular atypias, mitoses, or stromal infiltration, and has a fibro-hyaline and inflammatory stroma. (hematoxylin-eosin, ×200 magnification).

Histopathology demonstrating apocrine ductal differentiation in a tumor from a poroid hidradenoma (Case 9). A cystic duct is lined by epithelial cells exhibiting bulging apical eosinophilic cytoplasm with characteristic decapitation secretion (black arrow). Pure apocrine differentiation, characterized by bulging apical cytoplasm with decapitation secretions, was found in one patient, while mixed eccrine/apocrine differentiation was observed in 5 out of 13 patients. This case, a poroid hidradenoma, lacked the broad epidermal connection seen in classic poromas. The tumor comprises a variable mixture of poroid (uniform small cuboidal cells with round nuclei) and cuticular cells (larger cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm), lacking cellular atypias, mitoses, or stromal infiltration, and features a fibro-hyaline and inflammatory stroma. (hematoxylin-eosin, ×400 magnification).

Histopathology showing sebaceous differentiation within a tumor from a poroid hidradenoma (Case 9). This differentiation consists of large cells with abundant clear granular cytoplasm and central rounded nuclei. Sebaceous differentiation was noted in 2 out of 13 patients in this series. This case, a poroid hidradenoma, lacked the broad epidermal connection typical of classic poromas. The tumor is composed of a variable mixture of poroid (uniform small cuboidal cells with round nuclei) and cuticular cells (larger cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm), with no cellular atypias, mitoses, or stromal infiltration. The tumor's stroma is fibro-hyaline and inflammatory. (hematoxylin-eosin, ×400 magnification).

Histopathology of a classic poroma (CP) (Case 11) demonstrating large areas with melanin pigments. Melanin pigments were observed in one patient in this series. Classic poromas were diagnosed in 10 out of 13 patients (76.9%) and typically exhibit a broad epidermal connection. These tumors are characterized by a variable mixture of poroid (uniform small cuboidal cells with round nuclei) and cuticular cells (larger cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm), without cellular atypias, mitoses, or stromal infiltration, and possess a fibro-hyaline and inflammatory stroma. (hematoxylin-eosin, ×100 magnification).

Histological view of a classic eccrine poroma, showing a dermo-epidermic tumor with predominantly poroid cells, characterized as uniform small cuboidal cells with round nuclei. The tumor exhibits a broad-epidermal connection and large anastomosing trabeculae disposed in a hyaline and inflammatory stroma, which can sometimes appear loose and myxoid. All cases in the study exhibited a variable mixture of poroid and cuticular cells (larger cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm), without cellular atypia, mitoses, or stromal infiltration. This feature of broad epidermal connection was consistently observed in all classic poroma cases. Stained with hematoxylin-eosin, magnification ×100.

Histological image depicting large areas of clear cell changes within the tumor, characterized by abundant clear cytoplasm. Clear cells were observed in 7 out of 13 cases (53.8%) in the study. All tumors were composed of a variable mixture of poroid (uniform small cuboidal cells with round nuclei) and cuticular cells (larger cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm), without cellular atypia, mitoses, or stromal infiltration. Stained with hematoxylin-eosin, magnification ×200.

Histological view of a horn cyst, which consists of focal concentric lamellar keratin within a microcystic space. Focal keratin horns were identified in 2 out of 13 patients (15.4%) in the study. All tumors were composed of a variable mixture of poroid (uniform small cuboidal cells with round nuclei) and cuticular cells (larger cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm), without cellular atypia, mitoses, or stromal infiltration. Stained with hematoxylin-eosin, magnification ×200.

A squamous eddy is seen in the image, indicated by a red arrow, representing focal maturation of poroid cells. Focal poroid cell maturation into squamous eddies was found in 6 out of 13 cases (46.2%) in the study. All tumors were composed of a variable mixture of poroid (uniform small cuboidal cells with round nuclei) and cuticular cells (larger cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm), without cellular atypia, mitoses, or stromal infiltration. Stained with hematoxylin-eosin, magnification ×100.

Histopathological overview of a conjunctival melanocytic intraepithelial lesion (C-MIL) with severe atypia (melanoma in situ) transitioning to invasive melanoma, stained with Hematoxylin & Eosin (H&E) at 100x magnification. On the left side of the image, only a few melanocytic cells are scattered in the basal layer. Towards the right side, there is an increased number of atypical melanocytic cells showing vertical spread, characteristic of C-MIL high grade, with horizontal and suprabasilar extension and arrangement in intraepithelial confluent nests. On the far right, invasive melanoma is evident with invasion into the subepithelial connective tissue, displaying nests of tumor cells with nuclear atypia and stromal invasion.

High magnification histopathological image of corneal subepithelial connective tissue showing invasion of partially pigmented tumor cells with atypia, stained with Hematoxylin & Eosin (H&E) at 200x magnification. This represents invasive melanoma with nests of tumor cells exhibiting nuclear atypia and mitotic figures, consistent with a thickness of invasive melanoma less than 2 mm (pT1a). In this corneal sample, the invasive melanoma focally involved the margin, indicating incomplete surgical resection.

Histologic section (Hematoxylin and eosin, H&E, x100 magnification) of metastatic malignant melanoma in a lymph node. The image displays large, epithelioid tumor cells with enlarged nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and abundant and pigmented eosinophilic cytoplasm. Although initially suspected as poorly differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma due to E-cadherin positivity, further investigation, including the patient's history of malignant melanoma and immunohistochemistry results showing S100 positivity and GATA3 negativity, led to the amended diagnosis of amelanotic melanoma.

Histopathology showing malignant tumor proliferation in a tissue sample, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) under 20× magnification. The image displays large epithelioid and spindle cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, atypical nuclei, a high mitotic rate (50 mitoses/10 HPF), and tumor necrosis. The tumor proliferation also involved lymphoid tissue, consistent with a diagnosis of malignant melanoma.

Histopathology of the ano-rectal region, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 100x magnification, showing a pigmented lesion (arrow). This image confirms anorectal lesional tissue composed of nests of pigmented malignant cells, consistent with anal malignant melanoma.

Histopathology of a lymph node from the inguinal region, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 200x magnification, showing metastatic disease (long arrow) within the lymph node. A lymphoid follicle is also visible (short arrow). This image confirms metastatic malignant melanoma in a regional lymph node, following bilateral inguinal lymph node dissection.

High-power histopathology, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 400x magnification, showing nests of tumor cells within the dermis of the anus. These neoplastic clusters are composed of pleomorphic malignant cells exhibiting vesicular to hyperchromatic nuclei, occasional prominent nucleoli, and finely granular cytoplasmic melanin with an irregular distribution of pigments. Mitotic figures are frequently encountered, consistent with malignant melanoma.
Histopathological evaluation of a biopsy performed on an anal lesion, demonstrating malignant melanoma. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin at ×4 magnification.

Histopathologic features of keratoacanthoma, observed at 40× magnification. This image, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), illustrates characteristic features of keratoacanthoma across its various developmental and regressive phases. The early proliferation phase of keratoacanthoma is characterized by a small, primarily solid tumor containing several distinct infundibulocystic structures that have not yet coalesced into a central keratin plug. These structures include islands of laminated keratin with a ground-glass appearance, which may merge. Nuclear atypia is typically absent within the center of these structures, though some peripheral atypia may be allowed, and generally becomes less prominent with maturation. Inflammation, involving histiocytes, eosinophils, neutrophils, and plasma cells, may also be present. The maturation phase demonstrates more defined features, such as an exo–endophytic squamous proliferation with a central keratin plug, overhanging epithelial lips, and compact keratinization. Significant variability of cellular appearance and atypia can be observed, with most pleomorphic cells located in the most distant fringes. The regression phase presents with a “hollowing out” of the lesion, losing its central keratin plug, and beginning to resemble an empty bowl as the keratin clears and the epithelium thins. This phase is also marked by perilesional dermal inflammation, particularly lymphocytic infiltrate, and increasing cicatricial fibrosis.
