Histopathology demonstrating malignant melanoma metastasis in the subcutaneous tissue of the abdomen. The image shows malignant melanocytes with nuclear atypia, characterized by atypical and hyperchromatic nuclei, and dense melanin pigmentation, presenting as abundant black pigment granules within the cytoplasm. The tumor cells are composed of elongated spindle cells and oval epithelioid cells arranged in sheets and bundles. Extracellular melanin pigment is also observed. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification 100x.

Histopathology demonstrating malignant melanoma metastasis in the subcutaneous tissue of the abdomen. The image shows malignant melanocytes with nuclear atypia, characterized by atypical and hyperchromatic nuclei, and dense melanin pigmentation, presenting as abundant black pigment granules within the cytoplasm. The tumor cells are composed of elongated spindle cells and oval epithelioid cells arranged in sheets and bundles. Extracellular melanin pigment is also observed. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification 200x.

Postoperative hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining at ×100 magnification showing tumor tissue rich in melanin, confirming the diagnosis of melanoma for the 29-year-old female patient with left petrous apex melanoma. This histopathological confirmation is crucial for guiding subsequent adjuvant treatments, which in the study included conventional radiotherapy for patients with gross total resection.

Postoperative histopathological examination of melanoma from a 28-year-old male patient with right cerebellopontine angle melanoma. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining at ×400 magnification shows heteromorphous large cells with obvious nucleoli.

Histopathology of an intramucosal nevus stained with Hematoxylin & eosin (scale bar: 50 μm). The image shows nests of pigmented nevus cells that are clearly separated from the epithelial lining by an evident basement membrane. The subepithelial region contains polygonal and epithelioid cells, while deeper cells resemble lymphocytes. Oral melanocytic nevi are rare benign neoplasms, often found on the palate, and are diagnosed on average in the third and fourth decades of life. Histologically, intramucosal nevi frequently exhibit cells arranged in nests, with polygonal and epithelioid cell types observed. Small, dense nuclei resembling lymphocytes (Type B nevus cells) are also characteristic, and melanin pigment is commonly present within the cytoplasm.

Histopathology of an intramucosal nevus stained with Hematoxylin & eosin (scale bar: 50 μm), revealing deep-seated angled, spindle-shaped cells with neurotization, characteristic of Type C nevus cells. Oral melanocytic nevi are rare benign neoplasms, and the morphology of nevus cells varies depending on their location and stage of maturation. While intramucosal nevi commonly show polygonal and epithelioid cells, the presence of spindle-shaped cells with neurotization (Type C cells) is also a recognized feature, observed in some cases in this study and associated with the maturation process. Neurotization was found in two cases of intramucosal nevus, and such lesions typically exhibit symmetry, an important feature for defining them as benign.

Histopathology of a blue nevus stained with Hematoxylin & eosin (scale bar: 50 μm), composed of spindle-shaped cells with long cytoplasm and dendritic cells containing brownish melanic pigment. Blue nevus was the most frequent type of nevus identified in this study (46.67%, n=7), showing a female predilection (80%) and commonly located on the palate. These lesions are typically dark or black. Histologically, blue nevi are characterized by spindle-shaped cells often arranged parallel to the surface, and the presence of dendritic melanocytes is not uncommon in the oral mucosa, consistent with the brownish melanic pigment observed.

Histopathology showing grouped proliferated and dilated capillary vessels close to the eccrine ducts, in an area circled in black. These vascular changes were observed in correspondence with dermoscopic changes that led to a high suspicion of melanoma. The image is stained with Hematoxylin & eosin at ×40 magnification.

Histopathology showing residual melanoma in the deep dermis, with a circumscribed area of atypical morphology, consistent with a high suspicion of melanoma based on clinical history and dermoscopic findings. The image is stained with Hematoxylin & eosin at ×40 magnification.

Histopathology showing residual melanoma in the deep dermis, with a circumscribed area of atypical morphology, consistent with a high suspicion of melanoma based on clinical history and dermoscopic findings. The image is stained with Hematoxylin & eosin at ×100 magnification.
Histopathology showing a melanocytic tumor arising from the basal melanocytes of the stratified squamous epithelium. The image is magnified 100x and stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).
Histopathology showing the urothelial lining of the urethra invaded by tumor. The image is magnified 200x and stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Histopathology image showing dense lymphoplasmacytic infiltrates situated in between the tumor cells within the superficial dermis. No lymphovascular invasion or perineural invasion is observed. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 100x magnification.

Histopathology demonstrating melanoma at the site of a pre-existing cutaneous neurofibroma. This panel shows a hematoxylin and eosin stain which demonstrates an asymmetric and poorly circumscribed melanocytic neoplasm with junctional nests of varied size and shape.

Histopathology demonstrating melanoma at the site of a pre-existing cutaneous neurofibroma. This panel, at higher power magnification (likely hematoxylin and eosin stain), reveals a proliferation of single melanocytes in the epidermis, with lentiginous hyperplasia and single melanocytes present in the spinous and granular cell layers in pagetoid extension.
Histopathology of Malignant Melanoma (H&E stain, 100× magnification). The image shows atypical melanocytes with nuclear pleomorphism, hyperchromasia, and prominent nucleoli.

Histopathology of malignant melanoma (H&E stain, 100× magnification). The image shows atypical melanocytes with nuclear pleomorphism and prominent nucleoli. Tumor cells are arranged in nests with scattered brown melanin pigment, typical of malignant melanoma.

Histopathology of Malignant Melanoma (H&E stain, 400× magnification). This high-power image highlights atypical melanocytes with nuclear pleomorphism and prominent nucleoli. Scattered melanin pigment is evident within the tumor cells, consistent with malignant melanoma.

Histopathology showing an atrophic dermatofibroma, a subtype accounting for 7.5% of the dermatofibroma cases in the study. The lesion is hypocellular and exhibits marked hyalinization. (Hematoxylin & eosin, ×200)
Histopathology showing a cellular dermatofibroma, a subtype accounting for 4.6% of the dermatofibroma cases in the study, with noticeable cellularity. (Hematoxylin & eosin, ×100)
High magnification histopathology of a cellular dermatofibroma, a subtype accounting for 4.6% of the dermatofibroma cases in the study, showing prominent mitotic figures. (Hematoxylin & eosin, ×400)

Histopathology showing an aneurysmal fibrous histiocytoma, a subtype accounting for 0.8% of the dermatofibroma cases in the study. Cystic spaces filled with blood are observed within the lesion. (Hematoxylin & eosin, ×200)

Histopathology showing a fibrous histiocytoma, also known as dermatofibroma, with atypical features. This image is from a study of 239 dermatofibroma cases. Marked nuclear pleomorphism is evident. The image is stained with Hematoxylin & eosin and magnified ×200.

Histopathology showing a fibrous histiocytoma, also known as dermatofibroma, with atypical features. This image is from a study of 239 dermatofibroma cases. Bizarre nucleated cells are observed. The image is stained with Hematoxylin & eosin and magnified ×400.

Histopathology showing a lipidized fibrous histiocytoma, also known as dermatofibroma. This image is from a study of 239 dermatofibroma cases, where the lipidized subtype constituted 1.6% of cases. At low magnification, significant hyalinization is noticeable in the lesion. The image is stained with Hematoxylin & eosin and magnified ×40.

Histopathology showing a foamy cytoplasmic appearance in the cytoplasm of lesional cells within a fibrous histiocytoma, also known as dermatofibroma. This feature is characteristic of the lipidized subtype, which constituted 1.6% of cases in this study of 239 dermatofibroma cases. The image is stained with Hematoxylin & eosin and magnified ×400.

Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining showing histopathological features of a poorly differentiated invasive nodular melanoma, which measured 3.3 × 2.8 cm, with a Clark level of IV and a Breslow depth of 6 mm. The malignant neoplasm displays a solid growth pattern and forms nests (*).

Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining, at higher magnification, showing histopathological features of a poorly differentiated invasive nodular melanoma. Pleomorphic, polygonal cells with vesicular nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and abundant cytoplasm are observed. Note the pigment in the cytoplasm of the cells, which corresponds to melanin.

Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining, at higher magnification, showing histopathological features of a poorly differentiated invasive nodular melanoma. Pleomorphic, polygonal cells with vesicular nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and abundant cytoplasm are observed. Note the pigment in the cytoplasm of the cells, which corresponds to melanin.

Histopathology showing multifocal parakeratosis, marked epidermal spongiosis, and a dense upper dermal peri-vascular lymphocytic infiltrate with edema. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 100x magnification.

Histopathology of linear lichen planus showing lichenoid interface dermatitis (red arrow), with basal cell damage, pigmentary incontinence, and a confluent band-like lymphohistiocytic infiltrate in the upper dermis. Additionally, peri-vascular and peri-adnexal deep dermal infiltrates (black arrow) are present. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 40x magnification.
High power histopathological view of linear lichen planus, showing deep dermal peri-eccrine infiltrates. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 100x magnification.

Hematoxylin and eosin-stained section of a prophylactic thyroidectomy specimen from a patient with MEN2A syndrome, showing proliferation of epithelial cells. This finding is suggestive of C-cell hyperplasia. Prophylactic thyroidectomy is recommended in patients with MEN2 because C-cell hyperplasia can evolve into medullary thyroid carcinoma, which is the most frequent thyroid tumor in this syndrome. The proliferation shown here falls short of incipient medullary thyroid carcinoma, lacking infiltrative growth, desmoplastic stroma, and amyloid deposition.

Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining of a right renal mass from a 4-year-old boy with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome. At 2 years and 9 months follow-up, the patient presented with this mass, which was initially suspected of being a hepatoblastoma relapse. However, the tumor was subsequently diagnosed as a non-anaplastic Wilms tumor based on histological features.

Histopathology image stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E, 40× magnification) showing hyperkeratosis (indicated by a black arrow), basaloid cell proliferation without atypia (indicated by a red arrow), and pseudohorn cysts (indicated by a yellow circle).
Histopathology image stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E, 40× magnification) showing melanocytic nests in the dermis (indicated by black circles).

Histopathology image (H&E, 40×) showing hyperkeratotic and acanthotic lining epidermis, basal layer pigmentation (black arrow), dermis comprising of loose fibrovascular stroma (red arrowhead) and dilated lymphatic vessels (black circle).
Histopathology image (H&E, 40×) showing a predominance of fibroblasts (black circle) and collagen bundles, with a grenz zone (red triangle).

Histopathology showing cords and tubules lined by double layers of bland, monomorphic, cuboidal cells with small inconspicuous nuclei and a small amount of pale eosinophilic cytoplasm (Square). The image was stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and acquired at 40x magnification.

Histopathology showing poroma cells, characterized by monomorphic, cuboidal cells with basophilic round nuclei, inconspicuous nucleoli, and compact eosinophilic cytoplasm, alongside a well-formed duct (circle). The image was stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and acquired at 40x magnification.

Histopathological image stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) showing nevomelanocytic nests located at the dermoepidermal junction as well as within the dermis. The image was acquired at 40× magnification.

Histopathological image stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) showing hypergranulosis (indicated by a red arrowhead), melanin deposits in both the epidermis and dermis (indicated by a black circle), mild mitosis (indicated by a green arrow), and lymphocytic infiltrate in the dermis (indicated by a black arrow). Nests of melanocytes are arranged perpendicular to the epidermis. The image was acquired at 40× magnification.

Histopathological image (H&E, 40× magnification) showing a hyperplastic epidermis (indicated by a black arrow), a dermal lobular proliferation of capillary vessels (within a red circle) in a loose and edematous stroma, and an infiltrate of neutrophils, lymphocytes, and plasma cells (marked by a yellow star).

Histopathological image (H&E, 40× magnification) showing a proliferation of serpentine spindle cells (indicated by a red arrow), shredded collagen (indicated by a black arrow), and dilated capillaries (within a black circle).

Left forearm excisional biopsy findings: Hematoxylin and eosin staining showing the proliferation of spindle-shaped, non-pigmented nevomelanocytes in the papillary dermis (arrows). Magnification: ×100.

Histopathology of case 3 showing an unremarkable eosinophil infiltrate, with cysts lined with multiple layers of epithelium found within the connective tissue. Hematoxylin and eosin staining revealed clusters of round cells with melanocytic granules in the intrinsic mucosal layer with surrounding lymphocytes. This analysis was performed on a lesion from a patient who was treated with 0.1% dexamethasone and 0.1% tacrolimus for 4 months, which resulted in a slight resolution of the overall lesion length and tumor diameter, though a nodular lesion with feeder vessels persisted. Bar: 100 μm.

Histopathology revealing a junctional melanocytic neoplasm characterized by large, fused nests across rete pegs, suprapapillary growth, and suprabasal scatter of moderately atypical melanocytes. This histological presentation is considered 'borderline' for melanoma in situ. The paper notes that 'borderline' melanomas, like this case, showed a lower prevalence of dermoscopic features and a lower rate of positive 7-point checklist scores compared to 'unequivocal' melanomas. Hematoxylin and eosin (HE) stain, 100× magnification.

Histopathology at low power (10× magnification), stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), showing all three neoplasms. From left to right: an area (indicated by a dashed line) of nevus sebaceus characterized by an abortive hair follicle, sebaceous glands, and numerous apocrine ducts and glands; an area (indicated by a dotted line) of syringocystadenoma papilliferum; and an area (indicated by a mixed line) containing nodules of porocarcinoma.
Histopathology at higher magnification (200×), stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), specifically showing sebaceous glands, which are part of the nevus sebaceus.

Histopathology at higher magnification (400×), stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), showing apocrine glands with characteristic decapitation secretion, observed in the remaining part of the nevus sebaceus.

Histopathology showing porocarcinoma with proliferation of severely atypical epithelial cells in the epidermis and infiltrative extension into the dermis. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at 100x magnification.

Higher magnification histopathology of porocarcinoma showing evidence of microduct formation (indicated by a black arrow), multiple mitotic figures, and cystic degeneration with necrotic debris. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at 400x magnification.

Histopathology showing higher magnification of syringocystadenoma papilliferum and adjacent porocarcinoma, with evidence of comedo necrosis and microducts. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at 40x magnification.

Histopathology showing a different plane of syringocystadenoma papilliferum, characterized by typical papillary projections and associated cystic spaces. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at 40x magnification.

Histopathology of an Epithelioid Angiomyolipoma (EAML) specimen, stained with hematoxylin-eosin. The image shows both epithelioid components, including epithelioid cells with an intercellular bridge, and a smooth muscle component, alongside little fat. The epithelioid tumor cells are typically cytoplasmic-rich, with clear-to-eosinophilic cytoplasm, and can be arranged radially around hyalinized vascular walls. These cells possess abundant cytoplasm, vacuolated nuclei, and may sometimes be accompanied by significant nucleoli, reflecting key diagnostic features of EAML.

Histopathology of an Epithelioid Angiomyolipoma (EAML) specimen, stained with hematoxylin-eosin. The image shows both epithelioid components, including epithelioid cells with an intercellular bridge, and a smooth muscle component, alongside little fat. The epithelioid tumor cells are typically cytoplasmic-rich, with clear-to-eosinophilic cytoplasm, and can be arranged radially around hyalinized vascular walls. These cells possess abundant cytoplasm, vacuolated nuclei, and may sometimes be accompanied by significant nucleoli, reflecting key diagnostic features of EAML.

Histopathology of an Epithelioid Angiomyolipoma (EAML) specimen, stained with hematoxylin-eosin. The image shows both epithelioid components, including epithelioid cells with an intercellular bridge, and a smooth muscle component, alongside little fat. The epithelioid tumor cells are typically cytoplasmic-rich, with clear-to-eosinophilic cytoplasm, and can be arranged radially around hyalinized vascular walls. These cells possess abundant cytoplasm, vacuolated nuclei, and may sometimes be accompanied by significant nucleoli, reflecting key diagnostic features of EAML.
Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E)-stained section showing sheets of cells forming intramural nodules within the mass. Original magnification: 20×.

Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E)-stained section showing exophytic masses protruding toward the lumen. Dark brown pigment was occasionally present in neoplastic cells and intermixed macrophages. Original magnification: 20×.

Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E)-stained section showing flat lesions demonstrating a pagetoid spread of neoplastic cells throughout the urothelium. Dark brown pigment was occasionally present in neoplastic cells and intermixed macrophages. Original magnification: 20×.

Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E)-stained section showing flat lesions demonstrating a pagetoid spread of neoplastic cells throughout the urothelium. Dark brown pigment was occasionally present in the atypical neoplastic cells. Original magnification: 400×.

Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E)-stained section showing neoplastic cells with spindled to epithelioid morphology. The neoplastic cells are slightly dyscohesive, with moderate amounts of amphophilic cytoplasm, irregular and hyperchromatic nuclei, abundant mitotic figures, apoptotic debris, and an inflammatory cell infiltrate. Dark brown pigment was occasionally present in the intermixed macrophages and neoplastic cells. Original magnification: 400×.

Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E)-stained section showing neoplastic cells with spindled to epithelioid morphology. The neoplastic cells are slightly dyscohesive, with moderate amounts of amphophilic cytoplasm, irregular and hyperchromatic nuclei, abundant mitotic figures, apoptotic debris, and an inflammatory cell infiltrate. Original magnification: 400×.

Photomicrograph of a lesion revealing a highly atypical proliferation composed of spindle to epithelioid cells with large nuclei and prominent nucleoli. The cytoplasm contains melanin pigments (arrows). This histopathological finding, consistent with the overall tumor analysis where immunohistochemical study showed tumoral cells positive for HMB45, S100, and Melan-A, confirms the diagnosis of malignant melanoma. Stained with Hematoxylin-Eosin (H&E) at X200 magnification.

High-power histopathological image (X200) of hematoxylin and eosin-stained sections, showing a spindle cell tumor. The tumor cells exhibit pleomorphic and hyperchromatic nuclei with marked anisonucleosis. Multinucleation, including the presence of giant multinucleated cells, is evident, along with frequent atypical mitotic figures.

Low-power histopathological image (X20) of a hematoxylin and eosin-stained section, revealing sun-damaged skin with an ulcerated spindle cell tumor. The image shows the ulcerated nodular lesion surrounded by an epidermal collarette, and the tumor nodule is surrounded by chronic inflammatory infiltrates.

Histopathology of lichen amyloidosis (LA) showing epidermal hyperplasia with hyperkeratosis, mild acanthosis, and inflammatory infiltration with elongation of rete ridges. Amyloid deposits, confirmed by histopathological examination to be present in the papillary dermis, are marked with arrows. The image is stained with hematoxylin & eosin at 400x magnification.

Histopathological image of macular amyloidosis (MA) showing amyloid deposition (indicated by arrow) in the papillary dermis. The image also displays inflammatory infiltrates and no marked epidermal changes, which are characteristic findings in cases of macular amyloidosis. (Hematoxylin & eosin stain, 100x magnification).
Histopathological examination showing amyloid deposit in the papillary dermis. This feature was confirmed in all cases in the study. (Hematoxylin & eosin stain, 100x magnification).

Histopathological examination of the nodules shows most spindle tumor cells disordered and distributed in the lightly stained collagen matrix. The nuclei are deeply stained and S-shaped, and the cytoplasm is weakly eosinophilic. Therefore, the tumor is considered to be a neurofibroma (hematoxylin–eosin [HE] × 100 magnification).

Histopathological examination of the heel patch shows a small tissue sample. Melanoid tumor cells in the metacarpal and toe skin, stratum corneum, stratum acanthosis, and dermis exhibit obvious atypia. Therefore, the tumor is considered to be a malignant melanoma. In keeping with clinical practice, it was recommended that it be completely resected and then subjected to a pathological examination (hematoxylin–eosin [HE] × 100 magnification).

Histopathological examination at low magnification, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE), showing a dermal cystic formation with a cutaneous lining. The lining is bordered by regular, mature stratified squamous epithelium with a well-defined granular layer. The cyst lumen contains lamellated and concentric lamellae of keratin, and no atypia is noted. The surrounding dermis is loosely fibrous, with rare mononuclear inflammatory cells composed primarily of mature lymphocytes, traversed by a fine capillary network. Rare atrophic follicles are noted, surrounded by concentric fibrosis. The final diagnosis confirmed an epidermoid cyst, associated with follicular keratosis.

Histopathological image (hematoxylin-eosin staining) showing a vertical column of parakeratosis overlying a dilated acrosyringium (indicated by arrow), forming a characteristic cornoid lamella. This feature was revealed during histopathological examination for diagnosis and was consistent with those observed in PEODDN. Original magnification x100.

Histopathological image (hematoxylin-eosin staining) showing an epidermal dwelling with absence of a granular layer. The epidermis also exhibited perinuclear halos. These histopathological features were consistent with those observed in PEODDN, contributing to the diagnosis. Original magnification x400.

Histopathology of a skin biopsy from a 52-year-old male with scarring alopecia and hypertrophic plaques, showing features of comedonal discoid lupus erythematosus (DLE). The image displays mild acanthosis in the epidermis, focal basement membrane thickening, and liquefaction degeneration of the basal cell layer. Dilated follicular infundibula are present with perifollicular and peri-eccrine lymphocytic infiltrate, involving the interfollicular area. Deep dermal inflammation and melanin incontinence are also seen (hematoxylin and eosin, 40x magnification).

Histopathology of Merkel cell carcinoma (MCC) stained with hematoxylin and eosin (HE) at ×400 magnification. The image displays sheets, trabeculae, and cords of small monomorphic round blue cells with large nuclei and small amounts of cytoplasm. Nuclei exhibit fine granular/clear chromatin, indistinct nucleoli, and numerous mitoses. Consistent with standard hematoxylin-eosin staining of skin MCC biopsies, these cells show scant cytoplasm and abundant mitoses. The small basophilic tumoral cells are arranged in sheets, nests, and ribbons, separated by stroma, frequently forming nodules. Mitotic figures are a common histological feature, crucial for diagnosing and differentiating this tumor from other malignancies.

Histopathology of Merkel cell carcinoma (MCC) stained with hematoxylin and eosin (HE) at ×400 magnification. The image displays sheets, trabeculae, and cords of small monomorphic round blue cells with large nuclei and small amounts of cytoplasm. Nuclei exhibit fine granular/clear chromatin, indistinct nucleoli, and numerous mitoses. Consistent with standard hematoxylin-eosin staining of skin MCC biopsies, these cells show scant cytoplasm and abundant mitoses. The small basophilic tumoral cells are arranged in sheets, nests, and ribbons, separated by stroma, frequently forming nodules. Mitotic figures are a common histological feature, crucial for diagnosing and differentiating this tumor from other malignancies.

Photomicrograph of a hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained section from an incisional biopsy of an oral lesion in the upper labial mucosa, performed to rule out melanocytic hyperplasia or melanoma. At 10X magnification, the specimen reveals the presence of stratified squamous epithelium backed by fibrous connective tissue stroma. The juxta-epithelial region shows diffuse melanin pigmentation along with the presence of melanocytes and melanophages (macrophages that engulf melanin pigment). Multiple nests of melanin pigment with epithelial cells are appreciated within the epithelium. No evidence of melanocytic hyperplasia or dysplasia was observed, supporting a final diagnosis of oral melanotic macule.

Photomicrograph of a hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained section from an incisional biopsy of an oral lesion in the upper labial mucosa, performed to rule out melanocytic hyperplasia or melanoma. At 40X magnification, the specimen provides a higher-magnification view, revealing the presence of stratified squamous epithelium backed by fibrous connective tissue stroma. The juxta-epithelial region shows diffuse melanin pigmentation along with the presence of melanocytes and melanophages (macrophages that engulf melanin pigment). Multiple nests of melanin pigment with epithelial cells are appreciated within the epithelium. No evidence of melanocytic hyperplasia or dysplasia was observed, supporting a final diagnosis of oral melanotic macule.

Histopathology of Melasma (100×, H&E). Histologic examination reveals variable and increased basal keratinocytic pigmentation. This epidermal hyperpigmentation is characterized by an increased density of melanocytes, heightened melanin production, and melanin uptake by keratinocytes in the basal and suprabasal layers. Hyperactive melanocytes may be irregularly dispersed, leading to uneven pigmentation. Underlying telangiectatic blood vessels are also present, indicating increased vascularization, a key finding in melasma.

Histopathology of Melasma (400×, H&E). A higher power examination of the papillary dermis highlights pigment-laden macrophages (dermal melanophages) and intermixed solar elastosis. Dermal melanophages are formed when melanin, having seeped into the dermis due to basement membrane disruption, is phagocytosed by macrophages. These are particularly common in dermal and mixed types of melasma. Solar elastosis, a hallmark of chronic sun damage, is also observed and characterized by the accumulation of abnormal elastic fibers, indicative of UV-induced skin aging.

Histopathology by H&E stain showing involvement of the dermis predominantly by spindle-shaped Schwannian cells and small nests of round melanocytes at 40X magnification. The histopathological examination revealed extensive involvement of the dermis by small nests of spindle-shaped melanocytes. Increased vascularity was noted, along with clusters of small, round melanocytes interspersed between collagen bundles and around epithelial adnexal structures, extending into the subcutaneous septa and between adipocytes. Rare pagetoid arrays of melanocytes were also observed as both single cells and round nests, with pale, vacuolated cytoplasm and dusty melanin. No alarming features, such as increased mitotic activity or perineural invasion, were identified. These findings were interpreted as NCH (Nodular Cellular Nevus) with Schwannian differentiation and focal mild atypical features within a CMN (Congenital Melanocytic Nevus), highlighting the complexity of this lesion.

Histopathology by H&E stain showing involvement of the dermis predominantly by spindle-shaped Schwannian cells and small nests of round melanocytes at 200X magnification. Histopathological image of tumoral melanosis (TM) at ×10 magnification, stained with hematoxylin and eosin. The image is characterized by mild stromal reorganization with fibrosis, lymphoid inflammation with rare plasma cells, and massive accumulation of melanophages. From a histological point of view, TM is considered a complete regression of melanoma, characterized by the complete absence of dermal or junctional melanocytes, with the lesion area entirely replaced by varying degrees of fibrosis, inflammation, and sometimes abundant melanophages in the site of a previously documented pigmented lesion.

Histopathology of the enucleated eyeball, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (4x magnification), revealing the spindle cell melanoma (star) lifting the overlying layers of the ciliary body (arrow). The overall histopathological examination (HPE) indicated features of spindle cell melanoma, characterized by spindle cells with oval nuclei, prominent nucleoli, pale eosinophilic cytoplasm, and often associated with necrosis and fine granular pigment.

Histopathology of the enucleated eyeball, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (4x magnification), demonstrating areas of geographic tumor necrosis (star) surrounded by viable spindle cell melanoma cells. The histopathological examination (HPE) confirmed that the lesions were composed of spindle cells and associated with approximately 20% necrosis, further supporting the diagnosis of spindle cell melanoma of the ciliary body.

Low power view of representative histomorphology from a PRKC fusion tumor (Case 3). The image shows dermal melanocytic proliferation with a band-like distribution, alongside biphasic hypercellular and hypocellular areas. Original magnification 20×, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

High power view of representative histomorphology from a PRKC fusion tumor (Case 3). The image shows hypercellular areas containing epithelioid cells and light melanin pigment. Original magnification 200×, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

High power view of representative histomorphology from a PRKC fusion tumor (Case 3). The image shows hypocellular areas characterized by spindle cells and collagen trapping. Original magnification 200x, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Low power view showing representative histomorphology of a PRKC fusion tumor (Case 2). The image depicts dermal melanocytic proliferation characterized by biphasic hypercellular and hypocellular areas (20×, H&E).

High power view showing representative histomorphology of a PRKC fusion tumor (Case 2). This image highlights the hypocellular areas, which contain spindle cells and show collagen trapping (200×, H&E).
Histopathology from Case 8, a PRKC fusion tumor, showing unusual histomorphology. A high power view shows heavy melanin pigment in both melanocytes and melanophages (400×, H&E).

Histologic image (hematoxylin-eosin stain; 100x magnification) of a dysplastic nevus removed from the patient’s back. This nevus was one of three regressed nevi that were removed and showed a halo-type inflammatory reaction. The image demonstrates a “halo” type of inflammation, indicating early regression, consistent with the observed regressed dysplastic nevi.

Histopathology depicting a Syringocystadenoma papilliferum (SCAP) developed on a sebaceous nevus. This benign tumor, one of three SCAP cases identified in the study, exhibits characteristic papillary projections with apocrine decapitation and a prominent plasma cell infiltration. The tissue section is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) and viewed at 100x magnification.

Histopathology depicting a Syringocystadenoma papilliferum (SCAP) developed on a sebaceous nevus. This benign tumor, one of three SCAP cases identified in the study, exhibits characteristic papillary projections with apocrine decapitation and a prominent plasma cell infiltration. The tissue section is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) and viewed at 400x magnification.

Histopathology of a sebaceous nevus, displaying characteristic features including hyperkeratosis (orthokeratosis was observed in 75.0% of patients), acanthosis (observed in 81.7% of patients), and papillomatosis (observed in 85.0% of patients). The image also shows hyperplastic sebaceous glands directly connected to the epidermis, and dilated apocrine glands (observed in 23.3% of patients) and eccrine glands located in the deep dermis. This section is stained with hematoxylin and eosin, viewed at × 100 magnification.

Histopathology of anorectal malignant melanoma from Case 2, a 71-year-old man with an anal tumor confirmed as malignant melanoma. The image shows malignant melanocytes with cytologic atypia and epithelioid morphology, displaying minimal melanin pigment (dotted circles), consistent with the mild pigmentation noted in the biopsy. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining, 400× magnification.

Panoramic histopathological image of a pedunculated polypoid anorectal malignant melanoma, measuring 55 mm. This ulcerated tumor exhibited deep invasion greater than 4 mm and radial lentiginous growth. The image is consistent with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining.

Histopathology showing an ulcerated area of the anorectal malignant melanoma, with neoplastic cells exhibiting significant pigmentation located beneath the surface. This ulcerated malignant melanoma exhibited deep invasion greater than 4 mm and radial lentiginous growth. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at 100× magnification.

High-magnification histopathological image showing epithelioid neoplastic cells with prominent melanin pigment in the cytoplasm, characteristic of the anorectal malignant melanoma. These tumor cells exhibited significant pigmentation and a mitotic rate of 5 per 10 high-power fields. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at 400× magnification.

Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining of a lesion obtained via shave biopsy. This panel, at 20x magnification, shows a well-circumscribed proliferation of sebaceous glands embedded in a stromal matrix, characteristic of a folliculosebaceous cystic hamartoma.
Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining of a lesion obtained via shave biopsy. This panel, at 40x magnification, provides a higher power view, revealing no cytologic atypia or cellular abnormalities.

Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining of a lesion obtained via shave biopsy. This panel, at 100x magnification, demonstrates abundant mucus deposition (black arrow) within sebaceous lobules. Normal sebaceous cells are marked with an asterisk.

Histopathology showing nests and sheets of large pleomorphic tumour cells infiltrating the skeletal muscle. The tumour is composed of these cells and is ulcerating the epidermis and invading the skeletal muscle of the thorax. (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, 4x magnification).

High-magnification histopathology depicting rhabdoid tumour cells, which are large and polygonal. These tumour cells exhibit abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm and eccentric nuclei, with a conspicuous nucleolus. (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, 40x magnification).

Histopathology displaying extensive areas of geographic necrosis intermingled with sheets of tumour cells. These extensive areas of necrosis were noted following analysis of multiple sections. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 4× magnification.

Histopathology displaying sheets of large rhabdoid cells and a few, smaller pigmented cells. A few scattered pigmented cells were revealed following extensive analysis of multiple sections. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 20× magnification.

Histopathology showing tumour cells arranged in a pseudo-alveolar growth pattern, characterized by central discohesion and areas of necrosis. These tumour cells are generally large and polygonal with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm and eccentric nuclei, features that contributed to the suspicion of melanoma with rhabdoid features. Image taken with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) stain at 10× magnification.

Histopathology showing large, pleomorphic (polygonal) tumour cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm and eccentric nuclei, often with prominent nucleoli. Occasional multinucleated cells and scattered pigmented cells are noted, which raised the suspicion of melanoma with rhabdoid features after initial consideration of differential diagnoses such as alveolar soft part sarcoma and rhabdomyosarcoma. Image taken with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) stain at 40× magnification.

Histopathological section showing a proliferation of highly atypical neoplastic cells arranged in nests, with the tumour ulcerating the overlying epidermis. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 4× magnification.

Histopathological section showing a proliferation of highly atypical and pleomorphic neoplastic cells arranged in nests, which are separated by fibrous septa. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 20× magnification.

Photomicrograph (H&E staining, 4X magnification) of a lesional punch biopsy of skin from the left arm. The image demonstrates a mildly atrophic epidermis and an interface and superficial perivascular infiltrate.

Photomicrograph at higher power (10X magnification) of a punch biopsy specimen, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). The image displays characteristic features of an interface dermatitis, including intraepidermal lymphocytes, focal basal cell vacuolar change, and dyskeratotic keratinocytes at the dermal–epidermal junction. Additionally, a superficial perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate is noted in the upper dermis.

Histopathology of an amelanotic melanocytic nevus of the oral mucosa at low magnification (2×), stained with Hematoxylin and eosin. The image shows a well-differentiated sub-epithelial melanocytic proliferation with no significant deposition of melanin and devoid of mitotic activity, corroborating its benign nature.

Histopathology of an amelanotic melanocytic nevus of the oral mucosa at high magnification (10×), stained with Hematoxylin and eosin. The image reveals a well-differentiated sub-epithelial melanocytic proliferation with no significant deposition of melanin and devoid of mitotic activity, supporting its benign nature.

Microscopic aspects of choriocarcinoma: Neoplastic cell islands are visible, showing marked atypia, increased mitotic activity, including atypical mitoses, invading the myometrium. The image is stained with Hematoxylin–Eosin (HE) and captured at ×200 magnification.
Microscopic aspects of choriocarcinoma: Tumor emboli are identified within the blood vessel structure. The image is stained with Hematoxylin–Eosin (HE) and captured at ×200 magnification.

Microscopic aspect of invasive complete mole in the myometrium. The exocervical mucosa is visualized with the lesion area showing Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia III (CIN III) / High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL). Hematoxylin-Eosin (HE) staining, ×200 magnification.

Microscopic aspect of invasive complete mole in the myometrium, showing the presence of large hydropic villi with irregular contours, avascular, containing cysts, and circumferential trophoblastic hyperplasia with a disordered appearance. Hematoxylin-Eosin (HE) staining, ×200 magnification.
Microscopic aspect of invasive complete mole in the myometrium, showing evidence of trophoblastic invasion at the myometrial level. Hematoxylin-Eosin (HE) staining, ×200 magnification.

Microscopic aspect of invasive complete mole in the myometrium, showing the presence of cytotrophoblastic cells within the structure of a blood vessel (indicated by a yellow arrow). Hematoxylin-Eosin (HE) staining, ×200 magnification.

Microscopic aspect of the analyzed tissue showing frequent hydropic villi. Some villi exhibit invaginations and circumferential trophoblastic hyperplasia, occasionally with polar distribution of villous trophoblast. Decidua with dilated glands lined with atrophic epithelium, and relatively frequent bitrophoblastic mesenchymal villi are also observed. Hematoxylin–Eosin (HE) staining, ×200 magnification.

Microscopic aspect of the analyzed tissue showing frequent hydropic villi. Some villi exhibit invaginations and circumferential trophoblastic hyperplasia, occasionally with polar distribution of villous trophoblast. Decidua with dilated glands lined with atrophic epithelium, and relatively frequent bitrophoblastic mesenchymal villi are also observed. Hematoxylin–Eosin (HE) staining, ×200 magnification.

Microscopic aspect of the analyzed tissue showing frequent hydropic villi. Some villi exhibit invaginations and circumferential trophoblastic hyperplasia, occasionally with polar distribution of villous trophoblast. Decidua with dilated glands lined with atrophic epithelium, and relatively frequent bitrophoblastic mesenchymal villi are also observed. Hematoxylin–Eosin (HE) staining, ×200 magnification.

Haematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining, viewed at 10X magnification, reveals intraepidermal clefting and characteristic suprabasal acantholysis. This acantholysis is partial, with cells retaining some connections, giving the appearance of a 'dilapidated brick wall', a key histopathological feature of Hailey-Hailey disease (HHD).

Haematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining, viewed at 40X magnification, shows prominent intraepidermal clefting and suprabasal acantholysis. The cells maintain some connections, creating the characteristic 'dilapidated brick wall' appearance typical of Hailey-Hailey disease (HHD). This higher magnification also highlights overlying scale and crust, along with parakeratosis, features frequently observed in chronic lesions of HHD.

Histopathological findings of the skin lesion biopsy. Haematoxylin & eosin (H&E) staining on x100 magnification shows malignant cellular proliferation (*) in the dermis. This proliferation is composed of vaguely naevoid cells and larger cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, atypical pleomorphic nucleolated nuclei, and no junctional activity.

Histopathological findings of the gastric lesion biopsy. Haematoxylin & eosin (H&E) staining on x200 magnification shows malignant proliferation infiltrating the gastric mucosa. Tumour cells are pleomorphic and disaggregated, exhibiting marked nuclear atypia with hyperchromatic and sometimes monstruous nuclei (black arrows). Some larger cells with clear cytoplasm were present (white arrows). Deposits of brown pigments are also seen (*).

Histopathology of the giant congenital melanocytic naevus from Patient 3 at 19 months old, demonstrating a broad compound melanocytic proliferation of sheets, nests and cords of epithelioid melanocytes. The image, stained with Haematoxylin and eosin at original magnification × 10, shows inconspicuous nucleoli set in a desmoplastic stroma.

Histopathology of the giant congenital melanocytic naevus from Patient 3 at 19 months old, demonstrating a broad compound melanocytic proliferation of sheets, nests and cords of epithelioid melanocytes. The image is stained with Haematoxylin and eosin at original magnification × 100.

Haematoxylin and eosin-stained histopathology section (scanned with × 40 objective) from patient 1, diagnosed with a giant congenital melanocytic naevus (CMN) with a BRAF fusion gene. The image shows a plaque-like compound melanocytic proliferation of nests and cords of melanocytes within desmoplasia.

Haematoxylin and eosin-stained histopathology section (scanned with × 40 objective) from patient 1, diagnosed with a giant congenital melanocytic naevus (CMN) with a BRAF fusion gene. The image details cords of melanocytes with scant cytoplasm present between sclerotic collagen bundles in the dermis.

Histopathology of a giant congenital melanocytic naevus (CMN) from a 37-year-old man, showing clusters of melanocytes that mature with descent within a dermis with sclerotic collagen bundles. This image is from a patient who presented with a giant CMN on his back and anterior trunk, treated by dermabrasion in infancy, and later developed numerous satellite naevi and other papules/nodules. Haematoxylin and eosin, original magnification × 100.

Higher-power histopathology view of a giant congenital melanocytic naevus (CMN) from a 37-year-old man, showing melanocytes with round, darkly staining nuclei and occasional nuclear pseudoinclusions. The melanocytes have variable amounts of amphophilic cytoplasm. This image is from a patient with a giant CMN involving his entire back and anterior trunk, treated by dermabrasion as an infant, who later developed multiple satellite naevi. Haematoxylin and eosin, original magnification × 200.

Histopathology from Patient 4 at 6 weeks old with a giant congenital melanocytic naevus, showing a markedly thick compound proliferation of small, ovoid melanocytes. Stained with haematoxylin and eosin, original magnification × 10.

Histopathology from Patient 4 at 6 weeks old with a giant congenital melanocytic naevus, showing melanocytes present in storiform arrangements between desmoplastic collagen bundles. Stained with haematoxylin and eosin, original magnification × 100.

Haematoxylin and eosin-stained histopathology section of a satellite naevus from patient 2, diagnosed with a BRAF rearranged giant congenital melanocytic naevus with fibrosis. This image (original magnification × 40) shows epidermal hyperplasia with clefting around nests and between superficial melanocytes, as typically seen in Spitz naevi. The section was scanned with a × 40 objective.

Haematoxylin and eosin-stained histopathology section of a satellite naevus from patient 2, diagnosed with a BRAF rearranged giant congenital melanocytic naevus with fibrosis. This image (original magnification × 40) shows epidermal hyperplasia with clefting around nests and between superficial melanocytes, features consistent with Spitz naevi. The section was scanned with a × 40 objective.

Haematoxylin and eosin-stained histopathology section of a satellite naevus from patient 2, diagnosed with a BRAF rearranged giant congenital melanocytic naevus with fibrosis. This image (original magnification × 40) shows cords of small melanocytes present within the dermis, situated between thickened collagen bundles. The section was scanned with a × 40 objective.

Histopathology of a biopsy from gastric mucosa, showing atypical cellular proliferation leading to a diagnosis of malignant melanoma. H&E stain under 20× magnification, revealing large tumor cells with pleomorphic nuclei and abundant cytoplasm. The histopathology also featured large nuclei with conspicuous nucleoli, apoptotic bodies, and abnormal mitoses.
Pathological findings in an endoscopic biopsy specimen, showing brown-colored atypical melanocytes (indicated by arrows) on hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain at ×200 magnification.

Low-power histopathologic appearance of a fibrofolliculoma showing proliferation of fibrotic stroma surrounding the central dilated infundibulum of the hair follicles with proliferative thin epithelial strands. (Hematoxylin-eosin stain; original magnification: ×40).
Histopathology displaying features of fibrofolliculoma-trichodiscoma within the same lesion, visualized with hematoxylin-eosin staining.

Characteristic high-power histopathologic image presenting the appearance of proliferating infundibular epithelial strands with perifollicular fibrous reaction. The arrow indicates cords of basalioid cells. Image stained with hematoxylin-eosin, magnification ×100.

Histopathological findings of nevus cell nevus. Hematoxylin-eosin staining reveals the typical histological findings of nevus cell nevus, showing normal histology without excessive infiltration of inflammation-associated cells. Scale bar: 200 μm.

Histopathological features of pilomatricoma visualized by hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining at high magnification (×200). (A) A well-demarcated dermal tumor nest, characteristic of pilomatricoma, composed of peripheral basaloid cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and scant cytoplasm, arranged in a characteristic palisading pattern. Microscopically, these basaloid cells are small, uniform in size, with round or oval nuclei, and are typically arranged around tumor islands or in irregular cords or clusters. Basaloid cells predominate in the early stage of the lesion. The black arrow indicates the basaloid cell layer lining the periphery of the tumor island.

Histopathological features of pilomatricoma visualized by hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining at high magnification (×200). (B) Eosinophilic anucleate ghost cells occupy the central portion of the pilomatricoma lesion, retaining distinct cell contours but lacking nuclei, indicative of keratinization. As the lesion matures, these eosinophilic ghost cells gradually become dominant, with indistinct contours, condensed nuclei, and eventual nuclear loss. The arrow highlights ghost cells showing progressive nuclear loss and cytoplasmic eosinophilia.

Histopathological features of pilomatricoma visualized by hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining at high magnification (×200). (C) Multinucleated foreign body giant cells, which can be observed in some pilomatricoma cases, surround keratin debris released from ruptured ghost cells, reflecting a granulomatous reaction. The black arrow points to a foreign body giant cell, characterized by multiple nuclei within a single cytoplasmic body, adjacent to keratin deposits.

Histopathological features of pilomatricoma visualized by hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining at high magnification (×200). (D) Basophilic amorphous calcified deposits are localized within ghost cell areas of the pilomatricoma. Approximately 20% of patients with pilomatricoma exhibit ossification, which usually presents as osteogenic changes or calcification. The arrow marks a focus of calcification, appearing as dark-blue amorphous material among ghost cells.

Histopathologic examination of an irregular fragment of creamy brown soft to elastic tissue (measuring 3 × 2.5 × 0.7cm) showing ulcerated tissue diffusely infiltrated by oval to spindle cells. These cells feature vesicular nuclei, occasional prominent eosinophilic nucleoli, moderate nuclear pleomorphism, and eosinophilic cytoplasm with intracytoplasmic melanin pigment. Scattered mitotic figures are present. The histopathologic findings are consistent with malignant melanoma (H&E stain, x400).

Histopathology at 100x magnification showing accentuation of pigment at the tips of rete ridges and a subtle increase in smooth muscle, consistent with Becker's nevus. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Histopathological image stained with hematoxylin and eosin, showing nests of nevus cells within the connective tissue beneath the oral epithelium. The histologic section demonstrates a wedge-shaped proliferation of bland fusiform and dendritic melanocytes with abundant pigment and melanophages dissecting dermal collagen. The histopathological diagnosis indicated a benign blue nevus.

Histopathology of a facial mass punch biopsy, likely stained with hematoxylin and eosin, showing a population of spindled cells demonstrating pleomorphism and desmoplasia within the dermal and epidermal layer. This morphology is consistent with a SOX10-positive spindle cell tumor, favoring melanoma, as confirmed by laboratory studies. Similar clusters of spindled cells can be observed at the outer edges of the image. Magnification: 1.4x.

Histopathology of a facial mass punch biopsy, likely stained with hematoxylin and eosin, showing a detailed view of the SOX10-positive spindle cell tumor, favoring melanoma. This panel presents a 20x magnification of the pleomorphic and desmoplastic spindled cells previously described in the dermal and epidermal layers. Magnification: 1.20x-20x.

Histopathology of a facial mass punch biopsy, likely stained with hematoxylin and eosin, showing the main tissue foci of the SOX10-positive spindle cell tumor, favoring melanoma. This panel focuses on the top/dermal layer, revealing a population of spindled cells demonstrating pleomorphism and desmoplasia within this region. Magnification: 10x.

Histopathology of a facial mass punch biopsy, likely stained with hematoxylin and eosin, showing the main tissue foci of the SOX10-positive spindle cell tumor, favoring melanoma. This panel focuses on the bottom/epidermal layer, revealing a population of spindled cells demonstrating pleomorphism and desmoplasia within this region. Magnification: 10x.

Histopathology of a superficial dermal melanocytic lesion from a 55-year-old female, displaying fusiform melanocytes within the papillary dermis. This view shows the overall architecture of the lesion, which includes minimal intracellular pigment deposition, artificial pseudopapilliform transformation, and atrophy of the epidermis. The lesion measured 8 mm and had a brownish-blue color on presentation. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin. Original magnification 40×.

Histopathology of a dermal melanocytic lesion from a 55-year-old female, showing spindle cell melanocytes arranged in nests surrounded by a thin rim of sclerotic stroma within the papillary dermis. The lesion comprises fusiform melanocytes with minimal intracellular pigment deposition, and pigmented macrophages are also present. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin. Original magnification 100×.

Histopathology showing a remnant dendritic blue nevus on the deep resection margin. The overall lesion was diagnosed as melanoma arising in a blue nevus, characterized by atypical spindle cells of intermediate to low pigmentation, minimal stroma, sparse lymphocytic infiltration, and high mitotic activity. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification 40×.

Histopathology showing a remnant dendritic blue nevus and adjacent melanoma nests underneath the epidermis. The melanoma, which was diagnosed as arising in a blue nevus, presented predominantly with atypical spindle cells of intermediate to low pigmentation, minimal stroma, sparse lymphocytic infiltration, and high mitotic activity, growing in a nest-like pattern. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification 40×.

Histopathology showing a subepidermal lesion with subtle pigmentation. This lesion was diagnosed as melanoma arising in a blue nevus, characterized by atypical spindle cells of intermediate to low pigmentation, minimal stroma, sparse lymphocytic infiltration, and growing in a nest-like pattern with high mitotic activity. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification 40×.

Histopathology showing spindle cell melanocytes with subtle pigmentation and a nesticles growth pattern. The overall lesion was diagnosed as melanoma arising in a blue nevus, which presented predominantly with atypical spindle cells of intermediate to low pigmentation, minimal stroma, sparse lymphocytic infiltration, and high mitotic activity, including atypical forms. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification 100×.

Histopathology showing spindle cell melanocytes with subtle pigmentation and a nesticles growth pattern. The overall lesion was diagnosed as melanoma arising in a blue nevus, which presented predominantly with atypical spindle cells of intermediate to low pigmentation, minimal stroma, sparse lymphocytic infiltration, and high mitotic activity, including atypical forms. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification 100×.

Histopathology showing increased mitotic activity amongst the nesticles. The lesion was diagnosed as melanoma arising in a blue nevus, characterized by high mitotic activity, including atypical forms, in atypical spindle cells of intermediate to low pigmentation, growing in a nest-like pattern with minimal stroma and sparse lymphocytic infiltration. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification 200×.

Histopathology of the auricular lesion, diagnosed as squamous cell carcinoma in situ. The image shows acanthotic epidermis with superficial ulceration and no penetration of the basal lamina. The lesion is characterized by an acanthotic proliferation comprising large squamoid cells with light cytoplasm and easily identifiable mitoses, forming intraepidermal nests with microabscesses, single concentric keratin deposits, and focal ulceration. A dense lichenoid infiltrate is noted under the lesion, with no basement membrane penetration. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin. Original magnification 4×.

Histopathology of the auricular lesion, diagnosed as squamous cell carcinoma in situ. The image shows acanthotic epidermis with superficial ulceration and no penetration of the basal lamina. The lesion is characterized by an acanthotic proliferation comprising large squamoid cells with light cytoplasm and easily identifiable mitoses, forming intraepidermal nests with microabscesses, single concentric keratin deposits, and focal ulceration. A dense lichenoid infiltrate is noted under the lesion, with no basement membrane penetration. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin. Original magnification 4×.

Histopathology of the auricular lesion, diagnosed as squamous cell carcinoma in situ. The image shows acanthotic proliferation by atypical keratinocytes with clear cell cytoplasmic change. The lesion is characterized by an acanthotic proliferation comprising large squamoid cells with light cytoplasm and easily identifiable mitoses, forming intraepidermal nests with microabscesses, single concentric keratin deposits, and focal ulceration. A dense lichenoid infiltrate is noted under the lesion, with no basement membrane penetration. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin. Original magnification 100×.

Histopathology of a dermally located pigmented lesion, identified as a sclerotic blue nevus, from a 48-year-old female's 8mm bluish lesion on the left leg. The lesion was initially suspected to be a fibrous histiocytoma but showed morphological characteristics similar to a dendritic blue nevus with pronounced sclerotic stroma upon pathological examination. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification 40×.

Histopathology showing dendritic melanocytes with intensive pigment deposition and excessively sclerotic stroma, characteristic features of a sclerotic blue nevus, from a 48-year-old female's 8mm bluish lesion on the left leg. The lesion was initially suspected to be a fibrous histiocytoma but exhibited morphological characteristics similar to a dendritic blue nevus with pronounced sclerotic stroma. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification 100×.

Histopathology of the scalp lesion, diagnosed as pT3a melanoma. This image shows a pigmented lesion with superficial dermal involvement, consistent with a dermally located neoplastic proliferation of epithelioid-type cells that progressed beyond the border of the dermal component. The melanoma exhibited an asymmetric profile, with pigmentation varying from apigmented to coarsely pigmented, and extended to the reticular dermis (Clark IV). The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification 40×.

Histopathology of the scalp lesion, diagnosed as pT3a melanoma. This image reveals a large nest of neoplastic melanocytes with subtle pigmentation. The melanoma featured nesting structures at the dermoepidermal junction and comprised epithelioid-type cells with variable pigmentation. The tumor cells exhibited marked pleomorphism and eosinophilic cytoplasm, as well as vesicular nuclei and prominent nucleoli. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification 100×.

Histopathology of the scalp lesion, diagnosed as pT3a melanoma. This image demonstrates atypical melanocytes with increased mitotic activity. The tumor cells exhibited marked pleomorphism and eosinophilic cytoplasm, as well as vesicular nuclei and prominent nucleoli, characteristic of melanoma. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification 200×.

Histopathology of the cheek lesion, diagnosed as a cellular blue nevus. Panel A shows a pigmented melanocyte lesion in the superficial dermis, characterized by marked pigmentation and cellularity. The lesion is a melanocyte proliferation with well-defined borders involving the epidermis and extending to the reticular dermis. The cells are oval to spindle-shaped with small monomorphic nuclei, speckled chromatin, and abundant light or finely pigmented cytoplasm. Staining is hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification 40×.

Histopathology of the cheek lesion, diagnosed as a cellular blue nevus. Panel B shows a higher magnification view of the melanocyte lesion, illustrating the arrangement of tumor cells in nests and short fascicles. The lesion is composed of oval to spindle-shaped cells with small monomorphic nuclei, speckled chromatin, and light or finely pigmented cytoplasm, surrounded by pigmented macrophages and circumscriptive sclerotic stroma. Staining is hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification 100×.

Histopathology of the cheek lesion, diagnosed as a cellular blue nevus. Panel C shows spindle cell melanocytes with subtle pigment deposition. These tumor cells are oval to spindle-shaped, featuring small monomorphic nuclei, speckled chromatin, and light or finely pigmented cytoplasm. A distinct rim of sclerotic stroma surrounds the nests of these cells, which are also accompanied by pigmented macrophages. Staining is hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification 200×.

Histopathology of a dermal blue nevus, showing dendritic melanocytes admixed with significantly collagened and sclerotic stroma within the dermis. This morphology is typical for the deeply located lesion. Original magnification 200×. Staining is hematoxylin and eosin.

Histological image (hematoxylin-eosin, 10× magnification) of an NRAS- and CCND1 gene-mutated melanoma, 4.9 mm-thick with a mitotic rate of 11/mm², from the forearm of an 80-year-old woman. The image displays dilated capillaries (arrows) located beneath the epidermis and extending between tumor dermal aggregates. These dilated capillaries are a histological manifestation of the vascular patterns seen dermoscopically and are significantly associated with mutations in cell cycle genes like CCND1. This neoangiogenesis reflects the tumor's adaptive response to the increasing oxygen and nutrient demands of rapidly proliferating melanoma cells, often under hypoxic conditions, leading to the activation of factors like HIF-1α that induce the expression of genes involved in angiogenesis and melanoma progression.

Histopathological examination of an atypical melanocytic lesion, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 100× magnification, showing melanocytes infiltrating and disrupting the epidermis. This image reveals features of severe dysplasia, with nests of atypical melanocytes present in the epidermis and dermis, along with ulceration and pagetoid spread of melanocytes within the epidermis. Atypical melanocytes were also observed in the reticular dermis (Clark level 4). These histological findings contributed to the suspicion of invasive melanoma (pT3b).

Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained image revealing notable histopathological characteristics of the melanoma from the 60-year-old female patient's left cheek. The image shows densely clustered melanoma cells exhibiting atypical nuclei and melanin pigmentation. This melanoma was confirmed by histopathological analysis and positive staining for SOX10, MelanA, and HMB-45, and presented with metastasis on the left parotid.

Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained image revealing notable histopathological characteristics of the melanoma from the 60-year-old female patient's left cheek. The image shows densely clustered melanoma cells exhibiting atypical nuclei and melanin pigmentation. This melanoma was confirmed by histopathological analysis and positive staining for SOX10, MelanA, and HMB-45, and presented with metastasis on the left parotid.

Histopathology of lentigo maligna, showing intraepithelial proliferation of heavily pigmented, hyperchromatic melanocytes arranged along the dermal-epidermal junction in a lentiginous pattern, with neoplastic proliferation extending to the follicular epithelium. The image also displays severe solar elastosis in the superficial dermis. The melanocytes frequently exhibit moderate atypia and pleomorphism, and the epidermis is typically atrophic. Original magnification: 20×, hematoxylin-eosin stain.

Histopathology showing acral lentiginous in situ melanoma (hematoxylin–eosin stain), 10× magnification. The image displays features of eccrine duct involvement. Histologically, melanocytes are typically hyperchromatic and arranged in a lentiginous pattern at the basal epidermal layer.

Histopathology of nodular melanoma, stained with hematoxylin-eosin at 10× magnification. The image displays a densely packed dermal proliferation of atypical melanocytes extending to the reticular dermis, consistent with Clark’s level IV and a Breslow thickness of 2.9 mm. Several dermal mitoses are evident, counted at 10 mitoses per 1 mm². Nodular melanoma lesions frequently exhibit such dermal mitosis and may also present with epidermal ulceration. Histologically, a key diagnostic feature for nodular melanoma is that if an intraepidermal component is present, it should not extend for more than three rete ridges beyond the dermal component.

Histopathology (hematoxylin-eosin stain, 10× magnification) showing superficial spreading melanoma infiltrating the superficial dermis, with a Breslow thickness of 0.7 mm. The melanoma exhibits moderate non-brisk peritumoral and intratumoral inflammatory infiltrate. Histologically, superficial spreading melanoma is characterized by asymmetric, poorly demarcated melanocytes that lack cellular maturation. Melanocytes are distributed unevenly, often with solitary melanocytes being more predominant over nests, and commonly with evidence of intraepithelial spread in a pagetoid manner.

Histopathology (Hematoxylin–Eosin staining) showing the typical architecture of nested melanoma in a case (patient no. 27) with pagetoid intraepidermal spread of melanocytes in superficial spreading melanoma (SSM) with prominent nests. This specific case belongs to subgroup 1, characterized by no pagetoid spread (0) of melanocytes in suprabasal epidermal layers, as further classified by Melan A immunohistochemistry. Scale bar: 500 µm.

Histopathology (Hematoxylin–Eosin staining) showing a magnified view of the typical architecture of nested melanoma in a case (patient no. 27) with pagetoid intraepidermal spread of melanocytes in superficial spreading melanoma (SSM) with prominent nests. This specific case belongs to subgroup 1, characterized by no pagetoid spread (0) of melanocytes in suprabasal epidermal layers, as further classified by Melan A immunohistochemistry. Scale bar: 100 µm.

Histopathology (likely Hematoxylin–Eosin staining) highlighting an expansive, well-nested lesion in a case (patient no. 35) of nested melanoma with pagetoid intraepidermal spread of melanocytes in superficial spreading melanoma (SSM) with prominent nests. This case belongs to subgroup 2, characterized by focal suprabasal melanocytes (+1) as determined by Melan A immunohistochemistry. Scale bar: 1 mm.

Histopathology (likely Hematoxylin–Eosin staining) showing a magnified view of an expansive, well-nested lesion in a case (patient no. 35) of nested melanoma with pagetoid intraepidermal spread of melanocytes in superficial spreading melanoma (SSM) with prominent nests. This case belongs to subgroup 2, characterized by focal suprabasal melanocytes (+1) as determined by Melan A immunohistochemistry. Scale bar: 100 µm.

Histopathology (likely Hematoxylin–Eosin staining) showing morphological criteria initially leading to a classification of nested melanoma (patient no. 29). This case, related to pagetoid intraepidermal spread of melanocytes in superficial spreading melanoma (SSM) with prominent nests, was later reclassified as SSM with prominent nests after detection of pronounced pagetoid spread (classified as 2+) via Melan A immunostaining, placing it in subgroup 3. Scale bar: 500 µm.

Histopathology (likely Hematoxylin–Eosin staining) showing a magnified view of morphological criteria initially leading to a classification of nested melanoma (patient no. 29). This case, related to pagetoid intraepidermal spread of melanocytes in superficial spreading melanoma (SSM) with prominent nests, was later reclassified as SSM with prominent nests after detection of pronounced pagetoid spread (classified as 2+) via Melan A immunostaining, placing it in subgroup 3. Scale bar: 200 µm.

Histopathological imaging of Merkel cell carcinoma, specifically showing a dermal and subcutaneous malignancy from a right thigh specimen. Microscopically, the lesion is composed of diffuse sheets of basophilic tumor cells with vesicular nuclei and small nucleoli. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, X200 magnification.

Histopathological imaging of Merkel cell carcinoma, specifically showing a dermal and subcutaneous malignancy from a right thigh specimen. Microscopically, the lesion is composed of diffuse sheets of basophilic tumor cells with vesicular nuclei and small nucleoli. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, X400 magnification.

Histopathological imaging of superficial spreading melanoma, showing an asymmetrical proliferation of atypical epithelioid melanocytes with abundant cytoplasm, fine melanin pigmentation, and pleomorphic vesicular nuclei with prominent eosinophilic nucleoli, extending across all layers of the epidermis. H&E stain (X100).

Histopathological imaging of superficial spreading melanoma, showing an asymmetrical proliferation of atypical epithelioid melanocytes with abundant cytoplasm, fine melanin pigmentation, and pleomorphic vesicular nuclei with prominent eosinophilic nucleoli, extending across all layers of the epidermis. H&E stain (X200).

Histopathology of a mandibular lesion, specifically from the lower gingival tumor, showing infiltrating melanoma. The image, stained with hematoxylin and eosin, reveals key features including a mitotic index of 5/mm², ulceration, and involved margins. Final magnification ×100. Scale bar: 250 μm.

Histopathology showing an infiltrating melanoma from an upper gingival tumor (maxillary lesion) specimen, stained with hematoxylin and eosin. Key features include a mitotic index of 14/mm², presence of ulceration, and involved margins. Original magnification ×100. Scale bar: 250 μm.

Histopathology of an infiltrating melanoma from an upper gingival tumor (maxillary lesion), stained with hematoxylin and eosin. The image shows features of infiltrating melanoma, including a mitotic index of 14/mm², presence of ulceration, and involved margins. Final magnification ×400. Scale bar: 50 μm.

Histoscan showing histopathological features of cutaneous invasive melanoma from Patient L., a 55-year-old male. The melanoma is identified as an 8743/3 superficial spreading subtype with a Breslow thickness of 2.1 mm (pT3b). The neoplastic tissue exhibits characteristic irregular clusters, sheets, or fascicles of atypical melanocytic cells infiltrating the dermis and often extending into the subcutaneous fat. Staining is hematoxylin and eosin.

High magnification (×400) view of the tumor tissue, displaying histopathological features of cutaneous invasive melanoma from Patient L., a 55-year-old male. The melanoma is identified as an 8743/3 superficial spreading subtype with a Breslow thickness of 2.1 mm (pT3b). The neoplastic tissue mainly consists of irregular clusters, sheets, or fascicles of atypical melanocytic cells infiltrating the dermis and often extending into the subcutaneous fat. Staining is hematoxylin and eosin.

Histopathological microphotograph (hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification of 10×) showing focal hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, and fused and elongated interpapillary processes intersecting to form a trabecular-like net with storiform-patterned fibrous stroma.

Histopathological examination with hematoxylin and eosin staining at low-power magnification (4×) confirming the diagnosis of Verrucous Epidermal Nevus (VEN). The image demonstrates epithelial proliferation characterized by pronounced papillomatosis with prominent vertical projections (black arrows), focal irregular hypergranulosis, and basal layer hyperpigmentation.

Histopathological examination with hematoxylin and eosin staining at low-power view (4×) confirming the diagnosis of Verrucous Epidermal Nevus (VEN). The image reveals papillary and superficial reticular dermis with elongated interpapillary processes and mild perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate (black arrowheads).

Histopathological examination with hematoxylin and eosin staining at intermediate magnification (10×) confirming the diagnosis of Verrucous Epidermal Nevus (VEN). The image illustrates irregular acanthosis of the stratified squamous epithelium (black asterisk).

Histopathological examination with hematoxylin and eosin staining at high-power magnification (40×) confirming the diagnosis of Verrucous Epidermal Nevus (VEN). The image exhibits the stratum corneum with prominent lamellar hyperkeratosis (black star).

Histopathological examination of hematoxylin–eosin (H&E)-stained sections showing primary pulmonary malignant melanoma (PMML). The tumor is poorly demarcated from the surrounding area and grows along the alveolar wall. Tumor cells demonstrate prominent intracytoplasmic and interstitial melanin deposition.

Histopathological examination of hematoxylin–eosin (H&E)-stained sections showing primary pulmonary malignant melanoma (PMML). The tumor is mostly solid with some glandular lumen-like structures. Tumor cells demonstrate prominent intracytoplasmic and interstitial melanin deposition.

Histopathological examination of hematoxylin–eosin (H&E)-stained sections showing primary pulmonary malignant melanoma (PMML). The tumor in the solid area consists of epithelioid cells growing in nests and spindle cells arranged in bundles. Tumor cells are seen to invade the blood vessels and demonstrate prominent intracytoplasmic and interstitial melanin deposition.

Histopathological examination of hematoxylin–eosin (H&E)-stained sections showing primary pulmonary malignant melanoma (PMML). The tumor cells are clearly heterogeneous with distinct nucleoli, and pathological nuclear divisions are easily seen. Deposits of melanin granules are observed, consistent with prominent intracytoplasmic and interstitial melanin deposition, and eosinophilic infiltration is seen in the interstitium.

Histopathology (40x magnification) stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) showing a storiform arrangement of spindle cells with vesicular chromatin, conspicuous nucleoli, and abundant cytoplasmic melanin pigmentation.

Histopathology (400x magnification) stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) showing a storiform arrangement of spindle cells with vesicular chromatin, conspicuous nucleoli, and abundant cytoplasmic melanin pigmentation. A white arrow highlights the abundant cytoplasmic melanin pigmentation.

Histopathology of metastatic malignant melanoma (MM) showing tumor cells arranged in sheets with epithelioid morphology and visible thin-walled blood vessels. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (HE) at ×200 magnification.

Histopathology of metastatic malignant melanoma (MM) showing epithelioid, polygonal cells displaying varying degrees of eosinophilia, with some cells containing pigment in the cytoplasm. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (HE) at ×400 magnification.
Histopathology of metastatic malignant melanoma (MM) showing spindle-shaped cells interwoven with epithelioid cells. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (HE) at ×400 magnification.
Histopathology of the axillary metastatic malignant melanoma (MM) mass, predominantly composed of spindle-shaped cells. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (HE) at ×200 magnification.

Higher magnification histopathology (hematoxylin-eosin stain, original magnification x 200) of the melanocytic nevus with partial BRCA1-associated protein-1 (BAP1)-inactivation (BAPoma) from a 23-year-old female patient. The image reveals nests and strands of relatively monomorphic epithelioid cells with isolated mitoses (top right). This specific histology is compatible with partial BAP1 inactivation.

Histopathology (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, 100× magnification) showing basaloid cell proliferation over dermatofibroma from case number 6. This specific example exhibits a superficial growth pattern with lobule formation and peripheral palisading of basaloid cells, characteristic findings in such cases. Further features observed in these lesions include peritumoral clefting, absence of mature hair follicles, and occasional presence of small sebaceous glands.

Histopathology (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, 100× magnification) showing basaloid cell proliferation over dermatofibroma from case number 7. This specific example exhibits a superficial growth pattern with lobule formation and peripheral palisading of basaloid cells, characteristic findings in such cases. Further features observed in these lesions include peritumoral clefting, absence of mature hair follicles, and occasional presence of small sebaceous glands.
Histopathology showing individual lymphocytes migrating into the atrophic epithelium. The image is stained with Hematoxylin-Eosin and has an original magnification of 200:1.
At higher magnification, large, atypical lymphocytes with irregular nuclei are visible. The image is stained with Hematoxylin-Eosin, uses oil immersion, and has an original magnification of 630:1.
