Histopathology of pigmented dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (Bednar tumour), a rare histologic variant observed in 2% of cases in the study. The image shows numerous pigmented dendritic cells interspersed among spindle cells, demonstrating heavy melanin deposition. (Hematoxylin & eosin, ×100 magnification).

Histopathologic features of classic-pattern dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP). This classical histopathologic pattern, observed in 90% of DFSP cases in the study, is characterized by uniform spindle cells arranged in a storiform pattern. Panel A specifically shows these spindle cells infiltrating the dermis and extending into the subcutaneous tissue. (Hematoxylin & eosin, ×40 magnification).

Histopathologic features of classic-pattern dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP). This classical histopathologic pattern, observed in 90% of DFSP cases in the study, is characterized by uniform spindle cells arranged in a storiform pattern. Panel B specifically shows these spindle cells infiltrating the dermis and extending into the subcutaneous tissue. (Hematoxylin & eosin, ×100 magnification).

Histopathology showing a myxoid spindle cell neoplastic proliferation within the dermis, indicative of dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP) with myxoid change. This myxoid subtype was identified as a rare histologic variant, accounting for 2% of the total 42 histologically confirmed DFSP cases included in the study. The image is stained with Hematoxylin & eosin, at ×100 magnification.

Histopathology of dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP) with fibrosarcomatous transformation. The image shows spindle-shaped cells arranged in intersecting bundles, forming a prominent herringbone pattern. Fibrosarcomatous transformation is a rare histologic variant of DFSP, identified in 7% (3 out of 42) of the cases in this study, and is associated with a more aggressive clinical course. One patient with fibrosarcomatous DFSP developed pulmonary metastases and died from disease progression. Stained with Hematoxylin & eosin, magnification ×100.

Histopathology of dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP) with fibrosarcomatous transformation, showing numerous mitoses (highlighted with circles). The presence of increased mitotic activity is characteristic of the fibrosarcomatous component, indicating a higher proliferative rate. Fibrosarcomatous transformation is a rare histologic variant, identified in 7% (3 out of 42) of the cases in this study, and is associated with a more aggressive clinical course, including pulmonary metastases and disease progression. Stained with Hematoxylin & eosin, magnification ×400.

Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) stained tissue section (x200 magnification) from a patient with hypopigmented macular amyloidosis. The image shows reduced pigmentation of the basal layer, which correlates with the white structureless areas observed clinically. Additionally, the dermis displays deposition of acellular, eosinophilic materials within the papillary dermis, specifically located between the rete pegs, consistent with amyloidosis.

Histopathology with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) stain at 200x magnification showing flattened rete ridges and hypomelanosis of the basal layer of the epidermis, consistent with idiopathic guttate hypomelanosis (IGH).

Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) stained histopathology image (x100 magnification) of a skin biopsy from a lower leg affected by vitiligo. The section characteristically shows a complete absence of melanin and melanocytes in the epidermis, consistent with the diagnosis of vitiligo. There is also evidence of focal interface dermatitis (indicated by a brown arrow).

Histological slide of an anorectal melanoma (AM), showing features crucial for its diagnostic journey. This hematoxylin–eosin stained section displays anal glands and malignant cells arranged in solid nests. Key characteristics include pleomorphic nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and occasional melanin pigment in the cytoplasm. Systematic pathology protocols and clinical vigilance are highlighted as vital for early detection of this rare and diagnostically elusive malignancy, even when prognosis remains poor.

Microscopic examination of a histopathological section of an excised lesion, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), revealing a dilated follicular infundibulum filled with lamellar keratin. The epithelium is acanthotic, with radiating epithelial strands present at the base and sides of the pore. A superficial perivascular lymphohistiocytic infiltrate is also observed. These findings confirmed the diagnosis of Dilated Pore of Winer (DPW) (×2.5 magnification).

Histopathological image, hematoxylin-eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification × 5, showing an atrophic and flattened epidermis. The underlying dermis exhibits prominent actinic (solar) elastosis (indicated by arrow >), reflecting major actinic damage. Also present are amorphous grayish deposits interspersed throughout the mid and deep dermis (indicated by arrow →). These deposits are consistent with residual hyaluronic acid (HA) filler material, as confirmed by specialized stains like colloidal iron, and may be associated with subtle inflammatory changes. The histological findings align with HA filler-related post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation (PIH) and are observed in the central vermilion, which appeared lighter clinically.

Histologic examination of the small bowel showing a malignant neoplasm composed of sheets of poorly differentiated epithelioid neoplastic cells with enlarged, irregular nuclei and prominent nucleoli. These cells are infiltrating the mucosa, submucosa, and muscularis propria. The background small bowel mucosa is normal and free of dysplasia. Image stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Histopathology showing intestinal-type sinonasal adenocarcinoma (ITAC). This low-power view shows a complex villous/tubulopapillary architecture with surrounding stroma, simulating intestinal mucosa. The fronds are lined by atypical columnar epithelium with nuclear pseudostratification and intraluminal mucin. Intestinal-type adenocarcinomas (ITACs) are the more common subtype of non-salivary paranasal cavity adenocarcinoma, named for their histologic resemblance to intestinal tumors, which can range from benign polyps to aggressive adenocarcinoma. Patients in the sixth decade of life are most commonly affected, and the nasal cavity is the most frequent site. Hematoxylin–eosin (H&E). Original magnification ×100.

Histopathology showing non-intestinal-type sinonasal adenocarcinoma (non-ITAC), low-grade, with a tubulopapillary pattern. The image displays branching tubulo-papillary structures lined by uniform cuboidal-to-low-columnar cells, which exhibit mild cytologic atypia, inconspicuous nucleoli, and low mitotic activity. The background contains hemorrhagic debris and scattered inflammatory cells. Overt “dirty” necrosis and overt intestinal differentiation, features often seen in ITACs, are absent in this non-ITAC subtype. Most sinonasal non-ITACs are of the low-grade type, and like ITACs, patients in the sixth decade of life are most affected, with the nasal cavity being the most common site. Non-ITACs differ from ITACs in their specific histopathological characteristics. Hematoxylin–eosin (H&E). Original magnification ×100.

Histopathology from a skin biopsy, showing a follicular proliferation composed of basaloid cells with peripheral palisading, consistent with trichoblastoma. (Hematoxylin and eosin stain, 10× magnification).

Histopathological features of a nodular lesion consistent with eccrine poroma, showing a proliferation of uniform small cuboidal cells arranged in anastomosing bands. Visible ductal lumina are present, embedded in a fibrovascular stroma. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 10× magnification.

Histopathological features of a nodular lesion consistent with eccrine poroma, shown at higher magnification. This view details ductal differentiation and highlights poroid cells characterized by scant cytoplasm and round nuclei. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 40× magnification.

Histopathology from a plaque biopsy showing epidermal papillomatosis with acanthosis, associated with an increase in sebaceous glands and abortive hair follicles within the dermis, consistent with nevus sebaceous (H&E, 10× magnification).

Histopathology of a resected gastric polyp from a 75-year-old man, diagnosed as malignant melanoma, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (HE) at 20×10 magnification, revealing melanoma cells with irregular morphology, melanin granules within the cytoplasm, and nuclear pleomorphism and atypia.

Histopathology of a resected gastric polyp from a 75-year-old man, diagnosed as malignant melanoma, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (HE) at 20×10 magnification, revealing melanoma cells with irregular morphology, melanin granules within the cytoplasm, and nuclear pleomorphism and atypia.

Histopathology of a resected gastric polyp from a 75-year-old man, diagnosed as malignant melanoma, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (HE) at 40×10 magnification, revealing infiltration of melanocytes within the lesion accompanied by melanin deposition.

Histopathology with H&E stain (×200 magnification) showing tumor cells consistent with meningeal melanocytoma. The image displays melanin-rich spindle morphology with minimal atypia. These well-differentiated tumor cells were observed in a dural-based mass invading the clival and sellar bones and showed no mitotic activity, necrosis, or nuclear atypia.

Histopathology with H&E stain (×400 magnification) showing tumor cells consistent with meningeal melanocytoma. The image displays melanin-rich spindle morphology with minimal atypia. These well-differentiated tumor cells were observed in a dural-based mass invading the clival and sellar bones and showed no mitotic activity, necrosis, or nuclear atypia.

Histopathology with H&E stain (×200 magnification) showing benign melanosis in a biopsy sample from the sphenoid sinus. This was identified as part of additional biopsies taken from the sphenoid sinus and dura.

Histopathology with H&E stain (×100 magnification) showing benign melanosis in a biopsy sample from the sphenoid sinus. This was identified as part of additional biopsies taken from the sphenoid sinus and dura.

Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained low-power microscopic view (×1 magnification) of a second specimen, revealing a biphasic neoplasm characterized by the presence of epithelial nests and a spindle-cell stroma.

Histopathology at low-power magnification (H&E, ×4) showing a biphasic neoplasm from the second patient, which is composed of both epithelial and mesenchymal components. The image reveals basaloid epithelial nests with peripheral palisading, consistent with a basal cell carcinoma component. These epithelial nests are evident within a cellular spindle-cell stroma. The sarcomatous stroma demonstrates nuclear pleomorphism, scattered atypical mitotic figures, and multinucleated giant cells.

Low-power magnification (×4) image of the first specimen, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E). The image displays malignant epithelial islands embedded within a spindle-cell stroma, consistent with a biphasic tumour.

Hematoxylin and eosin staining of the first specimen showing cutaneous carcinosarcoma. The stained section displays biphasic morphology, characterized by both malignant epithelial and spindle-cell mesenchymal components.

Histopathology stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at higher magnification (10X) of the second specimen. The image demonstrates epithelial nests consistent with basal cell carcinoma, interspersed with sarcomatous stroma containing pleomorphic spindle cells, multinucleated giant cells, and atypical mitotic figures.

High-power view (×40 magnification) showing histopathology of the first specimen stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E). The image displays malignant spindle cells characterized by marked nuclear pleomorphism, vesicular chromatin, prominent nucleoli, and frequent atypical mitoses, situated adjacent to epithelial tumour nests.

Anatomopathological image of a recurrent melanocytic nevus. This image displays a trizonal pattern, a characteristic present in 84.5% of recurrent nevi. Key features indicated are the lentiginous junctional component (black arrow), cicatricial dermal fibrosis (blue arrow), and nests of nevus cells (red arrow). The sample is stained with Hematoxylin & eosin and viewed at ×200 magnification.

Histopathology of seborrheic keratosis on hematoxylin and eosin stain, showing characteristic pseudohorn cysts (black arrow), which represent intraepidermal invaginations filled with keratin. The image also displays proliferation of small basaloid keratinocytes (asterisk), reflecting the benign acanthotic growth pattern of seborrheic keratosis (magnification, ×100).

Histopathological examination revealing hyperkeratosis, parakeratosis, acanthosis with anastomosing rete ridges forming a reticulated pattern, and clusters of mature sebocytes in the mid-to-lower epidermis (H&E staining, ×200 magnification).

Microscopic image of histopathology for Case 21, an 82-year-old male presenting with lentigo maligna melanoma (LMM) on the forehead. The image, stained with H&E and viewed at 100x magnification, shows the tumor at Level 1 with a Breslow thickness of 0.5 mm.

Microscopic image of histopathology for Case 21, an 82-year-old male presenting with lentigo maligna melanoma (LMM) on the forehead. The image, stained with H&E and viewed at 100x magnification, shows the tumor at Level 4 with a Breslow thickness of 0.9 mm. This increased Breslow thickness (compared to 0.5 mm on Level 1 in panel a) resulted in the upstaging of the patient from pT1a to pT1b.

Microscopic image of histopathology for Case 39, an 82-year-old male with lentigo maligna melanoma (LMM) on the arm. The image, stained with H&E and viewed at 400x magnification, displays incipient ulceration with fibrin and epidermal consumption observed on Level 2. The overall Breslow thickness for this case was 1.5 mm.

Microscopic image of histopathology for Case 39, an 82-year-old male with lentigo maligna melanoma (LMM) on the arm. The image, stained with H&E and viewed at 200x magnification, reveals ulceration at the next 100 μm interval, specifically on Level 3. The presence of ulceration (also seen in incipient form in panel c) resulted in the upstaging of the patient from pT2a to pT2b. The overall Breslow thickness for this case was 1.5 mm.

Microscopic image of histopathology for Case 31, a 79-year-old male with lentigo maligna melanoma (LMM) on the scalp. The image, stained with H&E and viewed at 100x magnification, shows no evidence of lymphovascular invasion (LVI) on the first three levels of examination. The overall Breslow thickness for this case was 1.4 mm.

Microscopic image of histopathology for Case 31, a 79-year-old male with lentigo maligna melanoma (LMM) on the scalp. The image, stained with H&E and viewed at 100x magnification, shows evidence of lymphovascular invasion (LVI) on Level 4 of examination. In this specific case, the presence of LVI did not result in a change in the pT stage. The overall Breslow thickness for this case was 1.4 mm.

Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained histopathology showing dermal melanophages with viable melanoma cells (arrowhead), suggestive of partial regression. Tumoral melanosis (TM) is a histological term describing aggregations of melanin-containing macrophages (melanophages) often found in the dermis, typically devoid of accompanying melanocytes, and is strongly associated with primary and/or metastatic melanoma.

Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained histopathology showing dermal melanophages with viable melanoma cells (arrowhead), suggestive of partial regression. Tumoral melanosis (TM) is a histological term describing aggregations of melanin-containing macrophages (melanophages) often found in the dermis, typically devoid of accompanying melanocytes, and is strongly associated with primary and/or metastatic melanoma.
Histopathology image (H&E, ×1000 magnification) showing a tumor cell in the center. The tumor cell displays a large, pleomorphic nucleus containing several vacuoles.
Histopathology (H&E stain, ×1000 magnification) showing a tumor cell nucleus in the center of the field. The nucleus displays irregularly marginated chromatin with a pale, central pseudoinclusion.

Histopathology of a 5-µm section from formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded tissue, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×100 magnification, showing a deep penetrating nevus. Nests of spindle cells and epithelioid-like cells are observed as deep dermal and subcutaneous nested proliferations, arranged in a wedge-shaped pattern. These nests diffusely penetrate and infiltrate the surrounding tissues, including the deep subcutaneous adipose tissue on the left. Note the abundance of melanophages along with some pigment incontinence.

Histopathology (H&E, ×20 magnification) showing nested proliferations of spindle and epithelioid cells within the deep reticular dermis and subcutaneous tissue. These cells are arranged in a characteristic wedge shape with a broad base in parallel with the deep reticular dermis and an apex directed toward the epidermis. This lesion, subsequently diagnosed as a deep penetrating nevus, features nests that diffusely penetrate and infiltrate the surrounding tissues. The tumor cells exhibit severe cytologic atypia and pleomorphism, along with occasional nuclear vacuoles and large pseudoinclusions. Abundant melanophages and some pigment incontinence are also present.

Histopathology of a deep penetrating nevus, observed in 5-um sections from formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded tissue stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×400 magnification. The image displays tumor cells revealing severe cytologic atypia and pleomorphism. Several cells exhibit nuclear vacuolation, with occasional large pseudoinclusions also noted. The overall lesion showed deep dermal and subcutaneous nested proliferations of spindle and epithelioid cells arranged in a wedge-shaped pattern, with nests diffusely penetrating and infiltrating the surrounding tissues, along with abundant melanophages and some pigment incontinence.
High power microscopic image of a biopsy specimen, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Histopathology of a biphasic renal tumor, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at an original magnification of ×100. The tumor is composed mainly of medium to large epithelioid cells and focal areas of spindle cells, which are arranged around numerous small blood vessels.

Histopathology showing perivascular epithelioid cells, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at an original magnification of ×400. The cells are arranged in solid nests or cords, exhibiting well-defined cytoplasmic borders and abundant cytoplasm that varies from eosinophilic and granular to clear.

Histopathology, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at an original magnification of ×400, revealing moderate-to-severe nuclear pleomorphism and hyperchromatism. The image also shows bizarre multinucleated giant cells and mitotic figures.

This is a low-power histological view (hematoxylin and eosin stain, × 80 magnification) depicting the typical histological morphology of a polypoid malignant melanoma (MM) of the anorectal region, characterized by superficial ulceration. This represents primary anorectal melanoma, which is considered when the tumour arises in the rectum, anal canal, or anal margin.

This detailed histological view (hematoxylin and eosin stain, × 250 magnification) shows extensive tumour growth of anorectal melanoma beneath an intact surface squamous epithelium. This represents a typical histological morphology of primary anorectal melanoma, a condition where the tumour arises in the rectum, anal canal, or anal margin.

Low-power histopathologic appearance (Hematoxylin-eosin stain, ×40 magnification) of a solitary fibrofolliculoma, as confirmed by pathological examination. The image reveals a well-defined tumor mass involving a group of adjacent pilosebaceous follicles. It characteristically shows a proliferation of fibrotic stroma, forming a fibromucinous mesenchymal component, which surrounds the central dilated infundibulum of the hair follicle. Proliferative thin epithelial strands, cords, and spurs extend from the infundibular follicular epithelium into this fibrous mantle, often anastomosing to form an epithelial network or septa, contributing to an 'epithelial sponge' appearance.

High-power histopathologic photograph, stained with Hematoxylin-eosin (×100), showing a solitary fibrofolliculoma. The image displays the characteristic appearances of proliferating infundibular epithelial strands with perifollicular fibrous reaction, anastomosing to form an epithelial network. An arrow indicates a hair follicle. Histological examination revealed this well-defined tumor mass involves a group of adjacent pilosebaceous follicles and contains proliferative epithelial cords and spurs in the center, with a surrounding fibromucinous mesenchymal component, confirming the diagnosis of fibrofolliculoma.

Histopathology of the enucleated right eye from a 79-year-old man with a history of age-related macular degeneration, 9 months after local resection of a minimally pigmented ciliary body/choroidal mixed cell type melanoma. The enucleated eye showed no residual melanoma. This image highlights the area posterior to the resected ciliary body, where the choroid terminates (indicated by an arrow) in the region of the previously resected tumor. Detached, gliotic retina (labeled R) is present in this area. The tissue is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin at 25x magnification.

Histopathology of skin showing malignant melanoma (Clark's level V, Breslow thickness 45 mm) with infiltrating melanin pigment containing epithelioid and spindle tumor cells. Features include brisk mitoses (3 to 5 mitoses/high-power field) and junctional activity. (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, ×100 magnification).

Photomicrograph showing histopathological features of an excised orbital mass, consistent with a mixed spindle cell and epitheloid cell melanoma. The image displays a sheet of plump epitheloid tumor cells with large nuclei and prominent nucleoli. Melanin is absent in the tumor cells, consistent with the largely amelanotic nature of this melanoma. (H&E, ×400 magnification)

Low power photomicrograph of the tumor, showing a predominance of cells forming fascicles and marked vascular channels. This image was captured at X200 magnification using Hematoxylin and eosin staining.

Histopathology of a biopsy specimen from a 56-year-old man with flat and black pigmented mucosal lesions in the distal esophagus and esophagogastric junction, showing primary malignant melanoma of the esophagus (PMME). The tumor mainly consists of poorly cohesive neoplastic cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and cytosolic melanin granules, which predominantly proliferated in the mucosa. Hematoxylin and eosin stain, ×400 magnification.

Histopathology of an oncocytoma, one of 3 cases (7.14%) identified among the epithelial tumors. The image, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 400× magnification, shows sheets of large granular, eosinophilic polyhedral epithelial cells (oncocytes) having small, round, benign appearing central nuclei with large nucleoli.

Histopathology of a MALT Lymphoma, identified as a low-grade B cell lymphoma MALT in one case (2.38%) among the lymphoid tumors. The image, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 400× magnification, shows lymphoid B cells infiltrating the caruncle's surface epithelium.
Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained section showing malignant melanocytes located within the periosteum of the bone.
Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained section showing malignant melanocytes infiltrated into subcutaneous tissues.

Skin biopsy from a nodule in the infra mammary region, showing epidermis and subepithelial stroma (dermis) with sparse collections of mononuclear cells, without any junctional activity. The stratified squamous epithelium is unremarkable. Magnification: ×10. H&E stain.

Skin biopsy from a nodule in the infra mammary region, showing epidermis and subepithelial stroma (dermis) with sparse collections of mononuclear cells, without any junctional activity. The stratified squamous epithelium is unremarkable. Magnification: ×20. H&E stain.

A well-circumscribed nodular lesion in the dermis, composed of round to oval melanocytes with prominent nuclei and nucleoli, and condensed chromatin, arranged in tight nests. No continuity could be traced between the nodular lesion and the overlying skin. Magnification: ×20. H&E stain.

High magnification view of the tumor nodule within the dermis, showing melanocytes with prominent nuclei and nucleoli, condensed chromatin, and intralesional pigment. The cells are arranged in tight nests within this well-circumscribed lesion. Magnification: ×40. H&E stain.

Histopathologic findings of a dark brown, dome-shaped mass excised from the posterior wall of the left ear canal's cartilaginous portion in a 33-year-old woman. The image shows scattered clusters composed of round to oval-shaped melanocytic cells (black arrow) located in the dermis, consistent with a dysplastic nevus within an intradermal nevus, due to the presence of atypical melanocytes without pleomorphism. The image is stained with Hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×200.

Histopathologic findings of the mass excised from the left ear canal of a 33-year-old woman, showing numerous nests and groups of melanocytic nevus cells located in the dermis, covered with normal skin. These findings were compatible with an intradermal nevus, but the nevus contained atypical melanocytes without pleomorphism, leading to a final diagnosis of a dysplastic nevus within an intradermal nevus (Hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×10).
Microscopic findings of the lesion, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at low magnification.

Microscopic findings of the lesion, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at high magnification, showing plump epithelial cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm and numerous brown pigmented granules arranged in a tubular pattern.
Histopathologic appearance showing a junctional nevus in an 8-year-old boy. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) and captured at ×200 magnification.
Histopathologic appearance of a blue nevus, diagnosed in an adult and located at the caruncle, showing proliferating stromal melanocytes. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (×200 magnification).
Histopathologic appearance of a compound nevus, stained with hematoxylin and eosin, at ×100 magnification.

Histopathology showing a subepithelial cystic nevus (hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification ×200). In this study, subepithelial nevi comprised 24% (n=25) of the excised lesions, and 36% (9/25) of these subepithelial nevi were observed to be cystic. Overall, 60% of all nevi in the study were cystic.
Histopathologic appearance of a compound nevus, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) and viewed at ×200 magnification.

Histopathology showing a subepithelial nevus located at the caruncle in a 14-year-old boy. This image is an example of a subepithelial nevus, a diagnosis that comprised 24% (n=25) of the 105 excised lesions in the study. All three nevi located at the caruncle in the study were subepithelial. The section is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (×200 magnification).
Histopathologic appearance of a caruncular subepithelial nevus from this patient, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at ×200 magnification.

Photomicrograph showing malignant melanoma cells arranged in an alveolar pattern. Histologically, the tumour was composed predominantly of epithelioid tumour cells. The diagnosis of malignant melanoma was suggested by characteristic nesting of malignant cells beneath the bronchial epithelium with junctional change and mitotic activity, and was confirmed by positive immunohistochemical reactions for S-100 protein and melanoma associated monoclonal antibody HMB45. (Hematoxylin-Eosin stain, ×400 magnification).

Photomicrograph of a polypoidal mass of malignant melanoma, showing an endobronchial tumor with mucosal invasion. Histologically, the tumor is composed predominantly of epithelioid tumor cells, exhibiting junctional change and mitotic activity, with characteristic nesting of malignant cells beneath the bronchial epithelium, features suggestive of malignant melanoma. (Hematoxylin-Eosin ×50).

Histopathology depicting lymphocyte aggregates (mild perivascular infiltrate composed of lymphocytes) situated in between muscle bundles, which are characteristic of the interlacing bundles of smooth muscle fibers that form the tumor. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification ×200.

Photomicrograph of a piloleiomyoma, a tumor typically centered on the reticular dermis. The image displays unencapsulated, partly circumscribed interlacing bundles of smooth muscle fibers, which may be admixed with collagen. The tumor cells show eosinophilic cytoplasm and spindle-shaped nuclei, further described as plump, blunt-ended, and vesicular with inconspicuous nucleoli. This lesion can abut the epidermis, potentially leading to flattening of rete ridges overlying the tumor. The section is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) and viewed at ×100 magnification.

Histopathology showing tumor cells with large pleomorphic hyperchromatic nuclei. These pleomorphic cells typically comprised not more than 10% of the total cell population. The tumor cells generally featured eosinophilic cytoplasm and plump, blunt-ended vesicular nuclei with inconspicuous nucleoli. A moderate degree of anisonucleosis was noted in some cases. Mitosis is inconspicuous, consistent with the overall observation of no mitotic activity in any of the cases. (Hematoxylin and Eosin, ×400)

Histopathology of Piloleiomyoma, demonstrating prominent arrector pili (AP) in the superficial dermis, distinct from and adjacent to the main lesion. Piloleiomyomas are typically centered on the reticular dermis, sometimes extending to the papillary dermis, and are characterized by partly circumscribed, unencapsulated interlacing bundles of smooth muscle fibers admixed with collagen. The tumor cells show eosinophilic cytoplasm, plump, blunt-ended vesicular nuclei with inconspicuous nucleoli, and may exhibit a moderate degree of anisonucleosis. These lesions often abut the epidermis, resulting in flattening of the overlying rete ridges. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification ×200.

Photomicrograph of the central cyst of the mass lesion, revealing blood-filled, nonendothelial lined pseudovascular spaces. These pseudovascular spaces are surrounded and lined by dendritic melanocytes (lesional cells), a finding analogous to an angiomatoid melanoma or aneurysmal benign fibrous histiocytoma. Immunohistochemical analysis of these tumor cells demonstrated positivity for HMB-45, S-100, and melan-A, and negativity for estrogen receptor, progesterone receptor, CD34, smooth muscle actin, and AE1/AE3, with a MIB-1 proliferative index of less than 1%. (Hematoxylin and eosin stain, original magnification, × 40).

Photomicrograph of a vaginal mass from a 29-year-old pregnant woman, who presented with a gradually enlarging pigmented lesion on the anterior vaginal wall. The image shows a subepithelial cellular proliferation comprising spindle cells and heavily pigmented dendritic melanocytes, which are arranged predominantly in fascicles and epithelioid nests dissecting through the vaginal wall. These cells are surrounded by collagen fibers and a prominent vascular stroma, with abundant accompanying melanophages. The microscopic examination of the resected 6.0 × 4.3 × 3.5 cm cystic mass, which had focal areas of dark pigmentation, did not reveal cytologic pleomorphism, atypical mitosis, or necrosis. Original magnification, × 40, hematoxylin and eosin stain.

Histopathological image (H&E stain, ×25 magnification) showing ocular surface squamous neoplasia (OSSN). The image demonstrates replacement of the conjunctival epithelium by dysplastic squamous cells, along with thickening and keratinization of superficial cells, indicative of atypia. Histopathological examination of OSSN cases revealed partial to full thickness replacement of conjunctival epithelium by dysplastic squamous cells, and atypia was detected in 17 cases.

Histopathological image (H&E stain, ×25 magnification) showing ocular surface squamous neoplasia (OSSN). The image highlights a sudden transition (indicated by arrow) between the normal conjunctival epithelium and the dysplastic area, with an intact basement membrane. Histopathological examination of OSSN cases consistently revealed an abrupt transition between the normal conjunctiva and the dysplastic area, with an intact basement membrane, and no invasive squamous cell carcinoma was seen in any of the cases.

Histopathology photomicrograph showing nevus cells with junctional activity in the epidermodermal junction and extending into the dermis, accompanied by excessive chronic inflammatory cell infiltration. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and captured at ×100 magnification.
Photomicrograph depicting a cystic nevus. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and captured at ×25 magnification.

Photomicrograph illustrating a junctional nevus, characterized by nevus cells situated at the epidermodermal junction. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and captured at ×25 magnification.

Photomicrograph showing the cubical cell layer lining of a ductal retention cyst, with an area of epithelium rich in goblet cells (Hematoxylin and Eosin, ×25 magnification). This histological view corresponds to a ductal retention cyst, such as those found occupying the temporal fornix, which were among the most common cystic lesions observed (16 out of 23 cystic lesions, or 70%) and occurred with significant difference in middle-aged patients.

Histopathological examination of a pyogenic granuloma, which are the most frequent lesions observed. The image shows dilated and congested capillaries separated by fibrotic stroma, along with variable grades of inflammatory cell infiltration, characteristic features of pyogenic granulomas. (Hematoxylin and Eosin, ×25 magnification).
Histopathology showing coarse melanin granules that obscure the epithelioid cell membranes. Intermingling of dense collagen bundles produces a checkerboard appearance. H&E stain, 200× magnification.

Histopathology showing epithelioid cells with little pigmentation around the periphery of the cytoplasm. The cells also show a prominent nucleus and occasional dot-like nucleoli. The cell membranes are indistinct. H&E stain, 200× magnification.

Histopathology showing an incidental focus of Hailey-Hailey-like acantholysis, identified in a skin specimen. This specific case illustrates the acantholysis occurring in association with a benign keratosis exhibiting features of seborrheic keratosis, consistent with cases in the study where Hailey-Hailey-like patterns were associated with significant inflammation, such as inflamed seborrheic keratosis. The image is captured at 200X magnification and stained with hematoxylin and eosin.

Histopathology showing incidental focal acantholytic dyskeratosis (FAD) occurring in a punch biopsy of lichen simplex chronicus from the scalp. This image, stained with hematoxylin and eosin and viewed at 200X magnification, showcases an FAD pattern. This specific case is one of three FAD cases identified among six incidental FAD or Hailey-Hailey (HH) instances found in 247 reviewed skin specimens. It was associated with significant inflammation, and the average diameter of acantholysis across such FAD cases was 0.3 mm, with a range of 0.1 mm to 0.5 mm.

Histopathology demonstrating incidental epidermolytic hyperkeratosis (EHK) occurring in association with a dysplastic junctional nevus. This represents one of three cases of EHK identified in the study that were associated with biopsies of dysplastic/Clark's nevi. The EHK lesions in these cases had an average diameter of 0.15 mm, with a range of 0.05 mm to 0.8 mm. The image is presented at 200X magnification and stained with hematoxylin and eosin.

Histopathology showing incidental focal acantholytic dyskeratosis (FAD) associated with prominent solar elastosis. This specific FAD case, one of three FAD patterns identified in the study, was found in a skin specimen that occurred in association with an excision of a melanoma in situ. This is one of four cases in the study associated with prominent solar elastosis and one of three cases associated with malignant or premalignant epidermal neoplasia (melanoma in situ with FAD). The average diameter of acantholysis observed in such cases was 0.3 mm, with a range of 0.1 mm to 0.5 mm. Patients with incidental FAD had an average age of 68 years (range 41–86). (400X magnification, hematoxylin, and eosin stain).

High power view of the tumour, stained with H&E (×10 objective), showing spindle cells with slightly wavy nuclei forming short and long interlacing fascicles, exhibiting a prominent fascicular growth pattern. No significant nuclear pleomorphism was visible, and mitosis was rarely noted (1 in up to 30 high power field at ×40 objective).

Low power view of a well-defined, encapsulated nodular tumour, showing reactive lymphoid cell infiltrate and focal calcification at its periphery. The tumour appears as a well-defined nodular lesion. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, ×4 objective.

High power histopathological view of the tumour, an encapsulated and well-defined nodular lesion, showing prominent amianthoid fibres. The tumour cells are spindle-shaped with slightly wavy nuclei forming short interlacing fascicles. Amianthoid fibres were easily identified, though present in few areas of the tumour. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×40 objective magnification.

High power view of the tumour, which represents an encapsulated, well-defined nodular lesion, showing a prominent fascicular growth pattern with many short and long interlacing fascicles of tumour cells. The cells are spindle-shaped with slightly wavy nuclei. H&E stain, ×20 objective.

High-power photomicrograph showing pathologic findings consistent with congenital melanocytic nevi, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E). The image displays the keratinized, stratified squamous epithelium (thick black arrow) and the epidermodermal junction (thick white arrow). The epidermis is thinned out with loss of rete pegs. The underlying dermis shows diffuse deposition of melanin pigment (thin white arrow) and the presence of melanocytes (thin black arrow) around and within the hair follicles. These findings, observed during microscopic examination of the patient's scalp swelling, also included lobules and nests of nevi cells, hair follicles, sweat glands, and sebaceous glands, with melanin pigment and melanocytes extending up to the deep subcutis and infiltrating the fat, all indicative of congenital melanocytic nevi.
Photomicrograph showing a small focus of adenocarcinoma that was missed at the time of initial diagnosis. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).
High power view of adenocarcinoma, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Histopathology showing a symmetrical, well-circumscribed papule with a fibro-mucinous stroma containing spindle-shaped and dendritic melanocytes, which sometimes were arranged in whorls. Melanophages are present. These features are consistent with the diagnosis of a sclerosing mucinous blue naevus and help exclude malignant melanoma. Magnification 20x, Hematoxylin and Eosin stain.

Histopathological section of a lesion, likely a keratoacanthoma, from an excisional biopsy of a lip lesion or an incisional biopsy from the left buccal mucosa. The image shows hyperplastic stratified squamous epithelium covered with a thick layer of parakeratin, with characteristic parakeratin plugging clearly evident on the surface. Epithelial islands are invading the underlying connective tissue in a regular, pseudo-carcinomatous fashion, forming a pushing front where the connective tissue responds with an inflammatory infiltrate. Dysplasia is absent, and the underlying connective tissue is normal with uninfiltrated sebaceous and salivary glands. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin at 4× magnification.

Histopathology showing the margin of a lesion with an abrupt change from normal stratified epithelium to the lesional tissue, which is characteristic of keratoacanthoma. This specific section demonstrates the classical transition at the margins of the lesion, suggesting features of keratoacanthoma without any evidence of malignancy. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, 4× magnification.

Histopathologic findings of a nodular type tumor, observed in the nasolabial fold. The image shows a number of round or oval tumor islands and stromal retraction within the upper to mid dermis. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and captured at ×100 magnification.

Histopathologic findings of a superficial type tumor, observed in the back. The image displays multiple buds of basophilic cells extending into the papillary dermis from the basal layer of the epidermis. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and captured at ×100 magnification.

Histopathologic findings of a mixed pattern tumor, observed in the thigh. The image exhibits features characteristic of superficial, nodular, and some pigmented types. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and captured at ×100 magnification.
Histopathology showing an increased layer of thin meshwork of collagen fibers in the upper dermis. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at ×100 magnification.

Histopathology of a skin biopsy specimen from a 3-week-old Korean girl who presented with well-demarcated hemorrhage-like maculopatches on the right foot since birth. The image shows irregular acanthosis in the epidermis and hyperplasia of numerous eccrine glands and capillaries in the mid-upper dermis, consistent with Eccrine Angiomatous Hamartoma (EAH). (Hematoxylin and eosin stain, ×100 magnification).

Histopathology of a skin biopsy specimen from a 3-week-old Korean girl who presented with well-demarcated hemorrhage-like maculopatches on the right foot since birth. The image shows hyperplasia of numerous eccrine glands and capillaries, associated with fatty tissue. This finding, observed without pilar, lipomatous, mucinous, or lymphatic structural hyperplasia, supports a diagnosis of Eccrine Angiomatous Hamartoma (EAH). (Hematoxylin and eosin stain, ×200 magnification).

Photomicrograph showing the course of a perianal fistulous tract with a nest of melanocytic cells, consistent with a primary fistula melanoma. This lesion was located in the depth of the subcutaneous tissue, adjacent to the epithelialized fistulous tract, and surrounded by abundant inflammatory response. The pathologist's examination of the resected specimen revealed an abscessed fistulous tract associated with a small core of hyperpigmented, hyperplastic basal melanocytes arranged irregularly in a lentiginous pattern, and a discernible nest of epithelioid cells with atypical anaplastic nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and abundant melanin in the underlying dermis. Hematoxylin-Eosin staining; original magnification 4×.

Photomicrograph providing a closer view of the melanocytic cell core within the perianal fistula melanoma. This core consists of epithelioid cells with atypical anaplastic nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and abundant melanin, forming an irregular, lentiginous pattern within the underlying dermis next to the fistulous tract. The presence of these atypical cells and abundant melanic pigment throughout the lesion is characteristic of melanoma. Hematoxylin-Eosin staining; original magnification 10×.

Photomicrograph showing individual melanoma cancerous cells at high magnification, including one cell clearly undergoing mitosis. These epithelioid cells exhibit atypical anaplastic nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and abundant melanin. The presence of mitoses in deep cells is a key feature relatively specific for melanoma, supporting the diagnosis of a primary fistula melanoma identified incidentally in a 38-year-old male. Hematoxylin-Eosin staining; original magnification 40×.

Photomicrographic image of a cross-section of the entire resected fistula piece, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 2× magnification. This image shows the fistulous tract, the lentiginous melanocytic hyperplasia, and the perianal skin epidermis. The melanoma, which was quite small and found incidentally during histological examination, is located in the depth of the subcutaneous tissue, next to the fistulous tract, the interior of which was already epithelialised. The melanoma is surrounded by an abundant inflammatory response and is next to the visible lesion showing atypical lentiginous melanocytic hyperplasia. The presence of lentiginous hyperplasia suggested that the melanocytic lesion originated inside the fistulous tract, supporting the diagnosis of a primary melanoma. The opening of the fistulous tract in the perianal skin epidermis does not contain signs of inflammation or malignant tissue, ruling out the possibility of the fistula being a complication or a secondary manifestation of a cutaneous melanoma.
Low-power image of cutaneous melanoma in situ, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E). Melanocytes in melanoma in situ frequently fail to possess a primary cilium. Scale bar: 100 µm.

Low-power image of a cutaneous melanocytic nevus, where primary cilia are typically retained by the melanocytes. This image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), showing the general histopathology of the nevus. Scale bar: 100 µm.

Low-power image of invasive cutaneous melanoma, stained with hematoxylin and eosin. The study investigates melanocytes in invasive melanoma, which frequently fail to possess a primary cilium. Scale bar: 100 µm.

Histopathology showing interstitial mucin deposits appearing as blue-gray stringy material between the collagen bundles in the upper and mid-dermis. These fibromyxoid changes in the dermis are typically observed in treated facial lesions of leprosy and may resemble mucin deposits seen in collagen vascular diseases like lupus erythematosus. (H&E, ×400)
Scanning view showing flat pigmented epidermis and a thickened nerve with surrounding lymphocytic infiltrate in the subcutis. (Hematoxylin and Eosin, ×40 magnification)
Flat epidermis with uniformly increased melanin in the basal layer without increased melanocytes at the dermoepidermal junction. Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) stain, magnification ×400.

Histopathology showing an ill-formed, noncohesive, opened out granuloma. Intercellular edema is observed separating the epithelioid cells. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×400 magnification.

Histopathologic examination of an excisional biopsy specimen from a solitary, 1.5×1.5 cm subcutaneous tumor on the sole of the right foot of a 52-year-old Korean woman. The image shows increased numbers of eccrine glands and dilated vascular channels located in the deep dermis and subcutaneous tissue, findings consistent with an eccrine angiomatous hamartoma (EAH). (Hematoxylin and eosin stain, ×12.5 magnification).

Histopathology showing melanin pigmented cells separated from small cells with high nuclear to cytoplasmic ratios and hyperchromatic nuclei. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at ×100 magnification.
Histopathology showing a globular pattern of calcification with tall columnar cells and stellate reticulum. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×10 magnification.

Histopathology displaying calcifications with tall columnar cells showing reverse polarity, along with the presence of stellate reticulum, viewed at ×100 magnification using Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) staining.

Histopathological examination showing tumor cells arranged in alveolar-like spaces or a pseudoglandular structure with central infoldings, set against a dense fibrovascular stroma. The individual tumor cells exhibit a characteristic biphasic pattern, comprising two morphologically distinct types: larger cuboidal cells and small undifferentiated hyperchromatic cells. The irregular alveolar spaces are lined by the larger cuboidal cells, which have a moderate amount of cytoplasm, well-defined margins, round to oval nuclei with finely dispersed chromatin, and inconspicuous nucleoli; some of these cells contain brownish pigment. Small hyperchromatic cells with scanty cytoplasm are present within the spaces or as isolated nests within the fibrillar background. Isolated clusters of the larger cells are also present. No evidence of atypical mitosis or necrosis is observed in the tissue. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, ×10 magnification.

Histopathology showing a biphasic tumor cell population, characterized by the presence of both large and small cells. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at ×100 magnification.
Microscopic section (H&E stain, original magnification ×200) revealing melanin-pigmented cells with symplasmic cytoplasm.

Microscopic image showing cells with reticulo-granular nuclear chromatin and small nucleoli. The cytoplasm contains melanin pigment, as visualized with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) staining at ×400 magnification.

Histopathology of the resected temporal lobe neocortex from a 17-year-old male patient, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). The image shows abundant brown melanin pigment present within the cytoplasm of neurones and astrocytes, as well as free in the neuropil. This well-circumscribed area of pigment was located within layers I–IV of the cortex. Nests of melanocytes were not seen, and melanocytes were not apparent morphologically by light microscopy. Immunohistochemical staining for pre-melanosomes (HMB45) was positive in many pigment-bearing cells, including pyramidal neurones and cells morphologically resembling astrocytes. Scale bar is 50 μm.

Histopathology of the resected left amygdala from a 17-year-old male patient, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). The image shows brown melanin pigment present within neurones and in the neuropil, with large amounts of pigment observed. The tissue architecture in the amygdala appears less organized compared to the neocortex, consistent with the site, and many of the pigmented cells are located in the parenchyma adjacent to vessels. The patient has a history of intractable temporal lobe epilepsy. Scale bar is 20 μm.

Histopathology of the resected temporal lobe neocortex from a 17-year-old male patient, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). The image highlights that many of the pigment-bearing cells are astrocytes, which contain abundant brown melanin pigment. The pigment is also present in neurones and free in the neuropil within layers I-IV of the cortex. Immunohistochemical staining for pre-melanosomes (HMB45) was positive in many pigment-bearing cells, including cells that morphologically resembled astrocytes. The patient has a history of intractable temporal lobe epilepsy. Scale bar is 15 μm.

Histopathology image, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), showing occasional clusters of small brown-red granules. These granules were observed in surgical specimens from both the left amygdala and the left temporal lobe neocortex of a 17-year-old male patient with intractable temporal lobe epilepsy. The clusters were often associated with aggregates of extracellular melanin pigment but were notably not stained on the Masson Fontana preparation. Scale bar is 20 μm.
Histopathology using H&E staining showing epidermal acanthosis with parakeratosis and superficial perivascular lymphohistiocytic infiltration in the upper dermis, consistent with chronic eczema.

Light microscopic findings of the surgical specimen revealing large epithelioid tumor cells with dusty brown melanin pigments and frequent mitotic figures. These features are consistent with the diagnosis of primary malignant melanoma of the urethra. (H&E, ×400).

Histopathological findings of the central epidermal cyst showing a foreign body reaction with multiple giant cells. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) and viewed at ×20 magnification.

Histopathology demonstrating plentiful mature eccrine coils enmeshed in loose connective tissue, with a notable absence of associated blood vessels. This microscopic finding supports the diagnosis of a hamartoma, which was identified in a 26-year-old female presenting with a blue-colored swelling on the dorsum of her left hand. The biopsy revealed a lobulated, unencapsulated structure composed of numerous eccrine glands. (Hematoxylin and eosin stain, original magnification ×400)

Histopathology showing neoplastic cells, varying in morphology from short spindle-shaped to dendritic, infiltrating the iris stroma. The neoplastic proliferation also focally involved the contiguous ciliary body. All cells showed uniform, oval, vesicular nuclei with finely dispersed chromatin and inconspicuous nucleoli, and lacked mitotic figures, cellular atypia, or necrosis (H&E, ×200).

Photomicrograph of a choroidal section in a case of sympathetic ophthalmia, showing extensive inflammatory infiltration predominantly by lymphocytes with some plasma cells. Also visible is a choroidal granuloma composed mainly of epithelioid cells, which are interpreted as Dalen-Fuchs nodules. Magnification: ×200. Staining: Hematoxylin and eosin.

Photomicrograph of a choroidal section in a case of sympathetic ophthalmia, depicting epithelioid granulomata and a multinucleated giant cell. The choroid presents foci consistent with inflammatory infiltration. Magnification: ×200. Staining: Hematoxylin and eosin.

Photomicrograph of a choroidal section in a case of sympathetic ophthalmia, demonstrating a dense lymphocytic infiltration. The choroid shows foci of lymphocytes and plasma cells, typical of the inflammatory process in sympathetic ophthalmia. Magnification: ×200. Staining: Hematoxylin and eosin.

Photomicrograph of a choroidal section from the enucleated inciting right eye in a case of sympathetic ophthalmia, depicting a multinucleated giant cell with phagocytosed melanin granules. This is a characteristic finding in the choroid of eyes affected by sympathetic ophthalmia. Magnification: ×400. Staining: Hematoxylin and eosin.

Histopathology showing a cystic lesion located in the dermis, originating from a nodule. The cyst wall displays bland squamous proliferation, trichilemmal keratinization, dyskeratotic cells, and multiple squamous eddies, characteristic of a proliferating trichilemmal cyst. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin and is presented at 50X and 200X magnification, respectively.

Histopathology of an esophageal tumor biopsy showing a proliferation of epithelioid and spindle-shaped cells arranged in fascicles, with the presence of melanin pigment. This tumor, located in the junction medium-distal esophagus, was identified as a 2 cm, lobulated, and pigmented mass, leading to a diagnosis of primary esophageal melanoma. Hematoxylin and eosin (HE) stain, original magnification ×40.

Microscopic image of a bladder polyp biopsy from a 54-year-old male patient, revealing a diffuse, dense proliferation of small to medium-sized neoplastic plasmacytoid cells. The neoplastic cells demonstrate eosinophilic cytoplasm and eccentric nuclei with prominent nucleoli. Some cells are binucleated (indicated by '⇒'). Note the presence of melanin pigment (indicated by '⊷') within some cells. This morphology, in the context of the patient's presentation and subsequent immunohistochemistry, led to a diagnosis of metastatic plasmacytoid melanoma. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE), magnification ×400.

Histopathology of an esophageal tumor from a 54-year-old male patient, showing sheets of large cells with plasmacytoid features. This tumor was identified as a 2 cm, lobulated, and pigmented mass in the junction medium-distal esophagus, and the biopsy revealed a proliferation containing a mixture of epithelioid and spindle-shaped cells arranged in fascicles with the presence of melanin pigment. (Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification ×400).

Histopathology of a bladder polyp, showing a diffuse and dense proliferation of rounded, neoplastic cells with plasmacytoid morphology. The cells are small to medium, characterized by eosinophilic cytoplasm and eccentric nuclei with prominent central nucleoli. The neoplastic cells display incohesion within the tissue. This finding is consistent with metastatic plasmacytoid melanoma. Hematoxylin and eosin stain, original magnification ×40.

Histopathology showing atypical lymphocytes observed within lacunae in the epidermis. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at 400x magnification. This finding is from patient 4.
Atypical lymphocytes showing epidermotropism and formation of Pautrier's microabscesses (H&E stain, 400x).

Histopathology showing clusters of nevus cells containing melanin pigment. These nevus cells are characterized by a large nucleus and scanty eosinophilic cytoplasm. This image is from a case diagnosed as osteonevus of Nanta (or osseous metaplasia in benign intradermal melanocytic nevus). (H&E, 40x).

Histopathology showing a well-circumscribed lamellar bone with fatty marrow at the center, seen adjacent to nevus cells. This finding is consistent with a diagnosis of osteonevus of Nanta (or osseous metaplasia in benign intradermal melanocytic nevus). The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at 10x magnification.
Histopathology showing nests of nevus cells with overlying normal epidermis. The nevus cells have a large nucleus and scanty eosinophilic cytoplasm. (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, 10x magnification).

Histopathology of an incisional biopsy from buccal mucosa, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (40× magnification). The image shows marked acanthosis within the non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium, with diffuse distribution of dendritic melanocytes in the suprabasal layers. No cytologic atypia is observed, supporting a diagnosis of Oral Melanotic Macule (OMA).

Histopathology showing prominent parakeratosis in case 2, characterized by deep invaginated columns of parakeratosis throughout the hyperplastic epidermis. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and captured at 40× magnification.

Histopathology demonstrating several neutrophils infiltrating the upper spinous layers and aggregating on the surface of the lesion. The elongated dermal papillae are stuffed with foamy histiocytes, characterized by small central nuclei and abundant finely vacuolated cytoplasm. Image stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 100× magnification, from case 3.

Histopathology showing elongated dermal papillae stuffed with foam cells. These foam cells are further characterized as foamy histiocytes with small central nuclei and abundant finely vacuolated cytoplasm. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain; 400× magnification (case 3).

Histopathology demonstrating exophytic papillomatous and digitate epidermal hyperplasia, with some incurving of peripheral rete, giving the overall silhouette of a wart, as observed in Case 3. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 20× magnification.

Histopathology showing acanthotic seborrheic keratosis with bowenoid transformation. In this variant, the surface is smooth and rounded, and there is an obvious acanthosis, horn cysts, and a basaloid cell population. This image (haematoxylin eosin (H&E) staining, ×100) illustrates one of the cases of malignant transformation, specifically bowenoid transformation, found among atypical seborrheic keratoses in a study of 429 seborrheic keratosis cases.

Histopathology showing adenocarcinoma cells that have infiltrated the superficial dermal connective tissue and penetrated the dermoepidermal junction. Abundant melanin pigment is observed in elongated and dendritic melanocytes colonizing these underlying carcinoma cells. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (HE) at 40x magnification.

Histopathology of a polypoid, partially ulcerated melanoma found in the urethra of a 65-year-old woman. The image shows a polypoid tumor with superficial ulceration, which was part of a 3-cm wide, pedunculated, black pigmented, friable, haemorrhagic polyp found at the posterior wall of the urethral meatus. The tumor comprised squamous and transitional epithelia. Stained with haematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at ×40 magnification.

Histopathology of urethral melanoma from a 65-year-old woman, revealing loosely cohesive nests of atypical epithelioid and spindle-shaped melanocytes. The neoplastic cells exhibit abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, large hyperchromatic nuclei with prominent nucleoli, and numerous mitotic figures, indicating brisk mitotic activity. Most of the tumour cells contain coarsely granular melanocytic pigment. Stained with haematoxylin and eosin, original magnification ×400.

Histopathology illustrating Microscopic satellites (Ms) in a typical section. This panel shows a discrete tumor nest (indicated by a red arrowhead) that is greater than 0.05 mm in size. The tumor nest is separated from the main body of the tumor by normal reticular dermal collagen. The image is stained with H&E and viewed at ×100 magnification.

Histopathology illustrating Microscopic satellites (Ms) in a typical section. This panel shows a discrete tumor nest (indicated by a red arrowhead) that is greater than 0.05 mm in size. The tumor nest is separated from the main body of the tumor by normal reticular dermal collagen. The image is stained with H&E and viewed at ×200 magnification.

Histopathology showing a typical section of tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes (TILs), specifically representing the absent group where no lymphocytes are present within the tumor. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), ×100 magnification.

Histopathology showing a typical section of tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes (TILs), specifically representing the non-brisk group, characterized by sparse and isolated groups of lymphocytes present between melanoma cells. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), ×100 magnification.

Histopathology showing a typical section of tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes (TILs), specifically representing the brisk tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes (TIL) group. In this group, lymphocytes are diffusely interposed between melanoma cells throughout the entire vertical growth phase. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), ×100 magnification.

Histopathology (H & E staining) of the cyst wall from a jet-black cystic spinal nerve sheath tumor arising from the L5 root in a 45-year-old woman shows fibro-collagenous stroma with interspersed ganglion cells and brownish-black melanin pigmentation within the cyst.

Histopathology of the excised mass, stained with Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at an original magnification of ×100. The image shows lobules communicating with the epidermal surface via several openings. Each lobule is composed of a peripheral, mitotically active, basaloid germinative layer, which exhibits no cytologic atypia and matures to vacuolated sebocytes in the center. Transitional forms between these cell types are also visible.

Histopathology showing proliferation of mature eccrine glands and capillaries (vascular structures, generally capillary) in the middle to deep dermis of the right second finger from patient 2, characteristic of eccrine angiomatous hamartoma (EAH). The lesion, typical of those found in the study, is solitary and located on a distal extremity, and the epidermis appears normal. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification ×50.

Histopathology showing proliferation of mature eccrine glands and capillaries (vascular structures, generally capillary) in the middle to deep dermis of the right second finger from patient 2, characteristic of eccrine angiomatous hamartoma (EAH). The lesion, typical of those found in the study, is solitary and located on a distal extremity, and the epidermis appears normal. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification ×200.

Histopathology of a skin biopsy, showing discrete nests of nevus cells at the dermoepidermal junction, primarily located on the accentuated tips of rete ridges. The biopsy, taken from a 9-year-old girl with multiple clusters of pigmented moles diagnosed as agminated acquired melanocytic nevi, also revealed a markedly increased amount of melanin pigment in the epidermis with melanophages in the superficial dermis. No nuclear atypia or mitosis was observed among the nevus cells. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification ×100.

Histopathology of a pigmented poroma, displaying a symmetrical and well-circumscribed epithelial neoplasm. The neoplasm consists of cellular aggregates of regular sizes and shapes, which are connected to the base of the epidermis and protrude into the dermis. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at 40X magnification.

Histopathology of a pigmented poroma, showing an epithelial aggregate composed of both poroid and cuticular cells. The poroid cells are characterized by small, round, and uniform nuclei with scant cytoplasm, while the cuticular cells display larger nuclei and abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm. Ductal structures are visible, formed between the cuticular cells. Just above the center of this photomicrograph, there is a focus of necrosis en masse, a characteristic feature often observed in poromas (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, 200X magnification).

Photomicrograph showing a pigmented poroma. The image details cuticular cells at the center, between which tubules are formed. Granules of melanin are noted inside one of the tubules. Poroid cells predominate at the periphery. (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, 400X magnification).

Histopathology of a pigmented poroma, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at 400X magnification. The image shows details of poroid cells on the left side and a focus of necrosis en masse on the right side. It is notable that there is an absence of palisading of nuclei at the periphery of the aggregate of cells.
Melanocytic cells showing a wedge-shaped distribution in the dermis with diffuse fibrosis. This image was captured at ×20 magnification and stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Histopathology of a sebaceous lobule (magnification ×200) showing two sharply defined, circumscribed parts (A1 and A2) composed exclusively of small-sized, degenerative atrophic sebocytes. These atrophic sebocytes are reduced to almost half or one-third the size of normal sebocytes, with some nuclei compressed peripherally in the cell body and exhibiting pyknosis, and scanty cytoplasm. None of the sebocytes, including the atrophic ones, show atypia. In contrast, normal sebocytes (N), located in the upper right corner of the image, display a centrally situated, crenated nucleus and a delicate network of fine cytoplasmic vacuoles. There is slight lymphohistiocytic infiltration in the periadnexal dermis. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE).

Histopathology of sebaceous glands, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE). The image displays a sebaceous lobule containing two sharply defined, circumscribed atrophic parts, labeled A1 and A2. These atrophic regions are exclusively occupied by small-sized, degenerative sebocytes, which are reduced to approximately half or one-third the size of normal sebocytes. The nuclei of these atrophic sebocytes are compressed peripherally within the cell body and exhibit pyknosis, with scanty cytoplasm. In contrast, the normal part of the lobule, labeled N (located in the upper right corner), shows normal sebocytes characterized by a centrally situated, crenated nucleus and a delicate network of fine cytoplasmic vacuoles. No atypia is observed in any sebocytes, including the atrophic ones. Slight lymphohistiocytic infiltration is noted in the periadnexal dermis. Original magnification ×200.

Histopathology showing eczematous dermatitis, revealing features of spongiotic dermatitis and interface dermatitis with lymphohistiocytic cell infiltration. The image, obtained from a lesion biopsy, demonstrates relatively thick, confluent parakeratosis in the epidermis, along with moderate acanthosis and irregularly elongated rete ridges of uneven width. Mild focal spongiosis and focal liquefaction degeneration of basal cells are present. Exocytosis of lymphocytes and histiocytes is observed, and the basal layer is slightly hyperpigmented. There is moderate lymphohistiocytic infiltration extending from the dermal-epidermal junction to the papillary dermis. In the subpapillary and superficial reticular dermis, slight to moderate perivascular lymphohistiocytic infiltration is seen, and melanophages are scattered. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at an original magnification of ×50.

Histopathology stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 40x magnification showing lesional cells of the Pigmented Epithelioid Melanocytoma (PEM), a low-grade melanocytic tumor. These cells infiltrate well into the reticular dermis with a poorly circumscribed infiltrative pattern at the base, consistent with the described densely pigmented dermal nodule and its infiltrative borders. The proliferation is composed of epithelioid and spindle melanocytes with heavy pigmentation; atypical cells are present.

Histopathology stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 100x magnification showing densely and heavily pigmented spindle to epithelioid melanocytes admixed with melanophages. These features are characteristic of Pigmented Epithelioid Melanocytoma (PEM), a low-grade melanocytic tumor, which presents as a densely pigmented dermal nodule with infiltrative borders and contains atypical epithelioid and spindle melanocytes.

Histopathology from Case 1, demonstrating psoriasiform hyperplasia with diffuse clear-cell change of keratinocytes in the Malpighian layer and fusion of rete ridges. Stained with Hematoxylin-Eosin (H-E), original magnification 100x.

Histopathology (Hematoxylin-Eosin, original magnification 100x) from Case 2 showing elongated, fusioned, club-shaped rete ridges containing numerous clear cells. Notable features include papillary-dermal edema, elongated capillaries, and an inflammatory cell infiltrate.

Histopathology from Case 2 showing an eroded epidermis, congestive capillaries, and erythrocyte extravasation. This is presented alongside an acanthotic epidermis which displays intense clear-cell change. (Stain is Hematoxylin-Eosin, consistent with other histopathological panels in this series; original magnification not specified).
Histopathology (Hematoxylin-Eosin, original magnification 400x) from Case 2 showing neutrophils scattered among clear cells.

Histopathology (Hematoxylin-Eosin, original magnification 400x) from Case 2 showing a mixed interstitial and perivascular inflammatory cell infiltrate composed of lymphocytes and numerous eosinophils.
Histopathology showing certain tumor cells were pigmented, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (HE staining) at a magnification of 10×20.

Photomicrograph showing squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). Malignant squamous epithelial cells are infiltrating the underlying stroma. Squamous cell carcinoma was the commonest malignant lesion observed in this study, accounting for 9 cases. (Hematoxylin and Eosin, ×100 magnification).

Photomicrograph showing a dermoid cyst, which is classified as a benign cystic teratoma, located in the conjunctiva. The image displays squamous epithelium and adnexal glands, specifically including sebaceous glands, present within the subepithelial layer. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin, at ×100 magnification.

Photomicrograph showing an epithelial inclusion cyst in the conjunctiva. The image depicts a cystic lesion that is lined by epithelial cells. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin, at ×100 magnification.

Photomicrograph showing conjunctival intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN). The dysplastic cells involve the full thickness of the squamous layer, but the underlying stroma is uninvolved. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin at ×100 magnification.

Photomicrograph showing subepithelial nevus in conjunctiva. There are groups of melanin producing nevus cells underneath the non-keratinized squamous epithelial layer. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin at ×100 magnification.
Haematoxylin-eosin-stained section showing the dermal PDM (plexiform dermal melanocytic) nodule of the trunk, viewed at ×20 magnification.

Histologic details from a malignant neoplasm, showing tumor cells mainly with epithelioid morphology (red arrows) and less with spindle cell morphology. The image also displays multinuclear giant cells (yellow arrow) and abundant melanin deposition (green arrow). The histopathology revealed a malignant neoplasm, specifically vaginal primary malignant melanoma, with these predominant epithelioid cells, multinuclear giant cells, and abundant melanin deposition. Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification ×200.

Histologic details from a malignant neoplasm, showing tumor cells mainly with epithelioid morphology (red arrows) and less with spindle cell morphology. The image also displays multinuclear giant cells (yellow arrow) and abundant melanin deposition (green arrow). The histopathology revealed a malignant neoplasm, specifically vaginal primary malignant melanoma, with these predominant epithelioid cells, multinuclear giant cells, and abundant melanin deposition. Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification ×400.

Histopathology showing a malignant neoplasm diagnosed as vaginal primary malignant melanoma with ulceration, affecting the vaginal epithelium. The arrows point to the squamous cell epithelium of the vagina. Stained with H&E, original magnification ×200.

Histopathology showing a malignant neoplasm diagnosed as vaginal primary malignant melanoma with ulceration, affecting the vaginal epithelium. The arrows point to the squamous cell epithelium of the vagina. Stained with H&E, original magnification ×400.

Histopathology showing a malignant neoplasm diagnosed as vaginal primary malignant melanoma with ulceration, causing ulceration in the vaginal epithelium. The arrows point to the ulceration caused by the tumor in the vaginal squamous cell epithelium. Stained with H&E, original magnification ×200.

Histopathology showing a malignant neoplasm diagnosed as vaginal primary malignant melanoma with ulceration, causing ulceration in the vaginal epithelium. The arrows point to the ulceration caused by the tumor in the vaginal squamous cell epithelium. Stained with H&E, original magnification ×400.

Histopathology of an ungual matrix biopsy from a 17-year-old female patient presenting with longitudinal melanonychia on the right thumb. The image shows atypical melanocytes not confined to the basement membrane with pagetoid spread and no evidence of dermal invasion, compatible with melanoma in situ. (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, 40x magnification).

Histopathological examination of an excisional biopsy of a nodule shows an ulcerated tumor extending in a diffuse pattern from the epidermis to the inferior limit of the specimen. The tumor cells are rounded with vesicular nuclei, scant cytoplasm, numerous mitotic figures, and dyskeratotic and apoptotic cells. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at x40 objective magnification.

Histopathology of the specimen periphery showing hyperplasia and acanthosis of the epidermis. Intracytoplasmic melanin pigment is observed in small aggregates within the cells. The image was captured with a x10 objective using hematoxylin and eosin stain.

Histopathology showing nests of large, bizarre chondrocytes embedded in a chondroid matrix. This presence of nests was observed in approximately one third of the lesion and strongly suggests positivity for Alcian Blue. (hematoxylin and eosin stain, x 40 objective)

Nests of atypical melanocytes are observed at the dermoepidermal junction, without evidence of pagetoid spread. Isolated atypical melanocytes are also present in the upper dermis (hematoxylin and eosin stain, x 40 objective).
Histopathology showing the intraepidermic component of lentigo maligna melanoma. The image is stained with Haematoxylin Eosin and viewed at 200x magnification.
This image shows dermal melanocytes with a moderate amount of pigment, captured at 100x magnification. The tissue is stained with Haematoxylin & Eosin.

Histopathology of skin, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×40 magnification, showing elongated rete ridges and an increased number of junctional melanocytes, arranged in nests. At the dermoepidermal junction, nests of nevus cells are profuse on the tips and sides of the elongated rete ridges. Additionally, there are scattered single melanocytes in a lentiginous array, without continuous proliferations.

High-magnification histopathology of skin, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×400 magnification, depicting several melanocytes with abnormally large nuclei. These nuclei also exhibit irregular contours, as indicated by the arrows.
Histopathology image showing acanthotic epidermis with abundant melanin pigment. The image was captured at ×40 magnification using Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) staining.

Histopathology of the superficial dermis showing pigmented epithelioid and spindle tumor cells. The cells exhibit clear cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei, resembling atypical melanocytes, which are seen proliferating from the dermal-epidermal junction into the connective tissue. Specifically, epithelioid atypical melanocytes are observed in the superficial region, along with pigmented nests of atypical melanocytes and melanophages. Atypical features like hyperchromatism are also evident. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and captured at ×40 magnification, consistent with a diagnosis of malignant melanoma.

Histopathology of malignant melanoma, specifically the predominant spindle cell type consistent with desmoplastic malignant melanoma, showing atypical melanocytes. These tumor cells exhibit prominent atypical features including mitosis, multi-nucleation, pleomorphism, hyperchromatism, increased nuclear cytoplasmic ratio, and prominent nucleoli. The cells have a clear cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei, proliferating from the dermal-epidermal junction into the connective tissue, often appearing fusiform to round with an irregular branching pattern and intervening fibrous septae. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, ×40 magnification.

Histopathological examination of excised tissue revealing spindle tumor cells characteristic of malignant melanoma, specifically desmoplastic malignant melanoma, in the deeper regions of the connective tissue. The tumor cells appear fusiform to rounded in different orientations, forming an irregular branching pattern with intervening fibrous septae. Atypical features such as clear cytoplasm, hyperchromatic nuclei, pleomorphism, mitosis, multi-nucleation, increased nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio, and prominent nucleoli are present. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at ×40 magnification.

Histopathology of the deep dermis showing a tumor with a predominant spindle cell type, characteristic of atypical melanocytes.
