The tumor cells are arranged in an irregular branching pattern with intervening fibrous septae. These spindle cells appear fusiform to round in different orientations. This presentation, with spindle cell predominance and collagenous stroma, is suggestive of desmoplastic malignant melanoma. Histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of malignant melanoma. Atypical features such as mitosis, multi-nucleation, pleomorphism, hyperchromatism, increased nuclear cytoplasmic ratio, and prominent nucleoli are seen within the tumor. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at ×10 magnification.

Histopathology of a biopsy taken from a jet black papule, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at ×5 magnification, showing an asymmetric melanocytic neoplasm. There is an irregular distribution of nests of variable size, consisting of atypical melanocytes extending up to the mid reticular dermis. Features also include epidermal flattening overlying the dermal nests and several melanocytes present in solitary units above the basal layer of the epidermis.

Histopathology showing neoplastic melanocytes with mild to moderate atypia and occasional mitotic figures, along with haphazard pigment distribution in both normal and atypical melanocytes, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at ×10 magnification.

Histopathology showing neoplastic melanocytes with mild to moderate atypia and occasional mitotic figures, along with haphazard pigment distribution in both normal and atypical melanocytes, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at ×10 magnification.
Histopathology revealing neoplastic melanocytes within a dilated capillary in the deep dermis, suggestive of angioinvasion, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at ×20 magnification.

Photomicrograph of an areola biopsy specimen showing marked thickening of the epidermis with slight papillomatosis and striking filiform downward acanthosis and anastomizing rete ridges. The basal layer of the epidermis was hyperpigmented without associated melanocytic proliferation. Slight fibrosis of the upper dermis was also identified. These diagnostic histopathological clues are typical for NHNA type 3. (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, original magnification ×10)

Histopathological features of the back nodule showing the conventional component of the malignant melanoma. The tumor is composed of large polygonal cells with large round nuclei. The majority of these tumor cells contain melanin pigment. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (magnification, ×200).

Microscopical features of oral melanoacanthoma, showing numerous dendritic melanocytes distributed throughout the acanthotic epithelium, specifically in the basal and suprabasal layers. The melanocytes do not display any cytologic atypia. The connective tissue is normal, with the exception of occasional eosinophils, and there is no spillage of melanin pigment or melanocytes into the subepithelial zone. (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain; original magnification ×100)

Histopathology showing perforating calcific elastosis, viewed at ×20 magnification. Hematoxylin-eosin-stained section illustrates clumping of short, thick, irregularly shaped, and basophilic degenerated elastic fibers within the dermis. These elastic fibers are infiltrated with calcium and predominantly located in the middermis, characteristic of perforating calcific elastosis, where calcified elastic fibers can be extruded through the epidermis.

Histopathology showing perforating calcific elastosis, viewed at ×40 magnification. Hematoxylin-eosin-stained section illustrates clumping of short, thick, irregularly shaped, and basophilic degenerated elastic fibers within the dermis. These elastic fibers are infiltrated with calcium and predominantly located in the middermis, characteristic of perforating calcific elastosis, where calcified elastic fibers can be extruded through the epidermis.
Histopathology image showing few solid areas present in the upper dermis. The section is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×100 magnification.

Histopathology image showing a neoplastic proliferation with an infiltrative growth pattern among the collagen bundles in the lower dermis. The section is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×100 magnification.
Histopathology at low magnification (H&E ×20) showing an ill-defined neoplasm involving the entire dermis.
Histopathology at higher magnification (H&E ×100) showing the neoplasm consisting of long arborizing vessels dissecting the dermal collagen.
Histopathology at higher magnification (H&E ×200) showing the vessels of the neoplasm lined by plump endothelial cells with frequent papillary projections.
Panoramic view of the lesion revealing a well-circumscribed, symmetric lesion with hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, and pseudohorn cysts. Hematoxylin and eosin (HE) stain.
The lesion is composed of spindle-shaped and epithelioid melanocytes with large cytoplasm, arranged in confluent nests with peripheral clefts. Hematoxylin and eosin (HE) stain.
Observation of stromal fibrosis surrounding the nests within the lesion. Hematoxylin and eosin (HE) stain.
At the papillary layer of the lesion, proliferation of capillaries can be found. Hematoxylin and eosin (HE) stain.
A biopsy from normal-appearing skin shows normal pigment intensity in the epidermis. The image was stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and captured at 20× magnification.

Histopathology from a biopsy of a hypopigmented skin lesion shows a decrease in the pigment intensity within the epidermis. The image is stained with hematoxylin & eosin (H&E) and viewed at 20× magnification.

Microscopic view of a prostatic blue nevus, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), showing dusty and granular melanin pigment within myofibroblasts in the stroma. The image reveals fusiform stromal cells with intense melanin pigment, consistent with a blue nevus, associated with nodular hyperplasia and an acute inflammatory process (inset ×40 magnification).
Histopathology of the neoplasm in the left toe, showing the tumor occupying the entire dermis, stained with hematoxylin-eosin.

Histopathological findings of the neoplasm in the left toe, showing pleomorphic spindle cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm, blunt-ended nuclei, and perinuclear vacuoles, stained with hematoxylin-eosin.
Histopathological findings of the lymph node, showing a cytologically uniform eosinophilic spindle cell neoplasm with remarkable neural-like cytomorphology, stained with hematoxylin-eosin.

Histopathology showing the presence of fusion of nests along the sides of rete ridges, concentric fibroplasia, atypical melanocytes, melanophages in the dermis, and proliferated basaloid cells. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at 400x magnification.

Histopathology showing presence of hyperkeratosis, horny pseudocysts and melanophages in the dermis, and discrete perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, 100X magnification).

Histopathological biopsy sample, obtained via tru-cut needle biopsy, from a 43-year-old woman with a protruding anal lesion, diagnosed with melanoma of the rectum. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (× 100 magnification), the image shows pleomorphic lesions displaying high mitotic rate and prominent nucleoli. Both intra- and extra-cellular melanin pigment are visible (indicated by white solid arrows), suggestive of malignant melanoma.
Histopathology showing a tumor composed of fascicles of short spindle cells. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) and viewed at ×40 magnification.

Microscopic section, taken from a biopsy of black discoloration found in the middle part of the esophagus, showing scattered pigment-laden dendritic melanocytes and deposition of coarse brownish black pigment between the keratinocytes within the basal layer of the surface squamous epithelium. The overlying squamous epithelium is otherwise normal, with no cellular atypia. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 400x magnification.

Microscopic section, taken from a biopsy of black discoloration found in the middle part of the esophagus, showing many heavily pigmented cells in the lamina propria. These cells represent increased numbers of pigment-laden dendritic melanocytes and deposition of coarse brownish black pigment, and tested positive for Masson Fontana, HMB 45, and S100, and negative for Perls’ stain, with no cellular atypia. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 250x magnification.

High power histopathological view showing a cylindroma and surrounding adipocytes. The image highlights specific cellular and stromal features within the tissue: a red arrow points to an adipocyte, a green arrow indicates collagenous stroma, an orange arrow marks a peripheral cell characterized by a dark nucleus, and a blue arrow denotes a more centrally located cell with a pale nucleus. The tissue is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at 100x magnification.

High power view of a cylindroma, a tumor found in a 56-year-old woman presenting with a skin-colored nodule on the right anterior scalp. The image highlights key microscopic features, including a bright eosinophilic hyaline sheath (black arrow) ensheathing basaloid cell islands, consistent with the bright eosinophilic bands noted during microscopic examination. Also visible are duct-like structures (maroon arrows), two of which contain intraluminal amorphous eosinophilic content, and a small eosinophilic hyaline globule (yellow arrow), both characteristic findings within the tumor islands. (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, 200x magnification).

Histological section of sun-damaged skin showing multifocal, superficial basal cell carcinoma (BCC) colonised by small clusters and individually dispersed atypical melanocytes. The BCC was readily diagnosed on hematoxylin and eosin sections alone. The atypical melanocytes display abundant pale cytoplasm, large, vesicular nuclei, and prominent nucleoli. Original magnification ×20.

Histological section of sun-damaged skin showing multifocal, superficial basal cell carcinoma (BCC) colonised by small clusters and individually dispersed atypical melanocytes. The BCC was readily diagnosed on hematoxylin and eosin sections alone. The atypical melanocytes display abundant pale cytoplasm, large, vesicular nuclei, and prominent nucleoli. Original magnification ×40.

Histopathology of a biopsy taken from the prepuce of a 23-year-old man (case 1) who presented with pigmented lesions on his penis. The image shows a compound nevus with no sign of malignancy. Stained with haematoxylin and eosin; original magnification × 400.
Photomicrograph showing epidermal hyperkeratosis, papillomatosis, and elongation of rete ridges with mature adipose tissue in the dermis (H&E, 4× magnification).
Photomicrograph showing adipose tissue embedded in the dermal collagen. The image is taken at 10× magnification and stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Histopathology of Epithelioid fibrous histiocytoma, characterized by rounded or polygonal epithelioid cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm and round nuclei containing small eosinophilic nucleoli. This Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) stained image, viewed at 100x magnification, highlights these key cellular features. The lesion is typically well-demarcated, often located in the papillary and superficial reticular dermis, and its cells are separated by a delicate collagenous stroma, frequently interspersed with numerous small vessels.

Histopathology of a common fibrous histiocytoma. This panel shows an ill-defined, non-capsulated dermal lesion composed of interlacing fascicles of spindled cells. These lesional cells, which can include a variable admixture of fibroblasts, macrophages (some xanthomatous or multinucleated), and blood vessels, are set within a loose collagenous stroma. In this specific case, the lesion is separated from the epidermis by a grenz zone, a feature observed in 55% of cases in the study. An inflammatory, predominantly lymphocytic infiltrate can sometimes also be observed within the lesion. Hematoxylin and eosin stain, original magnification 40x.

Histopathology of a common fibrous histiocytoma, showing globular collagen bundles located at the periphery of the lesion. The presence of individual collagen bundles surrounded by lesional cells is a helpful diagnostic feature, often imparting a somewhat hyalinized or sclerotic appearance to the collagen. Long-standing lesions are typically fibrotic or sclerotic with decreased cellularity. Hematoxylin and eosin stain, original magnification 100x.

Histopathology of a common fibrous histiocytoma, depicting commonly associated epidermal changes. These features often include a hyperplastic epidermis with hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, and hyperpigmentation of the basal cell layer, as observed here. Other epidermal changes that can be detected include pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia or proliferation of hair follicle-like structures, which may mimic features of basal cell carcinoma. Hematoxylin and eosin stain, original magnification 40x.

Histopathology of aneurismal fibrous histiocytoma, showing a hemorrhagic space without endothelial lining, captured at 40x magnification with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) staining. This variant is histologically characterized by irregular hemorrhagic cleft-like and cystic spaces that lack an endothelial lining. Adjacent solid areas typically contain highly cellular tissues consistent with common fibrous histiocytoma. Focal interstitial hemorrhage and hemosiderin deposition are common features, and normal mitotic figures can be observed. The surrounding stroma frequently contains abundant small capillaries with interstitial hemorrhage and hemosiderin deposition. This lesion commonly shows extensive infiltration of the subcutis.

Histopathology of hemosiderotic fibrous histiocytoma, illustrating extensive hemosiderin deposition resulting from hemorrhage, captured at 100x magnification with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) staining. This lesion is composed of numerous small vessels, extravasated erythrocytes, and both intra- and extracellular hemosiderin deposition, which is a consequence of hemorrhage. Hemosiderotic histiocytoma is thought to represent a developmental stage of aneurysmal fibrous histiocytoma. Similar to the aneurysmal variant, this lesion is often distinguished by its depth, frequently involving the subcutis. Acanthosis is also a commonly observed feature in a large number of cases.

Histopathology showing clear cell fibrous histiocytoma, a very rare variant. The lesion is composed of sheets of clear cells occupying the reticular dermis. This uncommon variant typically occupies the reticular dermis and may extend into the subcutis, and in this study, lesions were located in the dermis and subcutis. Unlike most variants, clear cell fibrous histiocytoma was not associated with epidermal changes. It requires careful histological evaluation and differentiation from clear cell sarcoma and renal cell carcinoma metastasis. (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, 40x magnification).

Histopathology showing clear cell fibrous histiocytoma, a very rare variant. High magnification view of the lesion demonstrates clear cells with vesicular nuclei within the reticular dermis. The lesion usually consists of sheets of such clear cells occupying the reticular dermis and may extend into the subcutis, with cytological atypia and mitotic figures being rare. In this study, these lesions were located in the dermis and subcutis and were not associated with epidermal changes. This uncommon variant has a difficult histological evaluation and must be differentiated from clear cell sarcoma and renal cell carcinoma metastasis. (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, 100x magnification).

Histopathology demonstrating a lipidized fibrous histiocytoma, characterized by the presence of foamy cells (macrophages) enveloped by abundant sclerotic collagen bundles. This variant, sometimes informally referred to as 'ankle-type' fibrous histiocytoma, often presents clinically as a solitary exophytic yellow nodule. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and captured at 100x magnification.

Anatomopathological examination of a graft fragment, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at 10X magnification. Histopathological examination of the grafted area shows hyperorthokeratosis in basket weave, a pattern also found, although more tenuously, in normal acral skin. Other observed features include acanthosis, papillomatosis, and melanic epidermal hyperpigmentation mostly visible on the tips of epidermal ridges. Moderate pigment leakage, indicative of pigmentary incontinence, is also noted.

Histopathological examination of tissue obtained from neurosurgical resection, which confirmed the diagnosis of radionecrosis of the brain (RNB), indicating tissue necrosis and fibrinoid necrosis of small blood vessels. Staining is Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×200 magnification.

Histopathological examination of tissue obtained from neurosurgical resection, which confirmed the diagnosis of radionecrosis of the brain (RNB). Staining is Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×400 magnification.

Histopathological examination of tissue obtained from neurosurgical resection, which confirmed the diagnosis of radionecrosis of the brain (RNB), showing radionecrosis surrounding gliosis and an inflammatory cell reaction. Staining is Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×200 magnification.

Histopathological examination of tissue obtained from neurosurgical resection, which confirmed the diagnosis of radionecrosis of the brain (RNB), showing focal infiltration of inflammatory cells and subpial gliosis. Staining is Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×400 magnification.

Histopathological examination of a resected right frontoparietal brain lesion from a 72-year-old man, who presented with headache and gait disturbance 14 months after radiation therapy for brain metastases, showing an area of infarction. The neurosurgical resection was performed due to an enlarged lesion, with the overall diagnosis revealing radiation necrosis with brain metastasis. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification ×10.

Histopathological examination of a resected right frontoparietal brain lesion from a 72-year-old man, who presented with headache and gait disturbance 14 months after radiation therapy for brain metastases, showing a transitional zone indicating ischemia. The neurosurgical resection was performed due to an enlarged lesion, with the overall diagnosis revealing radiation necrosis with brain metastasis. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification ×20.

Histopathology at low magnification (x10) showing one portion of a lesion. The image displays mild thickening of the epidermis with focal areas of acantholysis involving all layers of the epidermis. Overlying parakeratosis and focal dyskeratosis are also present. The tissue is stained with hematoxylin and eosin.

Histopathology of an excisional biopsy specimen from a 0.7-×0.6-cm erythematous firm nodule on the medial side of the left eyebrow of a 30-year-old woman, who presented with a 5-year history of a slow-growing, painless nodule. The image shows a lobulated tumor located in the dermis, which is not encapsulated. These findings are consistent with myxoid cellular neurothekeoma. (H&E, ×20).

Histopathology of an excisional biopsy specimen from a 0.7-×0.6-cm erythematous firm nodule on the medial side of the left eyebrow of a 30-year-old woman, who presented with a 5-year history of a slow-growing, painless nodule. The image shows tumor cells composed of stellate and spindle-shaped cells loosely interconnected within an abundant myxoid stroma. The amount of myxoid matrix was found to be >50% in the study using alcian blue staining. These findings are consistent with myxoid cellular neurothekeoma. (H&E, ×100).

Histopathology of an excisional biopsy specimen from a 0.7-×0.6-cm erythematous firm nodule on the medial side of the left eyebrow of a 30-year-old woman, who presented with a 5-year history of a slow-growing, painless nodule. The image shows tumor cells composed of stellate and spindle-shaped cells loosely interconnected within an abundant myxoid stroma. The amount of myxoid matrix was found to be >50% in the study using alcian blue staining. These findings are consistent with myxoid cellular neurothekeoma. (H&E, ×200).

Histopathology of an excisional biopsy specimen from a 0.7-×0.6-cm erythematous firm nodule on the medial side of the left eyebrow of a 30-year-old woman, who presented with a 5-year history of a slow-growing, painless nodule. The image shows tumor cells composed of stellate and spindle-shaped cells loosely interconnected within an abundant myxoid stroma. The amount of myxoid matrix was found to be >50% in the study using alcian blue staining. These findings are consistent with myxoid cellular neurothekeoma. (H&E, ×400).
Histopathology of a proliferative nodule showing a proliferative dermal nodule within a giant congenital nevus, viewed at ×40 magnification with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining.
Histopathology showing congenital nevus cells forming nests at the dermo-epidermal junction and in the upper dermis, viewed at ×200 magnification with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining.

Histopathology showing melanocytic cells within the dermal nodule that are more cellular, larger, more heavily pigmented, and predominantly epithelioid. These cells display low-grade cytologic atypia and minimal pleomorphism, viewed at ×400 magnification with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining.
Histopathological examination revealing numerous dilated blood vessels and large sinusoidal spaces surrounded by endothelial cells (hematoxylin and eosin stain 40x).

Histopathological examination of fibrocellular connective tissue shows proliferating fibroblasts and numerous collagen fibers. Numerous dilated blood vessels and sinusoidal spaces surrounded by endothelial cells are also noted. (Hematoxylin and eosin stain, 10x magnification).
Histological aspect showing clear cells with a peripheral palisade arrangement. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) and viewed at 400x magnification.
Histopathology, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE), at 40x magnification, showing a panoramic view that evidences the connection of the lesion to a hair follicle.
Histopathology image showing adjacent epidermis with papillomatosis and sebaceous hyperplasia, viewed at 40x magnification using Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) staining.
Histopathology showing epithelial basaloid projections of the epidermis, involved by fibroblasts. Magnification 400x, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE).

Histopathology stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) showing non-Malassezia folliculitis (NMF). This image depicts a case initially diagnosed as NMF, characterized by follicular infiltration of inflammatory cells, before subsequent examination with serial tissue sections revealed the presence of Malassezia yeast in the hair follicle, which would lead to a re-diagnosis.

Histopathology stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) showing Malassezia folliculitis. Malassezia yeast cells, appearing as abundant eosinophilic round-to-oval structures, are clearly visible within the hair follicle. This finding, obtained through serial tissue sections, resulted in a change of diagnosis from non-Malassezia folliculitis to Malassezia folliculitis.

Histopathology stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) showing Malassezia folliculitis. Malassezia yeast cells, appearing as abundant eosinophilic round-to-oval structures, are clearly visible within the hair follicle. This finding, obtained through serial tissue sections, resulted in a change of diagnosis from non-Malassezia folliculitis to Malassezia folliculitis.

Histopathology of an initial slide, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), showing folliculitis that was initially diagnosed as non-Malassezia folliculitis (NMF). This image represents one of the cases from a study of 100 patients initially diagnosed with folliculitis.

Histopathology, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), showing a serial tissue section of the folliculitis case depicted in panel A. Malassezia microorganisms were not identified in this serial section, despite careful examination. Serial section with H&E stain was performed as part of the re-evaluation process for patients initially diagnosed with folliculitis.

Haematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) staining of a biopsy specimen from the urinary bladder, demonstrating urinary melanosis and not melanoma. The image shows benign urothelial mucosa with brown pigments focally present in the cytoplasm of urothelial cells. These pigments appear as light brown powdery material to dark brown globules, mainly located in the cytoplasm, partially or completely obscuring the nuclei. There is no evidence of any pigment deposit in the underlying lamina propria, which exhibited congestion and acute inflammation. No melanocytes were identified in the H&E stained sections.

Histopathology of metastatic melanoma in the urinary bladder, stained with Haematoxylin and Eosin. This image illustrates the morphology of melanoma within the urinary bladder, representing metastasis in a patient with a known history of malignant melanoma. Histology examination typically reveals spindle and epithelioid heavily pigmented malignant melanocytes, often with a high mitotic rate. Atypical melanocytes may also be present in the urothelium.

Histopathology (hematoxylin-eosin staining, 20×) showing acanthosis and hyperplastic, markedly elevated epidermis with exophytic growth. Atypical tumor cells are noted invading the epidermis, especially in the basal layer, with invasion of the upper dermis by melanophages and lymphocytes. Keratinocytes show no atypia.

Histopathology (hematoxylin-eosin staining, 40×) showing proliferation of atypical tumor cells at the base of a cutaneous horn. The cutaneous horn is composed of excessive compact hyperkeratosis with melanin pigments and pigment-laden degenerated macrophages in sun-damaged skin with solar elastosis. The atypical tumor cells are spindle-to-round epithelioid cells with prominent nucleoli and melanin pigments, confined to the base of the cutaneous horn without lentiginous or pagetoid spreading. An arrow indicates a mitotic tumor cell.

Microscopic examination of the resected specimen, stained with hematoxylin-eosin (loupe view), showing a cutaneous horn with excessive compact hyperkeratosis, melanin pigments, and pigment-laden degenerated macrophages in sun-damaged skin with marked solar elastosis. There is compact growth of tumor cells in the underlying epidermis and upper dermis. The final diagnosis was cutaneous horn malignant melanoma (MM).

Histopathology of a tissue biopsy, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 10x magnification, showing malignant melanoma. The dermis is infiltrated by sheets and nests of epithelioid and spindle tumor cells, which initially raised suspicion for a soft tissue sarcoma. These tumor cells have eosinophilic cytoplasm and large nuclei with prominent nucleoli. The epidermis remains uninvolved. The biopsy contributed to the histopathological diagnosis of malignant melanoma, supported by positive immunohistochemistry for S-100 protein, HMB-45, MART-1 (Melan-A), and MITF, and absence of melanin pigment on Fontana Masson stain (not shown).

Histopathology of a tissue biopsy, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 20x magnification, showing malignant melanoma. This higher power view of the tumor within the subcutis reveals a nested tumor architecture. The neoplastic cells are somewhat discohesive and possess bright eosinophilic cytoplasm. The biopsy ultimately led to a histopathological diagnosis of malignant melanoma, following immunohistochemical confirmation with positive S-100 protein, HMB-45, MART-1 (Melan-A), and MITF.

Histopathology section showing epidermis with marked acanthosis and neutrophilic abscess mixed with debris in the keratin layers. The papillary dermis contains epithelioid cell granulomas with multinucleated giant cells. The granulomas are surrounded by plasma cells and lymphocytes, with a few eosinophils seen amidst the chronic inflammatory cell infiltrate. Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) stain, magnification: ×40.

Histopathology showing epitheliod cell granulomas with Langerhans type giant cells located in the mid dermis. A mixed inflammatory infiltrate is also visible in the papillary dermis (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, ×100 magnification).

Histopathology of the skin showing the reticular dermis with a marked histiocytic and lymphocytic infiltrate, accompanied by few plasma cells. Epithelioid cell granulomas, which include Langerhans type giant cells, are observed. Additionally, a mixed inflammatory infiltrate is present in the papillary dermis. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at 100x magnification.

Histopathological examination of the surgical specimen, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), reveals a tumor located at the dermo-hypodermic level. The tumor exhibits a lobulated architecture and is well-delimited at the periphery. The proliferation consists of dense, pigmented, moderately atypical oval cells. The nuclei possess irregular contours, fine chromatin, and a small nucleolus. Mitotic activity does not exceed two per cross-section, and there are no visible zones of necrosis or superimposed inflammatory phenomena.

High magnification (x200) histopathology, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), showing a melanocytic proliferation within the reticular dermis. The proliferation is composed of fusiform (spindle-shaped) or stellate dendritic cells arranged in fascicles, associated with melanic pigment. These cells exhibit minimal cytonuclear atypia and small nucleoli. Mitotic activity does not exceed two per cross-section, and there are no visible zones of necrosis or superimposed inflammatory phenomena.
Histopathology image showing individual round tumor cells with a mitotic figure (indicated by an arrow) and occasional prominent nucleoli, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).
Histopathology stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×10 magnification, showing undifferentiated tumor cells arranged in sheets without any definite architectural arrangement.

Initial biopsy specimen showing histologic features of pigmented mammary Paget disease, with large neoplastic epithelial cells exhibiting pigmentation and dermal melanophages. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at ×400 magnification.

Excision specimen showing histologic features of pigmented mammary Paget disease, specifically an intraepidermal proliferation of atypical cells characterized by large hyperchromatic nuclei and pale cytoplasm. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at ×400 magnification.

Histopathological image showing prominent lentiginous hyperplasia of melanocytes exclusively in the epidermis, consistent with acral lentiginous melanoma in situ. The tissue section is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at ×200 magnification.

Histopathology of a biopsy specimen from a skin lesion on a 3-day-old female infant, consistent with nevus sebaceus. The image shows hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, numerous sebaceous glands, and malformed hair follicles. There are also proliferative changes of sebaceous glands and apocrine glands within the epidermis. The section is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at 100x magnification.

Histopathology of a representative retinoblastoma (RB) case from the RC (retinoblastoma with fleurettes/rosettes) group, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 100x magnification. The image shows well-differentiated RC cells with typical fleurettes, which are specific structures formed by differentiated cells. These fleurettes are surrounded by moderately differentiated tumor cells. In 65 cases examined, three tumors in the RC group predominantly comprised these fleurette structures surrounded by middle-sized tumor cells.

Histological observation of tumor tissue obtained via bronchoscopic biopsy. The image shows proliferation of epithelioid-shaped atypical cells with marginal melanin production. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin; magnification, ×100.

Histopathological examination of the tumor specimen, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×40 magnification, reveals anaplastic spindle-shaped and epithelioid cells. These cells exhibit prominent nucleoli and contain large amounts of melanin pigmentations. These histopathological findings confirmed the diagnosis of malignant melanoma.

Histopathology showing a subepithelial lesion extending up to the subcutis, composed of sheets and nests of cells arranged in a zellballen pattern, suggestive of paraganglioma. Individual cells display clear to eosinophilic cytoplasm and vesicular nuclei with prominent nucleoli. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, ×40 magnification.

Histopathology showing a subepithelial lesion, extending up to the subcutis, composed of sheets and nests of cells arranged in a zellballen pattern. The cells feature clear to eosinophilic cytoplasm and vesicular nuclei with prominent nucleoli. This pattern is suggestive of paraganglioma. No epidermal involvement, pagetoid spread, atypia, increased mitotic activity, or necrosis were observed, helping to rule out malignant tumors like melanoma. Hematoxylin and eosin stain, ×10 magnification.

Histopathology showing a melanoma nodule with extensive regression, characterized by the presence of melanophages. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) and viewed at ×40 magnification.
Histopathological evaluation of melanoma, showing melanoma cells with notable melanin pigment. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×400 magnification.

Histopathology showing a cluster of melanoma cells in a vascular-like space (indicated by an asterisk). The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×400 magnification, illustrating the initial detection of potential lymphovascular invasion.

Immunohistochemical evaluation of BAP-1 and BRAFV600E status in melanocytic lesions. Histopathology shows a melanocytic nevus composed of sheets of epithelioid-shaped melanocytes located in the dermis, visualized with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) stain at ×400 magnification.

Histopathology of chronic sun-damaged skin, demonstrating accurate enumeration of melanocytes in the epidermis. The image shows an atrophic epidermis and solar elastosis (*), with a background increase in melanocytes along the dermal–epidermal junction (DEJ) (arrows). The section is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×100 magnification.

A panoramic photomicrograph, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at an original magnification of 15x, showing marked symmetry and circumscription. The image displays prominent skin alterations including orthokeratosis, hypergranulosis, and acanthosis. Nests of melanocytes are visible, oriented perpendicularly to the epidermis. An artifactual cleft is present between the nests of melanocytes and the surrounding keratinocytes, along with pigmentary incontinence.

Histopathology image showing atypical melanocytes exhibiting a lack of maturation. The melanocytes display pleomorphism (variation in size and shape), anisokaryosis (variation in nuclear size), karyomegaly (enlarged nuclei), and prominent eosinophilic nucleoli. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at an original magnification of 400x.

Histopathology showing asymmetry and imperfect circumscription, along with orthokeratosis, hypergranulosis, and acanthosis. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at an original magnification of 40x.

Histopathology displaying atypical melanocytes exhibiting pleomorphism, hyperchromasia, and a mitotic figure (arrow) situated at the base of an intraepidermal nest. The image, at 400x magnification and stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE), illustrates cellular features associated with lesions where a lymphocytic inflammatory infiltrate is frequently observed in the superficial dermis. This infiltrate is typically mild or moderate and can be distributed in the central part of the lesion's base, in the periphery of the lesion, or diffusely.

Histopathology showing an area of pagetoid spread, characterized by an irregular distribution of pigmentation and irregular maturation of melanocytes. In the study, pagetoid spread was present in 68% of cases with an intraepidermal component, predominantly appearing as isolated cells rather than nests of melanocytes, and was frequently located at the center of the lesion. (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, original magnification 100x)

Histopathology demonstrating spindle melanocytes forming nests within the epithelium of the skin appendages, positioned deeper than the intradermal component. This image exemplifies a melanocytic proliferation extending to the epithelium of the skin appendages, a finding observed in 20 lesions. In similar lesions discussed in the paper, mitoses were noted in basal layer melanocytes in 11 cases (34%), and in one case, mitosis was present in dermal melanocytes of the superior part of the lesion, with a single atypical mitosis identified in one lesion. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at 100x original magnification.

Histopathologic examination demonstrating atypical melanocytes as single cells and clusters within the basaloid nodule and along the dermal-epidermal junction. The image is stained with hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×400.
Histopathologic examination revealed a nodular basaloid tumor island budding from the epidermis, stromal retraction, and small cystic spaces filled with mucin and pigment (hematoxylin-eosin, ×40).
Histopathology showing round to polygonal tumor cells arranged in diffuse sheets and papillae. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at ×200 magnification.

Histopathology of a biopsy from a hypopigmented patch on the face, showing a complete absence of melanin and melanocytes in the epidermis. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×100 magnification.

Histopathology of a biopsy from an ulcerative tumor on the fingertip, showing sheet-like arrangements of pleomorphic atypical tumor cells. The tissue is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). Original magnification ×100.

Histopathology of a biopsy from an ulcerative tumor on the fingertip, showing sheet-like arrangements of pleomorphic atypical tumor cells. The tissue is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). Original magnification ×400.

Histopathology (hematoxylin and eosin stain, ×10 magnification) of the nodular melanoma resected from the umbilicus of a 33-year-old female patient. The image shows poorly differentiated tumor cells that appear primitive, disorganized, and immature. This finding is consistent with the diagnosis of nodular melanoma, which upon further histological investigation, presented with a Breslow thickness of 40 mm, ulceration, and a mitotic rate of 6/mm^2.

High-magnification histopathology (hematoxylin and eosin stain, ×60 magnification) of the nodular melanoma resected from the umbilicus of a 33-year-old female patient. The image reveals detailed cytological features of the tumor, including diffused anisocytosis (variation in cell size), anisonucleosis (variation in nuclear size), an altered nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio, and evident nucleoli, all characteristic of the poorly differentiated melanoma cells. The tumor was diagnosed with a Breslow thickness of 40 mm, ulceration, and a mitotic rate of 6/mm^2.

Histopathology of the amelanotic melanoma tumor (hematoxylin-eosin stain, original magnification ×100). The image shows nests of intermediate-grade tumor cells with intervening stroma. The tumor cells display clear to eosinophilic cytoplasm, and no obvious pigment is observed, consistent with amelanotic melanoma.

Higher magnification histopathology of the amelanotic melanoma tumor (hematoxylin-eosin stain, original magnification ×400). This view highlights prominent nuclear mitosis and atypia within the intermediate-grade tumor cells, further supporting the diagnosis of amelanotic melanoma.

Histopathology of an original biopsy from an eyelid shows classic lentigo maligna, also known as melanoma in situ, stained with Hematoxylin and eosin (10X magnification). Key features include an increased number of melanocytes forming nests at the dermoepidermal junction, as well as presenting as single cells with mildly enlarged, hyperchromatic nuclei.

Histology of a biopsy taken from a pigmented patch on the inner surface of the prepuce of case 1 shows a compound nevus with no sign of malignancy. Histopathological findings reveal groups of melanocytic nevus cells located at the dermal-epidermal junction and in the upper dermis (papillary dermis), typical of a compound nevus. Mitoses and atypia were absent from the nevus cells. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin, at an original magnification of ×20.

Histopathologic examination of a pigmented macule on the glans reveals uniform nests of normal melanocytes located in the papillary layer of the dermis. The epidermis appeared normal, junctional activity was absent, and there was no upward migration of melanocytes into the epidermis. Mitoses and atypia were absent from the nevus cells. The final pathology was determined to be an intradermal nevus. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin, at an original magnification of ×20.

Photomicrograph showing a normal epidermis with increased melanization of the basal layer. The upper dermis contains aggregates of mature adipocytes. Normal vascularity is observed, and there is a lack of inflammatory infiltrate. Appendageal structures were not appreciated in the histological examination. Based on these histological features, alongside clinical presentation (huge dome-shaped tumorous masses over scapulae and lower back, soft to firm consistency, studded with smaller papules, fine wrinkling and peau d'orange appearance), a diagnosis of Nevus lipomatosus superficialis (NLCS) was made. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 40× magnification.

Histopathology showing diffuse hypercellular sheets and nests of basophilic medium to large tumor cells interspersed with patchy areas of geographic tumor necrosis, with tumor cells palisading around necrotic foci (hematoxylin-eosin, 40x magnification).

Histopathology showing basophilic medium to large tumor cells with a high nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio, exhibiting a moderate degree of nuclear pleomorphism, irregular nuclear contours, abundant intranuclear and cytoplasmic pseudoinclusions, vesicular chromatin, and occasional prominent nucleoli. Brisk mitotic activity with atypical mitotic figures and tumor cannibalism (tumor cells engulfing other tumor cells) are also noted (hematoxylin-eosin, 400x magnification).
Histopathology of the skin lesion, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×10 magnification. The image shows Breslow's thickness clearly exceeding 4 mm, and no ulceration is present.

Histopathology image, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×20 magnification, showing abundant irregular nests of varying size and shape. There is asymmetrical proliferation of enlarged atypical epithelioid and spindle-shaped melanocytes present in the deep dermis.

Histopathology image, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×40 magnification, showing atypical epithelioid and spindle-shaped melanocytes. These melanocytes exhibit large, hyperchromatic, and pleomorphic nuclei.
Histopathology showing subsequent wide excision with satellite/in transit metastasis of plasmacytoid melanoma. Stained with Hematoxylin & Eosin (H&E) at 20× magnification.
Histopathology showing subsequent wide excision with satellite/in transit metastasis of plasmacytoid melanoma. Stained with Hematoxylin & Eosin (H&E) at 40× magnification.
Histopathology showing subsequent wide excision with satellite/in transit metastasis of plasmacytoid melanoma. Stained with Hematoxylin & Eosin (H&E) at 100× magnification.
Histopathology showing subsequent wide excision with satellite/in transit metastasis of plasmacytoid melanoma. Stained with Hematoxylin & Eosin (H&E) at 200× magnification.

Histopathology of the initial excision from a 78-year-old man's enlarging erythematous mass on his left posterior shoulder, showing a large nodule within the dermis. The nodule is composed of sheets and nests of amelanotic plasmacytoid cells, exhibiting abundant cytoplasm, eccentric nuclei, and pale paranuclear zones, consistent with melanoma (confirmed by immunohistochemical analysis). Stained with Hematoxylin & Eosin (H&E) at 20× magnification.

Histopathology of the initial excision from a 78-year-old man's enlarging erythematous mass on his left posterior shoulder, showing a large nodule within the dermis. The nodule is composed of sheets and nests of amelanotic plasmacytoid cells, exhibiting abundant cytoplasm, eccentric nuclei, and pale paranuclear zones, consistent with melanoma (confirmed by immunohistochemical analysis). This panel also shows areas with pseudopapillary architecture lined by malignant cells. Stained with Hematoxylin & Eosin (H&E) at 200× magnification.

Histopathology of the initial excision from a 78-year-old man's enlarging erythematous mass on his left posterior shoulder, showing a large nodule within the dermis, consistent with melanoma (confirmed by immunohistochemical analysis). This panel highlights pseudopapillary architecture within the nodule, lined by malignant amelanotic plasmacytoid cells. The cells exhibit abundant cytoplasm, eccentric nuclei, and pale paranuclear zones. Stained with Hematoxylin & Eosin (H&E) at 100× magnification.

Histopathology of the initial excision from a 78-year-old man's enlarging erythematous mass on his left posterior shoulder, showing a large nodule within the dermis, consistent with melanoma (confirmed by immunohistochemical analysis). This panel highlights pseudopapillary architecture within the nodule, lined by malignant amelanotic plasmacytoid cells. The cells exhibit abundant cytoplasm, eccentric nuclei, and pale paranuclear zones. Stained with Hematoxylin & Eosin (H&E) at 100× magnification.

Histopathology of the initial excision from a 78-year-old man's enlarging erythematous mass on his left posterior shoulder, showing a large nodule within the dermis, consistent with melanoma (confirmed by immunohistochemical analysis). This panel highlights pseudopapillary architecture within the nodule, lined by malignant amelanotic plasmacytoid cells. The cells exhibit abundant cytoplasm, eccentric nuclei, and pale paranuclear zones. Stained with Hematoxylin & Eosin (H&E) at 100× magnification.

Histopathology of a lesional biopsy, consistent with bilateral, systematized epidermolytic verrucous epidermal nevus, showing massive hyperkeratosis and focal granular degeneration of the epidermis. Focal epidermolytic hyperkeratosis is evident in the form of perinuclear vacuolization of keratinocytes of the upper epidermis with coarse keratohyaline granules. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, ×100 magnification.

Histopathological section showing acantholysis and dyskeratosis, characterized by the presence of round bodies in the granular layer and grains in the corneal layer. These findings are compatible with segmental DD. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) and viewed at 200x magnification.

Fine spherical brown particles are observed cloaked in between the collagen fibers in the lamina propria. The image is a histopathological section stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) and viewed at 400x magnification.

Microscopic image of hard palate mucosa, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (HE) at ×40 magnification, showing a minor salivary gland within the lamina propria. The lamina propria contains minimal brown spherical bodies, representing pigment, located in between the collagen fibers. Microscopic examination revealed no signs of cellular atypia, melanocytic hyperplasia, hemorrhagic circumstances, or inflammation within the tissue.
Hematoxylin and eosin stained section at 10x magnification showing pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia seen in a non-specific chronic inflammatory lesion.
Hematoxylin and eosin stained section of a small oral biopsy specimen, showing tongue-like epithelial proliferations. Magnification is ×10.
Histopathology micrograph showing an excessive amount of normal apocrine glands. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×20 magnification.

Low-power photomicrograph of primary penile desmoplastic melanoma, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). The image depicts the penile glans, showing haphazardly arranged and disarrayed spindle tumor cells permeating in between abundant collagen bundles, which comprise over 90% of the entire neoplasm. These cells deeply infiltrate the dermis and corpus spongiosum, exhibiting conspicuous neurotropism. In intimate association with the spindle tumor cells, focal atypical intraepidermal melanocytic proliferation and pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia are observed in the overlying epidermis. Histologically, moderate nuclear pleomorphism and rare atypical mitoses are also characteristic features of this tumor.

Histopathology (10× hematoxylin & eosin [H&E] stain) revealing a very bland compound melanocytic neoplasm with clear-cut congenital-like features. The lesion was excised due to its large size and atypical dermoscopic presentation. The final histopathological diagnosis was acral compound melanocytic nevus with congenital features.

Histopathology (40× hematoxylin & eosin [H&E] stain) showing the central area of the lesion, which is mainly an intradermal combination of type C and dendritic (blue nevus-like) melanocytes. The final histopathological diagnosis was acral compound melanocytic nevus with congenital features.

Histopathology (40× hematoxylin & eosin [H&E] stain) illustrating a striking acrosyringial and periductal distribution of the melanocytic neoplasm. The final histopathological diagnosis was acral compound melanocytic nevus with congenital features.

Histopathology (20× hematoxylin & eosin [H&E] stain) demonstrating a junctional component that is mainly peripheral, with regularly arranged melanocytic nests at the dermo-epidermal junction without cytologic atypia. Additionally, areas with melanin columns from melanocytes located in the crista profunda intermedia are visible, a histologic finding also seen under the surface ridge in accordance with the dermoscopic appearance of the lesion. The final histopathological diagnosis was acral compound melanocytic nevus with congenital features.

Histopathology (40× hematoxylin & eosin [H&E] stain) depicting columnar melanin depositions (melanin columns) arrayed under the surface furrow. This histologic finding, also observed in the crista profunda intermedia under the surface ridge, is in accordance with the dermoscopic appearance of the lesion. The final histopathological diagnosis was acral compound melanocytic nevus with congenital features.
Photomicrograph stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×100 magnification.
Photomicrograph of the lesion, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×100 magnification. Specific microscopic features or a diagnosis are not provided in the accompanying text.
Photomicrograph showing the histopathology of the lesion, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 100x magnification.

Histopathology of lesions showing psoriasiform hyperplasia of the epidermis with acanthosis, varying amounts of spongiosis, and parakeratotic hyperkeratosis with underlying hypogranulosis alternating with orthokeratotic hyperkeratosis with normal or hypergranulosis. The papillary dermis contains a variable upper dermal perivascular lymphocytic inflammatory infiltrate. These histopathologic findings were consistently observed in all cases, reflecting the typical presentation in children without other mucocutaneous or systemic abnormalities and normal routine lab panels. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification ×100.

Histopathological examination showing a proliferative growth centered in the upper dermis with marked thinning of the epidermis. These features were observed during histopathological examination (HPE) that led to the diagnosis of malignant melanoma. (Hematoxylin and eosin stain, ×40 magnification).

Histopathological examination (HPE) showing a mass composed of clustered polygonal tumor cells. The cells exhibit hyperchromatic nuclei, perinuclear halos, prominent nucleoli, inclusion bodies, and conspicuous mitotic activity. Melanin pigment was frequently seen, and separate cell nests and tumor emboli were identified. These features are suggestive of malignant melanoma. (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, ×400 magnification)
Histopathology showing the pagetoid appearance characteristic of superficial spreading melanoma. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at ×10 magnification.
Histopathology showing atypical melanocytes containing prominent pigment. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at ×40 magnification.
Skin biopsy specimen showing infiltration of the dermis by inflammatory cells along with scattered signet ring-shaped tumor cells. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification ×20.

Skin biopsy specimen showing signet ring-shaped tumor cells (SRCs) within the dermis. Immunohistochemical analysis revealed that these SRCs presented positivity for cytokeratin. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification ×20.

Skin biopsy specimen showing signet ring-shaped tumor cells (SRCs) within the dermis. Immunohistochemical analysis revealed that these SRCs presented positivity for EMA. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification ×10.

Histopathological examination of a primary cervical spinal melanocytoma, identified as an intradural extramedullary mass. The image shows a diffusely pigmented tumor with a peritheliomatous arrangement, where the dense pigmentation obscures the cytological details. The lesion was firm, smooth-surfaced, and blackish in color during excision. (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, 40x magnification).

Histopathological examination of the primary cervical spinal melanocytoma (an intradural extramedullary mass) after bleaching to remove the dense pigment. The tumor cells now reveal pleomorphic round to oval nuclei with inconspicuous nucleoli and a moderate amount of cytoplasm. (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, 40x magnification).

Higher magnification histopathological examination of the primary cervical spinal melanocytoma (an intradural extramedullary mass). The tumor cells exhibit mild nuclear pleomorphism and moderate to abundant cytoplasm, with a few cells still containing blackish-brown pigment. No significant increase in mitosis was observed (<1 mitosis per 10 high power fields), and the proliferation index Ki-67 was low (<1%), which is diagnostic for melanocytomas. (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, 200x magnification).
Histological examination showing numerous nests of cells present in the entire dermis. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×40 magnification.
Histological examination showing proliferation of nevus cells and melanocytes visible on the tip of the rete ridges. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×40 magnification.

Histological examination showing cell nests in the superficial dermis. These cell nests are composed of epithelioid nevocytes, which have a large cell size, abundant cytoplasm, clefts around cells, and prominent nucleoli. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×200 magnification.

Histological examination showing cell nests in the deep dermis. These cell nests are composed of epithelioid nevocytes, which have a large cell size, abundant cytoplasm, clefts around cells, and prominent nucleoli. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×200 magnification.

Microscopic histopathology of anorectal melanoma (H&E staining, ×400 magnification) showing tumor containing highly anaplastic, discohesive cells without a specific growth pattern. Individual cells possess abundant acidophilic, finely granular, dense cytoplasm, and prominent macronucleoli are identified. Occasionally, multinucleated giant cells and cytoplasmic melanin pigments are also present.

Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) of an enlarged left inguinal lymph node, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×100 magnification. The smear shows highly cellular pleomorphic cells arranged in small clusters, groups, and individually scattered, admixed with lymphocytes. The inset further highlights individual cells, which are large and pleomorphic, possessing a centrally placed, hyperchromatic nucleus with abundant cytoplasm. Some cells exhibit an eccentrically placed nucleus and prominent nucleoli, and a few binucleated cells are also visible. These features are suggestive of secondary deposits in the lymph node, consistent with the patient's provisional diagnosis of amelanotic malignant melanoma.

Histopathology of the skin (H&E, ×100 magnification) showing the dermis with lobules of cuboidal cells. These cells exhibit hyperchromatic nuclei with mild to moderate pleomorphism and mitotic activity.

Histopathology showing slight hyperkeratosis, follicular plugging, acanthosis, and prominent papillomatosis. There is no neoplastic infiltration observed in the papillary dermis. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at ×100 magnification.

Histopathology, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (HE) at ×40 magnification, showing very prominent hyperkeratosis, verruciform acanthosis, and papillomatosis. There is no infiltration observed in the papillary dermis.

Histopathology, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (HE) at ×100 magnification, showing very prominent hyperkeratosis, verruciform acanthosis, and papillomatosis. There is no infiltration observed in the papillary dermis.

Photomicrograph showing multiple (at least nine) distinct nests of glandular epithelial structures within the capsular tissue of a postneoadjuvant, ipsilateral, and axillary sentinel lymph node. Some of these epithelial nests abutted the subcapsular sinus. These nodal capsular glandular cell groups were discontinuous and encircled approximately one-half of the circumference of the 3.5 mm lymph node. The histologic differential diagnosis for these glandular structures within the lymph node included metastatic disease versus benign/reactive heterotopic epithelium (Hematoxylin and Eosin [H&E] stain, original magnification 400x).

Histopathology of a lentigo maligna melanoma (LMM) from the face of a 64-year-old woman, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×20 magnification. LMM is often mistaken for other sun-damaged skin lesions like junctional dysplastic nevi, pigmented actinic keratosis, solar lentigo, or seborrheic keratosis, necessitating histological diagnosis. The gold standard for LM/LMM diagnosis involves skin biopsy to visualize dermatopathologic features such as a pagetoid appearance of melanocytes, melanocyte atypia, and non-uniform pigmentation and distribution of melanocytes, all occurring on a background of extensive photodamage.

Histopathology of a lentigo maligna melanoma (LMM) from the face of a 64-year-old woman, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×40 magnification. LMM is often mistaken for other sun-damaged skin lesions like junctional dysplastic nevi, pigmented actinic keratosis, solar lentigo, or seborrheic keratosis, necessitating histological diagnosis. The gold standard for LM/LMM diagnosis involves skin biopsy to visualize dermatopathologic features such as a pagetoid appearance of melanocytes, melanocyte atypia, and non-uniform pigmentation and distribution of melanocytes, all occurring on a background of extensive photodamage.

Histopathology of the excised pigmented lesion from the cheek of a middle-aged woman, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed on low-power (×10). This section reveals atypical intraepidermal melanocytic proliferation overlying dermal elastosis, consistent with a diagnosis of melanoma in situ on sun-damaged skin. The gold standard for LM/LMM diagnosis is skin biopsy, allowing visualization of dermatopathologic features like melanocyte atypia and non-uniform distribution on a background of extensive photodamage.

Histopathology of the excised pigmented lesion from the cheek of a middle-aged woman, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed on higher-power (×20). This magnification provides a clearer view of the atypical intraepidermal melanocytic proliferation, which was found to extend to all surgical margins, leading to a diagnosis of melanoma in situ on sun-damaged skin. Key dermatopathologic features consistent with this diagnosis include melanocyte atypia and their non-uniform distribution within the epidermis, often seen with extensive photodamage.

Histopathology of the excised pigmented lesion from the cheek of a middle-aged woman, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed on high-power (×40). This detailed view highlights the atypical intraepidermal melanocytic proliferation and the associated dermal elastosis, confirming the diagnosis of melanoma in situ on sun-damaged skin. The presence of a pagetoid appearance of melanocytes, melanocyte atypia, and non-uniform pigmentation and distribution of melanocytes on a background of extensive photodamage are characteristic dermatopathologic features for melanoma in situ.

Histopathological examination of the excisional biopsy from a 76-year-old man's lower anterior alveolar gingiva, showing invasive tumor cells characteristic of nodular-type oral mucosal melanoma with heavy melanin pigmentation. This image highlights the typical characteristics of an oral mucosal melanoma (OMM). (Hematoxylin & eosin stain, ×200 magnification).

Histopathological examination from a 76-year-old man with nodular-type malignant melanoma (MM) of the lower anterior alveolar gingiva. The image shows the intact bottom surgical margin, indicating that the lesion does not extend to this border. Reactive bone trabeculae are observed in this section (hematoxylin and eosin, ×20 magnification).
Histopathologic examination at ×40 magnification, stained with hematoxylin and eosin, revealing a non-encapsulated tumor.
Histopathology at ×100 magnification, stained with hematoxylin and eosin, showing the tumor composed of nests and bundles of epithelioid to spindle cells with a sparse myxoid matrix.
Histopathology at ×100 magnification, stained with hematoxylin and eosin, showing the tumor cells arranged in fascicles or nodules, often in a geographic pattern, separated by a collagen-rich stroma.

Histopathology at ×200 magnification, stained with hematoxylin and eosin, demonstrating mild to moderate pleomorphism of epithelioid cells with indistinct borders, including the presence of a giant cell and a mitotic figure.

Histopathologic findings showing that the tumor consists of uniformly small cuboidal cells, forming anastomosing bands and ductal lumen emanating from the epidermis embedded in a fibrovascular stroma. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at an original magnification of ×100.

Histopathologic findings showing that the tumor consists of uniformly small cuboidal cells, forming anastomosing bands and ductal lumen emanating from the epidermis embedded in a fibrovascular stroma. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at an original magnification of ×400.

Histopathology of a skin biopsy specimen obtained from a yellowish verrucous plaque, demonstrating mild epidermal papillomatosis associated with increased sebaceous gland and abortive hair follicles. These findings are consistent with nevus sebaceous, identified through routine histological examination of a 4-millimeter punch biopsy. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) and viewed at an original magnification of ×100.

Histopathological picture of apocrine hidrocystoma showing one or several cystic spaces typically lined by two layers of cells: an inner columnar epithelium that displays typical eosinophilic apical cytoplasm and the characteristic decapitation secretion, surrounded by outer myoepithelial cells. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×40 magnification.

Histopathological picture of a phakomatous choristoma, also known as Zimmerman's tumor, a rare and unique congenital lesion of lenticular anlage typically found in the eyelid. The image shows cataractous lens tissue surrounded by epithelium, which appears as epithelial-like cells, further embedded in fibrous tissue. These lesions histologically present findings similar to congenital cataract, including epithelial-like cells surrounded by a thick basement membrane. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at ×40 magnification.

Histopathology showing a solid, circumscribed type of basal cell carcinoma (BCC), which typically correlates with the clinical nodular type. The tumor is composed of nodules (or lobules) of epithelial tumor cells, characterized by oval nuclei and scanty cytoplasm, with prominent peripheral palisading of the nuclei. This image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×10 magnification.

Histopathologic image of a capillary hemangioma, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×4 magnification. The image displays characteristic lobules of capillaries, which are separated by fibrous tissue (also referred to as sparse fibrous septae). Capillary hemangiomas are benign lesions, and while the morphology can change with age, typical features include plump endothelial cells in early stages or attenuated endothelial cells with increased capillary lumina in later stages, potentially with thickened fibrous septae or replacement by adipose tissue. Mitotic figures may be observed within these lesions.

Histopathology picture of a papillomatous lesion, consisting of papillomatous structures of benign squamous epithelium showing epithelial acanthosis, hyperkeratosis (which can be of variable levels), and sometimes focal parakeratosis. The lesion overlies a central fibrovascular core and may show some chronic inflammation. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×4 magnification.

Histopathological image of a chalazion, showing a lipogranulomatous reaction to liberated lipid material from the sebaceous gland. The image highlights the formation of granulomas, each centered by clear spaces representing lipid globules. These granulomas are composed of epithelioid cells and multinucleated giant cells, intermixed with acute and chronic inflammatory cells. (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, ×25 magnification)

Histopathological picture of eccrine hidrocystoma. The lesion contains one cystic space lined by two layers of small cuboidal epithelial cells, with occasionally one layer lining the cyst. No myoepithelial cells are present. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification ×10.

Histopathological picture of molluscum contagiosum, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×40 magnification. The image displays the epidermis with invasive acanthosis forming pear-shaped lobules. The epithelial cells at the surface degenerate and fill the central cavity of the lesion. Characteristic globules of cells are visible, filled with intracytoplasmic eosinophilic "molluscum bodies." These molluscum bodies are intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies, appearing as round-to-oval eosinophilic structures, typically a single structure in each cell, which become darker toward the surface epithelium.

Histopathology showing hyperkeratosis, dilated infundibula with follicular plugging, increased basal epidermal membrane, and a mild perivascular and periadenexal chronic inflammatory infiltrate. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Phloxine-Eosin (H&PE) at ×4 magnification.

Histopathology showing hyperkeratosis, dilated infundibula with follicular plugging, increased basal epidermal membrane, and a mild perivascular and periadenexal chronic inflammatory infiltrate. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Phloxine-Eosin (H&PE) at ×4 magnification.

Histopathology of a biopsy from Lichenoid Keratosis (LK) demonstrating a dense band-like lymphocytic infiltrate. The image also shows lamellar and basket-weave follicular plugging, which is in contrast to the compact follicular plugging more commonly observed in lupus. Prominent solar elastosis, a feature also more common in LK, is evident beneath the infiltrate. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×20 magnification.

Histopathology of a biopsy from a case of Lichenoid Keratosis (LK), demonstrating prominent Civatte bodies. The presence of these high Civatte bodies is a significant characteristic more commonly observed in LK and serves as a helpful feature for distinguishing it from Lupus Erythematosus (LE). Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×40 magnification.

Histopathology of a biopsy from a patient with Lupus Erythematosus (LE), demonstrating characteristic features. The image shows prominent compact follicular plugging and cell-poor vacuolar interface changes in the adjacent epidermis. Follicular plugging, specifically compact follicular plugging as seen here, is highlighted as a key feature in distinguishing LE from Lichen Keratosis (LK) when lesions occur on the face. Cell-poor vacuolar interface dermatitis, also observed, is a feature more commonly associated with LE. Other shared histopathological features between LE and LK that may be present include follicular inflammation, epidermal atrophy, paucity of eosinophils, and pigment incontinence. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification ×40.

Histopathology showing a case of Lupus Erythematosus (LE) which may be confused with Lichenoid Keratosis (LK) due to the presence of perifollicular inflammation and Civatte bodies. The image demonstrates compact follicular plugging, a key feature that helps differentiate LE from LK. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification ×20.

Histopathology showing a case of Lupus Erythematosus (LE) with histologic features overlapping with Lichen Kerasosis (LK). The image displays a focal area of band-like lymphocytic infiltrate, which overlaps with features seen in LK. Additionally, the edge of the biopsy shows a cell-poor vacuolar interface, a feature more typical of LE. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at ×4 magnification.

Histopathology of a central part of a pigmented lesion, showing cystic degeneration and small foci of hemorrhage. This lesion was excised from a patient with a history of melanoma operation and presented with slow growth, revealing an expansive pattern of extension into the dermis and subcutaneous adipose tissue. The morphology was considered consistent with cellular blue nevus (CBN) but with suspicious features. The section was stained with hematoxylin-eosin.

Histopathology demonstrating multinucleated cells, which are a common finding in cellular blue nevus (CBN). This image is from a pigmented lesion that was excised due to slow growth and a patient's history of melanoma operation. Histological analysis revealed an expansive pattern of extension into the dermis and subcutaneous adipose tissue, with morphology consistent with CBN but also showing suspicious features. The section was stained with hematoxylin-eosin.

Histological image showing a pigmented lesion consistent with cellular blue nevus, characterized by an expansive pattern of extension into the dermis and subcutaneous adipose tissue. The image is a haematoxylin-eosin stained paraffin section. The morphology was considered consistent with cellular blue nevus but also suspicious given the patient's history of nodular melanoma.

Histological image showing a pigmented lesion consistent with cellular blue nevus, specifically highlighting the spared papillary dermis, with no junctional or dermal banal nevus component present. The image is a haematoxylin-eosin stained paraffin section. The morphology was considered consistent with cellular blue nevus but also suspicious given the patient's history of nodular melanoma.

Histological image showing cellular islands of closely aggregated large spindle-shaped cells with ovoid nuclei, surrounded by abundant melanin. A closer inspection reveals features such as mild nuclear enlargement, an increased nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio, a mild pleomorphism, and prominent nucleoli, without any evident mitotic figures. The image is a haematoxylin-eosin stained paraffin section of a pigmented lesion consistent with cellular blue nevus, which was considered suspicious given the patient's history of nodular melanoma.

Histological image showing the deepest boundary of the tumor, which presents as a blunt “pushing-type” border with mild fibrosis and a sharp demarcation line between the tumor and the dermis or subcutaneous tissue. The image is a haematoxylin-eosin stained paraffin section of a pigmented lesion consistent with cellular blue nevus, which was considered suspicious given the patient's history of nodular melanoma.

Histological image showing a focus where the tumor exhibits more irregular infiltrative borders, contrasting with the predominantly pushing border. The image is a haematoxylin-eosin stained paraffin section of a pigmented lesion consistent with cellular blue nevus, which was considered suspicious given the patient's history of nodular melanoma.

Histological image demonstrating the presence of perineural invasion within the tumor. The image is a haematoxylin-eosin stained paraffin section of a pigmented lesion consistent with cellular blue nevus, which was considered suspicious given the patient's history of nodular melanoma.

Histological study showing malignant melanoma, characterized by a mutation of exon 15 in the BRAF gene, with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain at 40x magnification. The patient was diagnosed with primary cerebral melanoma.

Histopathology of a lesion from the left helix of a 53-year-old female, initially submitted as “indeterminate” with a pre-test differential diagnosis of “dysplastic nevus versus atypical junctional melanocytic proliferation.” The Molecular Diagnostic Score (MDS) was +1.4 (likely malignant), leading to a final diagnosis of malignant melanoma. This case exemplifies a dysplastic nevus that was subsequently diagnosed as malignant melanoma after receiving a malignant test result, changing the treatment recommendation from “no further treatment necessary if lesion is completely excised” to “wide local excision.” The image is stained with Hematoxylin and eosin at original magnification ×20.

Histopathology of a lesion from the left helix of a 53-year-old female, initially submitted as “indeterminate” with a pre-test differential diagnosis of “dysplastic nevus versus atypical junctional melanocytic proliferation.” The Molecular Diagnostic Score (MDS) was +1.4 (likely malignant), leading to a final diagnosis of malignant melanoma. This case exemplifies a dysplastic nevus that was subsequently diagnosed as malignant melanoma after receiving a malignant test result, changing the treatment recommendation from “no further treatment necessary if lesion is completely excised” to “wide local excision.” The image is stained with Hematoxylin and eosin at original magnification ×100.

This case exemplifies a dysplastic nevus that was subsequently diagnosed as malignant melanoma after receiving a malignant test result, changing the treatment recommendation from “no further treatment necessary if lesion is completely excised” to “wide local excision.” The image is stained with Hematoxylin and eosin at original magnification ×200.

This case exemplifies a dysplastic nevus that was subsequently diagnosed as malignant melanoma after receiving a malignant test result, changing the treatment recommendation from “no further treatment necessary if lesion is completely excised” to “wide local excision.” The image is stained with Hematoxylin and eosin at original magnification ×400.

Histopathology of a lesion from the buttock of a 27-year-old female, initially submitted as “indeterminate” with a pre-test differential diagnosis of “atypical Spitz tumor versus Spitz nevus versus Spitzoid melanoma.” This case represents an atypical Spitz tumor that received a benign test result (MDS –5.4) and was assigned a final diagnosis of benign nevus. The pre-test treatment recommendation was “excision with a margin of normal skin,” which changed to “no further treatment necessary if lesion is completely excised” post-test. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin; original magnification ×20.

Histopathology of a lesion from the buttock of a 27-year-old female, initially submitted as “indeterminate” with a pre-test differential diagnosis of “atypical Spitz tumor versus Spitz nevus versus Spitzoid melanoma.” This case represents an atypical Spitz tumor that received a benign test result (MDS –5.4) and was assigned a final diagnosis of benign nevus. The pre-test treatment recommendation was “excision with a margin of normal skin,” which changed to “no further treatment necessary if lesion is completely excised” post-test. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin; original magnification ×100.
