The pre-test treatment recommendation was “excision with a margin of normal skin,” which changed to “no further treatment necessary if lesion is completely excised” post-test. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin; original magnification ×200.

Histopathology of a lesion from the buttock of a 27-year-old female, initially submitted as “indeterminate” with a pre-test differential diagnosis of “atypical Spitz tumor versus Spitz nevus versus Spitzoid melanoma.” This case represents an atypical Spitz tumor that received a benign test result (MDS –5.4) and was assigned a final diagnosis of benign nevus. The pre-test treatment recommendation was “excision with a margin of normal skin,” which changed to “no further treatment necessary if lesion is completely excised” post-test. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin; original magnification ×400.

Histopathology showing a tissue margin that appears clear (negative) on Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) stain at 20x magnification. Subtle atypical melanocytes extending to the margin were not identifiable in this H&E view.

Histopathology showing a clear margin, specifically the true lateral border of the lesion, identified as the last junctional melanocytic nest or the last atypical melanocyte (indicated by an arrow). The true lateral margin, defined as the edge of the specimen where the dermoepidermal junction is present, is indicated by an arrowhead. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at 20x magnification.

Histopathology of a melanocytic lesion (DN) stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 20x magnification. The image shows that the lesion appears not to extend to the hair follicle at the deep margin. This particular extension of atypical melanocytes to the hair follicle is not identifiable by H&E stain, as confirmed by complementary Melan-A staining.

Histopathologic image (hematoxylin-eosin, 100x magnification) showing a nodular to diffuse proliferation. This histological picture is consistent with Primary Cutaneous Diffuse Large B-cell Lymphoma, Not Otherwise Specified (PCDLBCL-NOS). In PCDLBCL-NOS, cases are almost entirely composed of large centroblastic cells, sometimes with a mixed inflammatory background, and a predominantly diffuse pattern, although limited gross nodular areas can also be observed. These tumors lack the typical features of PCDLBCL-Leg Type and Primary Cutaneous Follicle Center Lymphoma.

Histopathologic image (hematoxylin-eosin, 400x magnification) showing a mixed inflammatory infiltrate alongside predominantly large, centroblastic cells. This image is characteristic of a Primary Cutaneous Diffuse Large B-cell Lymphoma, Not Otherwise Specified (PCDLBCL-NOS). Specifically, this panel corresponds to a PCDLBCL-NOS germinal center B-cell type. PCDLBCL-NOS tumors are characterized by large centroblastic cells, often intermingled with a variable reactive cellular background, which can include small reactive CD3+ lymphocytes.
Histopathology image showing fusiform and oval-shaped melanocytic cells, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 400x magnification.

Histopathology showing brownish pigmented fusiform and oval-shaped melanocytic cells in the upper and deeper dermis. The cells are not forming nests but are arranged in bundles. H&E stain, 100x magnification.
Histopathology showing a blue nevus. The tissue section is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at 40x magnification.

Histopathology of a vulva tumor section showing tumor cells appearing as solid nests of cells resembling large alveolar glands, broadly connected to the epidermis (arrow). Histological examination reveals polygonal tumor cells with variable nuclear atypia and increased mitotic activity. The tumor lesions are broadly connected to the epidermis, although the presence of a direct connection to the squamous epithelium is unclear. (Hematoxylin and eosin [H&E] staining; magnification × 40).

Histopathology of a vulva tumor section showing tumor cells forming small glandular structures (arrowheads). Areas of comedo-necrosis are seen (arrows), where necrosis is present in the center of the nodules. The tumor cells appear as solid nests resembling large alveolar glands, without apparent keratinization, and exhibit an intracytoplasmic luminal and cribriform pattern. (Hematoxylin and eosin [H&E] staining; magnification × 100).

Histopathology of vulvar melanoma in situ. Photomicrograph of the initial biopsy specimen showing a broad, asymmetric, junctional melanocytic proliferation with variable epidermal acanthosis and dermal clusters of heavily pigmented melanophages. This finding is part of the histopathological examination revealing melanoma in situ, characterized by a proliferation of enlarged, poorly nested and confluent, severely atypical melanocytes. (Hematoxylin-eosin stain, original magnification ×100).

Histopathology of vulvar melanoma in situ. Photomicrograph of the excised specimen showing confluent, severely atypical melanocytes with pagetoid spread. This characteristic proliferation of enlarged, poorly nested and confluent, severely atypical melanocytes was revealed by the histopathological examination of the excised tissue, confirming melanoma in situ. (Hematoxylin-eosin stain, original magnification ×400).

Histopathology of vulvar melanoma in situ. Photomicrograph of the excised specimen showing areas with lichenoid lymphoid infiltrates and dermal melanophages. These findings are consistent with the variable lichenoid inflammatory infiltrate and skipping foci of heavily pigmented dermal melanophages observed in the histopathological examination of melanoma in situ. (Hematoxylin-eosin stain, original magnification ×200).

Histopathology of vulvar melanoma in situ. Photomicrograph of the excised specimen showing the intersection of congested and ectatic vasculature with dermal melanophages and junctional melanoma. This observation aligns with the marked vascular ectasia and congestion, along with skipping foci of heavily pigmented dermal melanophages, identified during the histopathological examination of melanoma in situ. (Hematoxylin-eosin stain, original magnification ×200).

Microscopic findings showing epithelioid cells. These are medium-sized round- to polygonal-shaped cells with densely pigmented cytoplasm. The cells contain round to oval vesicular nuclei with variably prominent nucleoli. This image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at 400x magnification.
Microscopic findings showing the peripheral area where epithelioid cells are intermixed with spindle cells. This image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at 400x magnification.

Microscopic findings of a lymph node specimen. Pigmented tumor cells are observed within the lymph node capsule. This image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at 100x magnification.

Standard histology of the breast tumor showing tumor cells that are medium-sized with hyperchromatic nuclei and very anisokaryotic. The cells possess abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm and numerous, often atypical, mitoses. (Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), ×40 magnification).
Intermediate-power view of cutaneous lesional cells, showing an admixture of spindle and epithelioid cells. (Hematoxylin and Eosin, 20× magnification)

Photomicrograph showing the junctional component of the tumor, which exhibits Spitzoid features of the lesional cells. Notably, the junctional nests do not display a uniform vertical orientation towards the epidermis, a characteristic that is typically expected in most Spitz nevi. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin at 40× magnification.

Photomicrographic panoramic view of the patient's cutaneous biopsy showing an asymmetric lesion with a basal confluent growth. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin and captured at 2× magnification.

Microscopic appearance of the resected presacral mass, ultimately diagnosed as a neurofibroma. The image displays a uniformly hypocellular specimen characterized by a haphazard admixture of wavy Schwann cells and collagen fibers dispersed in an abundant mucopolysaccharide matrix. Pathologic examination confirmed the absence of increased cellularity, nuclear pleomorphism, increased mitotic activity, or tumor coagulative cell necrosis. The morphological features seen here, combined with positive immunohistochemistry for S100, Neurofilament, and vimentin (and negative for epithelial membrane antigen), supported the diagnosis of neurofibroma. Hematoxylin and Eosin, 20× magnification.

Photomicrograph showing the cytologic features of the lesion. Note the nuclear pleomorphism and prominent nucleoli. This focus was near the deep edge of the lesion, reflecting a lack of histological maturation. (Hematoxylin and Eosin 20×)

Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining (×100) showing the microscopic features of the specimen. Microscopic findings did not reveal typical indicators of malignant melanoma such as mitoses, necrosis, or nuclear pleomorphism. This observation, combined with the results of immunohistochemical analysis and a low Ki-67 labeling index, was consistent with a diagnosis of melanocytoma rather than malignant melanoma.

Histopathology showing the radial growth phase (RGP) in primary cutaneous malignant melanoma. This phase represents the initial tumor progression where transformed melanocytes proliferate above the epidermal basement membrane with a lentiginous or pagetoid pattern, characteristic of in situ lentigo maligna melanoma (LMM), superficial spreading melanoma (SSM), or acral lentiginous melanoma (ALM). Stained with hematoxylin/eosin at 4× magnification.

Histopathology showing the vertical growth phase (VGP) in primary cutaneous malignant melanoma. This tumorigenic phase follows the radial growth phase and is characterized by deeper extension of the melanoma into the dermis or subcutis, indicating the acquisition of metastatic capacity. Stained with hematoxylin/eosin at 4× magnification.

Histopathology of Lymphomatoid papulosis type C, from an infiltrated non-ulcerated papule of a 60-year-old female patient who presented with cutaneous papules and erythematous-violet nodules. The image shows the dermis with a V-shaped cell infiltrate associated with blurring of the dermal-epidermal junction, rectification of epidermal cones (epidermis), and hyperkeratosis. (Hematoxylin & eosin stain, original magnification x40).

Histopathology of Lymphomatoid papulosis type C, from an infiltrated non-ulcerated papule of a 60-year-old female patient who presented with cutaneous papules and erythematous-violet nodules. The image displays a dense cellular infiltrate in the dermis, consisting of round cells (lymphocytes) with large, pleomorphic, and vesicular nuclei, sometimes bevelled, and conspicuous cytoplasm displaying coarse nucleoli. Some binucleate lymphocytes resembling Reed-Sternberg cells are present, and numerous mitotic figures were observed. (Hematoxylin & eosin stain, original magnification x400).

Histological examination showing melanocyte proliferation forming hypercellular nests within the papillary and reticular dermis, with no alteration observed in the epidermis. This solid melanocytic lesion, compatible with ACBN, is composed of hypercellular nests affecting the entire dermis and part of the subcutaneous tissue. Features observed in the lesion include dendritic pigmented cells at the nest extremity, ovoid and pale cells of intermediate size in the center, and focally, pleomorphic and vesicular nuclei with evident nucleoli and occasional mitosis (<2/mm2). Stained with Hematoxylin & eosin, original magnification x40.

Histopathology showing pleomorphic and vesicular nuclei, evident nucleoli, and occasional mitosis (<2/mm 2), features compatible with atypical cellular blue nevus. (Hematoxylin & eosin x400 magnification)

Histopathology image showing a cellular blue nevus. The lesion is characterized by nests composed of heavily pigmented and dendritic melanocytes located in the periphery, while the center features pale and ovoid melanocytes of intermediate size. Stained with Hematoxylin & eosin at x100 magnification.

Histological examination revealing an aggregation in palisading arrangement of basaloid cells in the superficial dermis, including melanin pigment both within and outside the tumour mass. The image is magnified x10 and stained with Hematoxylin & eosin.

Histopathology of a matrix biopsy specimen from the lesion (originally shown in Figure 1), stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). The image displays heavy pigmentation observed over both the epidermis and dermis, which significantly compromised the assessment of the tissue's architecture and cytology.

Histopathology of a bleached biopsy section. Bleaching was performed to address the heavy pigmentation seen in the original H&E staining (Panel a). This bleached section revealed an apparent epidermal melanocytic proliferation, though this finding was initially interpreted as keratinocytes modified by the bleaching process.

Histopathology image showing irregular islands of infiltrating melanoma cells. A vague pseudo glandular pattern is also visible. The section is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×200 magnification.

Histopathology of a lesion from the abdomen of a 36-year-old female. The pretest diagnosis was “favor traumatized atypical nevus.” All three reviewing dermatopathologists classified the lesion as melanoma, and the overall score was +1.1. The submitting dermatopathologist changed the diagnosis to atypical melanocytic proliferation. Stained with Hematoxylin-eosin; original magnification x20.

The submitting dermatopathologist changed the diagnosis to atypical melanocytic proliferation. Stained with Hematoxylin-eosin; original magnification x100.

Histopathology of a lesion from the back of a 58-year-old male. This lesion was initially submitted with a pretest diagnosis of “benign; favor severely dysplastic nevus,” but all three reviewing dermatopathologists classified it as melanoma. After the test, the submitting dermatopathologist changed the diagnosis to melanoma in situ. The image is stained with Hematoxylin-eosin; original magnification x20.

Histopathology of a lesion from the neck of a 71-year-old female, initially submitted as "indeterminate; favor dysplastic nevus with severe dysplasia versus evolving melanoma." Three reviewing dermatopathologists favored a benign diagnosis, but two noted they could not entirely exclude early melanoma and recommended re-excision. The score for this case was +3.1, and it was initially counted as an apparent false-positive because the triple-concordant diagnosis was dysplastic nevus. However, reviewing dermatopathologists considered superficial melanoma in the differential. Based on the score, the submitting dermatopathologist changed their diagnosis to superficial spreading melanoma. Stained with Hematoxylin-eosin; original magnification x20.

Based on the score, the submitting dermatopathologist changed their diagnosis to superficial spreading melanoma. Stained with Hematoxylin-eosin; original magnification x200.

Histopathology showing a lesion from the back of a 72-year-old man. Stained with Hematoxylin-eosin; original magnification x20.

Histopathology of a lesion from the scalp of a 52-year-old male, diagnosed by three dermatopathologists as malignant melanoma in situ. This lesion was initially submitted as lentigo maligna, which is a subtype where false-negative results for the diagnostic test were most common. This specific case represents a false-negative result, as the diagnostic test yielded a score of -2.3 (indicating a negative result), despite the expert consensus diagnosis of malignant melanoma in situ. Hematoxylin-eosin stain; original magnification x20.

Histopathology showing a benign Spitz nevus from the back of a 26-year-old female. The lesion was submitted as “indeterminate; favor atypical Spitz tumor,” but was subsequently classified as a benign Spitz nevus by all 3 reviewing dermatopathologists. The lesion received a score of –7.2. Hematoxylin-eosin stain; original magnification x20.

The lesion was submitted as “indeterminate; favor atypical Spitz tumor,” but was subsequently classified as a benign Spitz nevus by all 3 reviewing dermatopathologists. The lesion received a score of –7.2. Hematoxylin-eosin stain; original magnification x100.

Histopathology showing a benign Spitz nevus from the back of a 26-year-old female. The lesion was submitted as “indeterminate; favor atypical Spitz tumor,” but was subsequently classified as a benign Spitz nevus by all 3 reviewing dermatopathologists. The lesion received a score of –7.2. Hematoxylin-eosin stain; original magnification x200.

Histopathology showing a benign Spitz nevus from the back of a 26-year-old female. The lesion was submitted as “indeterminate; favor atypical Spitz tumor,” but was subsequently classified as a benign Spitz nevus by all 3 reviewing dermatopathologists. The lesion received a score of –7.2. Hematoxylin-eosin stain; original magnification x400.

Histopathology of a lesion from a 74-year-old male, initially submitted with a pretest diagnosis of “indeterminate; favor irritated compound nevus with moderate to severe atypia.” All three reviewing dermatopathologists classified the lesion as melanoma, with a score of +2.4. Following the test, the submitting dermatopathologist changed the diagnosis to superficial spreading melanoma. This image shows the lesion at an original magnification of x20, stained with Hematoxylin-eosin.

Histopathology of a lesion from a 74-year-old male, initially submitted with a pretest diagnosis of “indeterminate; favor irritated compound nevus with moderate to severe atypia.” All three reviewing dermatopathologists classified the lesion as melanoma, with a score of +2.4. Following the test, the submitting dermatopathologist changed the diagnosis to superficial spreading melanoma. This image shows the lesion at an original magnification of x100, stained with Hematoxylin-eosin.

Histopathology of a lesion from a 74-year-old male, initially submitted with a pretest diagnosis of “indeterminate; favor irritated compound nevus with moderate to severe atypia.” All three reviewing dermatopathologists classified the lesion as melanoma, with a score of +2.4. Following the test, the submitting dermatopathologist changed the diagnosis to superficial spreading melanoma. This image shows the lesion at an original magnification of x200, stained with Hematoxylin-eosin.

Histopathology of a lesion from a 74-year-old male, initially submitted with a pretest diagnosis of “indeterminate; favor irritated compound nevus with moderate to severe atypia.” All three reviewing dermatopathologists classified the lesion as melanoma, with a score of +2.4. Following the test, the submitting dermatopathologist changed the diagnosis to superficial spreading melanoma. This image shows the lesion at an original magnification of x400, stained with Hematoxylin-eosin.
Histopathology showing mature ectopic adipocytes grouped in irregular strips between the collagen bundles of the reticular dermis. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at 40x magnification.
Histopathology showing deposition of adipose tissue in the dermis, visualized with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) staining at 10x magnification.

Histopathology showing suprabasal acantholytic and dyskeratotic keratinocytes. The image also reveals an acantholytic phenomenon in the epidermis, hyperkeratosis, and bone of the distal phalanx. This sample specimen was taken from an eight mm reddish papule found in the middle of the nail bed. Hematoxylin-eosin (H-E) stain, original magnification ×10.

Microscopic examination of a lentigo maligna melanoma biopsy shows atypical melanocytes along the dermal-epidermal junction. There is also extension of the tumor cells down adnexal structures (hematoxylin and eosin; magnification x20).

Microscopic examination of a punch biopsy from a metastatic melanoma located on the left parietal scalp. This closer magnification (20x) reveals atypical melanocytes present in the deep dermis. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin.

Distant view of a subsequent punch biopsy, which was performed to evaluate residual pigment observed clinically in the center of a prior shave biopsy site. The histopathology shows a nodular configuration of atypical melanocytes located in the papillary and reticular dermis, along with small areas of junctional involvement and folliculotropism. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (original magnification x4).

Microscopic examination of a punch biopsy from tumoral melanosis on the left parietal scalp, showing dense collections of melanophages in a nodular aggregate. Tumor melanocytes are not observed. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin and viewed at x4 magnification.

Closer magnification of the microscopic examination of a punch biopsy, showing epidermotropic metastatic malignant melanoma. Atypical tumor melanocytes are visible, filling the dermis and extending into the follicular epithelium and overlying epidermis. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) and viewed at 20x magnification.

Microscopic examination of the initial shave biopsy from a 2 mm black papule on the left parietal scalp, revealing epidermotropic metastatic malignant melanoma. The image shows a follicle in the center of the specimen with a dense infiltrate of melanocytes in the dermis and extending into the overlying epidermis. Subsequent examination of the biopsy site showed pigment at the base. Hematoxylin and eosin stain; original magnification x = 4.

Microscopic examination of the punch biopsy of the metastatic melanoma on the left parietal scalp. Atypical melanocytes are seen in a nodular configuration in the papillary dermis and extend deeply into the reticular dermis (hematoxylin and eosin; magnification x = 4).

Microscopic examination of a lentigo maligna melanoma biopsy, showing a closer view of atypical melanocytes along the dermal-epidermal junction. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin at 40x magnification.

Histopathology of the nail unit, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at ×10 magnification, revealing scattered pigmentation in the hyponychium and the nail bed, accompanied by lymphocytic infiltration in the onychodermis layer.

Histopathology of the nail unit, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at ×100 magnification, demonstrating atypical melanocytes characterized by hyperchromatic nuclei, which have invaded the dermis layer.

Histopathological observation of sebaceous carcinoma (SC) showing well-differentiated sebaceous carcinoma with sebocyte-like tumor cells. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at × 100 magnification.
Histopathological observation of sebaceous carcinoma (SC) showing moderately differentiated sebaceous carcinoma. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at × 100 magnification.

Histopathological observation of sebaceous carcinoma (SC) showing poorly differentiated sebaceous carcinoma with fine stippling of the nuclear chromatin and few mitoses present. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at × 200 magnification.

Histopathological observation of sebaceous carcinoma (SC) showing a lobular pattern of infiltrative growth with central necrosis. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at × 100 magnification.

Histopathological observation of sebaceous carcinoma (SC) showing a trabecular pattern of infiltrative growth. The inset image shows an epidermoid dyskeratosis. The main image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at × 100 magnification; the inset is at × 400 magnification.

Histopathological observation of sebaceous carcinoma (SC) showing a papillary pattern of infiltrative growth with unencapsulated margins. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at × 100 magnification.
Histopathological observation of sebaceous carcinoma (SC) showing tumor cells surrounded by layers of basaloid cells. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at × 100 magnification.

Histopathological observation of sebaceous carcinoma (SC) showing an epidermoid infiltrative cell type with nonkeratinizing cells within a large lobule manifesting nonvacuolated eosinophilic cytoplasm with scattered pleomorphic nuclei in a comedonecrosis pattern. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at × 100 magnification.

Histopathological observation of sebaceous carcinoma (SC) showing a basosquamous infiltrative cell type with lobules composed of small cells with scant eosinophilic cytoplasm. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at × 100 magnification.

Histopathological observation of sebaceous carcinoma (SC) showing intraepithelial tumor cells with a pagetoid spreading pattern. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at × 100 magnification.
Pathological examination showing histopathology of malignant melanoma, which was revealed with a Breslow thickness of 1.6 mm, stained with H&E (×300).

Low magnification observation, taken with a ×2 objective lens and stitched, showing a tumor largely composed of adipose tissue, lobuled by fibrous septum. Hematoxylin and Eosin stained. A black bar represents 500 μm.

Histopathology showing an overview of lentigo malignant melanoma (LMM), stained with hematoxylin-eosin (x2 magnification). This image displays the proliferation of atypical melanocytes, seen singly and in nests along the basal layer of the epidermis, and epitheloid nests in the adjacent dermis. The atypical cells are small with prominent nuclei, confirming the diagnosis of LMM.

Detailed histopathology of lentigo malignant melanoma (LMM), stained with hematoxylin-eosin (x4 magnification). This image highlights the proliferation of atypical melanocytes, appearing singly and in nests along the basal layer of the epidermis, as well as epitheloid nests within the adjacent dermis. The atypical cells are characterized by their small size and prominent nuclei, consistent with LMM.

A photomicrograph of a chronic discoid lupus erythematosus (CDLE) lesion, a chronic form of cutaneous lupus. The image shows characteristic microscopic features including hyperparakeratosis and a lichenoid pattern of inflammation, which encompasses degeneration of the basal layer and subepithelial lymphocytic infiltration. Deep inflammatory infiltration, often with a perivascular orientation, also distinguishes CDLE lesions. (H & E, X 40)

A photomicrograph of a clinically verrucous lesion, showing significant epithelial proliferation. Histopathologic features visible include sharp and keratotic projections with keratin-filled invaginations, typically without obvious fibrovascular cores. The lesion's growth does not extend below the level of the adjacent normal epithelium. Mild dysplasia associated with a lichenoid/interface inflammatory reaction and heavy inflammatory cell infiltration, including lymphocytes, plasma cells, and histiocytes, may also be observed. Stained with Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), original magnification 40x.

A photomicrograph of an Oral Lichen Planus (OLP) lesion, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 400x magnification. The image displays characteristic histopathological features, including acanthosis, saw-toothed-shaped rete ridges, and a well-defined, band-like infiltration of lymphocytes immediately underlying the epithelium. This prominent band-like infiltration of inflammatory cells, predominantly lymphocytes, is a key diagnostic criterion for OLP. The absence of epithelial dysplasia is also an important criterion for OLP diagnosis. Infiltration of chronic inflammatory cells, as seen here, is considered a strong risk factor for potential cancer development.

A photomicrograph showing the histopathological features of a clinically diagnosed oral erythroplakia. Erythroplakia is an uncommon fiery red patch that clinically presents as flat to slightly raised red lesions with irregular borders. The image displays atrophic oral epithelium with atypia, which represents a degree of dysplasia, along with squamatization of the basal cell layer and underlying chronic inflammation. Histopathologically, oral erythroplakia is characterized by a lack of excess surface keratinization and often shows dysplasia, carcinoma in situ, or even squamous cell carcinoma. The tissue section is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 400x magnification.

A photomicrograph of a leukoplakic lesion, which is a clinical term for a white patch or plaque that cannot be characterized as any other disease, and whose histopathologic findings typically include hyperkeratosis with or without epithelial dysplasia. This image specifically shows mild epithelial dysplasia, a histopathological feature where epithelial cells exhibit abnormal growth and maturation, classified as one of three subclasses: mild, moderate, or severe. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin at X 40 magnification.

A photomicrograph, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 40x magnification, showing mild epithelial dysplasia, surface hyperorthokeratosis, and lichenoid mucositis. These findings are characteristic microscopic features of lichenoid dysplasia (LD), a condition observed in cases of lichenoid stomatitis with dysplasia. In LD, lichenoid infiltration occurs against atypical epithelial cells. Histologically, LD lesions, often appearing as erythematous or leukoplakic areas, are characterized by hyperparakeratosis or hyperorthokeratosis, epithelial dysplasia, and band-like lymphocyte infiltration. Important features also include basal cell hyperplasia and atypia, with a notable lack of liquefaction degeneration and an intact or even hyperplastic basal cell layer, which helps distinguish LD from oral lichen planus (OLP).

A photomicrograph of an actinic keratosis (AK) displaying characteristic surface hyperkeratosis and acanthosis. This acanthotic variant of AK is histopathologically characterized by elongated rete ridges, as the epidermis exhibits an increased thickness. Other key features of AK, which typically include pathognomonic atypical keratinocytes originating within the basal layer and potentially extending above the basal layer in advanced stages, and elastosis formation associated with mast cell infiltration, are also part of the diagnostic spectrum for actinic keratosis lesions. (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, 40x magnification).

Microscopic view of a shave biopsy from a 72-year-old male with a soft brown papule on his back. The image shows a heavily pigmented spindle, dendritic, and epithelioid melanocytic proliferation in the dermis, arising in the background of an intradermal melanocytic nevus with a congenital pattern. The brown color represents melanin pigment. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E). Microscopic magnification: ×4.

Microscopic view of a shave biopsy from a 72-year-old male with a soft brown papule on his back. The image shows a heavily pigmented spindle, dendritic, and epithelioid melanocytic proliferation in the dermis, arising in the background of an intradermal melanocytic nevus with a congenital pattern. Proliferating Epidermal Melanocytes (PEM) are also seen arising in and from the intradermal nevus. The brown color represents melanin pigment. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E). Microscopic magnification: ×10.

Microscopic view of a shave biopsy from a 72-year-old male with a soft brown papule on his back. The image shows Proliferating Epidermal Melanocytes (PEM) arising in and from an intradermal nevus. At least two mitotic figures were identified within the proliferation. The brown color represents melanin pigment. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E). Microscopic magnification: ×20.

Microscopic view of a shave biopsy from a 72-year-old male with a soft brown papule on his back. The image shows Proliferating Epidermal Melanocytes (PEM) arising in and from an intradermal nevus. At least two mitotic figures were identified within the proliferation. The brown color represents melanin pigment. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E). Microscopic magnification: ×20.

Histopathology showing a UV-induced melanoma obtained from an HGF/SF (Hepatocyte growth factor/scatter factor)-overexpression mouse model. The mice were irradiated at post-natal day four with 4 kJ/m2 of ultraviolet light (UV) (61% UVB, 28.3% UVA, 2.09% UVC). This image displays the morphology of a heavily pigmented tumor, which is strikingly similar to melanomas observed in rodents. Characteristically, these tumors display a proliferation of dendritic or spindled heavily pigmented melanocytes, often with epithelioid cells in the dermis and infiltrative borders. The brown color visible in the section represents melanin pigment. Although some lesions may initially resemble blue nevi or exhibit a borderline morphology, these tumors are known to metastasize. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). Microscopic magnification: ×4.

Histopathology showing a UV-induced melanoma obtained from an HGF/SF (Hepatocyte growth factor/scatter factor)-overexpression mouse model. The mice were irradiated at post-natal day four with 4 kJ/m2 of ultraviolet light (UV) (61% UVB, 28.3% UVA, 2.09% UVC). This image displays the morphology of a heavily pigmented tumor, which is strikingly similar to melanomas observed in rodents. Characteristically, these tumors display a proliferation of dendritic or spindled heavily pigmented melanocytes, often with epithelioid cells in the dermis and infiltrative borders. The brown color visible in the section represents melanin pigment. These lesions develop into heavily pigmented tumors with dendritic, spindle, and some epithelioid cells invading the dermis and adjacent structures. Despite the potentially benign-looking or borderline morphology, these tumors are known to metastasize. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). Microscopic magnification: ×10.

Histopathology showing a UV-induced melanoma obtained from an HGF/SF (Hepatocyte growth factor/scatter factor)-overexpression mouse model. The mice were irradiated at post-natal day four with 4 kJ/m2 of ultraviolet light (UV) (61% UVB, 28.3% UVA, 2.09% UVC). This image displays the morphology of a heavily pigmented tumor, which is strikingly similar to melanomas observed in rodents. Characteristically, these tumors display a proliferation of dendritic or spindled heavily pigmented melanocytes, often with epithelioid cells in the dermis and infiltrative borders. The brown color visible in the section represents melanin pigment. These tumors are observed to have infiltrative borders and contain dendritic, spindle, and some epithelioid cells invading the dermis and adjacent structures. Despite the potentially benign-looking or borderline morphology, these tumors are known to metastasize and cause mortality in the animals. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). Microscopic magnification: ×40.
Histopathology showing the dermis infiltrated by pleomorphic spindle-shaped cells within intervening marked desmoplastic stroma (Hematoxylin and Eosin, ×100 magnification).
Histopathology showing dermal pleomorphic spindle-shaped cells with bizarre nuclei and retraction artifact admixed with mature collagen fibers (arrow) (Hematoxylin and Eosin, ×400 magnification).
Histopathological view (H&E staining, original magnification ×100) showing junctional activity from the epithelium into the connective tissue.

Histopathological view (H&E staining, original magnification ×400) showing cells and nuclei that are markedly pleomorphic and amphophilic, with nucleoli varied in number and size, and the presence of melanin pigment.

Photomicrograph showing invasion of malignant spindle and polygonal cells with nuclear hyperchromasia in the connective tissue, consistent with the diagnosis of melanoma. This image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H & E) and viewed at an original magnification of ×40.

Histopathology of the lesion from an excisional biopsy, diagnosed as a collision tumor involving a trichofolliculoma (TF) and melanocytic nevus. This H&E stained image at ×2 magnification provides a full view of the lesion, revealing a central cystic cavity containing detritus and hair fragments (keratinous debris and hair shaft fragments), with numerous hair follicles arising from the cyst wall.

Histopathology of the lesion from an excisional biopsy, diagnosed as a collision tumor involving a trichofolliculoma (TF) and melanocytic nevus. This H&E stained image at ×20 magnification details the melanocytic nests which are part of an intradermal melanocytic proliferation, seen surrounding the hair follicles that arise from the cyst wall.

Histopathology of the lesion from an excisional biopsy, diagnosed as a collision tumor involving a trichofolliculoma (TF) and melanocytic nevus. This H&E stained image at ×100 magnification provides a high-power view of the melanocytic nests, which are part of an intradermal melanocytic proliferation, clearly showing them surrounding the hair follicles.

Histopathology of a central lesion from a 15-year-old female patient with a pigmented lesion on the lateral aspect of the left arm. The image shows spindle-shaped and dendritic, strongly pigmented melanocytes amid dense fibrous stroma and melanophages, predominantly occupying the upper and mid dermis. These features contribute to the diagnosis of common blue nevus with satellitosis. Stained with Hematoxylin & eosin, original magnification X40.

Photomicroscopy of the skin showing the superficial dermis with an area of vascular dilatation, observed in a 36-year-old female patient diagnosed with congenital plaque-like glomangioma. The patient presented with painful blue-purple papules and nodules. (Hematoxylin & eosin, X40 magnification).

Photomicroscopy of the skin showing the superficial dermis with an area of vascular dilatation, observed in a 36-year-old female patient diagnosed with congenital plaque-like glomangioma. The patient presented with painful blue-purple papules and nodules. (Hematoxylin & eosin, X100 magnification).

Photomicroscopy of the skin showing a group of multiple dilated vessels in the superficial dermis. This finding is consistent with the histopathology of congenital plaque-like glomangioma diagnosed in a 36-year-old female patient who presented with painful blue-purple papules and nodules. (Hematoxylin & eosin, X200 magnification).

Photomicroscopy of the skin showing a vascular wall composed of more than one layer of small, round, uniform cells, with central round nuclei and eosinophilic pale cytoplasm, characteristic of glomus cells. These cellular features are critical for the histopathological diagnosis of congenital plaque-like glomangioma in a 36-year-old female patient. (Hematoxylin & eosin, X400 magnification).

Histopathology of an abdominal plaque showing psoriasiform epidermal hyperplasia, a predominantly lymphocytic folliculotropic infiltrate, and loose epithelioid granulomas. These features are part of a dense atypical mononuclear infiltrate and a granulomatous reaction. (Hematoxylin & eosin, X100 magnification).

Histopathology of an abdominal plaque showing a lymphocytic infiltrate, described as dense and atypical mononuclear, involving the remaining external follicular sheaths. (Hematoxylin & eosin, X100 magnification).

Histopathology from the left shoulder tumor or left supraclavicular lymph node, stained with Hematoxylin-eosin, showing nests of monomorphic tumor cells. These cells display large atypia and deeply stained nuclei with active mitotic figures, infiltrating the lower dermis and subcutaneous fat layer. No obvious melanin is present. The epidermis was reported as normal. These features are consistent with Achromatic Malignant Melanoma (AMM). Magnification 400×.
Photomicrograph of a Spitz nevus histological section stained with hematoxylin and eosin (HE) for light optical microscopy, showing epithelial expansion with free borders (40x magnification).
Photomicrograph of a Spitz nevus histological section stained with hematoxylin and eosin (HE) for light optical microscopy, showing melanocytic nests (200x magnification).

Photomicrograph of a Spitz nevus histological section stained with hematoxylin and eosin (HE) for light optical microscopy, showing characteristic Kamino bodies underlying the epithelium (400x magnification).

Histopathology of cutaneous melanoma cells, stained with H&E, illustrating a complete lack of nucleoli in the neoplastic cells. This cytomorphological parameter corresponds to the '0' grouping for the presence of nucleoli in melanoma cells, indicating no nucleoli are present in the nuclei, thus no nucleolus size or number can be evaluated. The main image is at ×400 magnification, with an insert showing a higher magnification at ×600.

Histopathology of cutaneous melanoma cells, stained with H&E, showing a small number of melanoma cells with visible nucleoli. This observation aligns with the '1' grouping for the presence of nucleoli, indicating that a small number (≤ 20%) of melanoma cells in the analyzed specimen possess nucleoli. The main image is at ×400 magnification. The insert, at ×600 magnification, highlights two cells that exhibit both macronucleoli (prominent nucleoli) and micronucleoli (inconspicuous nucleoli), representing a mixed nucleolus size within the same specimen.

Histopathology of cutaneous melanoma cells, stained with H&E, demonstrating a high representation of cancer cells with distinct nucleoli. This falls under the '2' grouping for the presence of nucleoli, where a high percentage (> 20%) of melanoma cells show visible nucleoli. The main image is at ×600 magnification. The insert, also at ×600 magnification, specifically illustrates prominent binucleolization, where individual melanoma cells contain two distinct nucleoli, categorized as '2' for nucleoli number (two or more nucleoli per one nucleus) and indicating prominent macronucleoli.

Histopathology of cutaneous melanoma cells, stained with H&E, showing a high percentage of melanoma cells with prominent nucleoli. This corresponds to the '2' grouping for the presence of nucleoli, where a high percentage (> 20%) of melanoma cells display nucleoli, specifically prominent ones (macronucleoli). The main image is at ×400 magnification. The insert, at ×600 magnification, illustrates polynucleolization of melanoma cells, specifically highlighting individual cells containing three nucleoli, consistent with the '2' grouping for nucleoli number (two or more nucleoli per one nucleus) and indicating prominent macronucleoli.

Histopathology showing cutaneous melanoma cells with prominent macronucleoli. Macronucleoli are defined as prominent nucleoli within the melanoma cell nuclei. The image is shown at ×400 magnification, with an insert at ×600 magnification highlighting an eosinophilic roundish macronucleolus. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E).

Histopathology showing cutaneous melanoma cells with high heterogeneity in the cytomorphological parameters of the nucleoli. This panel displays cells containing micronucleoli (inconspicuous nucleoli) alongside cells with prominent macronucleoli. The image is shown at ×400 magnification, with an insert at ×600 magnification. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E).

Histopathology showing cutaneous melanoma cells with a high representation of distinct nucleoli, specifically featuring binucleolization. Binucleolization refers to the presence of two or more nucleoli per one nucleus of a melanoma cell. The image is shown at ×400 magnification, with an insert at ×600 magnification. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E).

Histopathology showing cutaneous melanoma cells with distinct eosinophilic micronucleoli. Micronucleoli are defined as inconspicuous nucleoli within the melanoma cell nuclei. The image is shown at ×400 magnification, with an insert at ×600 magnification specifically highlighting the eosinophilic micronucleoli. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E).

Photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen showing a superficial perivascular lymphocyte inflammatory infiltrate from patient 1. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) and captured at 10× magnification.

Photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen showing eosinophilic spongiosis with focal subepidermal clefting from patient 2 during their second eruption. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) and captured at 10× magnification.

Photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen showing spongiotic psoriasiform and interface dermatitis with necrotic keratinocytes from patient 5. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) and captured at 10× magnification.

Photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen showing epidermal spongiosis with patchy necrotic keratinocytes and dermal lymphocyte predominant perivascular infiltrate from patient 11. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) and captured at 10× magnification.

H&E stain, 40x view, showing microscopic features of a tumor consistent with a melanotic neuroectodermal tumor of infancy (MNTI). Two distinctive types of cells are observed: large cells arranged peripherally with abundant cytoplasm, a round vesicular nucleus, and brown pigment; and small cells with scanty cytoplasm and hyperchromatic round nuclei seen in the center. These cells comprise a tumor that, on microscopic examination, exhibited an alveolar pattern separated by fibrovascular stroma.

Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained section at 10X magnification, showing tumor cells arranged in an alveolar pattern separated by fibrovascular stroma. Microscopic examination of the tumor reveals two distinctive types of cells: large cells with abundant cytoplasm, a round vesicular nucleus, and brown pigment, typically arranged peripherally; and small cells with scanty cytoplasm and hyperchromatic round nuclei, typically located in the center. These histological features are consistent with a small round cell tumor, favoring a diagnosis of melanotic neuroectodermal tumor of infancy (MNTI).

Histopathology (H&E, ×40) from a punch biopsy of a rapidly enlarging nodule in a congenital melanocytic nevus shows cellular proliferation of melanocytes with no deep infiltration. This finding is observed in a 28-year-old pregnant woman presenting with rapidly enlarging papules and nodules in a 15 cm-sized black-pigmented plaque on her right posterior thigh. The biopsy was performed to exclude malignant melanoma arising within the congenital melanocytic nevus. The final diagnosis was benign proliferative nodules with mild atypia arising in a congenital melanocytic nevus.

Histopathology (H&E, ×100) from a punch biopsy of a rapidly enlarging nodule in a congenital melanocytic nevus shows proliferation of melanocytes in the background of a melanocytic nevus. This finding is observed in a 28-year-old pregnant woman presenting with rapidly enlarging papules and nodules in a 15 cm-sized black-pigmented plaque on her right posterior thigh. The biopsy was performed to exclude malignant melanoma arising within the congenital melanocytic nevus. The final diagnosis was benign proliferative nodules with mild atypia arising in a congenital melanocytic nevus.

Histopathology (H&E, ×200) from a punch biopsy of a rapidly enlarging nodule in a congenital melanocytic nevus shows intraepidermal pagetoid proliferation of melanocytes. The distribution of these pagetoid cells was mostly confined to the lower part of the epidermis, without mitosis, necrosis, and high-grade atypia. This finding is observed in a 28-year-old pregnant woman presenting with rapidly enlarging papules and nodules in a 15 cm-sized black-pigmented plaque on her right posterior thigh. The biopsy was performed to exclude malignant melanoma arising within the congenital melanocytic nevus. The final diagnosis was benign proliferative nodules with mild atypia arising in a congenital melanocytic nevus.
Histologic examination of the tumour, showing nests and fascicles of spindle cells with clear cytoplasm. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at x40 magnification.
Histologic examination of the tumour, showing wreath-like giant cells. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at x40 magnification.

Histopathological examination of a biopsy from a nodule on the right side of the neck of a 43-year-old female. The image shows diffuse infiltration of the dermis with sheets of neoplastic cells, forming a nodular mass composed of fascicles of spindle cells with clear cytoplasm and characteristic wreath-like giant cells. This infiltration involves the entire dermis, with focal extension into the superficial subcutaneous tissue. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification x40.

Histopathological examination of a biopsy from a nodule on the right side of the neck of a 43-year-old female, showing the same neoplastic process at a higher magnification. This panel specifically illustrates the absence of involvement of the epidermis by the neoplastic cells, despite the extensive dermal infiltration. The dermal infiltration consists of a nodular mass with sheets of neoplastic cells, including fascicles of spindle cells with clear cytoplasm and characteristic wreath-like giant cells, extensively involving the dermis with focal extension into the superficial subcutaneous tissue. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification x100.

Histopathology of a punch biopsy specimen obtained from the external auditory canal. The image shows strips of stratified squamous epithelium with underlying melanocytes. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification 40x.

Histopathology of a punch biopsy specimen from the external auditory canal, showing melanocytes at a higher magnification compared to panel A. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification 200x.
Histopathology of an excision specimen showing malignant melanocytes within the lymph node. The image is taken at 200x magnification and stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).
Histopathology of an excision specimen showing malignant melanocytes intermixed with the parotid gland acini. The image is taken at 200x magnification and stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Hematoxylin and eosin-stained slide (×40 magnification) showing a hypo- to moderately cellular tumor formed of epithelioid and spindle cells with bland oval nuclei, some macrophages, and dense cytoplasmic brown melanin pigments. The tumor cells are mostly masked by dense brown pigment deposition, with no significant mitoses or nuclear atypia.

Hematoxylin and eosin-stained slide (×100 magnification) showing a hypo- to moderately cellular tumor formed of epithelioid and spindle cells with bland oval nuclei, some macrophages, and dense cytoplasmic brown melanin pigments. The tumor cells are mostly masked by dense brown pigment deposition, with no significant mitoses or nuclear atypia.
Low-power view of a skin biopsy stained by hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) showing mature adipocytes situated in between the normal collagen bundles.

Histopathological finding. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining photomicrograph showing the tumor involving large and small blood vessels. Photomicrograph was taken under a ×20 objective and a ×10 ocular lens.

Histopathological finding. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining photomicrograph showing tumor cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm increased in number, in sheet form. Photomicrograph was taken under a ×40 objective and a ×10 ocular lens.

Histopathology of an acral lentiginous malignant melanoma (ALM) showing strong IMP-3 expression. Strong IMP-3 expression, with positive cells arranged as isolated single cells or rare small aggregates, was detected in 31 (43.1%) of ALM samples. The high rate of IMP-3 expression (97.2%) and its intensity (often ≥10% of tumor cells) in ALM is significantly different from that observed in benign acral nevi. This image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at ×200 magnification.

Histopathology showing amorphous materials and loosely separated collagen fibers in the papillary dermis, alongside acanthosis with elongated rete ridges. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at ×40 magnification.

Hematoxylin and eosin (×400) staining shows increased melanization within the basal cell layer of a vellus hair follicle. This observation, specifically the increased melanization of vellus hair follicles in the infraorbital region, is a novel finding not previously reported in the literature and is identified as a contributing factor to Periorbital Melanosis (POM). POM typically involves dermal melanocytosis and melanophages, with pigmentation that increases and darkens the periorbital region over time.

Histopathology stained with hematoxylin and eosin (400×) showing dermal melanophages and melanin deposition, indicative of melanin incontinence. A mild lymphocytic infiltrate is also visible in the mid dermis, arranged in a perivascular distribution. This specific pattern of dermal melanophages and a perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate was a consistent feature observed in patients, and was the sole finding in 10% of cases.

Histopathology of the proximal papule showing features of pagetoid dyskeratosis in an asymptomatic, flesh-colored papule at the base of the dorsal penile shaft of a 26-year-old man. There are multiple large, round intraepidermal pale cells extending singly and in clusters upwards in the epidermis. These pagetoid cells resemble those seen in extramammary Paget’s disease and contain condensed pyknotic nuclei with perinuclear halos of washed out clear cytoplasm. Additionally, they demonstrate premature keratinization without acantholysis or parakeratosis. Areas of focal dermal fibrosis are also noted. Hematoxylin and eosin stain, original magnification x10.

Histopathology of the proximal papule showing features of pagetoid dyskeratosis in an asymptomatic, flesh-colored papule at the base of the dorsal penile shaft of a 26-year-old man. There are multiple large, round intraepidermal pale cells extending singly and in clusters upwards in the epidermis. Histopathology of an asymptomatic, flesh-colored papule on the proximal dorsal penile shaft of a 26-year-old man, revealing pagetoid dyskeratosis. The opening of the hair follicle is dilated, and pagetoid cells (indicated by arrows) with premature keratinization are prominent within the epidermis. Immunoperoxidase staining with p16 was negative within the lesional keratinocytes, making a human papillomavirus infection unlikely. Hematoxylin and eosin stain, original magnification x4.

Histopathology of an asymptomatic, flesh-colored papule on the proximal dorsal penile shaft of a 26-year-old man, revealing pagetoid dyskeratosis. The opening of the hair follicle is dilated, and pagetoid cells (indicated by arrows) with premature keratinization are prominent within the epidermis. Immunoperoxidase staining with p16 was negative within the lesional keratinocytes, making a human papillomavirus infection unlikely. Hematoxylin and eosin stain, original magnification x10.

Histopathology of an asymptomatic, flesh-colored papule on the proximal dorsal penile shaft of a 26-year-old man, revealing pagetoid dyskeratosis. Immunoperoxidase staining with p16 was negative within the lesional keratinocytes, making a human papillomavirus infection unlikely. Hematoxylin and eosin stain, original magnification x20.

Photomicrograph showing hyperkeratosis, papillomatosis, and a horn cyst. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) and magnified 100 times.

Photomicrograph showing a pseudo horn cyst within a hyperkeratotic seborrheic keratosis (SK). Histopathological examination of the SK revealed the presence of both true horn cysts and pseudo horn cysts. The diagnosis of hyperkeratotic type of SK was made based on clinical and histopathological findings. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at ×100 magnification.
Photomicrograph showing hyperkeratosis, papillomatosis, and a horn cyst. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and captured at ×40 magnification.

Photomicrograph showing plenty of squamous cells, which constitute the main component of the epidermis in this hyperkeratotic type of seborrheic keratosis (SK). The image also reveals excess melanin dispersed throughout the epidermis. Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification ×100.

Histopathology of Bednar tumour (BT) in a 74-year-old Caucasian man, showing a noncircumscribed, highly cellular dermal neoplasm. The tumour is composed of monotonous, slightly atypical spindle-shaped cells arranged in a prominent storiform pattern, deeply infiltrating the hypodermal fat in a characteristic “honeycombing” pattern. A moderate mitotic activity (3 per 10 HPF) was recorded. Formalin-fixed paraffin section stained with haematoxylin-eosin; original magnification, 40x.

Histopathology of Bednar tumour (BT) in a 74-year-old Caucasian man, showing a noncircumscribed, highly cellular dermal neoplasm. The tumour is composed of monotonous, slightly atypical spindle-shaped cells arranged in a prominent storiform pattern, deeply infiltrating the hypodermal fat in a characteristic “honeycombing” pattern. A moderate mitotic activity (3 per 10 HPF) was recorded. Formalin-fixed paraffin section stained with haematoxylin-eosin; original magnification, 200x.

Histopathology of Bednar tumour (BT) in a 74-year-old Caucasian man. The dermal neoplasm contains scattered heavily pigmented cells, with round to oval vesicular nuclei and dendritic cytoplasm, visible within the tumor. Immunohistochemical investigation of serial sections revealed that these pigmented dendritic cells were positive for S100, Melan-A, and HMB-45. Formalin-fixed paraffin section stained with haematoxylin-eosin; original magnification, 100x.

Histopathology of Bednar tumour (BT) in a 74-year-old Caucasian man. The dermal neoplasm contains scattered heavily pigmented cells, with round to oval vesicular nuclei and dendritic cytoplasm, visible within the tumor. Immunohistochemical investigation of serial sections revealed that these pigmented dendritic cells were positive for S100, Melan-A, and HMB-45. Formalin-fixed paraffin section stained with haematoxylin-eosin; original magnification, 200x.

Histopathology of a metastasis to a satellite lymph node from malignant melanoma (MM) in a 74-year-old Caucasian man, originally diagnosed with superficial spreading MM. Microscopy at 40x original magnification reveals epithelioid tumor cells, characteristic of malignant melanoma. This metastatic lymph node, which was identified two months after surgical excision of the primary lesion, along with other metastases found in the lungs, liver, spleen, bones, dorsal vertebrae, and pelvis, microscopically presented similar epithelioid features. The primary and metastatic tumors were diffusely positive for immunohistochemical staining for S100 and Melan-A. Stained with Haematoxylin-eosin.

Histopathology of a metastasis to a satellite lymph node from malignant melanoma (MM) in a 74-year-old Caucasian man, originally diagnosed with superficial spreading MM. Microscopy at 200x original magnification reveals epithelioid tumor cells, characteristic of malignant melanoma. This metastatic lymph node, which was identified two months after surgical excision of the primary lesion, along with other metastases found in the lungs, liver, spleen, bones, dorsal vertebrae, and pelvis, microscopically presented similar epithelioid features. The primary and metastatic tumors were diffusely positive for immunohistochemical staining for S100 and Melan-A. Stained with Haematoxylin-eosin.

Histopathology image of verrucous nevoid melanoma from Case 2, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at original magnification ×10. The image displays epidermal hyperplasia, elongation of rete ridges, and overlying hyperkeratosis, features that can resemble a dermal nevus.

Histopathology image of verrucous nevoid melanoma from Case 2, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at higher magnification (×20). This view reveals a hypercellular lesion characterized by intraepidermal and dermal proliferation of atypical, nonmaturing melanocytes.

Histopathology (H&E stain, original magnification ×20) showing extensive regression in a melanocytic lesion, corresponding to a black-blue blotch seen in dermoscopy. The image displays characteristics of regression including nodular aggregates of dermal melanophages, referred to as tumoral melanosis, focal fibrosis, a dense infiltrate of lymphocytes, and an absence of melanocytes. While the residual lesion did not disclose clear-cut features of malignancy, the presence of these regressive features, particularly the tumoral melanosis, combined with clinical observations, strongly suggests a completely regressed melanoma. The pathologist initially reported the lesion displaying characteristics of a 'dysplastic nevus' with a wide area of regression.

Histopathology showing a benign nevus cell aggregate within a lymphatic vessel in the dermis (hematoxylin and eosin, ×40). The aggregate demonstrates morphological features of Type A, B, and C nevus cells, consistent with maturation. Type A nevus cells are typically found in the upper dermis, Type B cells (distinctly smaller) in the mid-dermis, and Type C cells (elongated, spindle-shaped) in the lower dermis. These nevus cell clusters are considered incidental intralymphatic benign emboli, with no evidence of dysplastic change or malignancy observed.

Histopathology showing a benign nevus cell aggregate within a lymphatic vessel in the dermis (hematoxylin and eosin, ×100). The aggregate demonstrates morphological features of Type A, B, and C nevus cells, illustrating a decrease in cell size and melanization, and progression from nests to cords to more neuroidal spindle cells with dermal descent, which is referred to as maturation. These nevus cell clusters are considered incidental intralymphatic benign emboli, with no evidence of dysplastic change or malignancy observed.

Histopathology showing an intralymphatic nevus (hematoxylin and eosin, ×400). The nevus cell clusters, composed of benign cells, are located within a lymphatic vessel. This aggregate is lined by flattened endothelial cells, consistent with intralymphatic nevus cell emboli. No mitotic figures, dysplastic changes, or malignancy were observed.

Histopathology showing benign intralymphatic nevus cell emboli identified within a lymphatic vessel (hematoxylin and eosin, ×400). The vessel is lined by flat endothelial cells, indicated by a solid blue arrow. The presence of these aggregates within the lymphatic channel is consistent with incidental intralymphatic nevus cell emboli. No evidence of dysplastic change or malignancy was observed.

Histopathologic photomicrograph showing cystic dilatation filled with keratin flakes and squamous metaplasia. This feature was observed during the histopathologic examination of a well-encapsulated lesion, which was diagnosed as an apocrine variant of benign chondroid syringoma (CS) with squamous metaplasia. (Hematoxylin and eosin stain, original magnification ×40)

Photomicrograph showing histopathological features of a well-encapsulated lesion, diagnosed as an apocrine variant of benign chondroid syringoma (CS) with squamous metaplasia. The image reveals benign epithelial cells arranged in nests, sheets, and irregular tubuloalveolar/tubuloductular structures. These epithelial components are embedded in a prominent myxoid to chondroid stroma, which includes mucoid faint basophilic areas with scattered stromal cells surrounded by a halo, resembling pseudocartilage. The tissue is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification ×10.

Photomicrograph showing a well-circumscribed lesion with a prominent peripheral capsule, as revealed by histopathologic examination. This macroscopic view of the tissue specimen highlights the encapsulation, which is a key feature contributing to the diagnosis of an apocrine variant of benign chondroid syringoma with squamous metaplasia. (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, original magnification ×10)

Photomicrograph showing an irregular tubulocystic structure, part of a well-encapsulated lesion diagnosed as an apocrine variant of benign CS with squamous metaplasia. The structure is lined by double rows of benign epithelial cells, with adjacent stromal hyalinization. The lesion generally presented with benign epithelial cells arranged in the form of sheets, nests, and tubuloductular structures within a prominent chondroid and myxoid stroma. (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, original magnification ×40)

H&E-stained histopathology microphotograph from the patient's amputation demonstrating melanoma in situ with regression. This image is part of the histological analysis that identified four distinct melanomas from the amputation.

H&E-stained histopathology microphotograph from the patient's amputation demonstrating melanoma in situ. This image is part of the histological analysis that identified four distinct melanomas from the amputation.

H&E-stained histopathology microphotograph from the patient's amputation demonstrating melanoma in situ. This image is part of the histological analysis that identified four distinct melanomas from the amputation.

H&E-stained histopathology microphotograph from the patient's amputation demonstrating invasive melanoma with a Breslow thickness of 1 mm. This image is part of the histological analysis that identified four distinct melanomas from the amputation.
Histologic examination revealing malignant pilomatricoma characterized by infiltrative borders, atypical cytologic features, and a high mitotic rate (H&E, ×200).

Hematoxylin and eosin stain of an excisional biopsy at 20x magnification, revealing a relatively symmetric compound melanocytic proliferation (nevus) involving the base of the epidermis and superficial dermis. The junctional component of the nevus is relatively symmetric and contains large melanocytes with abundant cytoplasm and nucleoli. In the epidermis, melanocytes are distributed primarily as nests at the tips and sides of the rete ridges with some clefting from the overlying epidermis and discohesion among melanocytes within the nests. An inflammatory response was not identified.

Hematoxylin and eosin stain of the biopsy at 40x magnification, showing most of the epidermal melanocytes confined to the epidermal base. There was only focal intra-epidermal ascent of the melanocytes identified. Nests appeared to predominate over single cells, without a significant upwards scatter.

Hematoxylin and eosin stain of the biopsy at 100x magnification, showing no intra-epidermal ascent of melanocytes identified in this photograph. Nests appeared to predominate over single cells, without a significant upwards scatter. The dermal melanocytes showed maturation to the base of the lesions.

Hematoxylin and eosin stain of the biopsy at 400x magnification, showing some of the melanocytes that are multinucleate and exhibit pleomorphism of nuclear size variation (>4x variation). Occasional nucleoli and mitoses were identified. Single cells are plump epithelioid cells with amphophilic to eosinophilic cytoplasm and nuclei; some had prominent nucleoli, and others had marked nuclear hyperchromasia and smudging. In the dermis, similar melanocytes are present with poor maturation upon descent, revealing prominent nuclear atypia with scattered mitotic figures. Asymmetrical melanin pigmentation of the dermal component and a mild, asymmetric lymphocytic infiltrate were also noted.

Histopathology showing a papillaroid arrangement of polygonal tumor cells, characterized by hyperchromatic nuclei and scant intracytoplasmic pigment in most of the areas. The main image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). An inset within panel (a) further highlights the melanin pigment using a Masson–Fontana stain.
Histopathology showing a focus with intracytoplasmic brownish-black pigment present within macrophages and possibly a few tumor cells. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Histopathology showing dilated, tortuous, and vertically oriented blood vessels within the dermal papillae. These findings were observed during a histopathological examination that led to the diagnosis of Clear cell acanthoma. Hematoxylin-eosin staining, 10x magnification.

Histopathology of skin revealing parakeratosis and neutrophils distributed throughout the epidermis and stratum corneum, consistent with the diagnosis of Clear cell acanthoma. Hematoxylin-eosin staining, 20x magnification.
Histopathology of the skin demonstrating psoriasiform hyperplasia, as revealed by histopathological examination. Hematoxylin-eosin (H&E) staining, 4x magnification.

Histopathological examination of skin showing an intraepithelial tumor proliferation characterized by clear keratinocytes. This finding is consistent with a diagnosis of Clear cell acanthoma. Hematoxylin-eosin staining, 20x magnification.
Histopathology showing dermal proliferation of spindle cells organized in fascicles with a storiform pattern or in nests, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). Original magnification, ×10.

Histopathology showing a dense granulomatous infiltrate present in the superficial and mid dermis. Numerous tattoo pigments are visible within the infiltrate. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H/E), original magnification ×20.
Histopathology showing well-delimited nonnecrotizing granulomas containing tattoo pigments. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H/E), original magnification ×100.

Histopathology of nonnecrotizing granulomas, with tattoo pigments localized in both intra- and extracellular spaces. Some foreign-body giant multinucleated cells are also observed. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H/E), original magnification ×100.

Histopathology image showing the distinctive microstructural architecture of medulloepithelioma, characterized by tubules and nests of basophilic neoplastic cells (black arrow). These neuroepithelial tubules are a feature highly specific to medulloepithelioma, resembling the medullary epithelium of the developing neurosensory retina. The cells are surrounded by a loose, mucopolysaccharide-rich matrix, which corresponds to the hyaluronic acid-rich hypocellular stroma characteristic of medulloepithelioma, akin to the vitreous. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at 2.5x magnification.
Microscopic examination (Hematoxylin and Eosin, magnification ×400) showing atypical melanocytes with a brown pigment in the cytoplasm, as observed in 2013.
Microscopic examination (Hematoxylin and Eosin, magnification ×400) showing pleomorphic, multinucleated giant cells with no pigment in the cytoplasm, as observed in 2018.

Histopathology by Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain (original magnification ×200) showing a cystic cavity. The cavity is lined externally by normal skin and internally by pseudostratified columnar epithelium, which in some areas features apical mucin. Histopathological examination of the excised cyst showed the lamina propria had mild chronic inflammatory infiltrates, and no features of dysplasia or malignancy were noted. The cyst had released mucinous content upon rupture during excision.

Histopathology by Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain (original magnification ×400) showing the cyst wall. The wall is lined partly by ciliated pseudostratified columnar epithelium and partly by columnar epithelium, including areas with apical mucin. The lamina propria of the cyst wall exhibits mild chronic inflammatory infiltrates. Histopathological examination of the excised cyst, which had released mucinous content upon rupture, showed no features of dysplasia or malignancy.

Histopathology of the dermis showing hypercellular epithelioid melanocytes and variable sized vessels (hematoxylin and eosin [H&E] stain, ×200 magnification). An inlet at higher magnification (×400) reveals cohesive clusters of uniform round tumor cells with scant cytoplasm, minimal nuclear pleomorphism, and indistinct nucleoli (H&E stain).

Hematoxylin and eosin-stained section showing the pathology features of an atrophic dermatofibroma from a 3-mm punch biopsy taken from the central portion of a depressed lesion on the left shoulder of a 45-year-old Caucasian man. At low magnification (×2), the image reveals epidermal acanthosis, indicated between blue arrows, along with basal layer hyperpigmentation, indicated by black arrows. There is also atrophy of the dermis. This represents a benign fibrohistiocytic lesion.

Hematoxylin and eosin-stained section showing the pathology features of an atrophic dermatofibroma from a 3-mm punch biopsy taken from the central portion of a depressed lesion on the left shoulder of a 45-year-old Caucasian man. At higher magnification (×4), the image reveals epidermal acanthosis, indicated between blue arrows, along with basal layer hyperpigmentation, indicated by black arrows. There is atrophy of the dermis, and the dermal tumor shows an increased number of fibroblasts with trapped collagen bundles in the periphery. This represents a benign fibrohistiocytic lesion.

Microscopic image of vulvar malignant melanoma, from a 58-year-old female presenting with a gray-white irregular mass on the right labia minora. Histologic examination of the vulvar tissue revealed a large number of tumor cells containing dark-brown intracellular pigment. The patient's tumor synchronously involved the vulva and uterine cervix. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), original magnification ×100.

Microscopic image of cervical malignant melanoma, from a 58-year-old female presenting with a darkly pigmented mass involving the posterior lip of the cervix. Histologic examination of the cervical tissue revealed a large number of tumor cells containing dark-brown intracellular pigment. The patient's tumor synchronously involved the vulva and uterine cervix. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), original magnification ×100.

Histopathology of a paratracheal or perihilar lymph node, stained with Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) and viewed at ×100 magnification. The image shows a poorly differentiated malignant neoplastic lesion constituted by pleomorphic cells, atypical nuclei with open chromatin, nuclear pseudo-inclusions, and mitosis. This lesion represents melanoma metastasis from an occult primary cancer, as diagnosed post-mortem.

Histopathology of a paratracheal or perihilar lymph node, stained with Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) and viewed at ×150 magnification. The image shows a poorly differentiated malignant neoplastic lesion constituted by pleomorphic cells, atypical nuclei with open chromatin, nuclear pseudo-inclusions, and mitosis. This lesion represents melanoma metastasis from an occult primary cancer, as diagnosed post-mortem.
Histopathology of an axillary ganglion, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), at ×50 magnification, showing a high-grade and poorly differentiated malignancy.

Histopathology of an axillary ganglion, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), at ×100 magnification, showing a poorly differentiated malignant neoplastic lesion. The lesion is constituted by pleomorphic cells, atypical nuclei with open chromatin, nuclear pseudo-inclusions, and mitosis.

Histopathological examination of a right medial rectus muscle biopsy, showing metastatic malignant melanoma. Hematoxylin and eosin stain at 200X magnification reveals diffusely infiltrative nested malignant cells, some with intracytoplasmic brown pigment. This metastatic melanoma was noted as a dark brown vascular lesion within the muscle and was found to have a somatic mutation in the GNA11 gene, but not a sensitizing BRAF mutation.

Histopathological examination of a right medial rectus muscle biopsy, showing metastatic malignant melanoma. Hematoxylin and eosin stain at 600X magnification reveals abnormal plump spindle and epithelioid cells, displaying nuclear pleomorphism with some nuclei bearing inclusions and others showing intracytoplasmic pigment, consistent with melanoma cells. This metastatic melanoma was noted as a dark brown vascular lesion within the muscle and was found to have a somatic mutation in the GNA11 gene, but not a sensitizing BRAF mutation.
Histopathology showing a pseudoglandular epithelioid proliferation. (magnification ×10, hematoxylin and eosin stain).

Pathological features of a sebaceoma, a benign tumor characterized by sebaceous cell differentiation, are displayed at panoramic magnification (×20). The image shows a regularly contoured epithelial neoplasia arranged in a “v” shape with the apex pointing toward the depth. There is acanthosis on the left side and a predominance of dermal masses on the right side, conferring an intrinsic asymmetry, which is an unusual characteristic for this type of proliferation, as sebaceomas typically exhibit symmetry and a greater vertical axis. The sebaceoma is constituted by masses located in the dermis, which have regular shapes and sizes, are predominantly rounded or oval, and are immersed in collagenized stroma. Clusters of epithelial cells with pale cytoplasm are visible permeating these masses, which are representative of mature sebocytes, indicating sebaceous differentiation. The tumor is composed of both undifferentiated cells and cells with varying degrees of sebaceous differentiation. The absence of peripheral palisade and clefts between the aggregates and the stroma further distinguishes this sebaceoma from basal cell carcinomas with sebaceous differentiation. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin.

Histopathology showing pathological features of sebaceoma, a benign neoplasm characterized by advanced differentiation. The image provides a detailed view of an epithelial mass arranged in the dermis. It highlights the predominance of vesicle-like epithelial cells with scarce cytoplasm, identified as immature sebocytes. These are less permeated by pale cytoplasm cells containing lipid vacuoles, some with indented nuclei, which are characteristic of mature sebocytes. The cells are randomly arranged and associated with ducts. A notable feature is the absence of palisading at the periphery of the masses. The presence of mature sebocytes and advanced differentiation supports its benign nature, contrasting with malignant neoplasms which typically show lower degrees of differentiation. (Hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification ×200).

Histological examination of the left leg, showing fibrosis and lymphocytes infiltration around blood vessels and among collagen fibers in the dermis. Stained with Hematoxylin-eosin (HE). Original magnification, ×40.

Histological examination of the left leg, showing fibrosis and lymphocytes infiltration around blood vessels and among collagen fibers in the dermis. Stained with Hematoxylin-eosin (HE). Original magnification, ×100.

Histological examination of the hyperkeratotic pigmented lesion in the left ankle, showing hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, papillomatosis, an increased number of melanocytes in the basal layer, and dermal fibrosis. Stained with Hematoxylin-eosin (HE). Original magnification, ×40.

Histopathology of the ovarian cystic mass shows that most of the mass is comprised of mature dermoid components, a finding consistent with the origin of the malignant melanoma from a mature cystic teratoma of the ovary. (H&E stain, original magnification × 100).

Histopathology of the brownish-black solid mass within the ovarian cyst reveals infiltrating nests of pleomorphic cells with prominent nucleoli and black pigments.
