Junctional activity is also present. These features are characteristic of malignant melanoma originating from the mature cystic teratoma of the ovary, with cytomorphologic features including prominent nucleoli. (H&E stain, original magnification × 400).
Histopathology showing a melanocytosis component from the enucleated right eyeball, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at ×400 magnification.

Histopathology showing the larger inferior tumor of two distinct melanomas, composed of pigmented epithelioid melanoma cells. This tumor is seen arising in an area of choroidal melanocytosis from the enucleated right eyeball, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at ×400 magnification.

Histopathology illustrating the base continuity with a steep indentation between two distinct melanomas, composed of pigmented epithelioid melanoma cells, from the enucleated right eyeball. The section is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at ×200 magnification.

Low magnification photomicrograph of an optic disk melanocytoma, stained with hematoxylin-eosin (original magnification 3x10). Histopathologically, optic disk melanocytoma is characterized as an intensely pigmented mass that occupies the optic disk and extends for a variable distance into the optic disk itself, as depicted here. The cells typically exhibit intense cytoplasmic pigmentation, a low nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio, and uniform cell and nuclear size, although copious cytoplasmic pigment can often obscure fine nuclear and cellular details.

Histopathology of an eccrine poroma, presenting as a well-circumscribed polypoid exophytic tumor. The tumor is composed of solid formations of monomorphous cuboidal cells showing ductal differentiation and a well vascularized fibrous stroma. No cellular atypia or atypical mitoses are observed. Hematoxylin and eosin (HE) stain, original magnification x 2.

Histopathological analysis of a superficial skin resection from a 69-year-old African Caribbean woman. The image, stained with hematoxylin-eosin at original magnification x 20, shows numerous cysts filled with keratin in the dermis. This finding is characteristic of nevus comedonicus, which was diagnosed in the patient who presented with long-standing, extensive, peri-orbital cutaneous lesions described as keratotic and hyperpigmented multiple papules.

Horizontal histological section of the debulking for a basal cell carcinoma, corresponding to the surface incision, showing lateral margin involvement highlighted by a red rectangle. Stained with hematoxylin-eosin at ×20 magnification.

Horizontal histological section of the debulking for a basal cell carcinoma, corresponding to the deepest incision, showing lateral margin involvement highlighted by a red rectangle. Stained with hematoxylin-eosin at ×20 magnification.

Microscopic view of a horizontal histological incision showing a compromised margin. This image is part of a case illustrating the step-by-step management of basal cell carcinoma located in the left malar region. Stained with hematoxylin-eosin (H&E) at ×100 magnification.

Histopathologic analysis of melanoacanthoma showing a hyperplastic epidermis, hyperkeratosis, and intense acanthosis. These findings are consistent with melanoacanthoma. Stained with Hematoxylin & eosin; original magnification: x40.

Histopathologic analysis of melanoacanthoma showing dendritic melanocytes intermingled with keratinocytes throughout the lesion. These findings are consistent with melanoacanthoma. Stained with Hematoxylin & eosin; original magnification: x400.

Histology of hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer (HLRCC)-associated renal cell carcinoma (RCC) from a 57-year-old man, diagnosed by genetic testing. HLRCC is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by a germline mutation in fumarate hydratase (FH), an enzyme involved in the tricarboxylic acid cycle. The image shows oncocytic tumor cells arranged in a solid sheet-like pattern. This rare, low-grade oncocytic morphology in HLRCC-associated RCC can be reminiscent of SDH-deficient RCC. The tumor cells were indistinguishable from oncocytomas by H&E staining alone, highlighting the challenges in morphological differential diagnosis.

Histology of SDH-deficient renal cell carcinoma (RCC) from a 40-year-old man, diagnosed by genetic testing. This RCC type develops in individuals with germline mutations in the SDHB gene. SDH subunits (SDHA-D) are enzymes involved in the tricarboxylic acid cycle. The image displays oncocytic tumor cells arranged in a solid sheet-like pattern. SDH-deficient RCC is generally regarded as low-grade. The tumor cells were indistinguishable from oncocytomas by H&E staining alone, demonstrating the need for genetic testing or specific immunohistochemical markers for accurate diagnosis and differentiation from other oncocytic tumors.

Histopathology showing a tumor with two distinct types of cells: large cells characterized by abundant cytoplasm, a round vesicular nucleus, and brown pigment; and small cells with scanty cytoplasm and hyperchromatic round nuclei (hematoxylin and eosin stain, 40x magnification).
Histopathology image showing tumor cells arranged in an alveolar pattern, separated by fibrovascular stroma. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 10x magnification.

Histopathology showing malignant melanoma that had invaded the right lower lobe. The tumor cells exhibit large nuclei with high nuclear/cytoplasmic ratios, large and distinct nucleoli, and melanin particles in their cytoplasm. Stained with Hematoxylin and eosin (HE).

Histopathology showing malignant melanoma that had invaded the right lower lobe. The tumor cells exhibit large nuclei with high nuclear/cytoplasmic ratios, large and distinct nucleoli, and melanin particles in their cytoplasm. Stained with Hematoxylin and eosin (HE).

Histopathology showing malignant melanoma exhibiting intraepithelial spread into a bronchus. The tumor cells have large nuclei with high nuclear/cytoplasmic ratios, large and distinct nucleoli, and melanin particles in their cytoplasm. Stained with Hematoxylin and eosin (HE).

Histopathology of a longitudinal biopsy of subungual in situ melanoma, stained with hematoxylin-eosin. This image reveals the microscopic features of in situ melanoma, characterized by the presence of atypical melanocytes confined to the epidermal layer without evidence of dermal invasion. The findings confirm the diagnosis suggested by the clinical signs of longitudinal melanonychia and Hutchinson’s sign.

Longitudinal nail biopsy of a nail matrix lentigo, stained with hematoxylin-eosin. This image shows that melanocytes are not readily observed with this staining method. Nail matrix lentigo is a benign melanocytic hyperplasia where melanocytes proliferate without forming nests, located mainly in the basal layer of the nail matrix epithelium, and typically present fine melanin granules with no cytological atypia. Melanophages may also be observed in the dermis.

Histopathology showing a symmetrical and well-circumscribed compound melanocytic proliferation, arranged in epithelioid cell nests. This proliferation, consistent with eruptive disseminated Spitz nevi, is composed of epithelioid cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm arranged in groups or singly in the dermis and dermo-epidermal junction. No significant cytological atypia or mitosis were observed. Stained with Hematoxylin & eosin at ×40 magnification.

Histopathology showing a symmetrical and well-circumscribed compound melanocytic proliferation, arranged in epithelioid cell nests. This proliferation, consistent with eruptive disseminated Spitz nevi, is composed of epithelioid cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm arranged in groups or singly in the dermis and dermo-epidermal junction. No significant cytological atypia or mitosis were observed. Stained with Hematoxylin & eosin at ×100 magnification.

High magnification histopathology showing epithelioid melanocytes with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, a vesicular nucleus, and a prominent nucleolus, characteristic of eruptive disseminated Spitz nevi. No significant cytological atypia or mitosis were observed in these cells. Stained with Hematoxylin & eosin at ×400 magnification.

Pathological section biopsy (magnification 100x) showing infiltration by invasive pulmonary adenocarcinoma cells from the right middle lobe of the lung, exhibiting an acinar and papillary mixed type. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E).
Photomicrograph showing basal cell carcinoma with actinic damage. The tissue is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin, viewed at ×40 magnification.

Gross appearance and histopathology of a smooth cutaneous granular cell tumor. Grossly, it presents as a 0.8-cm-sized, pinkish mass with a well-formed capsule. Microscopically, the tumor is covered by apparently normal epidermis. In the subcutaneous fat layer, there are irregular, infiltrating borders and irregular entrapment of adipocytes by the granular cells (arrows). Stained with hematoxylin–eosin, magnification ×10.

Histopathology of a smooth cutaneous granular cell tumor, stained with hematoxylin–eosin, showing tumor cells with abundant granular eosinophilic cytoplasm and round to oval nuclei. The tumor is covered by apparently normal epidermis. In the subcutaneous fat layer, there are irregular, infiltrating borders and irregular entrapment of adipocytes by the granular cells. (Magnification not specified for this panel, but part of a figure describing the same tumor at various magnifications including ×10, ×100, and ×200).

Histopathology of a smooth cutaneous granular cell tumor, stained with hematoxylin–eosin, showing eosinophilic ovoid bodies surrounded by a clear halo (arrowheads). The tumor cells also display abundant granular eosinophilic cytoplasm and round to oval nuclei. The tumor is covered by apparently normal epidermis, and granular cells exhibit irregular infiltration and entrapment of adipocytes in the subcutaneous fat layer. Magnification ×100 and ×200.

Histopathology from Case 2, a 43-year-old male presenting with longitudinal melanoníquia. The image shows a junctional nest of pigmented melanocytic cells in relation to epithelial islets located in the superficial connective tissue of the nail bed. These findings are consistent with a melanocytic nevus in association with follicular inclusions. Stained with Hematoxylin & eosin (H&E) at ×400 magnification.

Histopathology from Case 1, a 63-year-old male presenting with a 3 mm wide longitudinal melanonychia in the central portion of the left hallux with 8 months evolution. Dermoscopy revealed irregular bands of bluish gray and light brown pigmentation affecting the entire length of the nail plate. The image shows epithelial islets with keratinization of their central portion in variable degree, located in the connective tissue of the nail bed. These histological findings are identified as subungual follicular inclusions in association with melanonychia, without concomitant melanocytic lesion. Stained with Hematoxylin & eosin, ×400 magnification.

Histopathology at higher power showing a deep dermal tumor composed of sheets of densely arranged undifferentiated atypical cells, consistent with metastatic melanoma. The cells exhibit sebo-cyte-like morphology, with scalloped nuclei and 'bubbly' cytoplasm resembling sebaceous cells, and contain melanin pigment. H&E staining.

Histopathology showing a deep dermal tumor composed of sheets of densely arranged, undifferentiated atypical cells, consistent with a dermal proliferation. This image is from a skin biopsy that led to a diagnosis of metastatic melanoma. H&E staining.

Histopathology of an epithelioid schwannoma. The image shows the characteristic histological features of epithelioid schwannoma, which is a well-circumscribed and encapsulated tumor composed of bland epithelioid or polygonal Schwann cells. These tumor cells are arranged in distinctive sheets and nests. Occasional nuclear pseudoinclusions may be present, and the stroma can appear myxoid or hyalinized. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification 200×.

Histopathology of epithelioid hemangioendothelioma. The tumor is composed of relatively bland epithelioid cells arranged in trabecular or cord-like patterns within a variably myxohyaline stroma. Occasional intracytoplasmic vacuoles are present. (H&E stain, original magnification 200×).

Histopathology of classic-type epithelioid sarcoma. The tumor is composed of sheets of atypical epithelioid cells, which are characterized by abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm and vesicular nuclei. These cells are arranged in vague nodules and exhibit prominent central necrosis. Histologically, epithelioid sarcomas can also present with plump spindle-shaped cells and may show myxohyaline changes. This image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at 100x original magnification.

Histopathology of Myxoinflammatory fibroblastic sarcoma. A poorly defined lesion in the dermis shows prominent inflammatory cell infiltrates. The tumor is composed of myxohyaline and collagenous zones, with a multinodular appearance, and contains scattered mono- or multinucleated pleomorphic cells. These cells are variable, atypical, spindle to epithelioid tumor cells, some of which are large and pleomorphic with viral inclusion-like nucleoli. (H&E stain, original magnification 40×).

Histopathology of Myxoinflammatory fibroblastic sarcoma. A higher magnification view reveals occasional pleomorphic multinucleated giant cells with prominent viral inclusion-like nucleoli, which can resemble Reed-Sternberg-like cells, seen in the background of prominent inflammatory cell infiltrates. The overall tumor composition includes myxohyaline and collagenous zones with variable, atypical, spindle to epithelioid tumor cells. (H&E stain, original magnification 200×).

Histopathology of a distinctive dermal clear cell mesenchymal neoplasm. At scanning magnification (10×), the image shows a well-circumscribed, solitary tumor located in the dermis and subcutaneous tissue. Histologically, this tumor presents as a dermal-based nodular proliferation composed of large polygonal cells with abundant clear cytoplasm and vesicular nuclei. The tumor cells are typically arranged in sheets and may exhibit marked atypia with hyperchromatic nuclei; mitotic activity is rare. Immunohistochemically, these tumor cells are known to be positive for NKI-C3 (CD63) and CD68, but negative for melanocytic and epithelial markers. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Histopathology of a distinctive dermal clear cell mesenchymal neoplasm, displaying detailed cellular morphology at higher magnification (200×). The tumor cells are epithelioid or polygonal, characterized by abundant clear cytoplasm and vesicular nuclei, and are arranged in a sheet-like pattern. These cells form a dermal-based nodular proliferation and may show marked atypia with hyperchromatic nuclei, while mitotic activity is rare. Immunohistochemically, these tumor cells are positive for NKI-C3 (CD63) and CD68, but negative for melanocytic and epithelial markers. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Histopathology of a cutaneous PEComa, showing a nested architecture. The tumor is composed of epithelioid cells with abundant clear or granular eosinophilic cytoplasm and round to oval nuclei. The tumor cells are arranged in nested, trabecular, or sheet patterns, with thin-walled capillary vessels present between nests. (H&E stain, original magnification 100×).

Histopathology of myoepithelial carcinoma. The tumor is well-circumscribed and lobulated. The tumor cells exhibit a cohesive epithelioid appearance with moderate to severe nuclear atypia, nuclear pleomorphism, and prominent nucleoli, which are reliable characteristics of myoepithelial carcinoma of soft tissue. The tumor may also be composed of spindle, plasmacytoid, or clear cells, often with a myxoid or hyalinized stroma. Stained with H&E, original magnification 100×.

Cellular neurothekeoma, shown at lower power. Histologically, this micronodular or lobulated dermal neoplasm displays a nested growth pattern where tumor cells are arranged in nests, separated by dense fibrous septa composed of sclerotic collagen. The tumor is typically composed of epithelioid to spindle-shaped cells. This is a hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained image.

Cellular neurothekeoma, shown at higher power. This micronodular or lobulated dermal neoplasm is composed of epithelioid tumor cells that exhibit pale eosinophilic cytoplasm and typically have vesicular nuclei. Mild nuclear atypia is present, noting that significant cytologic atypia with marked nuclear atypia and pleomorphism can be observed in some cases. This is a hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained image.

Histopathology of ectopic meningioma showing tumor cells, identified as epithelioid meningothelial cells, arranged in a characteristic whorling or nesting pattern with fibromyxoid stroma. Histologically, ectopic meningiomas resemble primary meningiomas of the central nervous system and can be of any WHO grade (I-III), though benign tumors are most common. Structures resembling psammoma bodies may also be seen. (H&E stain, original magnification 100×).

Histopathology of a cellular epithelioid hemangioma, showing a tumor with epithelioid endothelial cells arranged in a solid pattern. These epithelioid endothelial cells typically have vesicular nuclei and abundant eosinophilic or amphophilic cytoplasm, often forming nest or sheet-like aggregates. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Histopathology showing predominantly single intraepidermal melanocytes (highlighted by a rectangle) in patient #2. This feature represents a significant histomorphological difference compared to patient #1, who exhibited predominantly nested melanocytes. The image is stained with hematoxylin-eosin at an original magnification of ×40.

Histopathology showing predominantly small pigment granules (highlighted by a rectangle) and obvious pleomorphism of the nucleolus and cytoplasmic abundance (indicated by an arrow) in patient #1. These features, including small pigment granules and obvious cytologic atypia, are significant histomorphological differences compared to patient #2. The image is stained with hematoxylin-eosin at an original magnification of ×400.

Histopathology showing predominantly thick pigment granules (highlighted by a rectangle) and no obvious cytologic atypia in patient #2. These features, including thick pigment granules and absence of obvious cytologic atypia, are significant histomorphological differences compared to patient #1. The image is stained with hematoxylin-eosin at an original magnification of ×400.

Histopathology illustrating epidermal thickness and fiber proliferation in patient #1. These features were more frequently observed in patient #1. The image is stained with hematoxylin-eosin at an original magnification of ×100.

Histopathology showing a neoplasm formed by the proliferation of atypical cells. These cells contain granular brown pigment, similar to melanin, and exhibit hyperchromatic, enlarged central nuclei with evident nucleoli, and frequent atypical mitoses. The neoplasm preferentially infiltrates the meningeal but also the adjacent brain parenchyma, amid areas of necrosis and hemorrhage (Hematoxylin & eosin, ×40 magnification).
Photomicrograph showing malignant melanoma with tumor cells arranged in nests and cords. Stained with Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), original magnification × 100.

Photomicrograph of malignant melanoma showing tumor cells with pleomorphic nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and intracytoplasmic melanin pigment. Stained with Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), original magnification × 400.

Photomicrograph of hidradenocarcinoma showing tumor cells (indicated by a white arrow) within a fibrovascular collagenous stroma (indicated by a black arrow). Stained with Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), original magnification × 40.

Photomicrograph of hidradenocarcinoma showing tumor cells arranged in sheets and areas of tumor necrosis (indicated by a black arrow). Stained with Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), original magnification × 40.

Photomicrograph showing well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). The image displays tumor cells with characteristic keratin pearls (indicated by the black arrow). Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at × 100 magnification.

Photomicrograph showing basal cell carcinoma, displaying a clefting artifact (indicated by the black arrow) and peripheral palisading of tumor cells (indicated by the arrow head). Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at × 400 magnification.

Photomicrograph showing basal cell carcinoma, displaying a clefting artifact (indicated by the black arrow) and peripheral palisading of tumor cells (indicated by the arrow head). Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at × 400 magnification.
Photomicrograph showing basosquamous carcinoma, with specific areas of squamous differentiation highlighted by the black arrow. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at × 100 magnification.

Photomicrograph of a Malignant proliferating trichilemmal tumor (MPTT) showing malignant squamous epithelium with abrupt (trichilemmal) keratinization, stained with Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at ×100 magnification.

Photomicrograph of a Malignant proliferating trichilemmal tumor (MPTT) showing malignant squamous epithelium with abrupt (trichilemmal) keratinization, stained with Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at ×400 magnification.
Photomicrograph of a Malignant proliferating trichilemmal tumor (MPTT) showing malignant spindle cells with marked pleomorphism, stained with Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at ×400 magnification.

Photomicrograph showing fibrosarcomatous dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP) characterized by densely packed spindle cells located in the dermis. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) and captured at × 40 magnification.

Photomicrograph showing fibrosarcomatous dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP) where tumor cells are arranged in intersecting fascicles and bundles, exhibiting a storiform pattern. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) and captured at × 100 magnification.

Histopathology of dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP) in an early non-protuberant stage I, presenting as a dermal plaque. The image shows elongated spindle cells loosely scattered in the upper dermis without involving the grenz zone. DFSP is derived from fibroblasts in the dermis and can infiltrate subcutaneous tissues. (Hematoxylin and eosin (HE) stain, 40 × magnification).

Histopathology of dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP) in a protuberant lesion (stage II or later). The image shows dense, uniformly monomorphous spindle cells arranged in a characteristic storiform (pinwheel-like) pattern. These spindle cells, found in the subcutaneous and dermal layers, typically exhibit little atypia and mitotic activity. Their nuclei are elongated with mild hyperchromasia, small to inconspicuous nucleoli, and low to moderate quantities of cytoplasm. (Hematoxylin and eosin (HE) stain, 100 × magnification).

Histopathology of dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP) showing characteristic infiltration. The image depicts spindle cells infiltrating into surrounding fatty tissues, forming a distinct honeycomb-like structure. This pattern of infiltration into subcutaneous adipose tissue can pose a challenge in determining the true extent of the tumor tissue. (Hematoxylin and eosin (HE) stain, 40 × magnification).

Histopathology of the myxoid variant of dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP). The image displays spindle cells embedded within an abundant myxoid stroma, representing one of the multiple histological variants of DFSP. These variants reflect morphologic heterogeneity associated with spindle cell differentiation during tumor development. (Hematoxylin and eosin (HE) stain, 100 × magnification).

Histopathology of the giant cell variant of dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP). The image reveals polymorphic and giant cells admixed with typical spindle cells. This is one of the histological variants of DFSP, which, along with others, reflects the morphologic heterogeneity during tumor development. (Hematoxylin and eosin (HE) stain, 100 × magnification).

Histopathology of the sclerotic variant of dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP). The image shows less than 50% of spindle cells within a hypocellular collagenous stroma, characteristic of this variant. The sclerotic variant is one of several histological subtypes of DFSP, which demonstrates morphological heterogeneity. (Hematoxylin and eosin (HE) stain, 100 × magnification).

Histopathology showing a fibrosarcomatous (FS) component of dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP). The image highlights a transition from classic DFSP (upper left part) to the FS component (right lower part). The FS component is characterized by increased atypia of cellularity, hyperchromasia, and mitotic activity. FS-DFSP features atypical spindle cells with significantly increased mitotic activity, often arranged in a herringbone pattern, and is considered an intermediate-grade sarcoma with higher risks of local recurrence and metastasis compared to classic DFSP. (Hematoxylin and eosin (HE) stain, 100 × magnification).
Histopathology showing dermatofibroma, characterized by interlacing fascicles of spindle-shaped fibroblasts and histiocytic cells mixed with collagens. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE).

Histopathology showing schwannoma, characterized by wavy hyperchromatic spindle cells arranged in palisades (Antoni A, upper part) and myxoid hypocellular components (Antoni B, lower part). Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE).
Histopathology showing neurofibroma, characterized by bland serpentine spindle-shaped cells and shredded carrot collagens. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE).
Histopathology showing neurofibroma, characterized by mast cells and lymphocytes interspersed among the spindle cells and tumor stroma. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE).
Histopathology showing spindle cell lipoma, characterized by bland spindle cells without matured lipocytes embedded in ropey/refractile collagen bundles. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE).
Histopathology showing melanoma, characterized by spindle-shaped cells with light scattered pigments. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE).

Histopathology from a biopsy taken from a comedonal lesion over the back of a 30-year-old female patient. The patient presented with scattered comedo-like lesions over the upper back, chest, axillae, cubital fossae, and buttocks, alongside progressive pigmentation and other dermatological symptoms. The image reveals a dilated follicular infundibulum filled with keratin and sebum debris, along with characteristic antler-like rete ridges and increased basal melanin pigmentation, suggestive of follicular Dowling–Degos disease (DDD). Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, magnification ×40.

Histopathology from a pigmented lesion over the axilla, taken from a 30-year-old female who presented with progressive reticular pigmentation and dark-brown macules in areas including the axillae. The image reveals long, narrow, branched rete ridges, giving an ”antler-like” appearance, along with dilated follicles containing cysts, and increased basal melanin pigmentation. These findings are suggestive of Dowling–Degos disease (DDD). The overall diagnosis for the patient was follicular DDD with hidradenitis suppurativa. (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, ×100 magnification).

Histopathology of an intraventricular biopsy specimen from a 67-year-old male with a history of cutaneous melanoma, showing metastatic malignant melanoma. The image, stained with H&E at 100x magnification, demonstrates discohesive malignant cells with necrosis and no melanin present. Microscopic examination confirmed metastatic malignant melanoma characterized by large and markedly atypical amelanotic cells forming diffuse sheets with abundant hemorrhage and necrosis.

Histopathology of an intraventricular biopsy specimen from a 67-year-old male with a history of cutaneous melanoma, showing metastatic malignant melanoma. The H&E stained image at 200x magnification highlights the nuclei of the malignant cells, which exhibit intranuclear pseudoinclusions. Microscopic examination revealed metastatic malignant melanoma characterized by large and markedly atypical amelanotic cells.

Histopathology of a malignant PEComa, showing the tumor composed of sheets of epithelioid cells and bundles of spindle cells. The tumor appeared as a high-grade spindle cell sarcoma with an infiltrative growth pattern. Epithelioid foci were also identified, displaying nests of large epithelioid cells surrounded by a delicate vasculature in a radial manner. The tumor cells exhibited large, vesicular nuclei with prominent nucleoli, abundant eosinophilic granular cytoplasm, and striking pleomorphism. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, × 40 magnification.

Histopathology of a malignant PEComa, showing mixed epithelioid and spindle cells exhibiting striking pleomorphism and extensive coagulative necrosis. The tumor cells displayed marked atypia with dispersed chromatin, macronucleoli, large, vesicular nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and an abundant eosinophilic granular cytoplasm. Substantial mitotic activity was also detected, reaching up to 40 mitoses per 10 high-power fields. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, × 100 magnification.

Histopathology of a malignant PEComa, showing mixed epithelioid and spindle cells exhibiting striking pleomorphism and extensive coagulative necrosis. The tumor cells displayed marked atypia with dispersed chromatin, macronucleoli, large, vesicular nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and an abundant eosinophilic granular cytoplasm. Substantial mitotic activity was also detected, reaching up to 40 mitoses per 10 high-power fields. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, × 100 magnification.

Histopathology of conjunctival melanoma in a Chinese woman, stained with Haematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at 2× magnification. This low power view shows an amelanotic conjunctival melanoma. In the study, the majority (80%) of conjunctival melanomas were amelanotic, characterized by minimal or no pigmentation. Mutational analysis of this specific specimen revealed the presence of a BRAF mutation.

Histopathology of conjunctival melanoma in a Chinese woman, stained with Haematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at 10× magnification. The black arrow highlights the pagetoid spread of melanoma cells within the conjunctiva.

Histopathology of conjunctival melanoma in a Chinese woman, stained with Haematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at 40× magnification. The red arrow highlights epithelioid cells with prominent nucleoli, while the blue arrow highlights an atypical mitosis. Epithelioid cells represent a poor prognostic morphology and were commonly seen in 66.7% of conjunctival melanomas in the study.

Histopathology of uveal melanoma in a Malay man, stained with Haematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at 1× magnification. This view shows the uveal melanoma extending from the equator of the globe to the ciliary body.

Histopathology of uveal melanoma in a Malay man, stained with Haematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at 40× magnification. The cellular morphology displays epithelioid cells. This epithelioid cell morphology is associated with a poorer prognosis and was observed in 48% of uveal melanomas in the study.

Histopathology of uveal melanoma in a Malay man, stained with Haematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at 40× magnification. The cellular morphology displays spindle cells. Approximately 51.7% of uveal melanomas in the study exhibited this non-epithelioid spindle cell morphology.

Histopathology showing the presence of micrometastasis (microsatellitosis) of melanoma located deep to the primary tumor. Micrometastasis is defined as nests of tumor cells adjacent or deep to the primary tumor, identified as a discontinuous nest separated from the primary tumor by normal skin. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification ×40.

Histopathology showing the presence of micrometastasis (microsatellitosis) of melanoma located deep to the primary tumor. Micrometastasis is defined as nests of tumor cells adjacent or deep to the primary tumor, identified as a discontinuous nest separated from the primary tumor by normal skin. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification ×100.

Histopathology showing the presence of micrometastasis (microsatellitosis) of melanoma located deep to the primary tumor. Micrometastasis is defined as nests of tumor cells adjacent or deep to the primary tumor, identified as a discontinuous nest separated from the primary tumor by normal skin. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification ×200.

Microscopic examination of an H&E-stained section of the dermis from the right heel, magnified ×200, showing portions of tissue infiltrated by fascicles of focally pigmented spindle cells. These spindle cells exhibit plump nuclei and intracytoplasmic yellow-brown pigment. Mitotic figures were not identified, but nests of nevus cells were noted adjacent to the lesion. There was no overlying epidermis or dermis identified in this histologic section. The differential diagnoses based on these H&E sections included melanoma, dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (Bednar's tumor), and fibromatosis.

Histopathology of lung metastatic melanoma, showing a predominantly spindle cell component. The lesion is composed of elongated spindle cells arranged in a fascicular or storiform pattern. Frequent necroses and hemorrhages are observed. The lesional cells have round to oval nuclei of various sizes with clear chromatin, visible nucleoli, and clear to eosinophilic cytoplasm. Angioinvasion is also present. (H&E stain, 200x magnification).

Histopathology of lung metastatic melanoma, showing an epithelioid cell component with no melanin pigment present. A minor portion of the lesion features a round cell component. The lesional cells have round to oval nuclei of various sizes with clear chromatin, visible nucleoli, and clear to eosinophilic cytoplasm. (H&E stain, 200x magnification).

Histopathology of an initial skin lesion, stained with H&E at 100x magnification, showing the epidermis uninvolved. This image displays spindle and epitheloid nevomelanocytes arranged in junctional and intradermal nests, with cytologic atypia and numerous mitotic activities. The lesion, which was subsequently considered for reclassification as Spitzoid melanoma with subsequent lung metastasis, also shows a pervasive lymphoid infiltrate, and pagetoid spread was not demonstrated.

Histopathology of the initial skin lesion, stained with H&E at 100x magnification, showing an epitheloid cell component with atypical cells infiltrating the dermis and partly the epidermis in a different part of the investigated specimen. Numerous lymphocytes are admixed within the infiltrate. This image, from a lesion subsequently considered for reclassification as Spitzoid melanoma, further illustrates spindle and epitheloid nevomelanocytes arranged in nests, along with cytologic atypia and numerous mitotic activities. A pervasive lymphoid infiltrate is also evident, and pagetoid spread was not demonstrated.

Histopathologic examination of Case 1, a primary cutaneous melanoma with a MAP2K1 in-frame deletion, reveals a polypoid proliferation of melanocytes. This primary tumor exhibits an exophytic nodular component with irregular nested growth at the base and marked asymmetry, along with a slight epidermal collarette. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×20 magnification.

Histopathologic examination of Case 1, a superficial spreading type melanoma with a MAP2K1 in-frame deletion, shows expansile nested growth along the epidermis with associated epidermal effacement. This image demonstrates epidermal involvement, including extension beyond the dermal component, confluent growth along the basal epidermis with rete effacement, and expansile intraepidermal nests. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Histopathologic examination of Case 1, a melanoma with a MAP2K1 in-frame deletion, shows elongated nests in the deep aspect of the dermal component. Dermal components universally consisted of variably sized nodules and nests, with this specific image highlighting elongated nests in some foci. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Histopathologic examination of Case 3, a primary cutaneous melanoma with a MAP2K1 in-frame deletion, presents as a melanocytic tumor with plaque-like and tumorigenic components. This primary tumor also exhibits an exophytic nodular component with irregular nested growth at the base and marked asymmetry. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×200 magnification.

Histopathologic examination of Case 3, a superficial spreading type melanoma with a MAP2K1 in-frame deletion, illustrates the radial growth phase. It is characterized by a confluent proliferation of atypical melanocytes along the basal epidermis, showing epidermal involvement and extension beyond the dermal component. This image also demonstrates confluent growth along the basal epidermis with rete effacement. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×200 magnification.

Histopathologic examination of the deep aspect of the tumorigenic component in a melanoma with a MAP2K1 in-frame deletion reveals nodules of atypical epithelioid cells. The dermal components universally consisted of variably sized nodules and nests, with this image showcasing the epithelioid cytomorphology noted in the majority of cases. Melanocytes typically have medium to large nuclei with heterogenous chromatin, variably prominent nucleoli, and moderate to severe nuclear pleomorphism. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×200 magnification.

Histopathologic examination of a metastatic lesion from a melanoma with a MAP2K1 in-frame deletion shows predominantly epithelioid cytomorphology. The melanocytes exhibit variable amounts of cytoplasm, which can be amphophilic or densely eosinophilic, and may show focal cytoplasmic pigmentation. Nuclei are typically medium to large with heterogenous chromatin, variably prominent nucleoli, and moderate to severe nuclear pleomorphism. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×400 magnification.

Histopathologic examination of a metastatic lesion from a melanoma with a MAP2K1 in-frame deletion shows spindled cytomorphology. While predominantly epithelioid, occasional cases display this spindled morphology. The melanocytes exhibit variable amounts of cytoplasm, which can be amphophilic or densely eosinophilic, and may show focal cytoplasmic pigmentation. Nuclei are typically medium to large with heterogenous chromatin, variably prominent nucleoli, and moderate to severe nuclear pleomorphism. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×400 magnification.

Histopathologic examination of a metastatic lesion from a melanoma with a MAP2K1 in-frame deletion shows rhabdoid morphology. Occasional cases display this specific rhabdoid cytomorphology, in contrast to the more common epithelioid or spindled forms. The melanocytes exhibit variable amounts of cytoplasm, which can be amphophilic or densely eosinophilic, and may show focal cytoplasmic pigmentation. Nuclei are typically medium to large with heterogenous chromatin, variably prominent nucleoli, and moderate to severe nuclear pleomorphism. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×400 magnification.
Microscopic findings showing neoplastic cells involving the muscularis propria to the submucosal layer under low-power magnification. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).
Microscopic findings showing tumor cells growing in a sheet-like fashion accompanied by scarce stroma. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification ×200.
Microscopic findings showing tumor cells also invading into the mucosa near the ulcer bed. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification ×100.

Microscopic findings showing individual cells with irregular, enlarged nuclei containing rough chromatin and polygonal or spindle cytoplasm with high pleomorphism. Multinucleated cells are observed at the center of the photograph. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification ×600.
Microscopic findings showing mitotic figures often observed under high-power magnification. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification ×400.
Microscopic findings showing many cells containing tiny tan granules in the cytoplasm, especially in the dark brown region. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification ×400.

Histopathology of the enucleated eye showing a brownish-black pigmented choroidal melanocytoma, composed of fusiform cells with brownish cytoplasm. The image shows a pigmented tumor at 10x magnification. No signs of necrosis or malignancy were found, consistent with choroidal melanocytoma rather than melanoma. Stained with hematoxylin-eosin.

High magnification histopathology of the choroidal melanocytoma, showing a highly pigmented zone with brownish cytoplasm. This zone is part of a brownish-black pigmented tumor arising from the choroid, composed of fusiform cells. No signs of necrosis or malignancy were found, consistent with choroidal melanocytoma rather than melanoma. Stained with hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification 40x.

High magnification histopathology of the choroidal melanocytoma, showing a less pigmented zone. In this zone, nuclear details are visible, revealing fusiform cells with elongated nuclei and small nucleoli. This area of the brownish-black pigmented choroidal tumor shows no necrosis, atypia, or mitotic activity. These findings are consistent with a choroidal melanocytoma, not a melanoma. Stained with hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification 40x.

Photomicrograph of a skin biopsy from Case #2, a 68-year-old female diagnosed with exogenous ochronosis. The histological examination shows yellow-brown dermal deposits, specifically banana-like bodies (ochronotic bodies), in the superficial dermis, which is diagnostic of ochronosis. The section is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 100X magnification.

Photomicrography of a skin biopsy from Case #1, the 58-year-old woman with exogenous ochronosis. The image shows elongated yellow-brown deposits, described as 'banana-like' acellular material, along with sharply defined irregularly shaped pigment granules, in the superficial/upper dermis. These features are diagnostic of exogenous ochronosis. Associated solar elastosis is also observed. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 200X magnification.

Photomicrograph of the synovium from a total knee arthroplasty in a patient with confirmed alkaptonuria (endogenous ochronosis). The image shows extensive ochronotic pigment deposition, with ochronotic bodies present in the synovium (arrow) and on the articular surface (arrow head), characteristic of endogenous ochronosis. (H&E stain, 40X magnification).

Histopathology of a punch biopsy specimen from a blue-gray macule on the right buttock of a young adult. The patient presented with multiple, discrete blue-gray macules that had appeared a few years prior on the buttocks, lower back, and arms. This image, at x10 magnification, shows an ill-defined, deep dermal proliferation of pigmented dendritic melanocytes (highlighted by a red circle) with associated melanophages (highlighted by a black circle). No associated mitoses or necrosis were appreciated, consistent with common blue nevus. Stained with hematoxylin-eosin.

Histopathology of a punch biopsy specimen from a blue-gray macule on the right buttock of a young adult. The patient presented with multiple, discrete blue-gray macules that had appeared a few years prior on the buttocks, lower back, and arms. This image, at x20 magnification, shows an ill-defined, deep dermal proliferation of pigmented dendritic melanocytes (highlighted by a red circle) with associated melanophages (highlighted by a black circle). No associated mitoses or necrosis were appreciated, consistent with common blue nevus. Stained with hematoxylin-eosin.

Close-up histopathology of a melanoma metastasis located in an inguinal lymph node, showing both conventional melanoma and vascular components. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin at ×20 magnification.

Histopathology showing a detail of the angiosarcomatous component. Highly atypical endothelial cells can be seen and mitotic figures are present. The vascular spaces contain erythrocytes (hematoxylin and eosin ×200 magnification).

Histopathology of a skin excision from the right upper leg of a 69-year-old man, diagnosed in 2017, showing a cutaneous nodular melanoma with a Breslow thickness of 13.0 mm, without any signs of heterologous differentiation. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin at ×10 magnification.
A close-up view of the angiosarcomatous component, stained with hematoxylin and eosin, showing vascular channels filled with erythrocytes. Original magnification ×100.

Histopathology of a lymph node showing metastatic melanoma. A prominent angiosarcomatous component is visible in the central and upper part of the lymph node. This vascular component features spaces lined by highly atypical endothelial cells, characterized by vesicular and hyperchromatic nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm. Mitotic figures are present within these cells, and the vascular spaces contain erythrocytes. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin, viewed at ×5 magnification.

Microscopic examination of the tumor by Hematoxylin-eosin staining, showing the histological features of the tumor cells. Fine melanin granules are present within or outside of the cells, indicated by an orange arrow.

Microscopic examination of the tumor by Hematoxylin-eosin staining, showing the histological features of the tumor cells. Fine melanin granules are present within or outside of the cells, indicated by an orange arrow.

Histopathology revealing a well-circumscribed mass infiltrating the dermis and subcutis. The mass is composed of an atypical spindle cell neoplasm with uniformly fusiform cells, possessing ovoid nuclei with prominent nucleoli and amphophilic cytoplasm. These tumor cells are arranged in compact nests and short fascicles throughout the dermis and into the subcutaneous tissue, separated by a hyalinized stroma. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at an original magnification of x40.
Histopathology showing a high-power view revealing fusiform and round cells with eosinophilic to clear cytoplasm within the dermis and subcutis. (H&E, original magnification x200).

Microscopic picture of the surgical specimen stained with H&E at ×40 magnification. Histological examination shows the presence of fibro-connective and lymphatic tissue containing malignant neoplastic cells, compatible with a nodule of melanoma inside the buccal fat pad. The image shows proliferating atypical cells containing coarse-brownish granules suspected to be melanin.

Microscopic picture of the surgical specimen stained with H&E at ×100 magnification. Histological examination shows the presence of fibro-connective and lymphatic tissue containing malignant neoplastic cells, compatible with a nodule of melanoma inside the buccal fat pad. The image shows proliferating atypical cells containing coarse-brownish granules suspected to be melanin.

Microscopic picture of the surgical specimen stained with H&E at ×200 magnification. Histological examination shows the presence of fibro-connective and lymphatic tissue containing malignant neoplastic cells, compatible with a nodule of melanoma inside the buccal fat pad. The image shows proliferating atypical cells containing coarse-brownish granules suspected to be melanin.

Microscopic picture of the surgical specimen stained with H&E at ×400 magnification. Histological examination shows the presence of fibro-connective and lymphatic tissue containing malignant neoplastic cells, compatible with a nodule of melanoma inside the buccal fat pad. The image shows proliferating atypical cells containing coarse-brownish granules suspected to be melanin.

Histopathological image from an incisional biopsy of the buccal mucosa, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 100x magnification. The image shows parakeratosis and acanthosis of the stratified squamous epithelium, with melanin confined to the basal layer. Clusters of melanophages are visible within the connective tissue papilla, indicative of phagocytosed melanin within macrophages in the upper connective tissue. Foci of lymphocytic infiltrate are present in the basal layer, associated with spongiosis and occasional cytoid bodies. There is no evidence of dysplasia or malignancy. These findings, correlating with clinical observations, contributed to the diagnosis of Laugier-Hunziker syndrome, effectively excluding melanoma from the differential diagnosis.

Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained image of a representative tissue section of melanoma brain metastasis from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill craniotomy cohort. This panel corresponds to the area shown in Panel A and highlights high intratumoral hemorrhage, indicated by yellow arrows, associated with the presence of immature blood vessels (CD31+αSMA-). This hemorrhage reflects the increased vascular permeability and fragility characteristic of a highly angiogenic tumor microenvironment, where angiogenic factors like VEGF and bFGF (produced by melanoma cells and TILs) can promote vessel dysfunction and contribute to vasogenic edema.

Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained image of a representative tissue section of melanoma brain metastasis from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill craniotomy cohort. This panel corresponds to the area shown in Panel D and highlights significantly low or absent intratumoral hemorrhage, indicated by blue arrows (center image), which is associated with the presence of mature blood vessels (CD31+αSMA+). This stable vascular morphology suggests a tumor microenvironment with more regulated angiogenesis, less vascular permeability, and consequently, less vasogenic edema, which can be influenced by the balance of angiogenic factors.

Histopathology showing an H&E stained incidental melanoma in situ (seventh melanoma), found during the wide excision of lesion #2 (a primary melanoma in situ). The image shows atypical melanocytes in single units along the dermoepidermal junction and in the upper layers of the epidermis, with melanophages and solar elastosis visible in the dermis. This incidental finding was not detected clinically or dermoscopically and shows no continuity with the scar of the previous excision. Original magnification ×100.

Histopathology of a lesion from a sixty-one-year-old woman on the thoracic region, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at 4× magnification. This image shows prominent large junctional nests, some of which are parallel to the epidermis. A large amount of melanophages is present in the dermis below the lesion. These findings contributed to the diagnosis being changed from Spitz nevus to malignant melanoma with spitzoid features. The rectangular area shown in this panel is magnified in Panel C.

Histopathology of a lesion from a sixty-one-year-old woman on the thoracic region, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at 40× magnification. This panel provides a magnified view of the rectangular area indicated in Panel B. It shows large, spindle-shaped cells within a nest on the left side and epithelioid cells in the lentiginous component of the lesion on the right side. These cellular features supported the diagnosis being changed from Spitz nevus to malignant melanoma with spitzoid features.

Histopathology of a lesion from a sixty-one-year-old woman on the thoracic region, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at 20× magnification. This panel shows a continuous lentiginous pattern of growth and some pagetoid elements that were evident in some fields. These observations were crucial in changing the diagnosis from Spitz nevus to malignant melanoma with spitzoid features.

Histopathology from the periphery of the lesion from a 52-year-old woman, showing pagetoid spread of single atypical melanocytes (Hematoxylin and Eosin, 20× magnification). Based on these findings, the diagnosis was changed from superficial atypical melanocytic proliferations of unknown significance (SAMPUS) to in situ melanoma.

Histopathology of cervical melanoma, showing tumor cells with characteristic melanin pigmentation. The tumor mass consists of medium to large sized neoplastic cells with markedly enlarged nuclei and discrete nucleoli with no clear cellular borders. Abundant large and round abnormal cells are present, either single isolated cells or gathered in aggregated groups, exhibiting enlarged, hyperchromatic, and eccentrically placed nuclei. Occasionally, giant cells could also be observed within the tumor. The patient's final diagnosis was stage IB1 melanoma of the cervix, with immunohistochemistry showing diffuse positive reactions for HMB-45, S-100, and Melan-A. Stained with Haematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×20.

Histopathology demonstrating focally keratinizing, atypical, squamous epithelial cells arising from the epidermis and extending into the dermis, characteristic of squamous cell carcinoma arising in nevus sebaceous. The tumor was widely excised, and a histopathologic examination confirmed these findings. (H&E stain; original magnification, 2×).

Histopathology of the adjacent skin showing features of nevus sebaceous, the site from which the squamous cell carcinoma arose. The image reveals acanthosis and papillomatosis, with an abnormal location of sebaceous glands which opened directly to the skin surface. Many ectopic apocrine glands associated with lacking anagen hair are also observed. (H&E stain; original magnification, 4×).

Histopathology of squamous cell carcinoma arising in nevus sebaceous, showing characteristic features including horn pearls and individual cell keratinization, which were present throughout the excised tumor. (H&E stain; original magnification, 10×).

High magnification histopathology of squamous cell carcinoma arising in nevus sebaceous, demonstrating large eosinophilic tumor cells with focally glassy cytoplasm and vesicular nuclei. (H&E stain; original magnification, 40×).

Histopathology showing a well-circumscribed dermal nodule with no involvement of the epidermis, characteristic of a circumscribed dermal-based melanocytic neoplasm. Histopathological examination confirmed a Breslow depth of 3.2 mm and Clark level IV, ultimately leading to a definitive diagnosis of PDM. The image is stained with Eosin and Hematoxylin, viewed at 2x magnification.

Histopathology showing proliferation of atypical and pleomorphic melanocytes with mitotic activity. Histopathological examination confirmed a mitotic rate of 8/mm2, and described melanocytes as epithelioid and spindled, arranged either as single cells or in multiple expansive nests within the dermal-based melanocytic neoplasm. There was no evidence of any underlying in situ component. The image is stained with Eosin and Hematoxylin, viewed at 200x magnification.

High-power view (×20) of the typical histopathology of a Junctional nevus, a type of large congenital melanocytic nevi (LCMNs) diagnosed in 2.3% of patients. This image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). LCMNs can exhibit various histopathological features such as collagenization and nodularization. Some lesions were observed to invade adipose tissue or striated muscle, indicating deeper infiltration of melanocytes which can make surgical removal challenging.

High-power view (×20) of the typical histopathology of an Intradermal nevus, a type of large congenital melanocytic nevi (LCMNs) diagnosed in 24.0% of patients. This image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). LCMNs can show diverse histopathological features like collagenization and nodularization. Some lesions were noted to invade adipose tissue or striated muscle, signifying deeper infiltration of melanocytes which can complicate surgical excision.

High-power view (×20) of the typical histopathology of a Compound nevus, the most common type of large congenital melanocytic nevi (LCMNs) diagnosed, accounting for 56.4% of patients. This image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). LCMNs often present with varied histopathological characteristics such as collagenization and nodularization. Observations also include lesions invading adipose tissue or striated muscle, indicating deeper melanocyte infiltration and potential difficulty in surgical removal.

High-power view (×20) of the typical histopathology of a Blue nevus, a type of large congenital melanocytic nevi (LCMNs) diagnosed in 2.3% of patients. This image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). LCMNs, including this type, can display various histopathological features such as collagenization and nodularization. Additionally, some lesions were found to invade adipose tissue or striated muscle, suggesting deeper infiltration of melanocytes that can pose challenges for surgical removal.

High-power view (×20) of the typical histopathology of a Neuronevus, a type of large congenital melanocytic nevi (LCMNs) diagnosed in 7.5% of patients. This image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). LCMNs often exhibit diverse histopathological features, including collagenization and nodularization. There were also observations of lesions invading adipose tissue or striated muscle, which implies deeper melanocyte infiltration and can make surgical removal more difficult.

Histopathological examination of the surgically excised nodular mass from a female baby, diagnosed as neonatal congenital nodular melanoma. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining shows the distribution of tumor cells in the dermis in sheets or nests. (Magnification × 100).

Histopathological examination of the surgically excised nodular mass from a female baby, diagnosed as neonatal congenital nodular melanoma. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining shows round or oval tumor cell nuclei, with evident nucleoli and common nuclear divisions. A large amount of melanin is seen in the cytoplasm, and local epithelium is absent. Infiltration and necrosis of neutrophils are also observed. (Magnification × 400).

Microscopic findings of the labia minora lesion, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at 40× magnification, confirming a diagnosis of Nevus Sebaceus (NS). The image shows plenty of enlarged sebaceous glands, slight hyperkeratosis, and an acanthotic epidermis with papillomatosis. The surface of the lesion is partially covered with proliferative squamous epithelium and displays papillary hyperplasia. A large number of proliferative, well-differentiated sebaceous glands lacking hair follicles are found under the skin and deep dermis.

Microscopic findings of the labia minora lesion, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at 40× magnification, confirming a diagnosis of Nevus Sebaceus (NS). The image shows plenty of enlarged sebaceous glands, slight hyperkeratosis, and an acanthotic epidermis with papillomatosis. The surface of the lesion is partially covered with proliferative squamous epithelium and displays papillary hyperplasia. A large number of proliferative, well-differentiated sebaceous glands lacking hair follicles are found under the skin and deep dermis.

Microscopic findings of the labia minora lesion, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at 40× magnification, confirming a diagnosis of Nevus Sebaceus (NS). The image shows plenty of enlarged sebaceous glands, slight hyperkeratosis, and an acanthotic epidermis with papillomatosis. The surface of the lesion is partially covered with proliferative squamous epithelium and displays papillary hyperplasia. A large number of proliferative, well-differentiated sebaceous glands lacking hair follicles are found under the skin and deep dermis.

Microscopic findings of the labia minora lesion, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at 10× magnification, confirming a diagnosis of Nevus Sebaceus (NS). The image shows plenty of enlarged sebaceous glands, slight hyperkeratosis, and an acanthotic epidermis with papillomatosis. The surface of the lesion is partially covered with proliferative squamous epithelium and displays papillary hyperplasia. A large number of proliferative, well-differentiated sebaceous glands lacking hair follicles are found under the skin and deep dermis.

Histopathology of pilomatricoma, a benign appendageal tumor, showing characteristic basaloid cells and shadow cells. In this study, pilomatricoma was the most common benign appendageal tumor, observed in 13 cases (38.3%). (Hematoxylin and eosin stain, 400x magnification)

Histopathology of Seborrhoeic keratosis, specifically the acanthotic variant, as observed in the study where it was the most common variant encountered, representing 50% (14 cases) of all seborrhoeic keratosis cases. Seborrhoeic keratosis accounted for 19.5% of benign keratinocytic tumors in the study. This image shows acanthosis and hyperkeratosis of the epidermis, along with the presence of numerous horn cysts. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 400x magnification.

Histologic features of a skin biopsy showing multiple anastomosing strands of basaloid cell proliferation with keratin material. Some cells are connected to the epidermis, displaying basaloid cell proliferation and scanty, loose stroma. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×200 magnification.

Histologic features of a skin biopsy showing basal hyperpigmentation and mild basaloid cell proliferation with peripheral palisading in the superficial dermis. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×200 magnification.

Histopathology of cerebral tissue showing neoplastic voluminous cells with melanin pigment (60× magnification). The brain samples were collected during autopsy, fixed in 10% buffered formalin, embedded in paraffin, and cut into 4 µm thick sections. Microscopic examination revealed many atypical and pleomorphic cells with voluminous discolored nuclei and melanin pigment in the cytoplasm, arranged in 'cordons' or irregularly like a 'vortex'. These sections were stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (E.E.). Images were obtained using a Zeiss Axioplan light microscope and a Zeiss AxioCam MRc5 digital camera.

Histopathology showing a neoplastic cell population characterized by numerous, voluminous melanoblasts with marked nuclear pleiomorphism. The brain samples were collected during autopsy, fixed in 10% buffered formalin, embedded in paraffin, and cut into 4 µm thick sections. Microscopic examination of brain tissues (specifically from the right parietal lobe and brain-stem) revealed many atypical and pleomorphic cells with voluminous discolored nuclei and melanin pigment in the cytoplasm, arranged in 'cordons' or irregularly like a 'vortex'. This morphology is consistent with primary leptomeningeal melanoma. These sections were stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). Images were obtained using a Zeiss Axioplan light microscope and a Zeiss AxioCam MRc5 digital camera.

Histopathology of cerebral tissue showing a neoplastic cell population located near a small cerebral artery (200× magnification). The brain samples were collected during autopsy, fixed in 10% buffered formalin, embedded in paraffin, and cut into 4 µm thick sections. Microscopic examination of brain tissues revealed many atypical and pleomorphic cells with voluminous discolored nuclei and melanin pigment in the cytoplasm, often associated with vascular proliferation. Around the leptomeningeal arteriolar vessels, which showed clots, many pleomorphic and atypical cells with melanin pigment in the cytoplasm were observed. These sections were stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (E.E.). Images were obtained using a Zeiss Axioplan light microscope and a Zeiss AxioCam MRc5 digital camera.

Histopathology showing intradermal atypical nevus cells in the left part of the biopsy, contrasting with regression in the right part. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) and magnified at 5x.

Histopathology of a superficial spreading melanoma from a 21-year-old patient. The melanocytic lesion is characterized by atypical junctional activity and extensive regression in the superficial dermis. This image depicts the regression at the margins of the lesion. The full histological evaluation confirmed a diagnosis of superficial spreading melanoma, Breslow 0.70 mm, Clark level three, pT1a. Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification ×10.

Histopathologic image showing nests of nevus cells with papillomatous proliferation observed in the dermis. Dermal nests and cords of nevus cells are present with no junctional activity. This finding led to the diagnosis of intradermal melanocytic nevus. Stained with hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×200.

Histopathology showing massive spindle-shaped neoplasm cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and varied heterogeneity. These cells are infiltrating through the tissue with associated thickening of interweaved collagen fibers. Spindle-shaped tumor cells, consistent with mixed desmoplastic melanoma (DM), accounted for 30–80% of the lesions in all three cases observed. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification ×100.

Histopathology showing neoplastic cells exhibiting mild to moderate atypia, which was observed in tumor cells from two of the three cases. Cell morphology varied, feathering either long or short spindles, accompanied by hyperchromatic nuclei, vesicular shape, increased nucleoplasm ratio, and sometimes mitotic figures. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification ×400.

Histopathology showing melanocytes at the dermo-epidermal junction arranged in a nesting or linear manner, similar to malignant freckles. Abnormal melanocyte proliferation with moderate atypia at the dermo-epidermal junction was observed in two cases. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification ×100.

Histopathology showing prominent melanin deposition in the cytoplasm of neoplasm cells. Melanin deposition was evident in two of the three cases. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification ×100.

Histopathology demonstrating neurophilicity, characterized by one or more well-defined spindle cell foci observed around the nerve or within the nerve sheath, squeezing the nerve sheath. Neurophilic characteristics were present in two cases. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification ×200.

Histopathology showing patchy lymphocytic infiltrates around and below the lesions, some of which formed lymphoid follicular-like structures. Prominent lymphocytic infiltration and lymphoid follicle structures were observed in two cases. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification ×100.

Microscopic picture of a biopsy taken from the penis, H&E-staining showing atypical melanocytes with focal pagetoid infiltration of the epidermis and strong junctional melanocytic pigmentation with pigmentary incontinence. Scale bar = 100 µm.

Histopathology of a superficial biopsy from the conjunctival lesion, exhibiting acanthotic stratified squamous epithelium displaying severe dysplasia. The basement membrane was not visualized in its entirety, and there was no subepithelial tissue present to comment on an invasion. This led to a diagnosis of conjunctival intraepithelial neoplasia 3 (severe dysplasia). Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) stain, 10X magnification.

Histopathology of a superficial biopsy from the conjunctival lesion, exhibiting acanthotic stratified squamous epithelium displaying severe dysplasia. The basement membrane was not visualized in its entirety, and there was no subepithelial tissue present to comment on an invasion. This led to a diagnosis of conjunctival intraepithelial neoplasia 3 (severe dysplasia). Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) stain, 40X magnification.

Photomicrograph of the eyelid lesion, consistent with an oncocytoma, showing a well-demarcated mass composed of glandular spaces separated by thin vasculature. The glandular spaces are lined by tall cells exhibiting uniform round to oval nuclei, fine chromatin, and abundant granular eosinophilic cytoplasm (oncocytes). There is evidence of secretion within the glandular spaces and interspersed lymphoplasmacytic inflammation. Mitotic figures were not seen. The overlying tissue is lined by non-ulcerated hyperplastic, hyperkeratotic stratified squamous epithelium. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 4X magnification.

Photomicrograph of the eyelid lesion, consistent with an oncocytoma, showing a well-demarcated mass composed of glandular spaces separated by thin vasculature. The glandular spaces are lined by tall cells exhibiting uniform round to oval nuclei, fine chromatin, and abundant granular eosinophilic cytoplasm (oncocytes). There is evidence of secretion within the glandular spaces and interspersed lymphoplasmacytic inflammation. Mitotic figures were not seen. The overlying tissue is lined by non-ulcerated hyperplastic, hyperkeratotic stratified squamous epithelium. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 10X magnification.

Photomicrograph of the eyelid lesion, consistent with an oncocytoma, showing a well-demarcated mass composed of glandular spaces separated by thin vasculature. The glandular spaces are lined by tall cells exhibiting uniform round to oval nuclei, fine chromatin, and abundant granular eosinophilic cytoplasm (oncocytes). There is evidence of secretion within the glandular spaces and interspersed lymphoplasmacytic inflammation. Mitotic figures were not seen. The overlying tissue is lined by non-ulcerated hyperplastic, hyperkeratotic stratified squamous epithelium. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 10X magnification.

Photomicrograph of the eyelid lesion, consistent with an oncocytoma, showing a well-demarcated mass composed of glandular spaces separated by thin vasculature. The glandular spaces are lined by tall cells exhibiting uniform round to oval nuclei, fine chromatin, and abundant granular eosinophilic cytoplasm (oncocytes). There is evidence of secretion within the glandular spaces and interspersed lymphoplasmacytic inflammation. Mitotic figures were not seen. The overlying tissue is lined by non-ulcerated hyperplastic, hyperkeratotic stratified squamous epithelium. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 40X magnification.
Histopathology showing basal cell carcinoma, characterized by lobulated nests of neoplastic cells with retraction artifact and a palisaded basal layer (H&E, ×200 magnification).

Photomicrograph from the nasopharyngeal tissue showing infiltrating tumor cells and brown pigment suggestive of melanin. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and captured at an original magnification of ×100.

Photomicrograph showing sheets of polygonal tumor cells characterized by large vesicular nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and ill-defined cytoplasm. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and captured at an original magnification of ×400.

Histopathology of oral amelanotic melanoma (case 5) at ×100 magnification, stained with hematoxylin and eosin. The image shows a diffuse proliferation of sheets and nests of predominantly amelanotic spindle and epithelioid melanocytic cells, displaying pleomorphic features with ovoid nuclei and pale cytoplasm. There is a variable number of mitotic figures, including atypical mitotic figures, and notably, an absence of melanin deposition. Variable degrees of nuclear hyperchromatism and cellular pleomorphism are observed. The lesion exhibits atypical and pleomorphic melanocytes in the basal and suprabasal layers, indicative of junctional activity. A scarce lymphocytic inflammatory response is also present.

Histopathology of oral amelanotic melanoma (case 5) at ×400 magnification, stained with hematoxylin and eosin, providing a higher-power view of the tumor cells. The image displays a diffuse proliferation of predominantly amelanotic spindle and epithelioid melanocytic cells, which are pleomorphic, with ovoid nuclei and pale cytoplasm. There is a variable number of mitotic figures, including atypical mitotic figures, and a notable absence of melanin deposition. Variable degrees of nuclear hyperchromatism and cellular pleomorphism are observed. The lesion exhibits atypical and pleomorphic melanocytes in the basal and suprabasal layers, indicative of junctional activity. A scarce lymphocytic inflammatory response is also present.

Histopathology of oral amelanotic melanoma (case 3) showing a diffuse proliferation of spindle and epithelioid melanocytes organized in sheets and nests. The pleomorphic tumor cells exhibit ovoid nuclei and pale cytoplasm, with variable degrees of nuclear hyperchromatism and cellular pleomorphism. A variable number of mitoses, including atypical mitotic figures, are observed. A scarce lymphocytic inflammatory response is present surrounding the tumor cells. (Hematoxylin and eosin stain, original magnification ×40).

Histopathology of oral amelanotic melanoma (case 3) showing the presence of focal melanin deposition within the pleomorphic melanocytic cells. The tumor cells exhibit spindle and epithelioid morphology, with ovoid nuclei and pale cytoplasm containing brown granules compatible with melanin, arranged in nests. (Hematoxylin and eosin stain, original magnification ×400).

Microscopic findings of oral melanoma (case 7), showing the lesion lined with parakeratinized stratified squamous epithelium. Evident junctional activity is noted, characterized by atypical and pleomorphic melanocytes in the basal and suprabasal layers of the epithelium. Histologically, these cases typically present a diffuse proliferation of sheets and nests of pleomorphic melanocytic cells with varying morphology. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), original magnification ×100.

Microscopic findings of oral melanoma (case 7), illustrating tumor cells and nuclei that are markedly pleomorphic with amphophilic nucleoli and varying degrees of melanin pigments in the cytoplasm. Histologically, the tumor cells often exhibit ovoid nuclei and pale cytoplasm containing brown granules compatible with melanin, with variable degrees of nuclear hyperchromatism and cellular pleomorphism. Atypical mitotic figures are also frequently observed. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), original magnification ×400.

Histopathology from Case 2, stained with Hematoxylin-Eosin at 100× original magnification, illustrating the cytological features of the neoplastic cells. The cells are large, sometimes with pale eosinophilic cytoplasm, and also exhibit clear features. In some areas, the nuclei are located at one pole of the cell, possessing an irregular nuclear membrane profile and dense chromatin. Severe necrosis and an elevated mitotic rate were observed in the lesions, which also contained extensive deposits of melanic pigment. In Case 2, a clear junctional neoplastic component was recognized.

Histological section of a Mohs surgery specimen, stained with Hematoxylin & eosin (×100 magnification), showing a fusocellular proliferation extending into the dermis and subcutaneous tissue, consistent with dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans. Preoperative immunohistochemistry was positive for CD34. This image illustrates a Mohs Micrographic Surgery (MMS) case performed by the authors.

Histological section of a Mohs surgery specimen, demonstrating irregular nests of basaloid cells consistent with infiltrative basal cell carcinoma, located on the right pre-auricular area. The section is stained with Hematoxylin & eosin and viewed at ×25 magnification. This image illustrates a case managed with Mohs Micrographic Surgery (MMS) by the authors, where meticulous histological examination is crucial for ensuring complete tumor removal in complex skin defects.

Histological section of the specimen obtained with Mohs micrographic surgery, showing nests of basaloid cells adjacent to or connected to the epidermis, consistent with mixed basal cell carcinoma (BCC) with extensive subclinical extension. The image is stained with Hematoxylin & eosin (×40 magnification), confirming the diagnosis during the staged excisional procedure.

Histological section of a Mohs surgery specimen from the squamous cell carcinoma on the left periorbital region, showing atypical keratinocytes and horn pearls, consistent with well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. This Hematoxylin & eosin (H&E) stained image at ×100 magnification demonstrates the microscopic features that guide the Mohs surgeon in achieving complete tumor removal while preserving healthy tissue, as part of an MMS case performed by the authors.

Histopathology (H&E, ×10 magnification) showing a heavily pigmented tumor composed of sheets of polygonal cells. On histology, the tumor was also noted to form nodules, with focal spindle cell morphology and perivascular arrangement. The tumor exhibited no significant mitotic activity or necrosis, consistent with its presentation in multiple black colored fragments resembling a blood clot.

Histopathology (H&E, ×40 magnification) of a heavily pigmented tumor, highlighting large vesicular nuclei and prominent nucleoli. The tumor cells were polygonal and arranged in sheets and nodules, showing no significant mitotic activity or necrosis.

Histopathology (H&E, ×10 magnification) of a postbleach section showing tumor cells. The original tumor was composed of heavily pigmented polygonal cells, and potassium permanganate (KMnO4) bleach was used to study the cell morphology in detail. This image reveals large polygonal and epithelioid tumor cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm and large vesicular nuclei with prominent nucleoli, which typically form sheets and nodules.

Histopathology (H&E, ×40 magnification) of a postbleach section showing tumor cells. The original tumor was composed of heavily pigmented polygonal cells, and potassium permanganate (KMnO4) bleach was used to study the cell morphology in detail. At this higher magnification, large polygonal and epithelioid tumor cells are visible, characterized by abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm and large vesicular nuclei with prominent nucleoli. The tumor cells are arranged in sheets and nodules.

Histopathology of a trichoblastoma, a benign basaloid tumor, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at ×400 magnification. The image shows tumor cells without peripheral palisading, clefting, or sebaceous differentiation. This trichoblastoma lesion was identified adjacent to a nodule of poorly differentiated sebaceous carcinoma and was described in the paper as a basaloid tumor which overall exhibited peripheral palisading and no evidence of clefting between the stroma and the tumor cells.
Histopathology showing sebaceous carcinoma, characterized by irregular lobules of basaloid cells in the dermis. (H&E stain, original magnification ×20).
Histopathology showing mature sebocytes from a sebaceous carcinoma, which display vacuolated cytoplasm and scalloped nuclei. (H&E stain, original magnification ×400).
Histopathology of sebaceous carcinoma showing tumor cells with nuclear atypia, accompanied by several mitotic figures and areas of necrosis. (H&E stain, original magnification ×400).
