Histopathology showing a sebaceoma, which is a small, superficial, benign basaloid tumor with sebaceous differentiation. This tumor is characterized by the absence of peripheral palisading, mitoses, or necrosis. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, magnification ×100.

Histopathology image showing features of nevus sebaceous (NS) in the background. The image depicts epidermal hyperplasia with sebaceous glands opening directly to the surface. The background skin from which this tissue was taken also exhibited hyperkeratosis, epidermal papillomatosis, and acanthosis, along with apocrine glands in the deep dermis, all consistent with a nevus sebaceous background. The tissue sections were formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded, and stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E). The image was captured at ×40 magnification.

Histopathology showing syringocystadenoma papilliferum (SCAP), characterized by an invagination of the epidermis. This invagination is filled with papillae that communicate with duct-like structures in the deep aspect of the lesion. These papillae are lined by two cell layers: an outer layer of tall columnar cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm and an inner layer of cuboidal cells. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification ×40.

Histopathological findings of syringocystadenoma papilliferum, showing papilloma-like hyperplasia of the epidermis, with the epidermis partly sinking into the dermis to form several cystic depressions. These depressions are lined with stratified squamous epithelium. Stained with hematoxylin-eosin (× 40 magnification).

Histopathological findings of syringocystadenoma papilliferum, showing glandular cavity-like structures in the dermis, with some opened into the epidermis. A large number of lymphocytes, neutrophils, and plasma cells were infiltrated in the interstitial area, and splinter hemorrhage was also observed. Stained with hematoxylin-eosin (× 100 magnification).

Histopathological findings of syringocystadenoma papilliferum, showing the cavity wall and villous epidermis of the glandular cavity composed of two layers of epithelial cells. The inner layer includes columnar cells, characterized by oval and eosinophilic nuclei and abundant cytoplasm. Apocrine secretion was observed. Stained with hematoxylin-eosin (× 200 magnification).

Histopathological findings of extensive nevus comedonicus, showing a multiplicity of the invagination of the follicular infundibulum with a keratin plug. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), scanning view.

Histopathological findings of extensive nevus comedonicus, showing projecting bulbous proliferation of infundibular keratinocytes and perifollicular inflammatory infiltrates. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), ×40 magnification.

Histopathology of the skin and subcutis showing an intensely pigmented melanocyte proliferation, identified as an animal-type hyperpigmented spindle cell melanoma. The neoplasm entirely occupies the dermis and approaches the subcutaneous tissue (V Clark Level), displaying a growth pattern predominantly in large nests, columns, and sometimes sheets of cells that displace and destroy normal dermal and follicular skin structures. (Hematoxylin-Eosin, Original Magnification: 4×).

Histological detail of a melanocyte proliferation, consistent with animal-type hyperpigmented spindle cell melanoma, consisting of variously intertwined cells with evident presence of melanic pigment. The cells are predominantly spindle, sometimes epithelioid, and even rarely dendritic. Nuclei are vesicular with thickened nuclear membranes, hyperchromatic with thickened chromatin, and show large, irregular, and angulated nucleoli. (Hematoxylin-Eosin, Original Magnification: 10×).
Histopathology showing micrometastases from the animal-type hyperpigmented spindle cell melanoma in the sentinel lymph node. (Hematoxylin-Eosin, Original Magnification: 4×).

Histopathology, Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, ×40 magnification, showing a solid proliferation of atypical epithelioid cells. Scattered pigmented melanophages are observed amidst fibroconnective tissue. The tissue samples are richly cellular with round to ovoid nuclei and prominent nucleoli. Areas of necrosis are present, associated with inflammation and hemorrhage.

Histopathology, Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, ×20 magnification, showing a solid proliferation of atypical epithelioid cells. Scattered pigmented melanophages are observed amidst fibroconnective tissue. The tissue samples are richly cellular with round to ovoid nuclei and prominent nucleoli. Areas of necrosis are present, associated with inflammation and hemorrhage.
Histopathology, Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, ×40 magnification, showing few spindle-shaped nests of cells admixed with melanophages.

Low and high-power view of hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained sections showing a primary intramedullary malignant melanoma of the thoracic spine. The tumor, which was a dark brown-green color grossly, is composed of cellular nests of medium- to large-sized cells, demarcated from the spinal cord tissue. These cells exhibit prominent nucleoli and a low nuclear-to-cytoplasmic (N-C) ratio. Fine granular cytoplasmic melanin pigments are present, some within the tumor cells. Appreciable mitotic activity is observed, along with a prominent lymphoplasmacytic reaction and hemosiderin deposits, indicative of prior hemorrhage.

Histopathology from the nipple-areola complex, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×50 magnification, showing suprabasal acantholysis. Also visible are corps ronds and grains located at the base of a surface crater.

Histopathological examination of a biopsy from the nail bed showing multiple subungual onycholemmal cysts (indicated by asterisks) within the dermis. The cysts appear to be free-lying but are in close proximity to the epithelium of the nail bed. These cysts are lined by stratified squamous epithelium without a granular layer or any cellular atypia, and they contain luminal onycholemmal keratin. Melanocytic lesions were not present, as confirmed by negative immunohistochemical melanocytic antigens. The image is stained with Hematoxylin-Eosin (H-E) and magnified 50 times.

Histopathology showing a representative section from an elevated area, depicting two types of lesions. The upper portion towards the skin surface shows exophytic and endophytic papillomatous projections, while the lower portion depicts a distinct well-circumscribed nodule. (Hematoxylin and Eosin, 20× magnification)

Histopathology showing a papillomatous projection, which is lined by two layers of cells and contains a dense stromal plasma cell-rich inflammatory infiltrate, representing syringocystadenoma papilliferum. (Hematoxylin and Eosin, 200× magnification)

Histopathology showing a nodule located in the dermis, characterized by tubules of varying size with stromal fibrosis and decapitation secretion visible in the lumina. (Hematoxylin and Eosin, 100× magnification)

Histopathology showing the tubules from the dermal nodule, which are lined by two layers of cells. The peripheral layer consists of flattened to cuboidal cells, and the luminal layer is composed of columnar cells with abundant granular eosinophilic cytoplasm. (Hematoxylin and Eosin, 200× magnification)

Histopathology showing a representative section featuring both syringocystadenoma papilliferum (upper left) and tubular apocrine adenoma (lower right). The section is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at 40x magnification.

Histopathological section, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at 200× magnification, derived from the plaque shown in panel (a). The section displays characteristic features of nevus sebaceous of Jadassohn, including hyperplastic sebaceous glands and immature hair follicles.

Histopathology (hematoxylin and eosin stain, 40x magnification) showing a proliferative nodule within a congenital melanocytic lesion. Proliferative nodules (PN) are generally much more frequent than melanoma and often present as multiple lesions. Distinguishing features favoring PN over melanoma include the presence of blending with nevus cells, and a lack of extensive ulceration, a very high mitotic index, necrosis within the nodule, inflammation, pleomorphism, or high-grade atypia.

Histopathology (hematoxylin and eosin stain, 250x magnification) showing melanocytes from a proliferative nodule. The melanocytes are epithelioid and exhibit a dusty cytoplasm, notably without nuclear atypia. A delicate transition, or blending (a smooth transition between proliferative nodule cells and nevus cells), is observed, which may be very focal and inconspicuous. This blending, along with the absence of nuclear atypia, are important characteristics that favor the diagnosis of a proliferative nodule over melanoma, which often presents with pleomorphism and high-grade atypia.

Histopathology of vitiligo in the inflammatory phase, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (HE) and viewed at ×200 magnification. The image displays characteristic features including parakeratosis, epidermal hyperplasia, and slight spongiosis. There is notable lymphocyte exocytosis and a discrete lymphocytic infiltrate observed in the superficial dermis. This infiltrate represents a marked superficial perivascular lymphocytic accumulation, which in the early inflammatory phase of vitiligo can sometimes exhibit a lichenoid pattern and be mistaken for epidermotropism. The intra-epidermal lymphocytes in inflammatory vitiligo are predominantly CD8-positive.

Histopathology (hematoxylin and eosin stain, ×40 magnification) showing Langerhans cell histiocytosis. The image displays a superficial infiltrate of histiocytes with epidermotropism and edema. This histological appearance is characteristic of Langerhans cell histiocytosis, a diagnosis often requiring further immunostaining for definitive confirmation and differentiation from other CD1a+ conditions.

Histopathology (hematoxylin and eosin stain, ×40 magnification) of spongiotic dermatitis with CD1a+ dendritic cell hyperplasia. The image presents the general histological features of the condition, which requires subsequent specific immunostaining, especially with CD1a and CD207, to fully characterize the cellular infiltrate and distinguish it from Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

Histopathology showing a junctional component of a congenital nevus in a newborn. The image displays irregularly distributed melanocytes with pagetoid spread. Melanocytic lesions in newborns can present with worrisome histological features like these, where irregularly distributed melanocytes in the junctional component and pagetoid spread are observed. It is crucial to interpret pagetoid spread with caution in newborns, as it is a common feature in many melanocytic lesions in this age group and can mimic superficial spreading melanoma (SSM), despite being a helpful criterion for the diagnosis of adult melanoma. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at ×250 magnification.

Histopathology of a Pagetoid Spitz nevus, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×250 magnification. The image displays prominent pagetoid growth of solitary units and nests of melanocytes in the stratum spinosum throughout the lesion. The melanocytes are epithelioid or spindle-shaped, exhibiting a predominantly epithelioid appearance characterized by enlarged, round-to-oval nuclei, often with a delicate open chromatin pattern, and abundant 'ground glass' cytoplasm.

Histopathology of IPEX (Immune dysregulation-poly-endocrinopathy-enteropathy-X-linked) syndrome, which can manifest as a skin rash including neonatal erythroderma. The image shows epidermal hyperplasia, marked lymphocytic exocytosis (resembling epidermotropism seen in mycosis fungoides), scattered apoptotic keratinocytes (indicated by the arrowhead), and a moderate lymphocytic infiltrate in the superficial dermis. The presence of necrotic/apoptotic changes in the epidermis in a newborn/infant skin biopsy, as seen here, should alert clinicians to consider a diagnosis of immunodeficiency. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (HE) at ×400 magnification.

Histopathology of Mycosis fungoides-like pityriasis lichenoides (PL), an infrequent skin disorder predominantly affecting children and young adults, often showing a histological picture similar to Mycosis fungoides (MF). This example demonstrates a marked lymphocytic exocytosis, with prominent intra-epidermal lymphocytes displaying nuclei surrounded by a clear halo, a feature also observed in MF. Note the few necrotic keratinocytes (indicated by an arrowhead), which, along with lymphocytic exocytosis, are key histological features usually observed in PL and can help distinguish it. These features are consistent with the histological picture in PL, which commonly includes variable numbers of necrotic keratinocytes and interface changes with prominent lymphocytic exocytosis. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at ×250 magnification.

Histopathology, stained with hematoxylin, phloxin, and safranin, showing a low-magnification silhouette of a melanoma that developed as a relapse from a BAP1-inactivated nevus. The initial lesion was observed at age 11, representing an exceptional transformation of such a lesion during childhood. The image depicts a compound melanocytic proliferation with dense dermal nodular areas, including pigmented clones, which are evocative of this melanoma diagnosis and associated with germline BAP1 mutations.

Histopathology, stained with hematoxylin, phloxin, and safranin, showing an intermediate view of a cellular area within a melanoma that originated as a relapse from a BAP1-inactivated nevus. This transformation is exceptional and occurred during childhood, with the initial lesion identified at age 11. The image shows admixed small and large cells, characteristic of the dense, clonal sheet-like areas that support the diagnosis of melanoma associated with germline BAP1 mutations.

Histopathology, stained with hematoxylin, phloxin, and safranin, showing a close-up view of a deep dermal nodule from a melanoma, which developed as a relapse from a BAP1-inactivated nevus. This rare transformation occurred during childhood, with the initial lesion at age 11. The nodule displays mixed small nevocytoid and large epithelioid melanocytes, some with pigmented cytoplasm. A mitotic figure (arrow) is visible, indicating proliferative activity consistent with melanoma. These features are observed in melanomas associated with germline BAP1 mutations.

Histopathology showing a lesion characterized by hyperkeratosis, parakeratosis, and acanthosis. In the epidermis, atypical features are present, including abnormal maturation of keratinocytes, prominent nucleoli, and many dyskeratotic cells (indicated by arrows) observed in all layers of the epithelium. The superficial dermis shows ectatic vessels, a moderate lymphohistiocytic infiltrate, and melanophages. The image is stained with Hematoxylin & eosin, at ×150 magnification.

Histopathology (hematoxylin and eosin stain) showing the halo phenomenon, characterized by lymphocytic inflammation intermingled with benign nevus cells. This image presents histopathological aspects from a 29-year-old patient who exhibited atypical clinical and dermoscopic features.

Histopathology stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) showing a melanocytic lesion from a 29-year-old patient who presented with atypical features clinically and dermoscopically. The lesion displays an irregular distribution of nests at the dermal-epidermal junction and dense chronic inflammation (halo type) within the dermis, partially obscuring the dermal component.

Histopathological aspect from the case of a 29-year-old patient with atypical clinical and dermoscopic features, showing fusion of junctional melanocytic nests with low-grade dysplasia, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE).

Histopathological aspect from the case of a 29-year-old patient with atypical clinical and dermoscopic features, showing fusion of junctional melanocytic nests with low-grade dysplasia, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE).

Histopathology of an expansile nodule demonstrating increased cellularity with ample eosinophilic glassy cytoplasm, moderate nuclear pleomorphism, and scattered dermal mitoses. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), original magnification x400.

A low-power histopathological view, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at x20 magnification, highlights the biphenotypic nature of the lesion. The image also notes the eccentric zone of expansile growth, which is compressing the surrounding epidermis.

Histopathology of a resected pharyngeal tumor biopsy from a 66-year-old female, showing amelanotic malignant melanoma (AMM). The patient presented with an irregularly elevated lesion on the base of the tongue (oropharynx) that was initially diagnosed as p16-positive poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. A reexamination of the biopsy specimens, prompted by later findings of metastatic malignant melanoma, resulted in a final diagnosis of AMM of the oropharynx. Hematoxylin and eosin (HE) staining did not reveal melanotic granules in the malignant cells. The image shows proliferating atypical cuboidal cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and nucleoli, distributed in small nests or as single cells, which have invaded the stroma. No apparent intercellular bridges or keratinization was observed.
Histopathology of Acral lentiginous melanoma, showing tumour cells that are usually spindle. (H&E, ×400).
Histopathology of Acral lentiginous melanoma, showing frequent deep extension along a sweat gland (arrows). (H&E, ×200).
Histopathology of Acral lentiginous melanoma, showing a desmoplastic reaction as an associated feature. (H&E, ×200).
Histopathology of Acral lentiginous melanoma, showing a band-like chronic inflammatory cell infiltrate as an associated feature. (H&E, ×100).

Acral melanoma. Histopathology showing in situ acral lentiginous melanoma (ALM), characterized by a lentiginous growth pattern. This image displays a continuous proliferation of atypical melanocytes with enlarged hyperchromatic nuclei and prominent dendrites along the dermoepidermal junction (arrowhead). At this late stage of the lesion, there is pagetoid spread and scattered junctional nests at the tips of the rete ridges (arrow), where the confluence of cells has increased. Established lesions also show acanthosis, hypergranulosis, and hyperkeratosis, with marked elongation of the rete ridges. (H&E, ×100).

Acral melanoma. Histopathology at higher magnification, showing the characteristics of tumor cells in acral lentiginous melanoma (ALM). The atypical melanocytes are hyperchromatic, consistent with enlarged hyperchromatic nuclei, and exhibit a cytoplasmic fixation retraction artefact (arrowhead). These cells can be spindle or epithelioid. The dermis contains a chronic inflammatory cell infiltrate, which is often described as band-like and surrounding the tumors, associated with macrophages (arrow). (H&E, ×400).

Histopathology of Acral lentiginous melanoma (ALM) showing a prominent ‘nodular-like’ vertical growth phase on the left side of the image. Adjacent to this, on the right side, there is a radial growth phase characterized by a lentiginous proliferation of atypical melanocytes along the dermoepidermal junction. The presence of an adjacent radial growth phase, alongside a vertical growth phase, is a key feature that distinguishes ALM from Nodular Melanoma (NM), as NM typically lacks this adjacent radial component. The lentiginous growth pattern observed here is often associated with KIT expression, which, when assessed by immunohistochemistry, generally supports a diagnosis of ALM. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×20 magnification.

Representative pathology slide from the primary excision of the exophytic clitoral mass demonstrating melanoma. This hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain (low power, 0.4×) shows the clitoral tumor. The excisional biopsy demonstrated ulcerated melanoma with spindle cell features, extending to a Breslow depth of at least 28 mm. The deep resection margin was focally involved by invasive melanoma, and the peripheral epidermal margins were also involved by the in-situ component of melanoma. Immunohistochemical stains, including SOX10, S100, HMB45, and MART1, were positive in the lesional cells, confirming the diagnosis.

Representative pathology slide from the primary excision of the exophytic clitoral mass demonstrating melanoma. This hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain (10× magnification) shows invasive melanoma with spindled cell morphology and an overlying in-situ component. The excisional biopsy demonstrated ulcerated melanoma with spindle cell features, extending to a Breslow depth of at least 28 mm. The deep resection margin was focally involved by invasive melanoma, and the peripheral epidermal margins were also involved by the in-situ component of melanoma. Immunohistochemical stains, including SOX10, S100, HMB45, and MART1, were positive in the lesional cells, confirming the diagnosis.

Histopathology (Hematoxylin and eosin (HE) staining, 400x magnification) showing typical features of melanocytoma, revealing spindle and epithelioid cells containing melanin pigment in the cytoplasm. These cells are assembled to form sheets, bundles, nests, or whorls and are surrounded by reticulin fibres (yellow arrow). This examination contributes to the histopathological confirmation of the lesion as a primary and intramedullary intermediate grade melanocytoma at the T9-T10 level.

Histopathology (Hematoxylin and eosin (HE) staining, 400x magnification) showing typical features of melanocytoma after the removal of melanin pigment from the cytoplasm. This procedure allows for clearer visualization of the cellular morphology of the primary and intramedullary intermediate grade melanocytoma, which was confirmed by histopathological examination.

Photomicrograph (× 200 magnification) showing hematoxylin and eosin staining with a Tumor-Infiltrating Lymphocyte (TIL) score of TIL0. This indicates that 0%–5% of the tumor stroma is occupied by tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes (TILs). TIL0 was observed in 23.4% of cases, making it one of the most commonly observed TIL scores in the study.

Photomicrograph (× 200 magnification) showing hematoxylin and eosin staining with a Tumor-Infiltrating Lymphocyte (TIL) score of TIL3. This indicates that more than 50% of the tumor stroma is occupied by tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes (TILs). High TILs (TIL2 or TIL3, where TILs occupy > 25% of tumor stroma) were observed in 26.6% of patients, with TIL3 specifically occurring in the least number of cases (7.8%).

Histopathological view of metastatic melanoma to the skin, specifically from a second excised tumor. The image shows the characteristic features of metastatic melanoma in the skin, as revealed by histopathological examination. Staining was performed using Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Histopathology (hematoxylin and eosin, H&E stain) showing a junctional amelanotic proliferation with a lentiginous pattern of growth, intraepidermal ascending cells, and deep follicular extension. A punch biopsy of the tumor revealed a predominantly lentiginous proliferation within the basal layer of the epidermis, with forming nests, consisting of epithelioid atypical cells, including areas of thinning of the epidermis with loss of rete ridges, and indefinite borders. Severe solar elastosis was present within the dermis, and no melanin pigmentation was identified. The diagnosis was amelanotic lentigo maligna melanoma with a Breslow thickness of 0.7 mm.

Histopathology (hematoxylin and eosin, H&E stain) showing a junctional amelanotic proliferation with a lentiginous pattern of growth. A punch biopsy of the tumor revealed a predominantly lentiginous proliferation within the basal layer of the epidermis, with forming nests, consisting of epithelioid atypical cells, including areas of thinning of the epidermis with loss of rete ridges, and indefinite borders. Severe solar elastosis was present within the dermis, and no melanin pigmentation was identified. The diagnosis was amelanotic lentigo maligna melanoma with a Breslow thickness of 0.7 mm.

Histopathology (hematoxylin and eosin, H&E stain) showing irregular nests formation with bridging of rete ridges and small foci of papillary dermal invasion. A punch biopsy of the tumor specimen revealed a predominantly lentiginous proliferation within the basal layer of the epidermis, with forming nests, consisting of epithelioid atypical cells, including areas of thinning of the epidermis with loss of rete ridges, and indefinite borders. Severe solar elastosis was present within the dermis, and no melanin pigmentation was identified. The diagnosis was amelanotic lentigo maligna melanoma with a Breslow thickness of 0.7 mm.
Routine hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining of a cell block prepared from the lymph node FNA, visualizing numerous small cell populations with a high nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio.
Routine hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining of a subsequent needle-core biopsy showing populations of small pleomorphic cells.

Whole view of a nodular lesion showing two distinct components: a central dermal nodule of atypical fibroxanthoma (AFX) surrounded by an invasive melanoma component. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

High power histopathology of an atypical fibroxanthoma (AFX) component, which presents as a well-circumscribed but unencapsulated dermal nodule with elevation of the overlying epidermis. The image shows enlarged, atypical, and mononuclear cells with vesicular nuclei and frequent mitoses, including atypical mitoses. These atypical mononuclear cells, which exhibit marked nuclear pleomorphism and a high mitotic count, are admixed with many atypical multinucleated giant cells, described as osteoclast-like. This distinct nodule is confined to the dermis and has a well-defined, regular border, with no evidence of necrosis, vascular space invasion, or perineural infiltration. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E).

A higher power histopathological view illustrating an invasive melanoma component, located to the right of the image, and an atypical fibroxanthoma (AFX) component, located to the left of the image. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

High power view of an invasive malignant melanoma, superficial spreading subtype, mainly showing its junctional component. The image displays enlarged, atypical, epithelioid melanocytes that are primarily forming nests, with some ascending through the epidermis (pagetoid spread). This melanoma had a Breslow thickness of 3.0mm with no evidence of ulceration, corresponding to a pathological stage of pT3a (AJCC 8) and clinical stage 2A. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Histopathology of urinary bladder tissue from an 80-year-old Thai female diagnosed with primary malignant melanoma, spindle cell variant, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). The tissue is composed of solid nests and groups of atypical, poorly differentiated, highly mitotically active cells with prominent nucleoli. Magnification: x10.

Histopathology of urinary bladder tissue from an 80-year-old Thai female diagnosed with primary malignant melanoma, spindle cell variant, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). The tissue is composed of solid nests and groups of atypical, poorly differentiated, highly mitotically active cells with prominent nucleoli. Magnification: x100.

Histopathology of urinary bladder tissue from an 80-year-old Thai female diagnosed with primary malignant melanoma, spindle cell variant, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). The tissue is composed of solid nests and groups of atypical, poorly differentiated, highly mitotically active cells with prominent nucleoli. Magnification: x400.

Histopathology of a collision tumor from a 69-year-old man, specifically showing a dermal squamomelanocytic tumor at 10x magnification, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). The image reveals admixed malignant melanocytes and keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma cells. The mixed element included well-to-moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma and a melanotic neoplasm consistent with melanoma, characterized by cell atypia, mitoses, and a high cell proliferation index (Ki67: 80%). This dermal squamomelanocytic tumor was part of a larger collision tumor found on the patient's back, which also included a superficial spreading basal cell carcinoma.

Histopathology depicting histological details of the lentiginous component and some architectural disorder within a melanocytic proliferation. The lesions, often located on lower extremities, back, or upper extremities in patients aged 12 to 51 years, are composed of spindle-shaped melanocytes arranged in elongated nests. Stained with Hematoxylin-Eosin, original magnification 4× and 20×.

Low magnification (H&E; original magnification 25×) histopathology of the enucleated eye from a 60-year-old female patient with a choroidal melanoma. The image shows a poorly pigmented polypoid vital tumor mass surrounded by a well-defined and heavily pigmented necrotic “ring.” Radiation-induced necrosis is characterized by a sharp demarcation from the residual viable tumor tissue and by a high degree of pigmentation, often higher than that of the surrounding viable tumor, due to abundant infiltration of melanophages within necrotic areas. This patient underwent secondary enucleation 29 months after proton beam radiotherapy due to tumor regrowth.

Histological detail (H&E; original magnification 200×) from the enucleated eye of a 60-year-old female patient with choroidal melanoma. The image illustrates the abrupt transition between the vital tumor (at the bottom) and radiation-induced necrosis (at the top). Radiation-induced necrosis is characterized by a sharp and well-defined demarcation from the residual viable tumor tissue and a high degree of pigmentation, often more pronounced than the surrounding viable tumor, due to copious melanophage infiltration. This patient underwent secondary enucleation 29 months after proton beam radiotherapy due to tumor regrowth.

Histopathology, low magnification (H&E, original magnification 25×), illustrating a poorly pigmented, protruding melanoma mass of the posterior segment of the eye, that induces retinal detachment. This image is from a 79-year-old female patient with a poorly pigmented choroidal melanoma of the left eye, belonging to the nonirradiated group (primary enucleation), where hemorrhagic-type necrosis was detected.

Histological detail (H&E, original magnification 150×) of a focus of intratumoral hemorrhagic/coagulative-type necrosis, characterized by fibrin deposition and hemorrhagic infarction, and rimmed by extravasated histiocytes. This image is from a 79-year-old female patient with a poorly pigmented choroidal melanoma of the left eye, belonging to the nonirradiated group (primary enucleation). Hemorrhagic-type necrosis, characterized by fibrin deposition and red blood cell extravasation, was found in this patient's tumor.

Histological low magnification (H&E, original magnification 50×) showing the conventional pattern of radiation-induced necrosis in uveal melanoma from a 54-year-old male patient who underwent secondary enucleation after proton beam radiotherapy due to tumor regrowth. A sharp and very stark demarcation is seen between the residual poorly pigmented, viable tumor mass (on the right) and the abundant and heavily pigmented necrotic tissue (on the left). In the majority of cases, radiation-induced necrosis is characterized by this sharp demarcation from residual viable tumor tissue and by a high degree of pigmentation (higher than that of surrounding viable tumor), due to an abundant infiltration of melanophages within necrotic areas. Note the emergence of the optic nerve (black arrow), which is compressed but not infiltrated by the tumor.

Low magnification (H&E, original magnification 25×) histological examination of the enucleated eye from a 78-year-old female patient with a choroidal melanoma. The patient underwent secondary enucleation 18 months after proton beam radiotherapy due to tumor regrowth. The image shows a largely viable and poorly pigmented residual tumor mass, located at the posterior segment of the eye, that contains multiple intratumoral foci of hemorrhagic/coagulative-type necrosis. This specific case (1 out of 7 described in the paper) exhibits a peculiar feature of moderate hemorrhagic infarction, characterized by fibrin deposition and red blood cell extravasation within the necrotic foci.

Higher magnification (H&E, original magnification 150×) histological examination of the enucleated eye from a 78-year-old female patient with a choroidal melanoma. The patient underwent secondary enucleation 18 months after proton beam radiotherapy due to tumor regrowth. The image shows necrotic foci exhibiting abundant fibrin deposition and hemorrhagic infarction, consistent with the peculiar features described in this specific case (1 out of 7 described in the paper), which also include red blood cell extravasation. These necrotic foci are rimmed by heavily-pigmented extravasated melanophages, demonstrating a striking consistency between the histologic and MR findings regarding the necrotic focus.

Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained histopathology image of the hippocampal cortex from a 21-year-old man with Nevus Sebaceous Syndrome (NSS) and drug-resistant seizures, obtained following a right anterior temporal lobectomy at age 4 years. At 20× original objective, the image shows intact neurons (CA3) in the right half of the field (arrows) with an abrupt disappearance and transition to mesial temporal sclerosis in the left half of the field, consistent with prominent neuronal loss from the cornu ammonis.

Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained histopathology image of the temporal cortex from a 21-year-old man with Nevus Sebaceous Syndrome (NSS) and drug-resistant seizures, obtained following a right anterior temporal lobectomy. At 10× original objective, this representative section of the temporal cortex shows preserved horizontal lamination, with molecular (I) and external granular (II) laminae only depicted. Subpial gliosis, a feature seen in protracted seizures, is indicated by a broad arrow.

Histopathology from an excisional biopsy, performed due to a hypothesis of melanoma, showing a close-up (×100 magnification) of a heavy melanophage infiltrate in the reticular dermis (Clark III). The histopathological examination revealed multiple aggregates of melanophages, which are macrophages full of melanin pigment, leading to a diagnosis of tumoral melanosis. The image is stained with Hematoxylin & eosin.
Light microscopy showing increased melanin pigment with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining at ×150 magnification.
Light microscopy showing increased melanin pigment with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining at ×400 magnification, where the pigment was also observed in suprabasal layers.

Histopathology showing ulcerated epidermis and malignant proliferation of anaplastic melanocytes arranged in small nests invading the dermis. The malignant melanocytes are highly pleomorphic, with large hyperchromatic nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and atypical mitotic figures. No melanin pigmented cells were seen. Hematoxylin & eosin, X40 magnification.

Histopathology showing ulcerated epidermis and malignant proliferation of anaplastic melanocytes arranged in small nests invading the dermis. The malignant melanocytes are highly pleomorphic, with large hyperchromatic nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and atypical mitotic figures. No melanin pigmented cells were seen. Hematoxylin & eosin, X4 magnification.

Histopathology of the biopsied lesion from a 14-year-old boy's right shin, revealing intradermal nevoid nests consistent with a congenital melanocytic nevus (CMN). This observation supports the overall diagnosis of a large CMN with a halo phenomenon. (H&E, ×200)

Histopathology of the biopsied lesion from a 14-year-old boy's right shin, showing hypermelanosis in the epidermal basal cell layer. This corresponds to the hyperpigmented area of the lesion, which is part of a large congenital melanocytic nevus (CMN) with a halo phenomenon. (H&E, ×200)

Histopathology of the biopsied lesion from a 14-year-old boy's right shin, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). The image shows a loss of epidermal melanin and dermal nevomelanocytes, corresponding to the depigmented part of the lesion, a feature observed in the context of a large congenital melanocytic nevus (CMN) with a halo phenomenon. (H&E, ×200)
Histopathological analysis of the tumour tissue from case 1, stained with Haematoxylin and eosin, showing tumour cells at × 200 magnification.
Histopathological analysis of the tumour tissue from case 1, stained with Haematoxylin and eosin, showing tumour cells at × 200 magnification.
Histopathological analysis of the tumour tissue from case 1, stained with Haematoxylin and eosin, showing tumour cells at × 200 magnification.
Histological analysis of the tumour tissue in case 2. Haematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining showing the tumour cells. Original magnification × 200.
Histological analysis of the tumour tissue in case 2. Haematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining showing the tumour cells. Original magnification × 200.
Histological analysis of the tumour tissue in case 2. Haematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining showing the tumour cells. Original magnification × 200.

Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) stained section from a shave biopsy of the conjunctival mucosa, revealing a proliferation of singly dispersed spindle to round cells within a prominent myxoid stroma. This histopathological finding is consistent with a conjunctival myxoid stromal tumor. Magnification x 40.
Histopathology image (hematoxylin and eosin, ×100 magnification) showing melanoma in situ confined to the epidermis, alongside a basal cell carcinoma located in the corium.

Histopathological image (hematoxylin and eosin, ×100 magnification) showing the collision lesion. The image displays a part of acanthotic seborrheic keratosis on the left side and melanoma in situ on the right side.

Histopathology image (hematoxylin and eosin, ×100 magnification) showing a collision tumor. The left side displays features of a seborrheic keratosis, while the right side displays features consistent with a basal cell carcinoma.

Microscopic examination of a large cystic structure, diagnosed as Follicular Sebaceous Hamartoma (FSCH). This specimen was obtained from an excised 2 x 1 cm preauricular cyst from a 17-year-old woman who presented with swelling, pain, and discharge in the left preauricular region. The image shows the large cystic structure surrounded by mature sebaceous follicles within a fibrovascular stroma. Histopathological examination revealed the cyst to be lined with keratinized stratified squamous epithelium, with mature sebaceous lobules observed on the floor of the fibrovascular stroma. The stroma also contains cartilage, fat, and nerve tissues, with nerve and fat sections clearly visible in the dermis. Additionally, increased collagen fibers are present around the sebaceous follicles and the large cystic structure. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification ×40.

Histopathological image of the limbal mass from Panel A, following excisional biopsy, showing wavy thick collagenous fibers and fat with overlying skin-like epithelium and pilosebaceous units. This appearance confirms the diagnosis of a choristoma, a developmental lesion typically encountered in children. (Original magnification × 50, hematoxylin and eosin stain).

Histopathological picture of the collapsed cyst wall from Panel C, following excisional biopsy. The wall consists of nonkeratinizing stratified squamous epithelium, representing the structure of an inclusion cyst. Tumor-like lesions, such as cysts, were observed as one of the less frequent categories of conjunctival lesions in this study. (Original magnification × 100, hematoxylin and eosin stain).

Histopathology image of the conjunctival lesion from Panel E, showing lobular areas of capillary proliferation. The final diagnosis is a capillary hemangioma, confirming its vascular nature, which represents one of the less frequent categories of conjunctival lesions. (Original magnification × 100, hematoxylin and eosin stain).

Histopathology corresponding to the lesion in Panel A, showing melanocytic cells within the stroma. The lesion exhibits mild architectural atypia (loss of maturity) but no cytological atypia, and was finally diagnosed as a benign subepithelial nevus. This finding is consistent with melanocytic lesions observed in adult patients, which accounted for 9.8% of cases, typically occurring around a mean age of 36.7 ± 17.3 years, and were always unilateral. (Original magnification × 200, hematoxylin and eosin stain).

Histopathological appearance of the papillomatous conjunctival lesion from Panel A, corresponding to an epithelial lesion. The image shows thick epithelium, an underlying fibrovascular core, and importantly, absent dysplasia, distinguishing it from the 75% of epithelial lesions in the study that were either malignant or premalignant. The section is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (original magnification × 200).

Histopathological examination of a conjunctival epithelial lesion, such as those clinically suspected of OSSN (as in Panel E). The section displays thick epithelium with moderate-to-severe dysplasia that does not involve the full thickness of the epithelium. This represents part of the wide spectrum of intraepithelial diseases of the conjunctiva ranging from mild squamous dysplasia to invasive SCC, observed in the study. 75% of epithelial lesions were found to be either malignant or premalignant. The section is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (original magnification × 400).

Histopathological evidence of excised tissue from a pterygium-like epithelial lesion (like that in Panel G), showing invasive squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) with overlying metaplasia of the conjunctival epithelium and early keratinization (black arrow), corresponding to the area of leukoplakia. This invasive SCC represents the severe end of the spectrum of intraepithelial diseases of the conjunctiva encountered in the study, where ocular surface squamous neoplasia (OSSN) was the most frequent malignant lesion (50% of adult specimens). The section is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (original magnification × 100).

Histopathology of the pinkish conjunctival mass from a child, shown clinically in Panel A. The image reveals a subepithelial mature lymphocytic infiltrate with follicle formation and germinal centers. The lesion was diagnosed as benign reactive lymphoid hyperplasia, a type of hematolymphoid lesion, a category found in pediatric patients. This diagnosis was further supported by immunohistochemical staining results. The image is captured at original magnification × 200, stained with hematoxylin and eosin.

Histopathology of the surgically excised salmon patch lesion from the 53-year-old adult female described in Panel C. The image displays sheets of mature lymphocytes, characteristic of mucosal-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphoma. Hematolymphoid lesions, including MALT lymphoma, represent 4.3% of conjunctival lesions identified in adult patients. The image is captured at original magnification × 400, stained with hematoxylin and eosin.

Histopathological appearance of the sessile, gelatinous inferior conjunctival lesion from an adult female, 33 years old, corresponding to the clinical presentation in Panel A. The image shows a papillomatous lesion with thick epithelium, absent dysplasia, and an underlying fibrovascular core, confirming the diagnosis of a benign squamous papilloma. While the study indicated that 75% of adult epithelial lesions were either malignant or premalignant (dysplasia), this specific lesion demonstrates benign features. Epithelial lesions in adults were also consistently unilateral. (Original magnification × 200, hematoxylin and eosin stain).

Histopathology (hematoxylin and eosin, H&E, x20 magnification) of the right upper eyelid basal cell carcinoma (BCC) corresponding to the clinical presentation in panel (a). The image reveals nests of tumor cells with a characteristic peripheral palisading pattern. BCC is the second most common malignant eyelid lesion, accounting for 21.1% of such cases, and commonly affects individuals over 60 years of age. Malignant eyelid lesions frequently involve the upper eyelid (46%) and often present unilaterally, with a preponderance for the right eye.

Microphotograph (hematoxylin and eosin, H&E, x40 magnification) displaying histopathological features of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) from the left lower eyelid, corresponding to the clinical presentation in panel (c). The image shows tumor cells characterized by acidophilic cytoplasm, prominent nuclei, and occasional keratin pearls. SCC represents 10.8% of malignant eyelid lesions and is more commonly found in patients aged 41-60 years. Malignant lesions in the lower eyelid account for 43% of cases.

Microphotograph (hematoxylin and eosin, H&E, x20 magnification) of molluscum contagiosum, corresponding to the clinical presentation in panel (e). The image reveals epidermal hyperplasia with characteristic eosinophilic inclusion bodies, also known as Henderson–Patterson bodies, confirming the diagnosis.
Histopathology showing perifollicular lymphohistocytic infiltrate and fibrosis, alongside a mild perivascular infiltrate. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).
Histopathology showing basket weave stratum corneum, atrophic epidermis, and small foci of lymphocytic exocytosis and pigment incontinence in the dermis. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E).

Histopathology of eosinophilic pattern colitis, documented in one patient (Figure 3) and also observed in two patients in combination with apoptotic and ischemic patterns. This panel shows a section from the left colon at 6× magnification, displaying a dense inflammatory infiltrate in the lamina propria with middle glandular distortion, stained with hematoxylin and eosin.

Histopathology of the distal colon from a patient who underwent surgical resection of the left colon for acute abdomen due to an intestinal perforation. The image shows extensive and severe ischemic pattern colitis, characterized by flattened mucosa and a thinned wall, at 6× magnification, stained with hematoxylin and eosin.

Histopathology showing ischemic changes in the colon from a patient who underwent surgical resection of the left colon for acute abdomen due to an intestinal perforation, consistent with extensive and severe ischemic pattern colitis. The image depicts extensively necrotic mucosa, neutrophilic infiltrate, and blood vessels ectasia, at 25× magnification, stained with hematoxylin and eosin.

Histopathology of apoptotic pattern colitis in the right colon, observed in patients where an apoptotic pattern was documented. This image, at 9x magnification, shows significant glandular atrophy and distortion. The section is stained with hematoxylin and eosin.

Histopathology of apoptotic pattern colitis, showing apoptotic bodies present within the glandular elements. This microscopic view, at 25x magnification, illustrates a key feature of the apoptotic pattern observed in patients. The section is stained with hematoxylin and eosin.

Histopathology of a skin nodule showing metastatic melanoma before mRNA vaccine treatment. This image is from a recurrent metastatic melanoma in a patient who had received various treatments, including nivolumab, which kept her disease under control for 15 months. The nodule displays epithelioid and neoplastic spindle cells. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H-E) at 4× magnification.

Histopathology of a skin nodule showing metastatic melanoma before mRNA vaccine treatment. This image is from a recurrent metastatic melanoma in a patient who had received various treatments, including nivolumab, which kept her disease under control for 15 months. The nodule exhibits lymphocytic infiltration. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H-E) at 20× magnification.

Histopathology of a skin nodule showing metastatic melanoma after mRNA vaccine treatment. This image is from a nodule surgically removed and histologically examined post-vaccine, with its histopathology compared to a previously removed melanoma nodule. The image shows prominent hemorrhagic deposits and necroses. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H-E) at 4× magnification.

Histopathology of a skin nodule showing metastatic melanoma after mRNA vaccine treatment. This image is from a nodule surgically removed and histologically examined post-vaccine, with its histopathology compared to a previously removed melanoma nodule. The image reveals marked nuclear atypia and polymorphism, with no lymphocytic infiltration. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H-E) at 20× magnification (by conventional light microscope).

Photomicrograph of an atypical Spitz tumor harboring NTRK1 fusion. This image, taken at low magnification, shows a slightly raised, compound, and symmetric melanocytic proliferation. Such lesions commonly exhibit thin and elongated (filigree-like) rete ridges, a flat-base or wedge shape silhouette, and lobulated nests of epithelioid and spindle melanocytes with mild to moderate nuclear pleomorphism. H&E staining; original magnification 12.5×.

Photomicrograph of an atypical Spitz tumor harboring NTRK1 fusion, illustrating a compound and symmetric melanocytic proliferation with filigree-like rete ridges and a flat-base silhouette. The image details lobulated nests of epithelioid and spindle melanocytes exhibiting moderate nuclear pleomorphism. Histologically, these tumors often show exaggerated maturation of melanocytes, and Kamino bodies are frequently encountered, while mitoses are rare. H&E staining; original magnification 100×.

Photomicrograph of an atypical Spitz tumor harboring NTRK1 fusion, depicting lobulated nests of epithelioid and spindle melanocytes with moderate nuclear pleomorphism. This compound and symmetric melanocytic proliferation typically presents with thin and elongated (filigree-like) rete ridges and a flat-base silhouette. At this magnification, features like mild to moderate nuclear pleomorphism and exaggerated maturation of epithelioid and/or spindle melanocytes are visible. Kamino bodies are frequently encountered, while mitoses are rare. H&E staining; original magnification 200×.

Photomicrograph showing a Spitz nevus harboring an HRAS mutation, observed at 10× magnification with H&E staining. The image displays a symmetric, exophytic, and predominantly intradermal melanocytic proliferation with a flat base. It is composed of fascicles of large spindle melanocytes characterized by amphophilic cytoplasm, moderately pleomorphic vesicular nuclei, and distinct nucleoli. These melanocytes are intermingled with thick collagen bundles, contributing to a desmoplastic appearance, a common feature in Spitz neoplasms with HRAS aberrations. These lesions tend to be symmetric with an infiltrative base, and while mitoses are usually rare and not atypical, moderate cytological atypia can be present in a significant percentage of HRAS-mutated cases.

Photomicrograph showing a Spitz nevus harboring an HRAS mutation, observed at 100× magnification with H&E staining. The image displays a symmetric, exophytic, and predominantly intradermal melanocytic proliferation with a flat base. It is composed of fascicles of large spindle melanocytes characterized by amphophilic cytoplasm, moderately pleomorphic vesicular nuclei, and distinct nucleoli. These melanocytes are intermingled with thick collagen bundles, contributing to a desmoplastic appearance, a common feature in Spitz neoplasms with HRAS aberrations. These lesions tend to be symmetric with an infiltrative base, and while mitoses are usually rare and not atypical, moderate cytological atypia can be present in a significant percentage of HRAS-mutated cases.

Photomicrograph showing a Spitz nevus harboring an HRAS mutation, observed at 200× magnification with H&E staining. The image displays a symmetric, exophytic, and predominantly intradermal melanocytic proliferation with a flat base. It is composed of fascicles of large spindle melanocytes characterized by amphophilic cytoplasm, moderately pleomorphic vesicular nuclei, and distinct nucleoli. These melanocytes are intermingled with thick collagen bundles, contributing to a desmoplastic appearance, a common feature in Spitz neoplasms with HRAS aberrations. These lesions tend to be symmetric with an infiltrative base, and while mitoses are usually rare and not atypical, moderate cytological atypia can be present in a significant percentage of HRAS-mutated cases.

Photomicrograph of a Spitz nevus harboring ALK fusion, showing a large, exophytic and dermal melanocytic proliferation with an infiltrative base. Clinically, ALK-fused Spitz neoplasms tend to be large and solitary papules or nodules, often arising on the extremities of young patients. Histologically, most of these lesions share a distinctive pattern substantiated by a compound wedge shape silhouette with a bulbous and/or infiltrative base. The proliferation is composed of nonpigmented, large, epithelioid and spindle melanocytes with amphophilic cytoplasm, vesicular nuclei, and prominent nucleoli, arranged in plexiform intersecting fascicles. H&E staining; original magnification 10×.

Photomicrograph of a Spitz nevus harboring ALK fusion, showing a dermal melanocytic proliferation composed of nonpigmented, large, epithelioid and spindle melanocytes with amphophilic cytoplasm, vesicular nuclei, and prominent nucleoli, arranged in plexiform intersecting fascicles. The presence of non-pigmented, large, spindle melanocytes with pericellular clefts, amphophilic cytoplasm, vesicular nuclei, and prominent nucleoli, growing in plexiform intersecting fascicles, appears as a hallmark of ALK fusions. The epidermis is often hyperplastic and pagetoid spread is usually absent. Nuclear pleomorphism is usually mild and rarely moderate. H&E staining; original magnification 100×.

Photomicrograph of a Spitz nevus harboring ALK fusion, detailing the characteristic cellular features. The image shows nonpigmented, large, epithelioid and spindle melanocytes with amphophilic cytoplasm, vesicular nuclei, and prominent nucleoli, arranged in plexiform intersecting fascicles. This growth pattern, along with pericellular clefts, is considered a hallmark for ALK fusions in Spitz neoplasms. Nuclear pleomorphism in these lesions is typically mild. H&E staining; original magnification 200×.

Photomicrograph showing a prototypical Spitz nevus, a benign melanocytic proliferation. This low-magnification view (original magnification 10×) highlights the distinctive architectural features of the lesion, which is symmetric, slightly raised, and compound, demonstrating a maturating melanocytic proliferation with epidermal hyperplasia and a flat base. The lesion often presents with a dome-shaped, wedge-shaped, or plaque-like silhouette, characterized by sharp lateral borders and maturation towards the deep part. Scattered Kamino bodies, which are small to large dull eosinophilic globules composed of amorphous filaments, may be seen. The pattern of growth is predominantly nested, composed of spindle and epithelioid melanocytes. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Photomicrograph illustrating a prototypical Spitz nevus, a benign melanocytic proliferation. This view (original magnification 100×) shows the characteristic architectural and cytological features, including large clefting nests of spindle and epithelioid melanocytes with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm. The lesion exhibits epidermal hyperplasia, and the overlying epidermis may be separated from the junctional nests and single melanocytes by clefts. Nests often display varying cellularity, size, and shape, and are typically arranged in parallel to the rete ridges. Scattered Kamino bodies, which are dull eosinophilic globules composed of amorphous filaments, are also present. The melanocytes feature moderately pleomorphic vesicular nuclei and prominent nucleoli. There is a predominance of enlarged epithelioid and/or spindle melanocytes with abundant eosinophilic or amphophilic cytoplasm, often with a “ground-glass” appearance, and round to oval to spindle nuclei with finely dispersed chromatin and distinct nucleoli. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Photomicrograph depicting a prototypical Spitz nevus, a benign melanocytic proliferation. This image (original magnification 100×) reveals the characteristic architectural and cytological features, including large clefting nests of spindle and epithelioid melanocytes with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm. The lesion presents with epidermal hyperplasia, and the overlying epidermis may be separated from the junctional nests and single melanocytes by clefts. Nests often display varying cellularity, size, and shape, and are typically arranged in parallel to the rete ridges. Scattered Kamino bodies, which are dull eosinophilic globules composed of amorphous filaments, are also present. The melanocytes feature moderately pleomorphic vesicular nuclei and prominent nucleoli. There is a predominance of enlarged epithelioid and/or spindle melanocytes with abundant eosinophilic or amphophilic cytoplasm, often with a “ground-glass” appearance, and round to oval to spindle nuclei with finely dispersed chromatin and distinct nucleoli. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

High-magnification photomicrograph (original magnification 400×) of a prototypical Spitz nevus, a benign melanocytic proliferation. This view focuses on the detailed cytological characteristics, showing large clefting nests composed of spindle and epithelioid melanocytes. These melanocytes exhibit abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, moderately pleomorphic vesicular nuclei, and prominent nucleoli. There is a predominance of enlarged epithelioid and/or spindle melanocytes with abundant eosinophilic or amphophilic cytoplasm, often with a “ground-glass” appearance, and round to oval to spindle nuclei with finely dispersed chromatin and distinct nucleoli. Nuclear pseudoinclusions and multinucleated melanocytes may also be encountered. Scattered Kamino bodies, small to large dull eosinophilic globules composed of amorphous filaments, are visible. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Histopathology from an excisional biopsy stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at ×100 magnification. The image shows increased vascularity, sweat glands, and sweat ducts with lumen dilation and narrowing. Numerous capillary channels are observed surrounding or intermingled with the eccrine structures. There is also fibroblast proliferation around the sweat glands, accompanied by edema, and large malformed sebaceous glands without continuity with hair follicles, consistent with Eccrine Angiomatous Hamartoma (EAH).

Histopathology from an excisional biopsy stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at ×400 magnification. The image shows increased vascularity, sweat glands, and sweat ducts with lumen dilation and narrowing. Numerous capillary channels are observed surrounding or intermingled with the eccrine structures. There is also fibroblast proliferation around the sweat glands, accompanied by edema, and large malformed sebaceous glands without continuity with hair follicles, consistent with Eccrine Angiomatous Hamartoma (EAH).

Microscopic image of the gallbladder from a 71-year-old woman with a history of cutaneous malignant melanoma, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). The image shows malignant epithelioid cells proliferating in variably large nests within the lamina propria (x 40 magnification). These findings were part of the initial diagnosis of metastatic malignant melanoma to the gallbladder, which presented as a polypoid lesion.

Microscopic image of the gallbladder from a 71-year-old woman with a history of cutaneous malignant melanoma, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). The image reveals malignant cells characterized by large, hyperchromatic, atypical nuclei with prominent nucleoli and coarse brown cytoplasmic pigment (x 100 magnification). These cytological features were key to the initial diagnosis of metastatic malignant melanoma to the gallbladder.

Histopathology of an eccrine angiomatous hamartoma (EAH) showing compact orthokeratinized hyperkeratosis with mild focal acanthosis of the epidermis. The lesion itself, characterized by hamartomatous proliferation of eccrine glands and ducts, along with vascular proliferation, is apparent at the bottom of the image. The image is stained with hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×20.

Histopathology showing Eccrine angiomatous hamartoma (EAH), characterized by an ill-defined hamartomatous proliferation in the mid-dermis. The image displays lobules of mature eccrine secretory glands and ducts, some exhibiting dilation of the lumina, focal hyperplasia of the lining epithelium, and luminal tufting. These eccrine structures are intermingled with proliferating blood vessels, which include lobules of small capillary-sized, thin-walled, and focally anastomosing vessels. Some vessels are ectatic, while others are large with distinct, unevenly thickened muscular walls and partially developed internal elastic lamina, all lined by bland endothelial cells containing red blood cells. Mature adipose tissue is also interspersed among the eccrine lobules and vessels. The intervening stroma shows collagenous fibrous tissue with prominent myxoid changes, extravasated red blood cells, and focal hemosiderin deposition. There is no evidence of cytologic atypia or increased mitotic activity within the lesion. Stained with hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×20.

Histopathology of an Eccrine angiomatous hamartoma (EAH) with a component of arteriovenous malformation, showing vascular proliferation within the mid-dermis and separate soft tissue. The image displays lobules of small capillary-sized, thin-walled, and focally anastomosing blood vessels. Some of these vessels are ectatic, while others are large with distinct, unevenly thickened muscular walls and partially developed internal elastic lamina. The vessels are lined by a single layer of bland-looking endothelial cells and contain red blood cells in the lumina. This ill-defined hamartomatous proliferation is closely associated and intermingled with lobules of mature eccrine secretory glands and ducts, and mature adipose tissue. The intervening stroma shows collagenous fibrous tissue with prominent myxoid changes, extravasated red blood cells, focal hemosiderin deposition, scattered mast cells, and rare small lymphocytes. There is no evidence of any cytologic atypia or increased mitotic activity within the lesion. Stained with hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×40.

Histologic findings of a hematoxylin and eosin-stained section at × 100 magnification. The tumor boundary is clear, composed of solid, slightly lobulated flake cells with consistent morphology. Scattered dilated vacuolar components are visible within the tumor cells. Tumor cells are of medium size, with unclear borders, and a bright cytoplasm. The nucleus is deeply stained, oval to spindle-shaped, and the nucleolus is not visible. No necrosis or mitosis is noted.

Histologic findings of a hematoxylin and eosin-stained section at × 200 magnification. The tumor boundary is clear, composed of solid, slightly lobulated flake cells with consistent morphology. Scattered dilated vacuolar components are visible within the tumor cells. Tumor cells are of medium size, with unclear borders, and a bright cytoplasm. The nucleus is deeply stained, oval to spindle-shaped, and the nucleolus is not visible. No necrosis or mitosis is noted.

Histologic findings of a hematoxylin and eosin-stained section at × 400 magnification. The tumor boundary is clear, composed of solid, slightly lobulated flake cells with consistent morphology. Scattered dilated vacuolar components are visible within the tumor cells. Tumor cells are of medium size, with unclear borders, and a bright cytoplasm. The nucleus is deeply stained, oval to spindle-shaped, and the nucleolus is not visible. No necrosis or mitosis is noted.

Histopathology demonstrating a sebaceoma, which presents as a basaloid dermal tumor. The tumor exhibits features such as cyst formation, superficial ulceration, and hemorrhage. Ductal structures, lined by an eosinophilic cuticle, are visible within the tumor. A random admixture of basaloid cells and mature sebocytes is noted, with mature sebocytes indicated by a black arrow. (H&E, ×40 magnification).

Histopathology image showing a desmoplastic trichilemmoma. The lesion comprises a well-defined lobular tumor featuring dense desmoplastic stroma occupying its central portion. Focal clear cell differentiation (indicated by a black arrow) is observed, surrounded by a basement membrane. Irregular epithelial strands, which lack cellular atypia, are admixed within the desmoplastic stroma (indicated by a white arrow). (H&E stain, ×40 magnification).

Histopathology image showing Trichoblastoma, characterized by basaloid proliferations with peripheral palisading emanating from the epidermis. The image highlights the presence of papillary mesenchymal bodies (indicated by a black arrow) and adjacent fibrotic stroma. The tissue section is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at ×40 magnification.
Histopathology showing a pigmented trichoblastoma, exhibiting melanin pigmentation within a typical trichoblastoma (H&E, ×200 magnification).

Histopathology demonstrating a sebaceous adenoma. The image shows a circumscribed tumor composed of irregular sebaceous lobules with surrounding basaloid cells that are more than two layers thick (indicated by black arrows). A few mitotic figures (highlighted by a black circle) are observed within the central sebaceous lobule. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and captured at ×100 magnification.

Histopathology of a compound Spitz nevus from the outer surface of the left labium majus. The image shows a pigmented melanocytic proliferation expanding the superficial dermis with mild epidermal hyperplasia. This proliferation consists of pigmented and epithelioid melanocytes, and mild perilesional lymphocytic infiltration was observed. (H&E, scanning magnification ×10).

Histopathology of a compound Spitz nevus from the outer surface of the left labium majus. The image displays a proliferation of pigmented and epithelioid melanocytes, characterized by no mitoses or atypical features, arranged in dermal nests and partially aligned at the dermo-epidermal junction. (H&E, scanning magnification ×20).

High magnification histopathology of a compound Spitz nevus from the outer surface of the left labium majus. The image highlights melanocytes with vesicular nuclei, small nucleoli, and a homogeneous cytoplasm containing many melanin granules. These melanocytes are part of a proliferation with no mitoses or atypical features. (H&E, scanning magnification ×40).

Histopathology with Haematoxylin and eosin staining (× 4 magnification) showing prominent nests of atypical melanocytes of variable sizes (indicated by arrows) surrounded by an extensive inflammatory infiltrate (indicated by asterisks). This image is from a punch biopsy of a 1.5 cm new lesion on the lower left leg of a mid-20s woman. Histopathology confirmed a final diagnosis of invasive Acral Melanoma (AM) with Breslow thickness 0.9 mm, Clark level IV, and tumour stage pT1b.

Histopathology with Haematoxylin and eosin staining (× 10 magnification) showing prominent nests of atypical melanocytes of variable sizes (indicated by arrows) surrounded by an extensive inflammatory infiltrate (indicated by asterisks). This image is from a punch biopsy of a 1.5 cm new lesion on the lower left leg of a mid-20s woman. Histopathology confirmed a final diagnosis of invasive Acral Melanoma (AM) with Breslow thickness 0.9 mm, Clark level IV, and tumour stage pT1b.

Histopathology with Haematoxylin and eosin staining (× 40 magnification) showing prominent nests of atypical melanocytes of variable sizes (indicated by arrows) surrounded by an extensive inflammatory infiltrate (indicated by asterisks). This image is from a punch biopsy of a 1.5 cm new lesion on the lower left leg of a mid-20s woman. Histopathology confirmed a final diagnosis of invasive Acral Melanoma (AM) with Breslow thickness 0.9 mm, Clark level IV, and tumour stage pT1b.

Histopathological examination of the enucleated eye using Hematoxylin and eosin stain (magnification: ×10), showing the superior iridociliary junction. This image reveals infiltration of an epithelioid-cell-type uveal melanoma infiltrating the ciliary body, consistent with the diagnosis of ring melanoma confirmed by histopathological analyses of the enucleated eye. The superior part of the iris was missing due to paraffin embedding.

Histopathological examination of the enucleated eye using Hematoxylin and eosin stain (magnification: ×10), showing the nasal iridociliary junction. This image reveals infiltration of an epithelioid-cell-type uveal melanoma infiltrating the ciliary body, consistent with the diagnosis of ring melanoma confirmed by histopathological analyses of the enucleated eye. The nasal part of the iris was missing due to paraffin embedding.

Histopathological examination of the enucleated eye using Hematoxylin and eosin stain (magnification: ×10), showing the inferior iridociliary junction. This image reveals infiltration of an epithelioid-cell-type uveal melanoma infiltrating the ciliary body, consistent with the diagnosis of ring melanoma confirmed by histopathological analyses of the enucleated eye.

Histopathological examination of the enucleated eye using Hematoxylin and eosin stain (magnification: ×10), showing the temporal iridociliary junction. This image reveals infiltration of an epithelioid-cell-type uveal melanoma infiltrating the ciliary body, consistent with the diagnosis of ring melanoma confirmed by histopathological analyses of the enucleated eye.

Histopathology showing an iris nodule adjacent to the pupillary margin, indicated by an asterisk. The image reveals a focal dystrophic calcification, which is encircled. The section is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at an original magnification of ×100.

Histopathology showing spindle-shaped nevoid cells with scattered intracytoplasmic melanin pigment granules, indicated by an arrow. The section is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at an original magnification of ×400.

Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained tissue section, original magnification x 1000, showing a lesion from the anorectal region. The lesion is composed of sheets of moderately pleomorphic cells characterized by large nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and containing brown granular cytoplasmic inclusions (pigment). These microscopic features are consistent with melanoma, which was further confirmed by positive immunohistochemistry for melanoma markers HMB-45, S-100, and Vimentin.

Histopathological examination of an excisional biopsy specimen from a 20-year-old female patient, evidencing a compound fusocellular-epithelioid melanocytic nevus compatible with Spitz nevus characteristics. (Hematoxylin & eosin, ×200).

Microphotograph of the inflamed juvenile conjunctival nevus from Case No. 6 (boy patient, 13 years old). The histological section shows compound nevoid melanocytic proliferation made up of intraepithelial and subepithelial melanocytic nests organized around solid or cystic epithelial inclusions that also contain goblet cells. There is also a dense, diffuse, stromal inflammatory infiltrate with lymphocytes, plasma cells, and eosinophils. At the base of the lesion, lymphocytes are organized into a lymphoid follicle with a germinal center. Hematoxylin–Eosin (HE) staining, original magnification ×100.

Microphotograph of the inflamed juvenile conjunctival nevus from Case No. 6 (boy patient, 13 years old). The image displays cystic epithelial inclusions, with a predominance of goblet cells, surrounded by nests of nevoid melanocytes, along with a dense stromal inflammatory infiltrate. Hematoxylin–Eosin (HE) staining, original magnification ×200.

Microphotograph of the inflamed juvenile conjunctival nevus from Case No. 6 (boy patient, 13 years old). Nevoid melanocytic cells are located in the conjunctival epithelium, but also in the subepithelial connective tissue, alongside solid epithelial inclusions and a high number of eosinophils which are diffusely dispersed among the nests of nevoid melanocytes. Hematoxylin–Eosin (HE) staining, original magnification ×200.

Microphotograph of a compound conjunctival nevus from a 6-year-old girl (Case No. 3), showing nevoid melanocytes present along the covering epithelium. The lesion exhibits low pigmentation and a significant inflammatory lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate at its base. Nests of nevoid melanocytes are visible around and among multiple cystic spaces, which are lined by invaginated conjunctival epithelium. These nevoid cell nests are found on the base of the lesion and surrounding the cystic structures. The conjunctival epithelium displays squamous metaplasia and hyperplasia, with deep invagination and the formation of these prominent cystic structures that are enveloped by tumor cells. This represents a compound melanocytic nevus, characterized by lentiginous expansion, reduced pigmentation, and an important inflammatory infiltrate made up of lymphocytes and plasmacytes. Hematoxylin–Eosin (HE) staining, original magnification ×20.
Histological features of nevi as seen in hematoxylin and eosin-stained slides, showing nests of epithelioid melanocytes in a junctional nevus, arranged at the tips of rete ridges.

Histological features of nevi as seen in hematoxylin and eosin-stained slides, showing melanocytes at the basal layer (black arrows) that are spaced out, with intervening keratinocytes. A mitosis in a basal keratinocyte can also be seen (green arrow).
Histological features of nevi as seen in hematoxylin and eosin-stained slides, showing small clusters, cords, or single cells of dermal melanocytes trickling down the reticular dermis.

Histological features of nevi as seen in hematoxylin and eosin-stained slides, showing normal maturation, where large nests of melanocytes in the superficial dermis transition to smaller ones, and finally, single cells are dispersed from one another in the deep dermis.

Histological features of nevi as seen in hematoxylin and eosin-stained slides, showing Type A melanocytes as large epithelioid cells at the top, and Type B melanocytes as small round blue cells at the bottom in the dermis.
Histological features of nevi as seen in hematoxylin and eosin-stained slides, showing Type A melanocytes with oval to round nuclei and abundant pale pink cytoplasm, forming nests at the junction.
Histological features of nevi as seen in hematoxylin and eosin-stained slides, showing Type B melanocytes at low power, resembling lymphocytes. These can mimic an inflamed nevus.

Histological features of nevi as seen in hematoxylin and eosin-stained slides. At high power, Type B melanocytes (green arrows) can be differentiated from lymphocytes (yellow arrows). Lymphocytes are smaller in size than Type B melanocytes with darker chromatin.

Histopathology of Cellular blue nevus (CBN) showing small cellular nodules composed of epithelioid cells (original magnification ×20). CBN typically lacks overt atypia and high mitotic activity (usually <1/mm²), which helps distinguish it from atypical CBN or melanoma. This image is stained with hematoxylin-eosin.

Histopathology of Cellular blue nevus (CBN) showing small cellular nodules composed of epithelioid cells (original magnification ×400). CBN typically lacks overt atypia and high mitotic activity (usually <1/mm²), which helps distinguish it from atypical CBN or melanoma. This image is stained with hematoxylin-eosin.

Histopathology of a large Cellular blue nevus (CBN) demonstrating a dumbbell-shaped appearance (original magnification ×20). CBN typically lacks overt atypia and high mitotic activity (usually <1/mm²). This image is stained with hematoxylin-eosin.

Histopathology of a large Cellular blue nevus (CBN) demonstrating uniform oval cells with inconspicuous nucleoli and clear cytoplasm at high power (original magnification ×400). These cellular features are characteristic of CBN, which typically lacks overt atypia and high mitotic activity (usually <1/mm²). This image is stained with hematoxylin-eosin.

Histopathology of Cellular blue nevus (CBN) showing an area of cystic degeneration (original magnification ×20). This feature should not be confused with tumor necrosis, which is typically associated with malignancy like melanoma, whereas CBN usually lacks overt atypia and high mitotic activity. This image is stained with hematoxylin-eosin.

Histopathology of Cellular blue nevus (CBN) showing an area of cystic degeneration (original magnification ×200). This feature should not be confused with tumor necrosis, which is typically associated with malignancy like melanoma, whereas CBN usually lacks overt atypia and high mitotic activity. This image is stained with hematoxylin-eosin.

Histopathology of a large atypical Cellular blue nevus (CBN) displaying areas of hemorrhage and hemosiderin deposition (original magnification ×100). Hot spots of cellular atypia and increased mitotic activity can also be seen. While atypical CBN shows cytological atypia, it is not to the malignant extent seen in melanoma, which is recognized by marked atypia and mitotic activity (>3/mm²). This image is stained with hematoxylin-eosin.

Histopathology of a large atypical Cellular blue nevus (CBN) displaying areas of hemorrhage and hemosiderin deposition, along with hot spots of cellular atypia and increased mitotic activity (original magnification ×400). While these features characterize atypical CBN, they are not to the malignant extent seen in melanoma, which is defined by marked atypia and mitotic activity greater than 3/mm². This image is stained with hematoxylin-eosin.

Histopathological features of a giant congenital nevus. The junctional component of the nevus displays atypia. While such changes could be construed as melanoma in situ in an adult patient, in a neonatal setting, these specific findings are invariably considered benign. This image, stained with hematoxylin-eosin at original magnification ×84, highlights the histological characteristics relevant to assessing the controversial risk of malignant transformation associated with giant congenital melanocytic nevi.

Histopathology of melanoma as seen in a hematoxylin and eosin-stained slide, showing pagetoid spread. Pagetoid spread is indicated by single melanocytes going above the basal layer of the epidermis into the upper spinous and even granular layer.
Histopathology of melanoma as seen in a hematoxylin and eosin-stained slide, showing confluent growth. Confluent growth is indicated by single melanocytes crowding out the basal keratinocytes.
