Histopathology of acral lentiginous melanoma as seen in a hematoxylin and eosin-stained slide. The epidermis can be seen detaching from the dermis, giving the illusion of a blister, which is called an “unzipping” artifact and indicates confluent growth.

Histopathology of lentigo maligna type of melanoma as seen in a hematoxylin and eosin-stained slide. The melanocytes involve the hair follicle, trickling down along the basal layer into the follicle either as nests or single cells.

Histopathology of melanoma as seen in a hematoxylin and eosin-stained slide, illustrating the phenomenon of “epidermal consumption.” Nests of melanocytes occupy the epidermis entirely, with only a thin strip of keratinocytes left in the epidermis above the melanocytes.
Histopathology of melanoma as seen in a hematoxylin and eosin-stained slide, demonstrating abnormal maturation. Large nests of melanocytes can be seen from top to bottom of the lesion.
Histopathology of melanoma as seen in a hematoxylin and eosin-stained slide, showing cytological atypia. The cells are hyperchromatic and pleomorphic with prominent nucleoli.

Histopathology of invasive melanoma as seen in a hematoxylin and eosin-stained slide. Sheets of pleomorphic cells with clumped chromatin and a prominent atypical mitotic figure are visible in the dermis.

Histopathology of a deep penetrating nevus, showing a symmetrical wedge-shaped dermal proliferation. The lesion exhibits a plexiform appearance with several extensions going deep into the reticular dermis along the adnexa and neurovascular bundles. This image depicts histological features of a deep penetrating nevus. (Hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×40).

Histopathology of a deep penetrating nevus, showing a junctional component with nests and minimal lentiginous proliferation of melanocytes, similar to an ordinary nevus. There is a discontinuity between the junctional and the dermal component of the lesion in the papillary dermis. This image depicts histological features of a deep penetrating nevus. (Hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×200).

Histopathology of a deep penetrating nevus, showing discohesion of melanocytes in the deeper aspects of the lesion. In deep penetrating nevi, mild cytological atypia and pleomorphic nuclei can be seen along with rare mitosis in these deeper aspects, features that can be a pitfall leading to misdiagnosis of melanoma. This image depicts histological features of a deep penetrating nevus. (Hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×200).

Histopathology of a deep penetrating nevus, demonstrating melanocytes growing along the skin adnexa and neurovascular bundles. In deep penetrating nevi, a lack of maturation around the adnexa can be a pitfall leading to the misdiagnosis of melanoma. This image depicts histological features of a deep penetrating nevus. (Hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×100).

Histopathology showing a Spitz nevus at scanning magnification. This benign melanocytic lesion is characterized by a symmetrical appearance and predominantly nested growth pattern with clefting artifacts surrounding the nests. The epidermis is acanthotic. These features are typical of a benign Spitz nevus, contrasting with atypical Spitz tumors (AST) which might show disturbing features such as large size (≥10 mm), ulceration, abnormal maturation, poor circumscription, significant cellular atypia, or an increased number of mitoses in deeper parts of the lesion, or malignant features like dense sheets of pleomorphic cells. Stained with hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×15.

Histopathology showing a Spitz nevus at higher magnification, highlighting key characteristics of this benign melanocytic lesion. The image reveals large epithelioid melanocytes with prominent nucleoli. Kamino bodies are present and indicated with yellow arrowheads. Black arrows in the dermis point towards nevomelanocytes that have retained their spitzoid morphology but demonstrate maturation by becoming smaller as they descend into the dermis. This orderly maturation and the presence of Kamino bodies are typical features of a benign Spitz nevus, helping to differentiate it from atypical Spitz tumors, which can exhibit abnormal maturation, poor circumscription, significant cellular atypia, or malignant features such as dense sheets of pleomorphic cells. Stained with hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×100.
Histopathology of an atypical Spitz tumor, shown at low magnification (×5) and stained with hematoxylin-eosin. The image displays a large polypoid tumor with ulceration.

Histopathology of an atypical Spitz tumor, shown at high magnification (×400) and stained with hematoxylin-eosin. The image reveals spindled spitzoid cells arranged in cellular fascicles, exhibiting minimal pleomorphism and occasional mitotic figures (indicated by yellow arrowheads).

Histopathology of a sentinel lymph node from an atypical Spitz tumor, shown at high magnification (×200) and stained with hematoxylin-eosin. Yellow arrowheads highlight subcapsular deposits of spitzoid cells within the lymph node.

Histopathology of a combined nevus at original magnification ×20, stained with hematoxylin-eosin. The lesion displays asymmetry, which raises concern for melanoma developing within the nevus. In combined nevi, while the lesion may initially seem asymmetrical, symmetry often becomes evident when considering each component individually. Findings such as solar elastosis, pagetoid spread, pulverocyte-type cells, and melanoma in situ-like features in the epidermis should also raise concern for melanoma.

Histopathology of a combined nevus at high original magnification ×400, stained with hematoxylin-eosin. The image shows deep penetrating nevus cells in the upper part of the panel and conventional nevus cells in the lower part. This illustrates the distinct cellular components that can be present within a combined nevus. In adult patients, it is very rare for a melanoma to develop in the dermal component of a nevus without an overlying melanoma in situ.

Histopathology of cPEComa showing a dermal-based lesion, relatively sharply demarcated from the surrounding tissue and extending into the subcutaneous tissue. The tumor exhibits a clear cell appearance and a characteristic trabecular pattern. It consists of epithelioid cells containing eosinophilic or clear granular cytoplasm, with round and vesicular nuclei and small nucleoli. Hematoxylin-eosin stain, original magnification 5×.

Histopathology of cPEComa showing a dermal-based lesion, relatively sharply demarcated from the surrounding tissue and extending into the subcutaneous tissue. The tumor exhibits a clear cell appearance and a characteristic trabecular pattern. It consists of epithelioid cells containing eosinophilic or clear granular cytoplasm, with round and vesicular nuclei and small nucleoli. Hematoxylin-eosin stain, original magnification 10×.

Histopathology of cPEComa showing tumor cells arranged in a trabecular pattern around numerous thick-walled vessels (capillaries). The lesion, relatively sharply demarcated, extends into the subcutaneous tissue, and tumor cells sometimes infiltrated the subcutis. Hematoxylin-eosin stain, original magnification 20×.

Histopathology of cPEComa showing tumor cells arranged in a trabecular pattern around numerous thick-walled vessels (capillaries). The lesion, relatively sharply demarcated, extends into the subcutaneous tissue, and tumor cells sometimes infiltrated the subcutis. There is no necrosis and no mitotic figures observed. Hematoxylin-eosin stain, original magnification 40×.

Histological micrograph showing a dermal, clear cell lesion, identified as a clear cell PEComa (cPEComa), infiltrating the subcutis at one point. The lesion is relatively sharply demarked from the surrounding tissue and extends into the subcutaneous tissue. The tumor consists of epithelioid cells containing eosinophilic or clear granular cytoplasm, with round and vesicular nuclei and small nucleoli, often growing around thick-walled capillaries. A black arrow indicates the adipocytic lobules of the subcutis buried by the infiltration of the lesion. Stain: hematoxylin–eosin, original magnification: 4×.

Microscopy of a malignant melanocytic nerve sheath tumor (MMNST) revealed a well-encapsulated tumor with peripheral lymphoid cuffing and intratumoral lymphocytic infiltration. The tumor was composed of pigmented tumor cells and showed cystic degeneration. The gross specimen was a cystic tissue, 5.8 × 4 × 3.1 cm, with a smooth and partially dark-pigmented outer surface, noting dark brown materials at the inner surface of the cystic wall. (H&E stain, objective lenses ×4, original magnification ×40, scale bar 1000 μm).

Higher magnification microscopy of a malignant melanocytic nerve sheath tumor (MMNST) revealed tumor cells with an epithelioid to spindle shape, featuring mild nuclear atypia, pleomorphic and hyperchromatic nuclei, small nucleoli, frequent nuclear pseudoinclusions, and abundant intracytoplasmic melanin pigments. No psammomatous bodies were present, and mitotic activity was observed. (H&E stain, objective lenses ×40, original magnification ×400, scale bar 100 μm).

Histopathology with Hematoxylin and eosin stain (12.5× magnification) showing a highly degenerate and necrotic melanocytic lesion, centered at the junction of the posterior edge of the ciliary body and the choroid.
Histopathology with Hematoxylin and eosin stain (bleached section, 200× magnification) showing extensive necrosis within the melanocytic lesion.

Histopathology of a punch biopsy from the margin of a lesion on the left leg, showing pathologic features of disseminated superficial actinic porokeratosis (DSAP). The image displays an area of hyperkeratosis including a cornoid lamella (between black arrows), which is a column of parakeratotic cells situated above an area of invaginated epidermis. Dyskeratotic cells are observed in the epidermis beneath the cornoid lamella (black oval), and the epidermis also shows flattening of the rete ridges. Severe solar elastosis (black triangles) is present in the dermis. Hematoxylin and eosin stain, ×20 magnification.

Histopathology showing bland spindle and stellate cells with a myxoid stroma within the superficial dermis, arranged in a loosely fascicular pattern. This image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 100x magnification.
Histopathology at low power magnification showing intracorneal hemorrhage. This image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 40x magnification.
Histology section showing a melanocytic nevus, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at 100x magnification.

High-power hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain showing atypical features in a compound vulvar nevus in a patient aged 14 years, in a background of juvenile vulvar lichen sclerosus (JVLS). This view helps in the assessment of cytonuclear and architectural atypia, which are frequently observed in vulvar nevi associated with VLS. Bar = 0.05 mm.

High-power hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain showing atypical features in a compound vulvar nevus in a patient aged 14 years, in a background of juvenile vulvar lichen sclerosus (JVLS). This view allows for detailed examination of the cytological and architectural characteristics of the nevus, which often present as moderate to severe atypia in cases with VLS. Bar = 0.100 mm.

Histopathology showing melanocytic nevi (NN) in a sentinel lymph node, observed in H&E staining at ×100 magnification. Small groups of melanocytic cells are visible within the nodal capsule (indicated by an arrow), exhibiting bland cytomorphology. NN are growth-arrested melanocytic clusters typically diagnosed in sentinel lymph nodes draining melanoma, breast, vulvar, or penile cancer. Unlike most melanomas, NN usually have bland cytomorphology and no mitotic activity. The localization of these melanocytes within the capsule or trabeculae of the lymph node strongly supports the diagnosis of a benign NN.

Histopathology showing melanocytic nevi (NN) in a sentinel lymph node, observed in H&E staining at ×200 magnification. Small groups of melanocytic cells are visible within the nodal capsule (indicated by an arrow), exhibiting bland cytomorphology. NN are growth-arrested melanocytic clusters typically diagnosed in sentinel lymph nodes draining melanoma, breast, vulvar, or penile cancer. Unlike most melanomas, NN usually have bland cytomorphology and no mitotic activity. The localization of these melanocytes within the capsule or trabeculae of the lymph node strongly supports the diagnosis of a benign NN.

Histopathology of a desmoplastic trichilemmoma demonstrating a peripheral palisade of nuclei surrounded by a hyaline cuticle with areas of desmoplasia. This lesion represents one component of a broader pathologic diagnosis that also included a nevus sebaceus with a neurofibroma and a tumor of the follicular infundibulum. The image is H&E stained and captured at 40x magnification.

Histopathology at 40x magnification showing a proliferation of bland-appearing spindled cells within the dermis surrounded by loose collagenous stroma, which is consistent with neurofibroma (black arrows). This finding is observed in conjunction with a nevus sebaceus. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Higher power view of the bland-appearing spindled cells within the dermis, surrounded by loose collagenous stroma and admixed mast cells (noted by arrows), consistent with a neurofibroma. The image shows hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining at 100x magnification.

Histopathology demonstrating a tumor of follicular infundibulum, a follicular neoplasm composed of inter-anastomosing strands of basaloid epithelium (arrow) emerging from the underside of the epidermis. This tumor was part of a larger pathologic diagnosis for the lesion, which also included a nevus sebaceus and a desmoplastic trichilemmoma. H&E staining, 40x magnification.

Histopathology displaying epidermal papillomatosis (indicated by black arrow) with numerous large sebaceous glands (indicated by red arrow) directly attached to the overlying acanthotic epidermis (indicated by blue arrow), consistent with a nevus sebaceus. Additionally, a neurofibroma is observed (indicated by green arrow). This image was obtained from a lesion whose histopathology, following complete elliptical excision, showed the characteristic features of epidermal papillomatosis with numerous large sebaceous glands directly attached to the overlying acanthotic epidermis. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining, 20x magnification.

Histopathology of a well-circumscribed, multinodular, asymmetrically pigmented dermal tumor, consistent with melanocytic matricoma. The tumor shows no connection to the overlying epidermis. It is composed predominantly of basaloid cells with scant cytoplasm and distinct nucleoli, showing moderate pleomorphism and 10 mitoses per 10 high-power fields. Occasional aggregates of eosinophilic shadow cells are present, along with heavily pigmented dendritic melanocytes without atypia scattered among the basaloid cells, forming small clusters. No necrosis or calcification is observed in the tumor. (Hematoxylin & eosin, ×100).

Histopathology of a biopsy section stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), showing a papillary and reticular dermal lesion composed of mature adipose tissue. There is no connection with the underlying subcutaneous tissue. Interspersed bands of collagen bundles are present, along with scattered sebaceous and sweat glands exhibiting normal morphology. The overlying epidermis is unremarkable, and no evidence of malignancy is seen. These features are suggestive of a benign hamartomatous lesion, consistent with nevus lipomatosus superficialis. Original magnification 200X.

Histopathology of a biopsy section stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), showing a papillary and reticular dermal lesion composed of mature adipose tissue. There is no connection with the underlying subcutaneous tissue. Interspersed bands of collagen bundles are present, along with scattered sebaceous and sweat glands exhibiting normal morphology. The overlying epidermis is unremarkable, and no evidence of malignancy is seen. These features are suggestive of a benign hamartomatous lesion, consistent with nevus lipomatosus superficialis. Original magnification 400X.

Histopathological image of pleomorphic dermal sarcoma (PDS) demonstrating an associated feature: atypical mitotic figures. The tissue is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at an original magnification of ×200.

Histopathological image of pleomorphic dermal sarcoma (PDS) demonstrating associated features: intratumoral haemorrhage and haemosiderin. The tissue is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at an original magnification of ×200.

Histopathology showing pleomorphic dermal sarcoma (PDS), which is an atypical dermal spindle cell tumour originating within the dermis. The tumour extends to the overlying epidermis and often presents with extensive dermal solar elastosis. It is characterized by markedly pleomorphic spindle cells. (Haematoxylin and eosin stain; original magnification ×40).

Histopathology showing pleomorphic epithelioid spindle cells, which are typical of pleomorphic dermal sarcoma (PDS). PDS is an atypical spindle cell tumour originating within the dermis, often associated with extensive dermal solar elastosis, and the predominant morphological pattern is of markedly pleomorphic spindle cells. (Haematoxylin and eosin stain; original magnification ×200).

Histopathology showing pleomorphic dermal sarcoma (PDS) demonstrating a pushing border into the subcutis. PDS is an atypical spindle cell tumour originating within the dermis, often with extensive dermal solar elastosis, and composed of markedly pleomorphic spindle cells. This predominantly pushing type of invasion is observed in some PDS cases, with invasion depths commonly extending to the subcutaneous adipose tissue. (Haematoxylin and eosin stain; original magnification ×40).

Histopathology showing pleomorphic dermal sarcoma (PDS) demonstrating the typical fascicular growth pattern. PDS is an atypical spindle cell tumour originating within the dermis, often with extensive dermal solar elastosis. The predominant morphological pattern is of markedly pleomorphic spindle cells arranged in fascicles. This image is from the same tumour as shown in panel A. (Haematoxylin and eosin stain; original magnification ×200).

Histopathology from a skin biopsy of a 24-year-old male presenting with a slowly progressing, cribriform, brown macule on the trunk, consistent with PCZH. The image shows elongated epidermal rete ridges and an accumulation of pigment at the tip of the rete ridges in the basal layer (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, 100× magnification).

Histopathology from a skin biopsy of a 24-year-old male presenting with a slowly progressing, cribriform, brown macule on the trunk, consistent with PCZH. The image shows a few melanophages in the dermis (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, 400× magnification).

Histopathology of a skin lesion supporting a diagnosis of Nevus Sebaceous (NS). This image displays epidermal hyperplasia and hyperkeratosis (indicated by red arrow 'A'), consistent with the hyperplastic squamous epithelium observed, which also showed acanthosis and no nuclear abnormalities. Mild papillomatosis and infiltration of lymphocytes in the upper dermis are also visible (indicated by red arrow 'B'). The subdermal area features fibrocollagenous connective tissue with lymphocytic infiltration and vasodilation. Stained with Hematoxylin–eosin at 40× magnification.

Histopathology of a skin lesion supporting a diagnosis of Nevus Sebaceous (NS). This image demonstrates hyperplasia of the sebaceous glands (indicated by red arrow 'A'). The overall histopathological findings for the lesion include hyperplasia of the sebaceous glands, hair follicles, and sudoriferous glands, with no signs of malignancy observed. Stained with Hematoxylin–eosin at 100× magnification.

Microscopy of Case 3, a classical Nevus Lipomatosus Cutaneus Superficialis (NLCS), showing irregular acanthosis, increased capillaries within the papillary dermis, and lobules of adipocytes in the reticular dermis. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 40x magnification.

Microscopy of Case 4, a Nevus Lipomatosus Cutaneus Superficialis (NLCS), displaying a largely unremarkable epidermis, increased dermal vasculature, haphazardly arranged collagen bundles, and adipocytic tissue in the mid and lower dermis. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 40x magnification.

Histopathology of a 2.5 cm (23 mm) subcutaneous heel mass nodule from a 31-year-old man, showing a dermal nodular mass with fascicles of spindle cells and cellular nests separated by fibrous bands. There is no epidermal component found, with a grenz zone observed. This image was part of the histopathologic examination that led to an initial diagnosis of melanoma, later revised to cutaneous clear-cell sarcoma. Staining is Hematoxylin, Eosin, Saffron (HES), magnified ×40.

Histopathological photomicrograph of a Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) stained section showing spongiosis, acanthosis, and dendritic melanocytes within the parakeratinized stratified squamous epithelium. The image also displays the lamina propria containing melanin deposit.

Histopathology showing two distinct types of cystic lesions coexisting in the upper and lower dermis. A cystic invagination extends from the epidermis toward the upper dermis, maintaining a connection to the epidermal opening. Additionally, several cystic cavities of various sizes are present in the lower dermis (H&E, ×40).

Histopathology showing the invaginated cyst, which is lined by an epithelial bilayer with papillary projections. The inner, or luminal, layer consists of columnar epithelial cells, while the outer layer is composed of small cuboidal epithelial cells (H&E, ×200).

Histopathology showing decapitation secretion in the inner layer of the invaginated cyst, with some cellular debris observed within the cystic cavity. Plasma cell infiltrations are also present in the papillary core (H&E, ×400).

Histopathology showing a large cyst in the lower dermis, which is also lined by an epithelial bilayer. This bilayer consists of small cuboidal epithelial cells in the inner layer and myoepithelial cells in the outer layer. Focal decapitation secretion is noted in the inner layer of this deep dermal cystic lesion, along with some amorphous materials within the cystic cavity (H&E, ×200).

Histopathology of Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP) showing neoplastic cells infiltrating into subcutaneous fat tissues, forming a characteristic “honeycomb” pattern. This image represents a common histological finding in DFSP, a tumor type that generally exhibits diffuse positivity for CD34 in most cases (57 out of 66, or 86.3%). A minority of DFSP tumors (13.6%) may show patchy or negative CD34 staining, particularly in myxoid and fibrosarcomatous areas. Other immunohistochemical markers typically show negativity for desmin, S-100 protein, myogenin, Bcl-2, CD99, p16, p63, cytokeratin, and EMA, although some cases (9 out of 46, or 20%) may exhibit positivity or focal staining for smooth muscle actin (SMA). Image stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at × 200 magnification.

Histopathology of the myxoid component of Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP) from case 40. This panel shows the histological appearance of a myxoid area, which is known to be one of the variants of DFSP that can present with decreased or lost expression of CD34. Overall immunohistochemical analysis reveals that a minority of DFSP tumors (9 out of 66, or 13.6%) show patchy or negative staining for CD34, with this decreased expression mainly observed in myxoid and fibrosarcomatous areas. Most conventional DFSPs (86.3%) demonstrate diffuse CD34 positivity. Additionally, DFSPs are typically negative for desmin, S-100 protein, myogenin, Bcl-2, CD99, p16, p63, cytokeratin, and EMA, though a few cases (20%) may show focal positivity for smooth muscle actin (SMA). Image stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at × 200 magnification.

Histopathology of the fibrosarcomatous component of Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP) from case 1. This panel shows the histological appearance of a fibrosarcomatous area, which is identified as one of the variants of DFSP that can exhibit decreased or lost expression of CD34. According to immunohistochemical analysis, a minority of DFSP tumors (9 out of 66, or 13.6%) show patchy or negative staining for CD34, with this decreased expression mainly observed in myxoid and fibrosarcomatous areas. Most conventional DFSPs (86.3%) demonstrate diffuse CD34 positivity. DFSPs are generally negative for other markers such as desmin, S-100 protein, myogenin, Bcl-2, CD99, p16, p63, cytokeratin, and EMA, though some cases (20%) may show focal positivity for smooth muscle actin (SMA). Image stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at × 200 magnification.

Histologic findings of conventional dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP) in a pediatric patient. The lesion consisted of uniform bland spindled neoplastic cells arranged in a classic cartwheel pattern (H&E × 200).

Histologic findings of myxoid dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP) in a pediatric patient. The tumor had relatively low cellularity and consisted of pump spindle or stellated tumor cells diffusely distributed in prominent myxoid architecture with numerous vessels (H&E × 100).

Histologic findings of pigmented dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP) in a pediatric patient. The dendritic cells with melanin pigment punctuated within monotonous storiform area of conventional DFSP (H&E × 200).

Histologic findings of plaque-like dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP) in a pediatric patient. The dermal-based lesion composed of regular plump tumor cells presenting a horizontally oriented arrangement and a focal storiform structure (H&E × 100).

Histologic findings of giant cell fibroblastoma (case 65), a subtype of pediatric dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP). High proportion of hyperchromatic multinucleated giant cells scattered in the loosely fibrous and myxoid stroma, and lined pseudovascular spaces (H&E × 200).

Histologic findings of fibrosarcomatous dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP) in a pediatric patient. The lesion was composed of high-grade fibrosarcoma-like component, showing a typical herringbone appearance with increasing mitoses (H&E × 200; insert × 400).

Histopathology showing architectural features of a sinonasal mucosal melanoma, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E). The tumor is observed growing as a polypoid, edematous, and highly vascularized mass, with melanoma involving the entire polyp as multiple confluent nodules, reaching at least 1 mm Breslow thickness. The transitional respiratory epithelium is still recognizable all around. Mucosal melanomas are often characterized by significant cytological variability, including spindle, rhabdoid, epithelioid, small, or giant pleomorphic (often multinucleated) cells, which can pose diagnostic challenges in differentiating them from lymphomas, carcinomas, or sarcomas. Necrotic areas are frequently observed, and mitotic activity is typically high. While many mucosal melanomas are associated with an in situ lateral spread on the mucosal surface, their heterogeneous presentation often necessitates immunohistochemical staining (e.g., S100, MART-1, HMB45, or SOX10) to confirm their melanocytic origin.

Histopathology showing architectural features of a nodular mucosal melanoma, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E). This melanoma arises at the interface between intestinal and squamous perianal epithelium and has a Breslow thickness of 14 mm. Mucosal melanomas are often characterized by significant cytological variability, including spindle, rhabdoid, epithelioid, small, or giant pleomorphic (often multinucleated) cells, which can pose diagnostic challenges in differentiating them from lymphomas, carcinomas, or sarcomas. Necrotic areas are frequently observed, and mitotic activity is typically high. While many mucosal melanomas are associated with an in situ lateral spread on the mucosal surface, their heterogeneous presentation often necessitates immunohistochemical staining (e.g., S100, MART-1, HMB45, or SOX10) to confirm their melanocytic origin.

Histopathology showing architectural features of a vaginal nodular mucosal melanoma, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E). The tumor is superficially ulcerated and has a Breslow thickness of 9 mm. Notably, this particular melanoma does not exhibit any visible in situ component in the squamous vaginal epithelium, contrasting with the common finding of an in situ lateral spread often associated with most mucosal melanomas. These tumors are characterized by significant cytological variability, including spindle, rhabdoid, epithelioid, small, or giant pleomorphic (often multinucleated) cells, which can pose diagnostic challenges in differentiating them from lymphomas, carcinomas, or sarcomas. Necrotic areas are frequently observed, and mitotic activity is typically high. Due to their heterogeneous appearance, immunohistochemical staining (e.g., S100, MART-1, HMB45, or SOX10) is often required to confirm their melanocytic origin.

Histopathology showing unusual cytological features of mucosal melanoma in hematoxylin and eosin. This panel displays pleomorphic areas in an epithelioid vulvar melanoma. Epithelioid features were prevalent in 25 out of 33 cases in the study series. The melanocytes are irregularly shaped, and their nuclei appear bizarre. The arrow specifically indicates an abnormal mitotic figure.

Histopathology showing unusual cytological features of mucosal melanoma in hematoxylin and eosin. This panel illustrates a hyperpigmented genital melanoma, composed of middle-sized, mitotically active spindle cells. In the study series, two cases were composed of spindle hyperpigmented cells.

Histopathology showing unusual cytological features of mucosal melanoma in hematoxylin and eosin. This panel depicts a rectal melanoma with a rhabdoid appearance, a pattern seen in one case in the study series. The neoplastic cells show a large, eosinophilic cytoplasm and a peripherally located round nucleus.

Histopathology of a Spitz nevus (Hematoxylin and Eosin, ×40 magnification), showing a papillomatous lesion with a predominance of epithelioid melanocytic cells, cellular maturation in the deep dermis, and absence of atypia or mitosis.
Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained section of melanocytic matricoma revealing a circumscribed basaloid dermal nodule.
Higher powered view of a hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained section of melanocytic matricoma, revealing scattered shadow cells and melanin pigment within the tumor.
Hematoxylin and eosin stained histopathology section revealing characteristic features of melanocytic matricoma, including shadow cells and basaloid germinative cells with prominent melanin pigment.
Hematoxylin and eosin stained histopathology section highlighting prominent anucleate shadow cells, which are a characteristic feature of melanocytic matricoma.

Histopathology from the cutaneous malignant melanoma of the scalp (primary tumor, 25 years prior) in a 72-year-old male patient, showing malignant cells with pagetoid spread into the epidermis (red arrow). The tumor cells are arranged in a nesting pattern in the dermis, displaying round nuclei and vacuolated and pink cytoplasm. A dermal host response with lymphocytic infiltrate is also visible. This case is notable for the later development of an isolated splenic metastasis 25 years after the initial diagnosis of cutaneous malignant melanoma. Hematoxylin and eosin-stained section, magnification × 20.

Histopathology from the spleen of a 72-year-old male patient, showing replacement of the splenic parenchyma by a malignant neoplasm, consistent with metastasis from cutaneous malignant melanoma. Residual lymphoid cells are observed at the periphery (black arrow). The patient presented with elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels and a solitary 4 × 3 × 3 cm solid lesion in the spleen, making this a rare case of isolated splenic metastasis 25 years after the initial diagnosis. Hematoxylin and eosin-stained section, magnification × 4.

Histopathology from the spleen of a 72-year-old male patient, showing replacement of the splenic parenchyma by a malignant neoplasm, consistent with metastasis from cutaneous malignant melanoma. Residual lymphoid cells are observed at the periphery (black arrow). The patient presented with elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels and a solitary 4 × 3 × 3 cm solid lesion in the spleen, making this a rare case of isolated splenic metastasis 25 years after the initial diagnosis. Hematoxylin and eosin-stained section, magnification × 10.

High-power view histopathology from the spleen of a 72-year-old male patient, illustrating the morphology of the metastatic malignant neoplasm. It shows round, short spindly, and ovoid tumor cells arranged in vague solid and fascicular patterns, with pink and eosinophilic cytoplasm. This splenic lesion represents a rare isolated metastasis from a cutaneous malignant melanoma diagnosed 25 years prior. Hematoxylin and eosin-stained section, magnification × 40.

Photomicrograph of retinoblastoma, a Malignant Ocular Tumor (MOT) accounting for 44.7% (38/85 cases) of MOTs, showing a sheet of small blue cells with scant cytoplasm, hyperchromatic nuclei and scanty stroma. (Haematoxylin and Eosin stains, X40).

Photomicrograph showing well differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. Squamous cell carcinoma is a type of malignant odontogenic tumor (MOT), accounting for 45.9% (39/85 cases) of the MOTs observed in the study. The image is stained with Haematoxylin and Eosin at 400x magnification.

Photomicrograph showing a squamous cell papilloma, which was identified as the most common cause of benign orbito-ocular tumours (BOTs) in this study, accounting for 31.8% (21/66 cases) of such tumours. The papilloma consists of a fibrovascular core surrounded by stratified squamous epithelium. (Haematoxylin and Eosin stains, X100).

Photomicrograph depicting adenoid cystic carcinoma, identified as one of the less common Malignant Odontogenic Tumors (MOTs) observed in a study involving 85 cases. The image shows solid aggregates of basaloid cells characterized by hyperchromatic nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and desmoplastic stroma. Tubules lined by these basaloid cells are also present. (Haematoxylin and Eosin stains, X100).

Histopathology of in situ matrix melanomas, stained with Hematoxylin and eosin. Panel A shows almost invisible changes. While Nevus of Ota-type Melanoma (NUM) in situ typically exhibits an uneven distribution of solitary melanocytes with irregularly scattered atypical melanocytes, some cases can present with very subtle alterations, reflecting a varied melanocyte density.

Histopathology of in situ matrix melanomas, stained with Hematoxylin and eosin. Panel B shows a few obvious cells (arrow). These are indicative of increased numbers of single junctional atypical melanocytes, which is a key histopathologic clue for the diagnosis of Nevus of Ota-type Melanoma (NUM) in situ, often appearing as irregularly scattered atypical melanocytes.

Histopathology of in situ matrix melanomas, stained with Hematoxylin and eosin. Panel C demonstrates prominent pagetoid spread of atypical melanocytes (arrows) throughout the entire matrix epithelium. Prominent pagetoid spread is a significant histopathologic clue for the diagnosis of Nevus of Ota-type Melanoma (NUM) in situ, with studies showing this feature in a substantial percentage of cases (67%) and contributing to increased cellular atypia.

Histopathology of in situ matrix melanomas, stained with Hematoxylin and eosin. Panel D illustrates both lentiginous (small arrows) and nest-like (large arrow) proliferation of atypical melanocytes. Lentiginous growth, where single melanocytes proliferate along the basal layer, and the proliferation of atypical melanocytes in scattered solitary units are important histopathologic clues for Nevus of Ota-type Melanoma (NUM) in situ.

Photomicrograph of H&E staining (200× magnification) showing atypical melanocyte proliferation with confluency and prominent pagetoid spread, consistent with subungual melanoma in situ. Histopathologic features for the diagnosis of subungual melanoma in situ include an uneven distribution of solitary melanocytes with irregularly scattered atypical melanocytes, increased cellular atypia, and prominent pagetoid spread.

Histopathology showing nests and diffuse collections of subepithelial nevus cells. The image displays entrapped epithelial inclusion cysts and the total absence of intraepithelial nevocytic junctional nests. The image is stained with hematoxylin-eosin, viewed at an original magnification of x100.

Histopathology showing melanoma, at 20× magnification, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). Melanoma cells are observed extending in a perivascular fashion within the deep dermis. This perivascular infiltration is consistent with findings from the pathology report and is indicative of in-transit metastases, where the melanoma spreads out via proximal vasculature and lymphatics, reflecting the overall severity and thickness of this malignancy.

Histopathology showing a low power view (1.25× magnification) of an entire lesion. The image reveals a prominent growth of squamous epithelium with central nodular growth of clear cells. The tissue section is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E).

This image, captured at 10x magnification, is a higher power histopathological view. It displays malignant small melanocytes, which are partially nested, located in the immediate vicinity of dilated vasculature. There is no clear-cut involvement of the vessels by the neoplasm. The tissue is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Histopathology stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at 20x magnification, showing a higher power view of a neoplasm. Numerous mitotic figures are visible throughout the neoplasm, with an arrow indicating a specific mitotic figure.

Histopathology (2× magnification, Hematoxylin and Eosin stain) showing a complete dermoepidermal separation with serum deposit between the dermis and epidermis. No melanoma is observed in the epidermis.

Histopathology of a Spitz tumor demonstrating marked tumor asymmetry, which is identified as a risk-associated histopathological feature and a proposed prognostic parameter indicating increased clinical risk for patients. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification ×25.

Histopathology of a Spitz tumor demonstrating solid nodular growth, which is identified as a risk-associated histopathological feature and a proposed prognostic parameter indicating increased clinical risk for patients. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification ×100.

Histopathology of a Spitz tumor demonstrating deep dermis and subcutaneous fat extension, which is identified as a risk-associated histopathological feature and a proposed prognostic parameter indicating increased clinical risk for patients. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification ×200.

Histopathology of a Spitz tumor demonstrating marked nuclear pleomorphism/atypia, which is identified as a risk-associated histopathological feature and a proposed prognostic parameter indicating increased clinical risk for patients. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification ×400.

Histopathology of a Spitz tumor demonstrating epidermal ulceration, which is identified as a risk-associated histopathological feature and a proposed prognostic parameter indicating increased clinical risk for patients. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification ×125.

Histopathology of a Spitz tumor demonstrating a high number of suprabasal melanocytes, which is identified as a risk-associated histopathological feature and a proposed prognostic parameter indicating increased clinical risk for patients. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification ×100.

Histopathology showing abundant melanin in deep cells of a Spitz tumor, identified as a risk-associated histopathological feature and proposed as a prognostic parameter. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification ×200.

Histopathology showing dermal mitotic figures in a Spitz tumor, identified as a risk-associated histopathological feature (specifically, dermal mitoses ≥2 per mm2) and proposed as a prognostic parameter. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification ×400.

Histopathology showing a cell within a lymphatic vessel in a Spitz tumor, identified as a risk-associated histopathological feature and proposed as a prognostic parameter. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification ×400.

Histopathology showing mitosis in the deep portion of a Spitz tumor, identified as a risk-associated histopathological feature (specifically, deep/marginal mitoses) and proposed as a prognostic parameter. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification ×125.

Histopathology showing a heavy inflammatory infiltrate in a Spitz tumor, identified as a risk-associated histopathological feature and proposed as a prognostic parameter. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification ×100.

Histopathology showing focal cellular necrosis in a Spitz tumor, identified as a risk-associated histopathological feature and proposed as a prognostic parameter. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification ×400.

Histopathology image of a nevus sample, stained with Hematoxylin-Eosin (H&E). This image serves as a reference for comparison with invasive melanoma samples using both H&E and label-free Hyperspectral Imaging (HSI) with phasor plots. The overall goal is to identify molecular fingerprints through autofluorescence that can discriminate between nevus and melanoma. Scale bar represents 500 μm.

Histopathology image of an invasive melanoma sample, stained with Hematoxylin-Eosin (H&E). This image is used for comparison with nevus samples (Panel A) and for subsequent label-free Hyperspectral Imaging (HSI) with phasor analysis. Spectral phasor analysis of HSI data from melanoma regions reveals distinct molecular fingerprints due to the specific biochemical composition of degenerated melanocytes, which are leveraged to differentiate melanoma from nevus. Scale bar represents 500 μm.

Representative histopathological findings of a nevus (patient #15) showing nests of nevus cells in the dermis that are covered by, but do not touch, the normal epidermis, as observed with Hematoxylin–eosin staining.

Histopathological aspect of the right hypogastric lesion, showing asymmetrical melanocytic proliferation with papillary dermal involvement, as seen in the hematoxylin-eosin (HE) stained tissue sample (original magnification × 4). The microscopical evaluation of the tissue sample excised from the right hypogastric region described features superposable to superficial spreading melanoma, developed on a pre-existing nevus, with a Breslow index measuring 0.5 mm.

Histopathological aspect of the right hypogastric lesion, showing an atypical epithelioid melanocytic population with junctional activity, moderate pleomorphism, dusty melanin pigmentation, angiotropism, and atypical mitoses, as seen in the hematoxylin-eosin (HE) stained tissue sample (original magnification × 20). These features are suggestive of superficial spreading melanoma. The microscopical evaluation of this tissue sample confirmed the diagnosis of superficial spreading melanoma, developed on a pre-existing nevus, with a Breslow index measuring 0.5 mm.

Histologic examination (hematoxylin and eosin, magnification, ×10) revealed proliferation of heavily pigmented melanocytes, mature nevus cells, and abundant melanin-laden macrophages in the underlying stroma, with multiple cysts, consistent with a pigmented cystic compound nevus of the conjunctiva. No evidence of pagetoid spread or dysplasia was detected.

Haematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) stained photomicrograph at ×40 magnification, depicting an inflamed fibro-epithelial polyp of the vulva. The section shows a polypoidal lesion lined by keratinised stratified squamous pigmented epithelium, which is hyperkeratotic, focally acanthotic, and exhibits pseudo-epitheliomatous hyperplasia, with some areas showing ulceration and denudation. The epithelium overlies a fibrovascular to fibromyxoid stroma. Interspersed within the stroma are intense chronic inflammatory cellular infiltrates, primarily comprising lymphoplasma cells and histiocytes.
Histopathology showing a nodule composed of many sebaceous lobules with hair follicles. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain; magnification, 12.5x.
Histopathology showing underlying groups of mature fat cells among the dermal collagen. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain; magnification, 40x.

Histopathology showing Demodex mites found in follicles with perifollicular inflammation. The inset shows Demodex mites in sebaceous glands at higher magnification. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain; magnifications, 100x (main image) and 400x (inset).

Histopathological examination of the lesion revealed acanthosis of the epidermis with hyperkeratosis (indicated by a black arrow) and horn pseudo-cysts (indicated by an asterisk). The image is stained with H&E at × 40 magnification.
Histopathological examination of the lesion revealed acanthosis of the epidermis with hyperkeratosis and horn pseudo-cysts. The image is stained with H&E at × 40 magnification.
Histopathological examination of the lesion revealed acanthosis of the epidermis with hyperkeratosis and horn pseudo-cysts. The image is stained with H&E at × 40 magnification.
Microscopic examination showed basaloid cell proliferation (indicated by a red arrow) with hyperpigmentation of the basal layer. The image is stained with H&E at ×200 magnification.
Photomicrograph showing hair follicles surrounded by concentric fibrosis. Additionally, variably sized dilated hair follicles containing keratin were observed. (Hematoxylin & Eosin, 10x)

Histopathological examination showing variably sized dilated hair follicles containing keratin, surrounded by collagen fibers. There was accompanying perifollicular fibrosis and thick dermal collagen bands extending into the subcutaneous tissue (Hematoxylin & Eosin, 40x).

Photomicrograph depicting perifollicular fibrosis and thick dermal collagen bands, where collagen fibers are arranged haphazardly in the dermis. The image also shows dilated blood vessels extending into the subcutaneous tissue, along with a few unpaired arrector pili muscles observed and indicated by black arrows (Hematoxylin & Eosin, 40x).

Scanning photomicrograph showing the epidermis with irregular acanthosis and hyperkeratosis, along with dermal infiltration of collagen fibers and dilated hair follicles. Stained with Hematoxylin & Eosin at 10x magnification.

Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained histopathological section at higher magnification (40x) from a 4 mm punch biopsy of a lesion. This image further details the abnormal epidermis, showing acanthosis and papillomatosis, and abnormal pilosebaceous units, which include sebaceous glands located in the superficial dermis occasionally opening directly onto the epidermal surface. A chronic inflammatory infiltrate comprising of lymphocytes is also observed in the sub-epidermal region. The histopathological examination found no evidence of atypia, granulomas, or malignancies.

Pathological image of an excisional biopsy demonstrating Intraocular Junctional Conjunctival Nevus (IJCN). Histopathology (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, ×100 magnification) shows a prominent and dense infiltrate of nevus cells, characterized by mild nuclear atypia, within the conjunctival epithelium. Cyst formation is observed within the epithelium (yellow arrow). Additionally, there is dense lymphocyte infiltration forming a lymphoid follicle (red arrow).

Pathological image of an excisional biopsy demonstrating Intraocular Junctional Conjunctival Nevus (IJCN). Histopathology (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, ×200 magnification) at higher magnification reveals a congregation of small foci consisting of nevus cells with moderately irregular nuclei. These nevus cells show mild nuclear atypia and are part of the dense proliferation within the conjunctival epithelium, as observed in this case of IJCN.

A hematoxylin and eosin micrograph at 100x magnification from a biopsy confirming the diagnosis of Ota nevus. The image shows clusters of dendritic and fusiform melanocytes (indicated by black arrowheads) in the papillary dermis, diffusely infiltrating the collagen interstitium, around and near vessels (indicated by red asterisks). Melanophages (indicated by white arrowheads) are also observed in the dermis, extending into the reticular dermis, which collectively supported the pathological report of Ota nevus.

Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) image showing a poorly differentiated malignancy. The tumor cells are arranged in sheets and display a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio. Individual cells are highly pleomorphic, appearing round to oval, elongated, and spindle-shaped. They exhibit moderate eosinophilic cytoplasm, a round-oval to irregular hyperchromatic nucleus, and inconspicuous nucleoli. No melanin pigment was observed in the sections studied.

Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) image showing a poorly differentiated malignancy. The tumor cells exhibit moderate to marked nuclear pleomorphism and hyperchromatism, along with mild to moderate eosinophilic cytoplasm and inconspicuous nucleoli. Individual cells are highly pleomorphic, with a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio and a round-oval to irregular hyperchromatic nucleus. Atypical mitoses were observed at a rate of 4-5 per 10 high power fields. No melanin pigment was noted in the sections studied, which was confirmed by Masson Fontana staining being negative for melanin in related studies.

Histopathology (H&E stain) from a biopsy of a 60-year-old female patient presenting with anorectal bleeding, loose stools, and pain in the perianal region. The image shows the anorectal mucosa infiltrated by tumor cells. The biopsy was taken from a nodular ulcerative growth identified during a colonoscopy at 7 o'clock, 2 cm from the lower edge of the anal canal.

Histopathology (H&E stain) from a biopsy of a 60-year-old female patient presenting with anorectal bleeding, loose stools, and pain in the perianal region. The image displays tumor cells (black arrow) arranged as cords, trabeculae, and sheets, with few remnants of colonic epithelium. These tumor cells were observed infiltrating the anorectal mucosa in a biopsy taken from a nodular ulcerative growth identified during a colonoscopy at 7 o'clock, 2 cm from the lower edge of the anal canal.

Histopathological representation of papilloma in the right eye, stained with hematoxylin and eosin at 100x magnification. This image is from a 50-year-old man who presented with a painless, pedunculated, pale pink mass with multiple finger-like projections, which was clinically diagnosed as papilloma and subsequently excised. Histopathological confirmation of papilloma was obtained.

Histopathological representation of a nevus, stained with hematoxylin and eosin at 100x magnification. This image is associated with a 30-year-old woman who presented with a concern regarding an increase in the size of a pre-existing pigmented lesion in her right eye, which was clinically diagnosed as a nevus without features of malignant transformation.

Histopathological representation of dysplasia, stained with hematoxylin and eosin at 100x magnification. This image depicts a moderate level of dysplasia, characterized by disorganization and irregular stratification of the epithelial cells. The lesion was from a 50-year-old patient who presented with a painless pink swelling near the medial canthus of the left eye, with clinical examination revealing keratin on the surface, raising suspicion for ocular surface squamous neoplasia. The excised specimen was confirmed histopathologically to have dysplasia.

Histopathology of a pyogenic granuloma from an 18-year-old male patient presenting with a painless, fleshy swelling in the left eye that had been present for four months. The image shows benign vascular proliferative tissue with characteristic granulation tissue and inflammatory cells, confirming the diagnosis. Magnification: 400×, stained with hematoxylin and eosin.

Histopathology of a steatocytoma from a 20-year-old male patient who presented with a painless, very slow-growing lesion in the left eye, present for 10 years. The image shows cystic structures filled with sebum, consistent with the diagnosis of steatocytoma. Magnification: 400×, stained with hematoxylin and eosin.

Histopathology of a sebaceous cell carcinoma from a 60-year-old woman who presented with a painless mass in her right eye, slowly growing over two years. The image confirms the diagnosis by showing solid, trabecular, and nested growth patterns characterized by vacuolated or foamy cytoplasm containing lipid droplets. Magnification: 100×, stained with hematoxylin and eosin.

Histopathology of a 61-year-old female's back, showing late-onset lentiginous and nested melanoma. The image reveals a chaotic architecture with variably sized nests and confluent single nevoid melanocytes that extend along broad junctional zones where the rete ridges are absent, producing a lentiginous pattern. Key features include loss of rete ridges and confluent melanocytes. This is an H&E stained digital scan at ×2 magnification.

Histopathology from the chest of an eighty-year-old male showing a late-onset hypercellular nested melanoma with an accentuated rete ridge pattern. This panel highlights the hypercellular nests. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) and is a digital scan taken at ×2 magnification.

Photomicrograph (H&E, 20x magnification) from an excisional biopsy, illustrating the histopathological findings of a stromal lesion. The image shows numerous large foamy cells, also known as xanthoma cells or foamy macrophages, characterized by pale cytoplasm and eccentric nuclei, located within the connective tissue stroma. These findings are part of a broader histopathological evaluation which also revealed stratified squamous epithelium of variable thickness overlying the connective tissue stroma with ulceration, and a mild to moderate chronic inflammatory cell infiltration predominantly lymphocytes and plasma cells. This biopsy was performed following a provisional clinical diagnosis of mucocele, with traumatic fibroma considered in the differential diagnosis.

A photomicrograph showing xanthoma cells present in the stroma, alongside ulcerated epithelium and inflammation. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and captured at 4x magnification.
Photomicrograph showing hyperplastic parakeratinized stratified squamous epithelium and intense inflammation (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, 20x magnification).

Histopathological findings of a hepatic resection specimen. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain at 100× magnification showing proliferation of different components: blood vessels (*) varying in size, mature adipocytes (#), and smooth muscle (§).

Histopathological findings of a hepatic resection specimen. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain at 200× magnification demonstrating prominent smooth muscle contingent, with variable morphology including fusiform (black arrows), epithelioid (white arrows), and pleomorphic cells. These cells displayed abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm as well as large nucleolated nuclei.

Hematoxylin and eosin stain (original magnification 10x) of a dysplastic nevus (DN) with mild atypia. Histologically, the image shows pigmented parakeratosis overlying a hyperplastic epidermis with lentigo-like features, which are frequently observed in DN with mild atypia. It is associated with a melanocytic proliferation displaying a discrete junctional proliferation with very small nests, irregularly distributed along the dermal–epidermal junction. Other features include a “shoulder sign”, a slight papillary fibroplasia, and a slight dermal lymphocytic infiltrate associated with melanophages.

Hematoxylin and eosin stain (original magnification 10x) of a dysplastic nevus (DN) with moderate atypia. The junctional proliferation shows small nests irregularly distributed along the dermal–epidermal junction, not completely filling the rete ridges. These medium-sized nests are observed histologically and likely correspond to the slightly larger pigmented network or small globi seen clinically.

Hematoxylin and eosin stain (original magnification 15x) of a dysplastic nevus (DN) with moderate atypia, showing mild cytonuclear atypia. This higher magnification view also reveals papillary fibroplasia, a “shoulder sign”, and a slight dermal lymphocytic infiltrate associated with melanophages. The dermal component shows a superficial congenital architecture. These histological features are consistent with lesions that clinically present with a larger pigmented network or small globi.

Histopathology of a melanoma in situ (hematoxylin and eosin stain, original magnification 10x), shown for comparison. The image reveals intraepidermal anarchic proliferation characterized by irregular nests, numerous solitary units, and pagetoid spread.

Histopathology of a melanoma in situ (hematoxylin and eosin stain, original magnification 20x), shown for comparison. This higher magnification view details severe cytonuclear atypia, displaying very large cytoplasm and very large nuclei. A moderate dermal lymphocytic infiltrate associated with melanophages is also present. This panel highlights features seen in the intraepidermal anarchic proliferation described in panel B.

Hematoxylin and eosin stain (original magnification 10x) of a superficial spreading melanoma (Breslow 0.3 mm), which is a microinvasive superficial spreading melanoma shown for comparison. The image demonstrates intraepidermal anarchic proliferation with irregular nests, numerous solitary units, and pagetoid spread.

Hematoxylin and eosin stain (original magnification 20x) of a superficial spreading melanoma (Breslow 0.3 mm), which is a microinvasive superficial spreading melanoma shown for comparison. This panel highlights severe cytonuclear atypia, characterized by very large cytoplasm and very large nuclei. The same atypia is also present in a few nests in the superficial dermis (arrow). Additionally, there is a moderate dermal lymphocytic infiltrate associated with melanophages.

Hematoxylin and eosin stain (original magnification 10x) of a dysplastic nevus (DN) with marked atypia. The junctional component shows a continuous proliferation of solitary units along the dermal–epidermal junction, and some irregular nests. Histological features also include a slight papillary fibroplasia and a moderate dermal lymphocytic infiltrate associated with melanophages.

Hematoxylin and eosin stain (original magnification 20x) of a dysplastic nevus (DN) with marked atypia, showing marked cytonuclear atypia. The atypical features include large cytoplasm and large nuclei with hyperchromasia. This image provides a higher magnification view of the histological characteristics observed in a dysplastic nevus with marked atypia.

Histopathology of a dysplastic nevus (DN) with mild atypia, stained with Hematoxylin and eosin (original magnification 10x). This lesion is defined by mild cytological, nuclear, and nucleolar atypia. Architecturally, it shows a discrete junctional melanocytic proliferation with very small nests, irregularly distributed along the dermal–epidermal junction. There is pigmented parakeratosis overlying a hyperplastic epidermis with lentigo-like features and hyperpigmentation. Additional features include a slight “shoulder sign”, slight papillary fibroplasia, and a slight-to-moderate dermal lymphocytic infiltrate associated with melanophages.

Histopathology of a dysplastic nevus (DN) with moderate atypia, stained with Hematoxylin and eosin (original magnification 10x). This lesion is defined by mild cytological, nuclear, and nucleolar atypia. Architecturally, it shows a more pronounced junctional proliferation with well-developed, irregularly distributed nests, which do not completely fill the rete ridges. Other features include a “shoulder sign”, papillary fibroplasia, and a slight dermal lymphocytic infiltrate associated with melanophages.

Histopathology of a dysplastic nevus (DN) with distinct atypia, specifically of the “nested type”, stained with Hematoxylin and eosin (original magnification 10x). This lesion is defined by more pronounced cytological and nucleolar atypia, presenting as moderate cytonuclear atypia. Architecturally, the junctional component shows large, irregularly distributed, voluminous nests completely filling the rete ridges. Other features include a “shoulder sign”, papillary fibroplasia, and a slight-to-moderate dermal lymphocytic infiltrate associated with melanophages. There is no suprabasal melanocyte proliferation and no solitary units between the rete ridges.

Histopathology of a dysplastic nevus (DN) with distinct atypia, specifically of the “solitary unit type”, stained with Hematoxylin and eosin (original magnification 10x). This lesion is defined by more pronounced cytological and nucleolar atypia, presenting as moderate cytonuclear atypia. Architecturally, it shows lentiginous hyperplasia and hyperpigmentation of the epidermis, and a junctional melanocytic proliferation with solitary units completely filling the rete ridges. There are no signs of continuous proliferation or pagetoid spread, no suprabasal melanocyte proliferation, and no solitary units between the rete ridges.

Histopathology of a superficial borderline atypical melanocytic lesion with junctional atypia, stained with Hematoxylin and eosin (original magnification 10x). The junctional component displays a continuous proliferation with solitary units arranged along the dermal–epidermal junction. This lesion also presents with a 'shoulder sign', papillary fibroplasia, and a slight dermal lymphocytic infiltrate associated with melanophages.

Histopathology of a superficial borderline atypical melanocytic lesion with junctional atypia, stained with Hematoxylin and eosin (original magnification 20x). This higher magnification view demonstrates severe cytonuclear atypia, characterized by vacuolated cytoplasm and irregular nuclei with pronounced hyperchromasia. Additional histopathological features include a 'shoulder sign', papillary fibroplasia, and a slight dermal lymphocytic infiltrate associated with melanophages.

Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain (original magnification 10x) of a superficial borderline atypical melanocytic lesion with junctional and dermal atypia. The junctional component shows a continuous proliferation with solitary units along the dermal–epidermal junction, exhibiting severe cytonuclear atypia.

Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain (original magnification 10x) of a superficial borderline atypical melanocytic lesion with junctional and dermal atypia. The image displays a “shoulder sign”, papillary fibroplasia, and a slight dermal lymphocytic infiltrate associated with melanophages. The dermal component is focal (arrow), composed of few nests, showing the same degree of atypia as the junctional component, without differentiation, and with overlying fibrosis.

Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain (original magnification 20x) of a superficial borderline atypical melanocytic lesion with junctional and dermal atypia. This image highlights severe cytonuclear atypia within the junctional component, characterized by abundant and dusty cytoplasm, and irregular nuclei with pronounced hyperchromasia.

Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain (original magnification 20x) of a superficial borderline atypical melanocytic lesion with junctional and dermal atypia. This image highlights severe cytonuclear atypia within the junctional component, characterized by abundant and dusty cytoplasm, and irregular nuclei with pronounced hyperchromasia.

Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain (original magnification 40x) of a superficial borderline atypical melanocytic lesion with junctional and dermal atypia. The image shows the focal dermal component (arrow), composed of few nests. These nests exhibit the same degree of atypia as the junctional component, without differentiation, and are associated with overlying fibrosis.

Histopathology stained with Hematoxylin and eosin (original magnification 10x), depicting a Dysplastic Nevus (DN) with marked atypia. This condition is defined by marked cytological, nuclear, and nucleolar atypia, and architecturally by a continuous proliferation along the dermal–epidermal junction, or with solitary units between the rete ridges, eventually with the presence of few suprabasal melanocytes, but only focally. The junctional component in this image shows marked cytonuclear atypia, specifically with marked nuclear hyperchromasia, and a continuous proliferation along the dermal–epidermal junction, with solitary units between the rete ridges.

Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain (original magnification 10x) of a dysplastic nevus (DN) with distinct atypia, nested type. Junctional proliferation shows large and voluminous nests, probably representing the larger nests observed histologically, irregularly distributed along the dermal–epidermal junction, completely filling the rete ridges, with moderate cytonuclear atypia. A slight papillary fibroplasia, a “shoulder sign”, and a slight dermal lymphocytic infiltrate associated with melanophages are observed.

Histopathology of a dysplastic nevus (DN) with severe atypia, stained with Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E). The image shows the junctional component with a very disorganized proliferation, including solitary units and irregular nests. These histological characteristics contribute to the classification of DN with severe atypia, a lesion type that may present clinically without major or specific differences compared to superficial borderline atypical melanocytic lesions. (Original magnification 10x).

Histopathology of a dysplastic nevus (DN) with severe atypia, likely stained with Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), showing marked and/or severe cytonuclear atypia. The cells display abundant cytoplasm, and large and irregular nuclei with hyperchromasia. Additional features include a “shoulder sign”, papillary fibroplasia, and a moderate dermal lymphocytic infiltrate associated with melanophages. These findings are consistent with DN with severe atypia, which can be challenging to differentiate clinically from superficial borderline atypical melanocytic lesions. (Original magnification 20x).

Histopathology of an initial biopsy showing a compound dysplastic nevus. The image displays a nested junctional component with bridging and concentric lamellar fibroplasia around rete ridges. The dermal component is composed of small bland epithelioid melanocytes and shows maturation with depth. (Hematoxylin and eosin stain, 100× magnification).

Histopathology of a subsequent biopsy revealing melanoma. This image shows melanoma in situ with predominantly lentiginous and contiguous growth and pagetoid spread of the junctional component. The invasive melanoma component is composed of large atypical epithelioid to spindled cells, which are distinct from those seen in the nevus component. (Hematoxylin and eosin stain, 100× magnification).

Histopathology showing typical features of BAP1‐inactivated melanocytoma (Case 3). This scanning magnification image (original magnification ×80) depicts a dome‐shaped, predominantly intradermal melanocytic proliferation with an associated patchy lymphoid infiltrate. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Histopathology showing typical features of BAP1‐inactivated melanocytoma (Case 1). Close inspection (original magnification ×400) reveals epithelioid melanocytes with irregular, pleomorphic nuclei, abundant palely eosinophilic cytoplasm, variable intranuclear inclusions, and distinct cell borders. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Histopathology showing typical features of BAP1‐inactivated melanocytoma (Case 3). Close inspection (original magnification ×400) reveals epithelioid melanocytes with irregular, pleomorphic nuclei, abundant palely eosinophilic cytoplasm, variable intranuclear inclusions, and distinct cell borders. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Histopathology showing typical features of BAP1‐inactivated melanocytoma (Case 7). Close inspection (original magnification ×400) reveals epithelioid melanocytes with irregular, pleomorphic nuclei, abundant palely eosinophilic cytoplasm, variable intranuclear inclusions, and distinct cell borders. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Histopathology showing typical features of BAP1‐inactivated melanocytoma (Case 10). Close inspection (original magnification ×400) reveals epithelioid melanocytes with irregular, pleomorphic nuclei, abundant palely eosinophilic cytoplasm, variable intranuclear inclusions, and distinct cell borders. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Histopathology from Case 1M. Scanning magnification image of a foot lesion reveals a predominantly intradermal neoplasm with regions of expansile growth superficially and extension into the deep dermis. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification ×46.

Histopathology from Case 1M. Histologic evaluation of an ankle lesion reveals an intradermal population of monotonous, moderately sized melanocytes. Expression of BAP1 was diffusely lost. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification ×400.

Histopathology from Case 1M. Histologic evaluation of a malleolus specimen shows an intradermal population of monotonous, moderately sized melanocytes with diffuse loss of BAP1 staining. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification ×400.
Low-magnification histopathology image showing a biphenotypic and asymmetric intradermal proliferation of melanocytes. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Histopathology image at a closer inspection, revealing that the majority of the cells are arranged in sheets and show abundant grey cytoplasm with numerous associated melanophages. Smaller cells present in tight nests and resembling ordinary nevus are also present. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

High-magnification histopathology image revealing vesicular nuclei with variably prominent nucleoli in the epithelioid population of melanocytes. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Histopathology (H&E stain, original magnification ×100 or ×200) from Case 5, showing a scanning magnification image of an asymmetric, predominantly intradermal melanocytic proliferation. A patchy lymphocytic infiltrate is also present.

Histopathology (H&E stain, original magnification ×100 or ×200) from Case 5. The composite melanocytes consist of large, atypical epithelioid forms as well as smaller nevoid melanocytes that demonstrate variable cytologic atypia.

Histopathology (H&E stain, original magnification ×100 or ×200) from Case 5, showing prominent infiltrative and single-file growth at the base of the lesion. Although the majority of cells are small in size in the deep dermis, occasional large, epithelioid forms are also visualized.

Histopathology (H&E stain, original magnification ×100 or ×200) from Case 5, showing prominent infiltrative and single-file growth at the base of the lesion. Although the majority of cells are small in size in the deep dermis, occasional large, epithelioid forms are also visualized.

Case 4. Scanning magnification image showing an asymmetric predominantly intradermal melanocytic proliferation that is nested superficially and disperses with dermal descent. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification ×20.

Case 4. Higher magnification image revealing that the composite melanocytes are arranged in large, expansile nests and as single cells. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification ×100.

Case 4. Cytological image showing most tumour cells are small, with less cytoplasm than is typically observed in BAP1‐inactived melanocytomas. Many of the cells contain rhabdoid intracytoplasmic inclusions that peripherally displace the nuclei. Scattered smaller nevomelanocytes are seen in the background. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification ×200.

A Hematoxylin-Eosin-stained section of a left hemithorax soft tissue mass at 40× magnification shows a diffuse arrangement of tumor cells, consisting of atypical plasmacytoid cells, infiltrating the surrounding area.

A Hematoxylin-Eosin-stained section of the fracture sites of the humerus at 40× magnification shows a diffuse arrangement of tumor cells, consisting of atypical plasmacytoid cells, infiltrating the surrounding area.
Histopathology showing dermal black pigment deposits with surrounding granulomatous reaction and multinucleated giant cells. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, viewed at 20× magnification.
Histopathology showing dermal black pigment deposits with surrounding granulomatous reaction and multinucleated giant cells. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, viewed at 100× magnification.

Hematoxylin-eosin-stained section of a uterine PEComa. Histologically, PEComas are composed of epithelioid cells, as seen here, which exhibit clear to eosinophilic cytoplasm (which can also be granular). The cells are arranged in a radial/perivascular distribution, a common architectural pattern for PEComas, which can also present as dyscohesive nests surrounded by delicate, thin-walled blood vessels or in solid sheets. Prominent stromal hyalinization is also evident, representing an additional feature frequently observed in these tumors. (20× magnification).

Histopathology showing focal melanin deposition (H&E, ×100 magnification). This finding is associated with tumors characterized by epithelioid or spindled neoplastic cells, nuclear pleomorphism (enlargement, hyperchromasia, prominent nucleoli), and abundant eosinophilic to granular cytoplasm, exhibiting infiltrative growth patterns into smooth muscle and fibrous septa, often with adjacent mucosal necrosis.

Photomicrograph of nasolacrimal duct mucosa from a lacrimal sac biopsy, demonstrating focal areas of granulomatous inflammation with associated pigmented granules (an example area is indicated by a yellow circle). These features suggest an exogenous source for the inflammation. The tissue is stained with Hematoxylin-eosin at 100× magnification.
Histopathology showing melanoma underlying the respiratory mucosa of the sinonasal area, stained with hematoxylin & eosin and viewed at 10x magnification.
Histopathology showing melanoma with prominent atypia, mitosis, and melanin pigments. Stained with Hematoxylin & eosin (x20 magnification).

Histopathology at 400x magnification showing an H&E stained section. The image features an intact epidermis with a focal underlying inflammatory infiltrate. In the deep dermis and subcutaneous tissue, a nodular lesion is present, composed of a cystic space adjacent to a proliferation of diffuse nests of atypical cells and marked necrosis extending into subcutaneous tissue without epidermal involvement. This histopathological examination contributed to confirming the diagnosis of invasive malignant melanoma.

Histopathology at 400x magnification, showing an H&E stained close-up view of the lesion detailed in panel (a). This close-up illustrates diffuse atypical cells surrounding a dermal vessel. This image is part of the histopathological examination featuring a deep dermal nodule composed of a cystic space adjacent to a proliferation of atypical cells and marked necrosis extending into subcutaneous tissue without epidermal involvement, confirming the diagnosis of invasive malignant melanoma.

Histopathology demonstrating Ota's nevus from a skin biopsy taken from the right malar area (right cheek) of a 36-year-old Korean woman. The image, stained with hematoxylin-eosin and viewed at ×200 magnification, shows scattered, bipolar or irregular melanocytes within the dermis.
Skin biopsy from the left forehead stained with hematoxylin-eosin and viewed at ×200 magnification, showing melanocytes scattered in the dermis.

Histopathology showing desmoplastic melanoma, characterized by atypical spindle cells embedded in a dense fibrous matrix. The image is stained with haematoxylin and eosin at an original magnification of ×10.

Histopathological examination with hematoxylin and eosin staining revealed marked acanthosis with elongation and thickening of the rete ridges, hyperkeratosis, and irregular melanin pigment distribution throughout the epidermis to the papillary dermis. The epidermis also showed marked atypia of keratinocytes, with some containing large, hyperchromatic nuclei and coarse keratohyaline granules, and atypical mitoses were observed. Basal melanosis was irregularly demonstrated. The papillary dermis showed a dense infiltrate of lymphocytes and numerous scattered melanophages, with no evidence of dermal invasion. These histopathologic features are consistent with a diagnosis of pigmented BD.
Histopathology of clear cell sarcoma at higher magnification showing spindled to epithelioid cells with pale eosinophilic cytoplasm and vesicular nuclei with prominent nucleoli (H&E, ×400).

Histopathology revealing a clear cell sarcoma, presenting as a dermal malignancy composed of tumor cell nests and fascicles that are delineated by fibrous septa. At low power magnification, there is no evidence of junctional activity or pagetoid spread of abnormal melanocytes. (Hematoxylin and eosin, ×100 magnification)

Histopathology of a skin biopsy from the right side of the cheek, from a patient diagnosed with an extensive epidermal nevus with sebaceous features. The image shows compact hyperkeratosis, moderate papillomatosis, and acanthosis. There is a substantial increase in the number of mature sebaceous glands, hair follicles, and eccrine glands in the epidermis, which is compatible with an organoid nevus with sebaceous differentiation. (H&E stain, × 40 magnification).

Histopathology of a skin biopsy from the right side of the cheek, from a patient diagnosed with an extensive epidermal nevus with sebaceous features, shown at high power magnification. The image reveals immature and increased sebaceous glands. This finding, in conjunction with compact hyperkeratosis, moderate papillomatosis, acanthosis, and a substantial increase in mature sebaceous glands, hair follicles, and eccrine glands, supports the diagnosis of an organoid nevus with sebaceous differentiation. (H&E stain, × 100 magnification).

Micrograph of the primary tumor from patient 001-CSS, a 33-year-old caucasian woman diagnosed with stage IIC cutaneous epithelioid nodular melanoma. Stained with hematoxylin/eosin, the image shows highly melanotic tumor cells and scarce lymphocytes in the tumor periphery. The primary tumor was located in the intermammary sulcus, ulcerated, in vertical growth phase, with a Breslow thickness of 4.1 mm and a Clark’s level of IV. Original magnification = 200×; scale bar = 20 μm.
