Micrograph of a hepatic needle biopsy from patient 001-CSS, stained with hematoxylin/eosin. This biopsy confirmed the presence of multiple melanoma metastases in the hepatic parenchyma, correlating with the new lesions detected in the March 2012 CAT scans (Panels E and F). The biopsy revealed highly melanotic cells. Original magnification = 200×; scale bar = 20 μm.

Low power microscopic view of an H&E stained tissue section showing an unencapsulated neoplasm. The image displays intramucosal micronodules, arranged in a characteristic whorled pattern with concentric growth. The neoplastic cells are epithelioid to spindle shaped, with most appearing fibroblastic and showing mild nuclear atypia. The mucosa is widely involved, and some invasion to submucosa is observed. Scattered osteoclast type giant cells are present within the whorled nodules, with almost absent mitotic activity and no myxoid matrix.

High power microscopic view of an H&E stained tissue section showing an unencapsulated neoplasm. The image displays intramucosal micronodules with concentric whorled appearance. The neoplastic cells are epithelioid to spindle shaped, with most appearing fibroblastic and showing mild nuclear atypia. Scattered osteoclast type giant cells are visible within the whorled nodules, with almost absent mitotic activity and no myxoid matrix.

Histopathology at ×4 magnification, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), showing epidermis with hyperkeratosis, papillomatosis, acanthosis. Melanocytes are spanning all layers of the epidermis with abundant melanin and small horn cysts. The base of the tumor is seen lying in a straight line with the surrounding normal epidermis.

Histopathology of Mycosis fungoides, showing intense epidermotropism where atypical lymphocytes infiltrate the epidermis. These lymphocytes, characteristic of Mycosis fungoides, often possess irregular and cerebriform nuclei. The image also displays mild spongiosis. This prominent epidermotropism is a key microscopic finding in Mycosis fungoides. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at 400X magnification.

Histopathology showing Mycosis fungoides, characterized by a psoriasiform pattern with hyperplasia of the epidermis (acanthosis) and rare or absent spongiosis. There is a dense subepidermal and band-like inflammatory infiltration composed of lymphocytes, many of which exhibit cerebriform nuclei. Prominent epidermotropism of lymphocytes is also observed. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (100X magnification).

Histopathology showing Mycosis fungoides, characterized by epidermotropism of lymphocytes and the presence of Pautrier’s micro-abscess. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) and viewed at 400x magnification.

Histopathology at 400X magnification showing mycosis fungoides. The image demonstrates epidermotropism and the alignment of lymphocytes in the basal layer of the epidermis, consistent with mycosis fungoides. The tissue is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE).

Histopathology of the main papule showing hyperpigmented, spindle-shaped melanocytes infiltrating among the collagen bundles. No features suggestive of malignancy, such as cytological atypia, atypical mitoses, or necrosis, were observed. Hematoxylin and eosin (HE) stain. Original magnification ×40.
Histopathology of the main lesion showing periappendageal and perivascular concentrations of nevus cells. Hematoxylin and eosin (HE) stain. Original magnification ×100.
Histopathology of the satellite lesions showing perivascular concentration of nevus cells. Hematoxylin and eosin (HE) stain. Original magnification ×100.

Histopathological features of the thigh nodule showing signet-ring cell appearance of the neoplastic cells. The neoplastic cells exhibited eccentrically located enlarged nuclei and abundant pale cytoplasm (hematoxylin and eosin stain; magnification, ×400).

Histopathological features of a nodule on the ventral aspect of the penis. The image shows the cyst wall covered by bland urothelial cells, with dendritic melanocytes present within the epithelium. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), magnified ×400.

Photomicrography of a lacrimal sac melanoma, confirming the diagnosis of malignant melanoma via histological examination. The image shows tumor cells, characterized by solid growth and production of melanin pigmentation, infiltrating the adjacent stroma. Histological examination further identified these malignant cells as having hyperchromatic nuclei and prominent nucleoli. (Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification ×100)

Photomicrography of a lacrimal sac melanoma, confirming the diagnosis of malignant melanoma via histological examination. The image shows solid growth of malignant cells characterized by the production of melanin pigments, hyperchromatic nuclei, and prominent nucleoli. (Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification ×400)

Histopathology showing the Trabecular type, which is one of the distinct histological variants of Merkel cell carcinoma (MCC). MCC has been classified into three distinct subtypes. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×100 magnification.

Histopathology showing the Intermediate type, which is one of the distinct histological variants of Merkel cell carcinoma (MCC). MCC has been classified into three distinct subtypes. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×400 magnification.

Histopathology showing the Small cell type, which is one of the distinct histological variants of Merkel cell carcinoma (MCC). MCC has been classified into three distinct subtypes. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×400 magnification.
Histopathology at ×400 magnification, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), from the truncal lesion. It shows nests and fascicles of spindle-shaped cells with abundant pale cytoplasm.
Microscopic view (×100 magnification) of a truncal lesion, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), showing fascicles of spindle-shaped cells.

Histopathology at ×400 magnification, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin, showing a punch biopsy from a scalp lesion. The image displays multiple nests and cords of nevus cells in the upper dermis, which contain a moderate amount of melanin. There was no cellular atypia. Based on the clinical features and histology, this image represents a case diagnosed as congenital melanocytic nevus with cellular blue nevi.

Histopathologic specimen from the central lesion, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (original magnification ×100), showing spindle cells with melanin pigments in the upper dermis, but not in the epidermis.

Histopathologic specimen from the peripheral lesion, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (original magnification ×100), showing focally aggregated and isolated spindle cells with melanin pigments in the upper dermis. Deep sections confirmed that the dermal dendritic melanocytes were distributed in the direction of the streaks.

Histopathologic specimen from the peripheral lesion, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (original magnification ×400), showing focally aggregated and isolated spindle cells with melanin pigments in the upper dermis. Deep sections confirmed that the dermal dendritic melanocytes were distributed in the direction of the streaks.

Histopathological examination of hyperpigmented macules over the right frontal region of the scalp, revealing increased melanin in the basal layers of the epidermis, and clusters and singly dispersed pigmented melanocytes within the papillary dermis and upper reticular dermis. Melanin pigment is clearly visible in the upper and middle dermis. (H&E stain, ×10 magnification).
Histopathology showing a nodule of atypical melanocytes, viewed at ×20 magnification. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Histopathology of a hyperpigmented and hyperkeratotic plaque over the groin area, obtained via punch biopsy. The image reveals hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, elongated rete ridges, and increased pigmentation of basal keratinocytes. These observations are suggestive of Becker's nevus (H&E, ×100).

Histopathologic examination, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×5 magnification, reveals an exophytic lesion characteristic of folliculosebaceous cystic hamartoma (FSCH). The lesion consists of a dilated infundibular cystic structure connected with multiple sebaceous lobules via sebaceous ducts. This structure is surrounded by fibrous connective tissue with thick collagen bundles, consistent with the overall diagnosis of folliculosebaceous cystic hamartoma.

Histopathologic examination, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×20 magnification, shows numerous mature sebaceous lobules along with the elongation of the rete ridges in the epidermis, which are features seen in folliculosebaceous cystic hamartoma.

Histopathologic examination, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×40 magnification, reveals a prominent cleft formation between the fibroepithelial units and the surrounding stroma, a key feature of folliculosebaceous cystic hamartoma (FSCH). The stroma is fibrotic and prominent, characterized by fibrillar bundles of collagen and a high number of small blood vessels. No hair shafts are present in the cystic cavity.

Scanning view of a well-circumscribed symmetric dome-shaped nodule, comprising various-sized nests of tumor cells, as seen in a histopathological image stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×12 magnification.
Histopathological image showing epidermal tumor nests and single cells exhibiting pagetoid spread throughout the epidermis, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×40 magnification.

Histopathological image of tumor cells exhibiting epithelioid morphology, characterized by monotonous and hyperchromatic nuclei, and loss of maturation, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×100 magnification.
Histopathological image showing atypical mitoses observed within the epidermis, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×200 magnification.
Histopathological image showing atypical mitoses observed within the dermis, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×200 magnification.

Histopathological image showing atypical tumor cell nests and individual cells located around blood vessels and inside vessel lumens, indicating the presence of angiotropism, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×200 magnification.

Histopathological examination showing irregular junctional melanocytic activity with a focal trend toward upward spreading (pagetoid pattern), indicated by an arrow. In the dermis, there is the presence of melanocytes with small round nuclei, rare nucleoli, and a solid growth pattern with high cellularity, but no significant atypia. This image was captured using hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain at ×20–40 magnification.

Histopathology of a skin biopsy from a 55-year-old male, diagnosed with congenital melanocytic nevus with extensive neurotization resembling a pigmented neurofibroma. The image displays nests of nevus cells containing melanin pigment in the dermis, showing maturation into spindle-shaped cells. This view represents the upper portion of the lesion, characterized by large nests of nevus cells in the mid-dermis, some containing melanin pigment, which progressively mature into spindle-shaped cells in the lower part of the lesion. Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification ×40.

Histopathology demonstrating an epithelial granuloma-like tumor located in the dermis. Atypical mitosis is observed predominantly in the deep dermis, with some also present in the superficial dermis. Kamino bodies and pagetoid spread are absent from the epidermal component. The deep dermal invasion pattern at the lower border shows a mixed type, exhibiting both expansive and infiltrative characteristics (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, original magnification ×40).

Histopathology showing the characteristics of the epithelial granuloma-like tumor cells. The tumor cells are multinucleate and display significant pleomorphism, possessing abundant cytoplasm and large vesicular nuclei (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, original magnification ×200).

High-magnification histopathology of the epithelial granuloma-like tumor cells, revealing large vesicular nuclei which contain prominent eosinophilic nucleoli (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, original magnification ×400).

Histopathology of Kikuchi-Fujimoto disease (histiocytic necrotizing lymphadenitis) in a deep inguinal lymph node. The image shows a sheet-like lymphohistiocytic infiltrate with partial architectural effacement by a mixed proliferation of small lymphocytes, large immunoblast-like lymphocytes, and histiocytes, present in a predominantly paracortical distribution. Many of the histiocytes have eccentric crescent-shaped nuclei and contain abundant intracytoplasmic karyorrhectic debris. The mitotic rate in these areas is very brisk (up to 10 mitoses per high power field), and neutrophils and eosinophils are noticeably absent. In some areas, the cellular proliferation is entirely replaced by large zones of necrosis. Stained with hematoxylin-eosin, 400x magnification.

Histopathology image stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at ×100 magnification, showing melanin pigments dispersed throughout the scleral tissue. This indicates scleral invasion, but the invasion did not reach the outermost layer of the sclera or the vessels.
Histopathology of skin lesions showing dyskeratotic keratinocytes below a site of perforation. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), viewed at ×40 magnification.

Histopathology of skin lesions showing dilated capillaries with a granulomatous lymphocytic infiltrate in the deep dermis below an area of epidermal perforation. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), viewed at ×10 magnification.
Histopathology of a skin lesion showing epidermal invagination. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×10 magnification.

Histopathology of a skin lesion showing a focal cornified plug with basophilic degenerated material in small collections throughout the plug. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×40 magnification.

Histopathologic examination revealed acanthosis, hyperkeratosis, papillomatosis, and follicular plugging in the epidermis. The upper dermis showed underdeveloped hair follicles with sebaceous glands. These findings are consistent with nevus sebaceus (SN). The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at 100x magnification.

Histopathological study of a skin biopsy, which was performed on two different lesions (a yellowish cerebriform plaque and a large, erythematous, cerebriform, pedunculated mass), showing papillomatosis of the epidermis with enlarged sebaceous glands. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×4 magnification.

Histopathology showing an acanthotic type of seborrheic keratosis, taken from the left postauricular region of an 86-year-old woman. This acanthotic subtype was identified as the most frequent histopathological subtype in the study, accounting for 93 cases (45.1%). The image displays a greatly thickened epidermis and horny invaginations appearing as pseudohorn cysts. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×40 magnification.

Histopathology showing an adenoid-type seborrheic keratosis from the forehead of a 73-year-old man. This adenoid type was identified as the fifth most frequent histopathological subtype of seborrheic keratosis in the study, accounting for 4.4% (9 cases) of the evaluated cases. Numerous thin tracts of epidermal cells extend from the epidermis and branch and interweave within the dermis. Many of the tracts are composed of only a double row of basaloid cells (H&E, ×40).
Histopathology at 40× magnification showing ramifying trabeculae of basaloid epithelium. The image is stained with hematoxylin & eosin.
This image, captured at 200× magnification, shows pigmented macrophages located within the intervening stroma of the pigmented lesion. The tissue was stained with hematoxylin & eosin.
Histopathology at 100× magnification, stained with hematoxylin & eosin, showing detail of interconnecting trabeculae of basaloid epithelium and loose stroma.

Histopathological findings from the black node showing tumor nests with a sheet-like appearance extending downward into the deep dermis and melanin deposits scattered irregularly. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at an original magnification of ×20.

Histopathological findings showing individual tumor cells that are atypical, with insular tumor aggregations recognized within the tumor nests. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at an original magnification of ×200.

Histopathological findings at the periphery of the black node showing tumor nests composed of several different components. The dotted box indicates the portion shown in panel 'e'. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at an original magnification of ×12.5.

Histopathological findings showing tumor nests with interlacing cords, observed in the upper portion of the lesion. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at an original magnification of ×100.

Histopathological findings showing numerous structures resembling follicular germinative cells, some of which are extruding from interlacing cords. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at an original magnification of ×200.

Histopathological findings showing tumor nests exhibiting lobular aggregations and containing ductal and/or cystic structures, observed in the lower portion of the lesion. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at an original magnification of ×100.
Histopathological findings showing tumor nests consisting of sebocytes, characterized by a foamy cytoplasm. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at an original magnification of ×400.
Histopathological findings in an erosive lesion showing papillated structures with apocrine epithelium. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at an original magnification of ×20.

Histopathological findings showing the epithelium of tubules displaying decapitation secretion, with numerous plasma cells noted in the surrounding stroma. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at an original magnification of ×100.

Histopathological findings in a slightly elevated light brown plaque, showing hyperkeratotic epidermis and enlargement of sebaceous lobules. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at an original magnification of ×40.

Medium power hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained section (10× magnification) showing adenosis and usual type ductal hyperplasia within the nipple stroma and nipple skin dermis. This histopathologic evaluation supports a diagnosis of nipple adenoma, with no histologic evidence of atypia or malignancy identified.

Histologic examination of the excised right nipple tissue at low power (hematoxylin and eosin, 2×), showing a circumscribed, compact aggregate of tubules within the nipple stroma and nipple skin dermis. Histopathologic evaluation by a breast-specific pathologist revealed a well-circumscribed, compact proliferation of tubular glands within the nipple stroma and nipple skin dermis, centered in the reticular dermis with focal extension into the papillary dermis. The overlying epidermis showed acanthosis but was not directly involved, and no epidermal ulceration was identified. A final pathologic diagnosis of Nipple Adenoma (NA) was given, with no histologic evidence of atypia or malignancy identified.

Histologic examination of the excised right nipple tissue at medium power (hematoxylin and eosin, 20×), showing an adenosis pattern with proliferation of benign tubular and oval glands within the nipple stroma and nipple skin dermis. Histopathologic evaluation confirmed an adenosis pattern with proliferation of benign tubular glands. A final pathologic diagnosis of Nipple Adenoma (NA) was given, with no histologic evidence of atypia or malignancy identified.

Histologic examination of the excised right nipple tissue at high power (hematoxylin and eosin, 40×), showing several glands with usual type ductal hyperplasia within the nipple stroma and nipple skin dermis. Histopathologic evaluation confirmed usual type ductal hyperplasia in several glands. A final pathologic diagnosis of Nipple Adenoma (NA) was given, with no histologic evidence of atypia or malignancy identified.

Histologic examination of the excised right nipple tissue at high power (hematoxylin and eosin, 40×), showing several glands with apocrine metaplasia within the nipple stroma and nipple skin dermis. Histopathologic evaluation confirmed apocrine metaplasia in several glands. A final pathologic diagnosis of Nipple Adenoma (NA) was given, with no histologic evidence of atypia or malignancy identified.

Histopathology of an adjacent macule/papule presenting into the plaque and included into the excision, showing features of a common blue nevus. Stained with hematoxylin–eosin, original magnification ×40.
Histopathology showing aggregates of type C cells in the adjacent blue nevus. Stained with hematoxylin–eosin, original magnification ×100.

Histopathology (hematoxylin and eosin stain, x10 magnification) of the orbital mass, showing the blue nevus component. This component is characterized by interweaving cells with increased cellularity and heavily pigmented spindle cells, similar to a previous biopsy. Diagnostic pigmented spindle-shaped dendritic cells are visible at the left upper corner, adjacent to amelanotic uniform oval to spindle cells with inconspicuous nucleoli and clear cytoplasm.

Low power histopathology (hematoxylin and eosin stain, x10 magnification) of the orbital mass, showing the benign blue nevus component on the right side. This blue nevus component is characterized by interweaving cells with increased cellularity and heavily pigmented spindle cells with a slight increase in mitotic cells. There is an abrupt transition to the distinctive malignant melanoma component on the left side, which is of epithelioid type and characterized by large hyperchromatic nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and cytoplasmic melanin.

Magnified histopathology (hematoxylin and eosin stain, x40 magnification) of the benign blue nevus component of the orbital mass. This low-grade blue nevus component is characterized by interweaving cells with increased cellularity and heavily pigmented spindle cells with a slight increase in mitotic cells.

Magnified histopathology (hematoxylin and eosin stain, x40 magnification) of the malignant melanoma component of the orbital mass. This epithelioid type melanoma shows pigmented melanocytes with prominent nucleoli, a high nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio, increased mitosis, large hyperchromatic nuclei, and cytoplasmic melanin.

Histopathology of the nevus spilus, depicting the intervening epidermis between neoplastic foci, which is consistent with a background nevus spilus (NS) lesion. The image shows mild acanthosis, elongation of rete ridges, and lentiginous proliferation of basal melanocytes at the dermoepidermal junction with hyperpigmentation of basal keratinocytes. Stained with Hematoxylin & eosin (x200 magnification).

Histopathologic examination of lesion A shows invasive superficial spreading melanoma, characterized by multiple irregular nests and sheets of neoplastic cells forming in the dermis. Histopathological analysis revealed a Breslow thickness of 2.51 mm. Ulceration and satellite nodules were absent, lymphovascular or perineural invasion were not seen, and the margins were negative. (Hematoxylin & eosin stain, x100 magnification).

Histopathologic examination of lesion B shows invasive superficial spreading melanoma, characterized by multiple irregular nests and sheets of neoplastic cells forming in the dermis. Histopathological analysis revealed a Breslow thickness of 1.18 mm. Ulceration and satellite nodules were absent, lymphovascular or perineural invasion were not seen, and the margins were negative. (Hematoxylin & eosin stain, x40 magnification).

Histologic examination of lesion C shows the characteristics of in situ malignant melanoma, with marked proliferation of atypical melanocytes along the dermal-epidermal junction and superficial inflammatory infiltration of the dermis. Ulceration and satellite nodules were absent, lymphovascular or perineural invasion were not seen, and the margins were negative. (Hematoxylin & eosin stain, x100 magnification).

Histologic examination of lesion D shows the characteristics of in situ malignant melanoma, with marked proliferation of atypical melanocytes along the dermal-epidermal junction and superficial inflammatory infiltration of the dermis. Ulceration and satellite nodules were absent, lymphovascular or perineural invasion were not seen, and the margins were negative. (Hematoxylin & eosin stain, x100 magnification).
Histopathology showing nests of atypical melanocytes surrounded by myxoid stroma. Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification x40.
Histopathology showing nests of atypical melanocytes surrounded by myxoid stroma at a higher magnification. Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification x200.

Histopathology from a 29-year-old woman who presented with a new polychromatic nodule on the left scapular region, previously suspected to be melanoma. The image shows a large and well-circumscribed nodule with cells gathered in small and well-formed uniform nests. Mitotic activity was almost null. Large pale cells with hyperchromatic nuclei, vacuolated cytoplasm, and dusty-appearing melanin are also present. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at 10x magnification.

Histopathology image showing marked acanthosis with elongation and thickening of rete ridges. The epidermis displays full-thickness atypia and disarray of keratinocytes, along with a significant clear cell change. This image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) and captured at ×100 magnification.

Histopathology image showing marked acanthosis with elongation and thickening of rete ridges. The epidermis displays full-thickness atypia and disarray of keratinocytes, along with a significant clear cell change. This image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) and captured at ×400 magnification.

Histopathology of 'Papillated' Bowen's disease (H&E, ×100 magnification), demonstrating papillomatous changes that correspond to the clinically verrucous appearance. This represents a confirmed case of Bowen's disease, developed on the right fifth finger of a 45-year-old man, used to highlight the clinicopathological differences from 'lobulated' Bowen's disease.

Histopathology of 'Lobulated' Bowen's disease (H&E, ×100 magnification), showing marked acanthosis with elongation and thickening of rete ridges. These histopathological findings correlate with the clinically cerebriform or walnut-like appearance. This novel variant is distinguished from 'papillated' Bowen's disease by the absence of papillomatosis and a verrucous or hyperkeratotic surface.

Histopathology showing malignant melanoma in situ. The image reveals a symmetrical junctional melanocytic proliferation with isolated cells and nests of epithelioid and stellate cells. There is severe cytological atypia, with nuclear size increased at least 2 times, and focal pagetoid dissemination characterized by suprabasal melanocytes present in the central area of the lesion. The epidermis exhibits mild acanthosis and pigmentation of basal keratinocytes. An inflammatory infiltrate is associated with ectatic vessels, and focal lamellar fibroplasia is present in the papillary dermis. Hematoxylin & eosin (×100).

Histopathology of a non-diagnostic case, representing one of ten such cases that did not meet the minimum histological criteria of classically established entities. The image shows a junctional melanocytic proliferation with severe cytological atypia and spitzoid features from an 18-year-old boy. Specifically, the junctional melanocytes exhibit an expanded eosinophilic cytoplasm, consistent with spitzoid morphology, without nest formation, along with a few isolated intradermal cells. General features of these non-diagnostic cases include a lentiginous junctional melanocytic proliferation with epithelioid morphology and increased nuclear size in the acanthotic epidermis. (Hematoxylin & eosin, x400 magnification).
Histopathology showing Nodular hidradenoma, characterized by a well-circumscribed lobule with cystic changes. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×100 magnification.
Histopathology showing Chondroid syringoma, characterized by tubules and ducts embedded within a chondromyxoid matrix. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×100 magnification.
Histopathology showing Eccrine spiradenoma, characterized by lobules composed of intertwining cords of cells. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×100 magnification.

Histopathology showing Eccrine spiradenoma, specifically depicting the stroma which contains a dilated vessel and a lymphocytic infiltrate (indicated by an arrow). Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×400 magnification.
Histopathology of Pilomatricoma, showing well-circumscribed islands of epithelial cells. The tissue is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at ×100 magnification.
Histopathology of Pilomatricoma, showing basaloid cells transforming into ghost cells (indicated by an arrow). The tissue is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at ×400 magnification.
Histopathology of Pilomatrix carcinoma, showing an irregular, asymmetrical infiltrating tumor. The tissue is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at ×100 magnification.
Histopathology of Pilomatrix carcinoma, showing an irregular, asymmetrical infiltrating tumor. The tissue is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at ×100 magnification.
Histopathology showing eccrine poroma, characterized by well-defined lobules of tumor cells. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at ×100 magnification.

Histopathology showing eccrine poroma, characterized by uniform small cuboidal cells with deeply basophilic nuclei. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at ×400 magnification.
Histopathology showing porocarcinoma, characterized by infiltrating bands of tumor cells. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at ×100 magnification.
Histopathology showing porocarcinoma, characterized by tumor cells exhibiting marked atypia and mitosis. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at ×400 magnification.
Histopathology showing adenoid cystic carcinoma, characterized by epithelial cells arranged in a cribriform pattern. Magnification: ×400. Staining: Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).
Histopathology showing apocrine adenocarcinoma, characterized by infiltrating tumor glands. Magnification: ×100. Staining: Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).
Histopathology of Syringocystadenoma papilliferum showing epidermis with cystic invaginations. The tissue is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) and viewed at ×100 magnification.

Histopathology of Syringocystadenoma papilliferum showing a papillary core with plasma cells, indicated by an arrow. The tissue is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) and viewed at ×400 magnification.
Histopathology of Cylindroma showing irregular islands of epithelial cells fitting into each other. The tissue is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) and viewed at ×100 magnification.
Histopathology of Syringoma showing small ducts embedded in fibrous stroma. The tissue is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) and viewed at ×100 magnification.
Histopathology of nevus sebaceous, showing epidermal papillomatosis and large sebaceous glands. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification ×100.
Histopathology of sebaceous hyperplasia, characterized by an enlarged sebaceous gland. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification ×100.

Histological section (X100 magnification) stained with Hematoxylin & eosin showing papillomatosis and hyperparakeratosis with a deposit of melanin in the stratum corneum. The epidermis is entirely composed of atypical keratinocytes, some of which are pigmented. The dermis also contains melanophages, which explains the color variation observed in dermoscopy.
Histological section stained with Hematoxylin & eosin (X200) detailing the corneal layer with melanin (1), apoptotic keratinocytes (2), and melanophages in the dermis (3).

Photomicroscopy of the glans skin from a 9-year-old boy with penile lesions, showing histopathology of a compound melanocytic nevus. There is a proliferation of densely pigmented melanocytes with abundant cytoplasm along the dermal-epidermal junction and extending into the papillary dermis. Stained with Hematoxylin & eosin, original magnification X100.

Photomicroscopy of the glans skin from a 9-year-old boy with penile lesions, showing histopathology of a compound melanocytic nevus. There is a proliferation of densely pigmented melanocytes with abundant cytoplasm along the dermal-epidermal junction, forming nests in the papillary dermis. Stained with Hematoxylin & eosin, original magnification X400.

Photomicroscopy of the glans skin from a 9-year-old boy with penile lesions, showing histopathology of a compound melanocytic nevus. Individual melanocytes, part of a proliferation of densely pigmented melanocytes with abundant cytoplasm along the dermal-epidermal junction and forming nests in the papillary dermis, are visible with evident nuclei (arrows). Stained with Hematoxylin & eosin, original magnification X400.

Hematoxylin & eosin staining showing melanoma in situ with follicular involvement and syringoma structures in the middle dermis. The melanoma in situ is characterized by lentiginous melanocytic dysplasia, nucleocytoplasmic abnormalities, and an irregular distribution, primarily involving the hair follicles in the basal layer. The syringoma structures are visible as clusters of small ducts, occasionally with comma-shaped extensions, lined by a double-layered epithelium. (Original magnification X2).

Hematoxylin & eosin staining providing a detailed view of the collision between the melanoma in situ and the syringoma. The melanoma in situ components display melanocytic dysplasia and nucleocytoplasmic abnormalities with an irregular distribution, involving hair follicles. The syringoma components are represented by clusters of small ducts, occasionally with comma-shaped extensions, lined by a double-layered epithelium. (Original magnification X200).

Representative hematoxylin-eosin (HE) stained section demonstrating immune checkpoint inhibition-related colitis, characterized by increased lamina propria cellularity and extension of the inflammatory infiltrate into the submucosa.

Representative hematoxylin-eosin (HE) stained section demonstrating immune checkpoint inhibition-related colitis, characterized by increased lamina propria cellularity, neutrophilic inflammation with crypt abscesses, mild cryptitis, mucin depletion of epithelial cells, and small foci with minimal increase in intraepithelial lymphocytes.
Representative hematoxylin-eosin (HE) stained section demonstrating immune checkpoint inhibition-related colitis, showing apoptotic cells in the crypt epithelium.

Representative hematoxylin-eosin (HE) stained section demonstrating immune checkpoint inhibition-related colitis, characterized by increased lamina propria cellularity and prominent intraepithelial lymphocytosis.

Histopathology showing a tumor composed of spindle and epithelioid tumor cells, arranged in sheets or solid nests. The image displays 5μm thick formalin-fixed and paraffin-embedded tissue sections stained with hematoxylin and eosin, viewed at x100 original magnification.

Histopathology revealing neoplastic cells with large, pleomorphic, hyperchromatic or vesicular nuclei, multiple prominent nucleoli, and abundant eosinophilic or hypochromatic cytoplasm with intracytoplasmic brown pigment aggregates consistent with melanin, observed at x400 original magnification. Approximately 10 mitotic figures were noted per high power field. The image displays 5μm thick formalin-fixed and paraffin-embedded tissue sections stained with hematoxylin and eosin.

Microscopic appearance of a combined lesion, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at ×75 magnification. The image displays nests of nevus cells (indicated by an asterisk) located within the dermis, alongside some pigmented melanocytes. A papilloma component is also visible, characterized by central fibrovascular cores covered by acanthotic squamous epithelium. Additionally, elements typical of the lacrimal caruncle are shown, including conjunctival epithelium with goblet cells, sebaceous glands (marked by an arrow), and hair follicles (indicated by an arrowhead).
Histopathology of malignant melanoma, showing diffuse atypical cells infiltration forming a solid sheet (H&E, ×40).

Histopathology of a tangential biopsy revealing atypical melanocytic hyperplasia, characterized by nests and lentiginous proliferation of melanocytes. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×4 magnification.

High magnification histopathology image showing atypical melanocytes present within the matrix epithelium, consistent with atypical melanocytic hyperplasia. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×40 magnification.

This panel shows a histopathological view of early in situ melanoma. There is an increased density of solitary units of melanocytes displayed in an abnormal pattern at all layers of the subungual epithelium. Confluency of cells and pagetoid spread are noted, with minimal pigmentation. The image is stained with H&E, original magnification ×4.

This panel shows a histopathological view of early in situ melanoma. There is an increased density of solitary units of atypical epithelioid melanocytes in the lower third of the subungual matrix epithelium. The image is stained with H&E, original magnification ×40.

Longitudinal section of a normal nail unit, stained with H&E at ×4 magnification. This image shows the overall composition of the nail unit, including the nail matrix, nail bed, cuticle, nail folds and grooves, and the surrounding fibrocollagenous supportive tissue.
Higher magnification view (×40) of a longitudinal H&E-stained section of the normal nail matrix. This image highlights the proximal matrix, which is characterized by 4–10 cell layers.

This H&E stained histological section (×4 magnification) from the tangential matrix biopsy shows some barely recognizable melanocytes and very little pigment. Localized melanophages are also present in the dermis.

This H&E stained histological section (×40 magnification) provides a higher-power view, showing the melanocytes from the tangential matrix biopsy. Cytologically, the melanocytes appear normal, and no mitoses are observed.
Histopathology showing a junctional nevus of the matrix, consistent with melanocytic nevi. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and captured at ×10 magnification.
Histopathology revealing melanocyte nests within the matrix epithelium, consistent with melanocytic nevi. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and captured at ×40 magnification.

Histopathology of melanocytic hyperplasia (lentigo), showing a tangential biopsy of a lentigo of the matrix with heavily pigmented melanocytes present in the matrix epithelium. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification ×4.

Histopathology of melanocytic hyperplasia (lentigo), showing heavily pigmented melanocytes in the matrix epithelium from a tangential biopsy of a lentigo of the matrix, at higher magnification. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification ×40.

Histopathology showing invasive subungual melanoma (SUM), where the basal and suprabasal layers of the nail matrix and bed epithelium and dermis are invaded by an excessive number of melanocytes often displaying severe cellular atypia. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification ×4.

Histopathology showing in situ subungual melanoma (SUM), characterized by nests and lentiginous proliferation of severely atypical melanocytes. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification ×40.
Histopathology of the neoplasm stained with Hematoxylin and eosin (original magnification ×40), showing round cells characterized by clear, foamy cytoplasm and nuclear pleomorphism.
Histopathology of the neoplasm stained with hematoxylin and eosin (original magnification ×10), revealing a nodular and asymmetrical lesion.
Microscopic image showing dermal aggregates of pigmented nevus cells (H&E stain, original magnification ×200).
Microscopic image showing a fibrolipomatous lesion in the underlying dermis (H&E stain, original magnification ×200).
Histopathology showing the mesenchymal component with a myxoid and fibrillary appearance, containing elongated and wavy spindle cells arranged in fascicles resembling neurofibroma. Stained with H&E.

Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining of the larger lesion, which presented as a 10x5mm skin-colored dome-shaped firm mass with surface ulcerations on the face of a 40-year-old male, showing basal cell carcinoma (BCC), nodular type.
Histopathology showing distorted and hyperplastic pilosebaceous units with prominent sebaceous glands. H&E staining of epithelial and mesenchymal components.
Histopathology showing melanocytic tumor cells and atypical mitotic figures, indicated by a yellow arrow, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×200 magnification.

Histological findings showing melanocytes apparently decreased in number on both the lesional and perilesional skin. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) and captured at an original magnification of ×100.

Microscopic presentation of melanoacanthoma on the left lower abdomen of an 85-year-old man, showing the exophytic portion at low magnification (x2). The image reveals hyperkeratosis (thickening of the stratum corneum, indicated between the red bracket), acanthosis (thickening of the epidermis, indicated between the black bracket), and papillomatosis. There is prominent hyperpigmentation throughout all layers of the epidermis (black stars) due to heavily pigmented melanocytes. Tangential sectioning of the tumor shows keratin-filled pseudocysts (yellow arrows) and small areas of dermis containing epithelial lined vessels and erythrocytes within the epithelium (red arrows). Heavily pigmented melanophages are also present in the dermis, along with lymphocytic perivascular inflammation. The diagnosis of melanoacanthoma was established by correlating clinical morphology and pathologic findings. Stained with Hematoxylin and eosin.

Microscopic presentation of melanoacanthoma on the left lower abdomen of an 85-year-old man, showing a higher magnification (x10) view of the exophytic portion, specifically the area enclosed in the black circle of image A. The image reveals prominent hyperkeratosis (thickening of the stratum corneum, indicated between the red bracket), acanthosis (thickening of the epidermis, indicated between the black bracket), and papillomatosis. There is prominent hyperpigmentation throughout all layers of the epidermis (black stars) due to heavily pigmented melanocytes. Tangential sectioning of the tumor shows keratin-filled pseudocysts (yellow arrows) and small areas of dermis containing epithelial lined vessels and erythrocytes within the epithelium (red arrows). Heavily pigmented melanophages are also present in the dermis, along with lymphocytic perivascular inflammation. The diagnosis of melanoacanthoma was established by correlating clinical morphology and pathologic findings. Stained with Hematoxylin and eosin.

Microscopic presentation of melanoacanthoma on the left lower abdomen of an 85-year-old man, showing the endophytic portion at low magnification (x40). The image reveals pathologic changes similar to the exophytic portion, including hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, and papillomatosis. There is prominent hyperpigmentation throughout all layers of the epidermis (black stars) due to heavily pigmented melanocytes. Keratin-filled pseudocysts (yellow arrows) are visible, as are small areas of dermis containing epithelial lined vessels and erythrocytes within the epithelium (red arrows). Heavily pigmented melanophages are also present in the dermis, along with lymphocytic perivascular inflammation. The diagnosis of melanoacanthoma was established by correlating clinical morphology and pathologic findings. Stained with Hematoxylin and eosin.

Microscopic presentation of melanoacanthoma on the left lower abdomen of an 85-year-old man, showing a higher magnification (x40) view of the endophytic portion, specifically the area enclosed in the black circle of image C. The image reveals pathologic changes including hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, and papillomatosis. There is prominent hyperpigmentation throughout all layers of the epidermis (black stars), with numerous dendritic melanocytes (black arrows) observed throughout all layers of the epidermis. Keratin-filled pseudocysts (yellow arrows) are visible, as are small areas of dermis containing epithelial lined vessels and erythrocytes within the epithelium (red arrows). Heavily pigmented melanophages are also present in the dermis, along with lymphocytic perivascular inflammation. The diagnosis of melanoacanthoma was established by correlating clinical morphology and pathologic findings. Stained with Hematoxylin and eosin.

Histopathology showing a distant view of a melanoacanthoma, a benign pigmented lesion, on the right preauricular area of a 65-year-old woman. Low magnification (x2) of hematoxylin and eosin stained sections reveals an exophytic nodule with hyperkeratosis (thickening of the stratum corneum, shown between the red bracket) and acanthosis (thickening of the epidermis, shown between the black bracket). The microscopic evaluation of the biopsy specimen revealed acanthosis with a uniform proliferation of heavily pigmented basaloid cells extending into the upper epidermis, and variable maturation of the epithelium. There is hyperpigmentation throughout all layers of the epidermis (black stars). Tangential sectioning of the tumor shows small areas of dermis, containing epithelial lined vessels and erythrocytes within the epithelium (red arrows). Heavily pigmented melanophages and lymphocytic perivascular inflammation are present in the dermis. The area enclosed in the black circle of image A is shown at higher magnification in image B.

Histopathology showing a closer view of a melanoacanthoma, a benign pigmented lesion, on the right preauricular area of a 65-year-old woman. Higher magnification (x10) of hematoxylin and eosin stained sections, corresponding to the area enclosed in the black circle of image A, reveals an exophytic nodule with hyperkeratosis (thickening of the stratum corneum) and acanthosis (thickening of the epidermis). The microscopic evaluation of the biopsy specimen revealed acanthosis with a uniform proliferation of heavily pigmented basaloid cells extending into the upper epidermis, and variable maturation of the epithelium with occasional mitoses. There is hyperpigmentation throughout all layers of the epidermis (black stars). Tangential sectioning of the tumor shows small areas of dermis, containing epithelial lined vessels and erythrocytes within the epithelium (red arrows). Heavily pigmented melanophages and lymphocytic perivascular inflammation are present in the dermis.

Histopathology showing a closer view of a melanoacanthoma, a benign pigmented lesion, on the right preauricular area of a 65-year-old woman. Higher magnification (x40) of hematoxylin and eosin stained sections reveals an exophytic nodule with hyperkeratosis (thickening of the stratum corneum) and acanthosis (thickening of the epidermis). The microscopic evaluation of the biopsy specimen revealed acanthosis with a uniform proliferation of heavily pigmented basaloid cells extending into the upper epidermis, and variable maturation of the epithelium with occasional mitoses. There is hyperpigmentation throughout all layers of the epidermis (black stars). Tangential sectioning of the tumor shows small areas of dermis, containing epithelial lined vessels and erythrocytes within the epithelium (red arrows). Heavily pigmented melanophages and lymphocytic perivascular inflammation are present in the dermis.

Microscopic presentation of pigmented seborrheic keratosis from the left posterior shoulder of an 85-year-old man. The image shows a complete view of the lesion. Pathologic features include hyperkeratosis (thickening of the stratum corneum, as shown between the red bracket), acanthosis (thickening of the epidermis, as shown between the black bracket), and hyperpigmentation restricted to the basal layers of the epidermis (indicated by black stars). Tangential sectioning of the tumor also shows keratin-filled pseudocysts (indicated by yellow arrows). Microscopic examination revealed acanthosis with heavy melanin deposits in the dermis. The clinical morphology and pathologic features established a diagnosis of pigmented seborrheic keratosis. The entire lesion was removed with the biopsy. Stained with Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at 2x magnification.

Microscopic presentation of pigmented seborrheic keratosis from the left axilla of an 85-year-old man. The image shows a complete view of the lesion. Pathologic features include hyperkeratosis (thickening of the stratum corneum, as shown between the red bracket), acanthosis (thickening of the epidermis, as shown between the black bracket), and hyperpigmentation restricted to the basal layers of the epidermis (indicated by black stars). Tangential sectioning of the tumor also shows keratin-filled pseudocysts (indicated by yellow arrows). Microscopic examination revealed acanthosis with heavy melanin deposits in the dermis. The clinical morphology and pathologic features established a diagnosis of pigmented seborrheic keratosis. The entire lesion was removed with the biopsy. Stained with Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at 2x magnification.

Microscopic presentation of recurrent melanoacanthoma on the right preauricular area of a 65-year-old woman. This low magnification (x2) hematoxylin and eosin stained section provides a distant view of the pathological features of a melanoacanthoma, with findings consistent with those observed on initial biopsy. The image shows an exophytic nodule with hyperkeratosis (thickening of the stratum corneum, indicated between the red bracket) and acanthosis (thickening of the epidermis, indicated between the black bracket). Hyperpigmentation is present throughout all layers of the epidermis (black stars). Tangential sectioning of the tumor reveals small areas of dermis, containing epithelial lined vessels and erythrocytes within the epithelium (red arrows). Lymphocytic perivascular inflammation is also observed in the dermis.

Microscopic presentation of recurrent melanoacanthoma on the right preauricular area of a 65-year-old woman. This higher magnification (x40) hematoxylin and eosin stained section provides a closer view of the pathological features of a melanoacanthoma, with findings consistent with those observed on initial biopsy. The image displays an exophytic nodule with hyperkeratosis (thickening of the stratum corneum, indicated between the red bracket) and acanthosis (thickening of the epidermis, indicated between the black bracket). Hyperpigmentation is observed throughout all layers of the epidermis (black stars). Tangential sectioning of the tumor shows small areas of dermis, containing epithelial lined vessels and erythrocytes within the epithelium (red arrows). Lymphocytic perivascular inflammation is also present in the dermis.

Histopathological examination showing both a spindle cellular area and a round nodular growing area. The spindle-shaped cells suggest sarcomatous differentiation, while the round nodular cells suggest carcinomatous differentiation. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at ×40 magnification.

Histopathological examination showing a spindle cellular area. These spindle-shaped cells suggest sarcomatous differentiation as observed during H&E staining. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at ×100 magnification.

Histopathological examination showing spindle tumor cells with frequent mitoses. These spindle-shaped cells suggest sarcomatous differentiation as observed during H&E staining. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at ×400 magnification.

Histopathological examination showing a round nodular growing area. These round nodular cells suggest carcinomatous differentiation as observed during H&E staining. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at ×100 magnification.

Histopathological examination showing round tumor cells with vesicular nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and frequent mitoses. These features are observed in the carcinomatous differentiated area. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at ×400 magnification.

Low-power histopathological photograph (100×) of a solitary fibrofolliculoma. The image shows a well-defined tumor mass involving a hair follicle, with a proliferation of multiple thin strands of basaloid cells extending from the central follicle into the surrounding fibrous stroma. The fibrous stroma presents a sharp contrast with the surrounding dermis. These histologic findings are characteristic of fibrofolliculoma. Stained with Hematoxylin-eosin.

High-power histopathological photograph (200×) of a solitary fibrofolliculoma, showing the fibrous stroma contents with mucin, surrounding the hair follicle. The lesion shows a well-defined tumor mass involving a hair follicle, and the fibrous stroma presents a sharp contrast with the surrounding dermis. These histologic findings are characteristic of fibrofolliculoma. Stained with Hematoxylin-eosin.

Histopathology demonstrating melanocytic proliferation arranged in a lentiginous pattern along the dermoepidermal junction. The image also reveals focal individual epithelioid melanocytes exhibiting architectural and cytologic atypia. This image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin.

Histopathological low power image of a choroidal melanoma, revealing the classic mushroom-shaped mass formed due to ruptured Bruch's membrane. This morphology is a characteristic feature observed in some choroidal melanomas. Histopathologically, choroidal melanomas commonly present with spindle cell type (50%), followed by epithelioid (35.7%) and mixed cell types (14.3%). The image is stained with Hematoxylin and eosin; original magnification x12.5.

Histopathological image showing the appearance of spindle cell-type melanoma, which represents one area within this particular mixed cell type tumor. The spindle cell type was the most common cell type found in choroidal melanomas, accounting for 50% of cases in the studied cohort. Other cell types included epithelioid (35.7%) and mixed (14.3%). The image is stained with Hematoxylin and eosin-bleached; original magnification x200.

Histopathological image of another area within the choroidal melanoma, showing epithelioid cell proliferation. Epithelioid cell type was observed in 35.7% of choroidal melanomas, making it the second most common cell type after spindle cell type (50%). Mixed cell types were found in 14.3% of cases. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and eosin; original magnification x400.

Histopathology (H&E stain) of a malignant melanoma sample, showing a tumor with mild, focal lymphocytic infiltration. This represents a non-T cell-inflamed (cold) tumor microenvironment, indicating a minimal host immune response, which is generally associated with less favorable patient outcomes compared to tumors with dense lymphocyte infiltration. Scale bar = 100 μm.

Histopathology (H&E stain) of a malignant melanoma sample, showing a tumor exhibiting dense Tumor-Infiltrating Lymphocyte (TIL) patterns. This represents a T cell-inflamed (hot) tumor microenvironment, indicative of a robust host immune response to the tumor. Increased TIL levels, particularly brisk TIL patterns, are associated with improved patient outcomes, including overall survival, recurrence-free survival, and disease-specific survival. Scale bar = 100 μm.

Histological examination of a large pigmented colorectal polyp revealing features of malignant melanoma. This panel shows atypical melanocytic cells with pigmented debris in the cytoplasm infiltrating the gland. Hematoxylin and Eosin (H.E.) stain, original magnification x 100.

Histological examination of a large pigmented colorectal polyp revealing features of malignant melanoma. This panel shows atypical melanocytic cells with pigmented debris in the cytoplasm infiltrating the gland. Hematoxylin and Eosin (H.E.) stain, original magnification x 400.

Histological examination of a large pigmented colorectal polyp revealing features of malignant melanoma. This panel shows atypical melanocytic cells with pigmented debris in the cytoplasm infiltrating the gland. Hematoxylin and Eosin (H.E.) stain, original magnification x 400.

Histopathology image, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H.E.) at 100x magnification, showing pigmented atypical melanocytic cells infiltrating into the muscle with a thickness of 7 mm. This finding is from the surgical specimen described in panel A, obtained from a patient who had undergone malignancy-risk assessment. Initial examinations, including CT scans, had not revealed metastasis lesions.

Histological image of lentigo maligna in the radial growth phase, stained with Hematoxylin-eosin (10x magnification). This panel shows solar elastosis (arrow), a patchy lymphocytic infiltrate, and melanophages (+ sign) within the dermis. An atrophic epidermis (asterisk) is visible, alongside an increased density of melanocytes along the dermal-epidermal junction. Some of these melanocytes exhibit variable nuclear atypia (arrowheads), a key characteristic of lentigo maligna. Typically, lentigo maligna is characterized by an increased density of melanocytes along the dermal-epidermal junction and these melanocytes, which can show dendritic appearance, may also extend into the spinous layer or involve the adnexa.

Histological image of extrafacial lentigo maligna on chronically sun-damaged skin, stained with Hematoxylin-eosin (10x magnification). This panel shows an atrophic epidermis (asterisk) and prominent solar elastosis (arrow). There is an increased density of junctional pleomorphic melanocytes forming asymmetric nests, along with pagetoid growth of single melanocytes (arrowheads), which signifies their presence in the spinous layer. A dermal inflammatory infiltrate containing melanophages (+ sign) is also evident. Lentigo maligna is characterized by an increased density of melanocytes along the dermal-epidermal junction, often with variable nuclear atypia and pleomorphism, and can exhibit pagetoid spread, sometimes involving deeper portions of follicles and adnexa.

Histopathology of gastric tissue from a 74-year-old male patient diagnosed with Primary Gastric Malignant Melanoma (PGMM). The image shows infiltration of the gastric mucosa by a tumor consisting of large atypical epithelioid or spindle cells growing in solid sheets and fascicles (hematoxylin and eosin staining, x20).

Histopathology of gastric tissue from a 74-year-old male patient diagnosed with Primary Gastric Malignant Melanoma (PGMM). The tumor cells are round with hyperchromatic eccentric nuclei, a high nuclear/cytoplasmic ratio, rare nucleoli, and mixed eosinophilic and basophilic cytoplasm (hematoxylin and eosin staining, x40).

Histopathology of gastric tissue from a 74-year-old male patient diagnosed with Primary Gastric Malignant Melanoma (PGMM). The tumor cells appear dyscohesive with no identifiable pigment formation. Widespread mitotic activity and necrosis were also observed (hematoxylin and eosin staining, x200).

Histopathology (H&E, x40 magnification) of oral mucosal melanoma (OMM) showing a poorly circumscribed pigmented tumor infiltrating the underlying tissue, with overlying mucosa. The tumor is composed of oval to spindle cells arranged in diffuse sheets and nests, exhibiting moderate nuclear pleomorphism, vesicular to hyperchromatic nuclei, prominent eosinophilic nucleoli, and both intracellular and extracellular pigment, consistent with the diagnosis of OMM.

Histopathology (H&E, x40 magnification) of oral mucosal melanoma (OMM) depicting pigmented tumor cells, characterized by oval to spindle morphology, moderate nuclear pleomorphism, vesicular to hyperchromatic nuclei, prominent eosinophilic nucleoli, and intracellular and extracellular pigment, adjacent to seromucinous glands.

Scanning micrograph of the porocarcinoma shows an expansile tumor arising from the epidermis with extension deep into the reticular dermis. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin at 4x magnification.

Higher power scanning micrograph of the porocarcinoma shows focal necrosis of the tumor, which displays cytologic atypia, including mitotic figures. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin at 20x magnification.

Histologic representative section (Hematoxylin and eosin, ×2 original magnification) of the excavated optic nerve head. The image shows pigmented cells layering the surface and invading the lamina cribrosa (L), correlating with the focal invasion by a few single epithelioid melanoma cells into the nerve head and lamina cribrosa. The postlaminar optic nerve exhibits basophilic (blue) cystic cavities (arrows), indicative of Schnabel's degeneration, which was noted in the markedly cupped and atrophic optic nerve.

High-power histologic view (Hematoxylin and eosin, ×100 original magnification) of the optic nerve head surface over the central vein. The image displays epithelioid pigmented melanoma cells, consistent with the tumor seeds of pigmented melanoma cells that lined the inner limiting membrane of the optic nerve and focally invaded the nerve head.

Digital scan of a histopathological section of an enucleated eye, stained with hematoxylin and eosin, showing diffuse iris ring-type melanoma. This view highlights the absence of a defined mass formation but demonstrates significant hyperpigmentation of the anterior chamber angle (indicated by arrows), consistent with the melanoma involving approximately 75% of the anterior chamber angle structures. The image also reveals an excavated optic nerve head (indicated by an arrowhead), a finding associated with glaucoma, and further supported by the optic nerve being markedly cupped and atrophic with Schnabel's degeneration and focal invasion by a few single epithelioid melanoma cells.

Histopathology providing an overview of the anterior segment, demonstrating melanoma tumor infiltrating the angle and the iris surface. The end of Descemet's membrane is indicated by an arrow, and the tumor completely fills the angle. The enucleated eye showed diffuse iris ring-type melanoma involving the ciliary body, iris root, and approximately 75% of the anterior chamber angle structures. Stained with Hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification ×2.

Histopathology showing a closeup of melanoma tumor cells lining the anterior surface of the iris near the ectropion uvea. The image reveals spindle cells, including both type A and B melanoma cells, which are partially pigmented. This observation is part of the histopathological examination that identified a diffuse iris ring-type melanoma involving the iris root and anterior chamber angle structures, with the tumor primarily composed of spindle B-type cells extending in a sheath-like pattern over the iris. Stained with Hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification ×100.

Histopathology showing a closeup of melanoma tumor cells at the anterior chamber angle, characterized by large epithelioid cells with clear cytoplasm and prominent nucleoli, alternating with spindle cells. This appearance is consistent with the histopathological examination of a diffuse iris ring-type melanoma involving the ciliary body, iris root, and anterior chamber angle structures, where epithelioid-type cells are seen at the tumor margins forming nests and invading the trabecular meshwork, and spindle B-type cells are also present. Stained with Hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification ×100.

Histopathology showing binucleated epithelioid melanoma cells infiltrating deep into the stroma of the iris at the root of the iris. This finding supports the histopathological diagnosis of a diffuse iris ring-type melanoma involving the ciliary body and iris root, with epithelioid-type cells observed at the tumor margins. Stained with Hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification ×100.
Histopathology showing a circumscribed tumor with cells arranged in fascicles and nests. Stained with hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×40.
Histopathology showing fascicles and nests composed of plump spindle cells within the tumor. Stained with hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×100.
Histopathology showing adipose-like cells admixed with tumor cells. Stained with hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×200.
Histopathology showing melanin pigment deposition within the tumor cells. Stained with hematoxylin-eosin, original magnification ×200.

Histologic examination reveals solid tumor cell nests. These nests are composed of two distinct cell types: small, dark poroid cells (indicated by a white arrow) and larger, pale cuticular cells (indicated by a black arrow) which exhibit clear cytoplasm. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at ×100 magnification.

Histopathology of a superficial spreading melanoma (SSM) from case 2, stained with H&E at ×5 magnification. The image shows a relatively symmetrical, compound melanocytic lesion extending into the superficial dermis with large nests at the junction, consistent with the described microscopical findings for this case, which also noted few melanocytes in the epidermis, no ascension, and hyperplastic, hyperkeratotic epidermal changes.

Histopathology of a superficial spreading melanoma (SSM) from case 2, stained with H&E at ×40 magnification. The image details epithelioid to spindle-shaped melanocytes with pale, eosinophilic cytoplasm. There is variation in the size and shape of the cells, which exhibit large nuclei with prominent nucleoli and nuclear vacuoles, indicating slight nuclear atypia. A few multinucleated cells are also visible, consistent with the detailed microscopical findings for this case.

Histopathology of a Variant Spitz nevus from the left upper leg of a 48-year-old female, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×5 magnification. The image displays a symmetrical, compound melanocytic lesion with nests and solitary melanocytes at the dermo-epidermal junction. The dermal component shows a partly naevoid aspect. Melanocytes are observed spreading out between desmoplastic stroma at the base of the lesion, which also features hyperplastic, hyper- and parakeratotic epidermis, and moderate nuclear atypia.

High-magnification histopathology of a Variant Spitz nevus from the left upper leg of a 48-year-old female, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×40 magnification. This image shows epithelioid to slightly spindle-shaped melanocytes with pale, eosinophilic, and partly pigmented cytoplasm. The cells exhibit enlarged nuclei and prominent nucleoli, characteristic of the moderate nuclear atypia observed in this case. A single mitotic figure was noted in the upper dermis.
Histopathology showing hematoxylin-eosin staining of a yellowish plaque located on the right cheek. The image reveals numerous Touton giant cells, which are highlighted by arrows.

Photomicrograph of the tumor section showing intact squamous epithelium and diffuse infiltration of the subepithelium by tumor cells. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at 40x magnification.

High power photomicrograph of the tumor showing round and spindle cells with prominent nucleoli, and melanin in the cells. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at 400x magnification.
Histopathology stained with hematoxylin and eosin (10× magnification) demonstrating few non-necrotizing sarcoid-like epithelioid granulomas. Multinucleated giant cells are not present in this field.

Representative image of a biopsy specimen taken from the tympanic membrane of a 68-year-old male patient presenting with left-sided, progressive hearing loss and an atypical granulomatous presentation. Hematoxylin-eosin staining (200× magnification) shows nests and sheets of a highly atypical melanocytic proliferation (marked with an asterisk) within a fibrous background (indicated by arrows). This finding is consistent with mucosal melanoma.

Detail of the biopsy specimen from the tympanic membrane of a 68-year-old male patient diagnosed with mucosal melanoma. Hematoxylin-eosin staining (400× magnification) shows the highly atypical melanocytic proliferation, where tumor cells exhibit an epithelioid, eosinophilic, and partly vacuolated cytoplasm. The cells have anisomorphic nuclei with prominent macronucleoli and demonstrate prominent mitotic activity (indicated by arrows), consistent with the aggressive nature of mucosal melanoma.

Histopathology of a Nevus Cell Nevus (NCN) from patient 3 (slide number 1256), stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). This NCN sample serves as a representative image for the immunohistochemical staining results shown in subsequent panels. Scale bar represents 200 μm. Overview inserts are two times lower in magnification.

Histopathology showing Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC) tissue from patient 10 (slide number 8931), stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). This panel provides a general view of the SCC morphology. The scale bar represents 200 μm, with overview inserts at two times lower magnification.

Histopathology of a Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC) from patient 2 (slide number 27), stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). This image provides a morphological overview and serves as a reference for the subsequent immunohistochemical stainings shown in panels b-e of the same BCC tissue. The epidermis is visible and serves as an anatomical reference. Scale bar represents 200 μm, with overview inserts showing two times lower magnification.

Microscopic characteristics of the Oral Lichen Planus (OLP) lesion removed from the right buccal mucosa. Panel A shows the lesion covered by stratified hyperorthokeratinized squamous epithelium. A histopathological examination confirmed the clinical suspicion of OLP for reticular lesions, evidencing a fragment of the oral mucosa covered by stratified orthokeratinized squamous epithelium. The image displays a banded subepithelial inflammatory infiltrate. The subepithelial connective tissue presented an intense banded inflammatory infiltrate, predominantly lymphocytic. (Hematoxylin and eosin, scale bar 50 µm).

Microscopic characteristics of the Oral Lichen Planus (OLP) lesion removed from the right buccal mucosa. Panel B shows epithelial changes comprising exocytosis and spongiosis. A histopathological examination confirmed the clinical suspicion of OLP for reticular lesions, evidencing a fragment of the oral mucosa covered by stratified orthokeratinized squamous epithelium exhibiting acanthosis, spongiosis, exocytosis, and edematous degeneration. There is a predominantly lymphocytic connective tissue inflammatory infiltrate, consistent with an intense banded inflammatory infiltrate predominantly lymphocytic in the subepithelial connective tissue. (Hematoxylin and eosin, scale bar 200 µm).

Microscopic characteristics of the lesion removed from the left buccal mucosa, diagnosed as Verruciform Xanthoma (VX). Histopathology shows digitiform proliferation of the stratified parakeratinized squamous epithelium. The lesion was initially diagnosed as leukoplakia, presenting as a hyperparakeratinized stratified squamous epithelium with exophytic and digitiform projections, including parakeratin plugs. A VX diagnosis was later confirmed based on further histopathological and immunohistochemical findings. (H&E scale bar 200 µm).

Microscopic characteristics of the lesion removed from the left buccal mucosa, diagnosed as Verruciform Xanthoma (VX). Histopathology reveals the presence of large spongy or xanthoma cells within the subepithelial connective tissue. These spongy cells are similar to macrophages, and their presence raised histopathological suspicion of VX. PAS with diastasis was performed to identify the presence of lipids in these cells, which was positive, contributing to the confirmation of the VX diagnosis. (H&E scale bar 100 µm).
Histopathology showing a nodular melanoma (NM) with nodular growth, characterized by a prominent vertical component to the invasion of the tumor. (H&E stain, 40× magnification).
Histopathology showing a nodular melanoma (NM) with nodular growth, characterized by a prominent vertical component to the invasion of the tumor. (H&E stain, 40× magnification).
Microscopic view of a tumor cell exhibiting heavy melanin pigmentation. (H&E stain, 100× magnification).
Microscopic view of a tumor cell exhibiting heavy melanin pigmentation. (H&E stain, 100× magnification).

Histopathology demonstrating an intradermal nevus, diagnosed from a lesion excised from a 36-year-old woman who presented with otalgia and a 0.7 × 0.7 cm firm, non-tender, nodular mass in the anteroinferior portion of the right external auditory canal. The image shows clusters of nevus cells in the dermis without junctional activity. (Hematoxylin–eosin stain, ×40 magnification).
Histopathology of the resected lesion showing microscopic examination confirmed melanoma, stained with Hematoxylin and eosin (x100).

Histopathology of the resected lesion showing multiple anaplastic cells and mitotic figures, stained with Hematoxylin and eosin (x400). This high magnification confirmed melanoma and showed extensive anaplasia and mitotic activity.

Histopathology of the resected lesion, showing oval, short-spindle shaped cells with a heterogeneous intracellular distribution of melanin, consistent with primary meningeal melanocytoma of the cervical spine. Hematoxylin and eosin staining (x100).

High magnification histopathology of the resected lesion, showing oval cells with large nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and little mitotic activity, consistent with primary meningeal melanocytoma of the cervical spine. Hematoxylin and eosin staining (x400).

Histopathology (hematoxylin and eosin, H&E stain) showing diffuse plasma cells (CD138 positive) in a representative case of successful treatment for melanoma with talimogene laherparepvec (T-VEC). This image demonstrates a complete response, with no residual melanoma tumor tissue observed after 12 months of T-VEC treatment. Plasma cells can be recognized by their oval shape, round and eccentric nucleus with coarse chromatin, a prominent perinuclear hof, and abundant basophilic cytoplasm. These plasma cell infiltrates were not present prior to intralesional T-VEC injections and were observed to form after T-VEC start, being present in varying degrees in all biopsies from T-VEC injected sites. The relative degree of plasma cells (CD138) in such cases was comparable to cytotoxic T cells (CD8).

Histopathology (hematoxylin and eosin, H&E stain) showing angiocentric features, part of a classical HSV-associated histopathological pattern. This image is from a representative case of successful treatment for melanoma with talimogene laherparepvec (T-VEC), demonstrating a complete response with no residual melanoma tumor tissue after 12 months of treatment. Angiocentric features were significantly more frequently identified in patients with complete response (>6 months) compared with patients without a durable response (75% vs. 29%, P = 0.015), indicating their association with a positive treatment outcome.

Histopathology (hematoxylin and eosin, H&E stain) showing perineural features, part of a classical HSV-associated histopathological pattern. This image is from a representative case of successful treatment for melanoma with talimogene laherparepvec (T-VEC), demonstrating a complete response with no residual melanoma tumor tissue after 12 months of treatment. Perineural features were observed in conjunction with diffuse plasma cells, angiocentric features, and granulomas in this successful treatment outcome. In biopsies from T-VEC injected sites, localization of immune infiltrates, which include these features, shifted from solely superficial to deep, occasionally in combination with superficial patterns.

Histopathology (hematoxylin and eosin, H&E stain) showing granulomas, part of a classical HSV-associated histopathological pattern. This image is from a representative case of successful treatment for melanoma with talimogene laherparepvec (T-VEC), demonstrating a complete response with no residual melanoma tumor tissue after 12 months of treatment. These 'classical' granulomas were significantly more frequently identified in patients with complete response (>6 months) compared with patients without a durable response (58% vs. 15%, P = 0.041), highlighting their association with a positive treatment outcome.

Histopathological section through a uterine tumor mass, stained with Hematoxylin–Eosin (HE). The myometrium exhibits a leiomyomatous structure with multiple nodular formations showing malignant tumor proliferation, most likely mesenchymal. The tumor displays marked cell and nuclear pleomorphism, with a solid and fasciculate pattern and moderate mitotic activity, suggesting a poorly differentiated malignant tumor. Areas of hyalinization are also visible. Original magnification ×100.

Histopathological section through a uterine tumor mass, stained with Hematoxylin–Eosin (HE). The myometrium exhibits a leiomyomatous structure with multiple nodular formations showing malignant tumor proliferation, most likely mesenchymal. The tumor displays marked cell and nuclear pleomorphism, with a solid and fasciculate pattern and moderate mitotic activity, suggesting a poorly differentiated malignant tumor. Areas of hyalinization are also visible. Original magnification ×200.

Histopathology showing a micronodular basal cell carcinoma (BCC) in a haematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained tissue section. This BCC presented as large tumours of basaloid cells, characteristic of the micronodular subtype, invading the dermis and displaying mitotic activity and slight cytological atypia. This lesion was identified from one of the multiple skin-coloured papules found on the patient's face and neck.

Histopathology showing a basal cell naevus (BCN) in a haematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained tissue section. The BCN consists of tiny arborescent buddings of cytologically bland basaloid cells, which are either attached to the epidermis or replacing the hair follicles. This lesion was identified from one of the multiple skin-coloured papules found on the patient's face and neck, with its diagnosis confirmed by H&E staining of the excised tissue.

Histopathology of a melanocytic neoplasm characterized by proliferation of cells that are either epithelioid or fusiform with eosinophilic cytoplasm, whose nuclei have a moderate degree of polymorphism and prominent nucleoli, forming an extensive dermal lesion (Hematoxylin and eosin stain, 100x magnification).
