Histopathology of a biopsy from a 46-year-old woman who presented with a painless, verrucous lesion of the scalp. The image displays features of an invasive melanoma with prominent verrucous morphology. Microscopic examination reveals papilliferous acanthosis and hyperplasia of the epidermis, characterized by elongated rete ridges and orthohyperkeratosis. Atypical fragmented melanocytes, demonstrating anisokaryosis, are primarily arranged in nests along the dermis. The melanoma extends to the base and peripheral edges of the biopsy. The lesion was subsequently identified as a superficially spreading melanoma with a Breslow depth of 2 mm and Clark Level III, accompanied by brisk tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes. (Hematoxylin and eosin, ×20 magnification).

Histopathology (Hematoxylin and Eosin, H&E, 200X magnification) showing scattered intra and extracellular brown pigment within the tumor. Many intermingled cells are also noted to contain cytoplasmic brownish-orange pigment granules, some of which obscure nuclear details. This finding, observed in both patients' tumors, contributed to the histomorphological assessment of a primary benign spindle cell tumor.

Histopathology of an office biopsy specimen, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). The biopsy report indicated a malignant melanoma with no definite presence of ulceration. Lymphovascular or perineural invasion was not demonstrated, and focal changes suggestive of a regression phenomenon were present. The report also noted one mitosis per square millimeter and a minimal inflammatory response, with no evidence of a precursor melanocytic lesion. Complete excision of the lesion with appropriate margins of normal surrounding tissue was recommended.

Histomorphology of a tumor specimen revealing a spindle cell neoplasm. This panel shows a fascicular growth pattern and focal squamous cell remnants from the oral cavity mucosa. The tumor morphology includes a predominantly intersecting fascicular morphology, high mitotic activity, and bizarre and monstrous cells. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification 100x.

Histomorphology of a tumor specimen revealing a spindle cell neoplasm. This panel shows spindle cells, some with truncated nuclear ends, growing in an intertwining fascicular pattern, and a pathological mitotic figure (arrow). The tumor morphology includes high mitotic activity, bizarre and monstrous cells, and a predominantly intersecting fascicular morphology. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification 400x.

Panoramic histopathological view of the lesion examined. Histopathological analysis showed pleomorphic and atypical elements, with numerous typical and atypical mitotic figures, eosinophilic intracytoplasmic paranuclear inclusions, nuclei with thinned chromatin, and numerous central and peripheral nucleoli. Note the presence of an abundant pseudo-vascular cell component with extravasated erythrocytes. Stained with hematoxylin–eosin, original magnification 4×.

Histological preparation showing cytological details of the neoplastic cells. These cells are pleomorphic and atypical elements, with numerous typical and atypical mitotic figures, eosinophilic intracytoplasmic paranuclear inclusions, nuclei with thinned chromatin, and numerous central and peripheral nucleoli, presenting a pseudo-vascular appearance. Stained with hematoxylin–eosin, original magnification 10×.

Photomicrograph showing pseudo-vascular structures formed by neoplastic cells containing red blood cells, with some foci of necrosis. No pigment interspersed with this cell population was appreciated. The large blood-filled spaces are bordered by neoplastic cells, not true endothelial cells, creating a pseudo-vascular pattern. Stained with H&E, original magnification 20×.

Photomicrograph showing details of foci of hemorrhage. These large blood-filled spaces are bordered by neoplastic cells, not true endothelial cells, forming a pseudo-vascular pattern. Stained with H&E, original magnification 20×.

Histopathology showing an area of transition into heterologous chondroid differentiation within a melanoma. The overall histopathology of the case revealed melanoma with areas of heterologous osteocartilaginous differentiation, invading soft tissues and bone. The diagnosis of melanoma was confirmed by immunoreactivity with SOX10 and HMB45. (Hematoxylin & eosin, ×400).

Histopathology showing an area of transition into heterologous osteoid differentiation within a melanoma, consistent with the presence of heterologous osteocartilaginous differentiation. The overall histopathology indicated melanoma with areas of heterologous osteocartilaginous differentiation, invading soft tissues and bone. The diagnosis of melanoma was confirmed by immunoreactivity with SOX10 and HMB45. Hematoxylin & eosin stain, original magnification ×400.

Histopathology showing melanoma cells characterized by atypia, pleomorphism, evident nucleoli, and frequent mitotic figures. This image depicts the melanoma component of a tumor that also showed areas of heterologous osteocartilaginous differentiation, invading soft tissues and bone, and was confirmed by immunoreactivity with SOX10 and HMB45. (Hematoxylin & eosin, ×400).

Histopathological findings of a Reed nevus on the finger, showing several small tumor cell nests scattered within the epidermis. These nests are vertically oriented and composed of heavily pigmented spindled melanocytes along the dermo-epidermal junction (Hematoxylin & eosin, ×100 magnification).

Histopathological findings of a Reed nevus on the finger, showing junctional nests composed of heavily pigmented spindle-shaped melanocytes, which are vertically oriented along the dermo-epidermal junction (Hematoxylin & eosin, ×200 magnification).

Histopathology of Bowen's disease (Case 1) showing parakeratosis, acanthosis, and full-thickness keratinocyte atypia in the epidermis, with increased mitosis and diskeratosis. The papillary dermis contains eosinophilic homogeneous globular material deposition, identified as amyloid accumulation, and mononuclear inflammatory infiltrate. This image is from a 73-year-old woman with a 3 cm-sized, irregular pigmented, slightly hyperkeratotic solitary plaque of Bowen's disease on the right groin. A punch biopsy confirmed hyperkeratosis, lack of maturation, loss of polarity in all epidermal layers, and apoptotic keratinocytes, consistent with Bowen's disease. The presence of amyloid was incidentally detected as eosinophilic material during routine histopathological examination. (H&E; x200 magnification).

Histopathology of Bowen's disease (Case 3) from an area of regression, showing epidermal keratinocyte atypia and homogeneous eosinophilic material deposition in the papillary dermis. This eosinophilic material represents amyloid accumulation, observed as aggregates of eosinophilic droplets. This image is from a 76-year-old man who presented with a plaque of Bowen's disease associated with superficially invasive squamous cell carcinoma, with the sample taken from an area of regression. The presence of amyloid deposition was incidentally detected during routine histopathological examination. (H&E; x200 magnification).

Histopathology from Case 4, a 64-year-old man with bowenoid papulosis, showing bowenoid histopathology and eosinophilic substance accumulation filling the dermal papillae. A punch biopsy from a hyperpigmented flat plaque revealed these features. Staining: Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). Magnification: x200.

Histopathology from Case 5, a 66-year-old man with bowenoid papulosis, showing atypical keratinocytes, mitoses, and apoptotic cells in the epidermis, along with eosinophilic material in the papillary dermis. An excisional biopsy of a papular lesion, from multiple clustered hyperpigmented dome-shaped papules, revealed these features. Staining: Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). Magnification: x200.

Histopathology showing melanoma in situ (MIS) with regression. The image displays neoplastic melanocytes located at the dermoepidermal junction. Below the epithelium, there are features indicative of regression, including fibrosis, a lymphocytic infiltrate, some clustering melanophages, and neoangiogenesis phenomena. The histopathological evaluation of MIS can be very challenging, even for highly experienced pathologists, and ancillary techniques such as immunohistochemistry (IHC) using markers like Melan-A, HMB-45, SOX-10, and PRAME are often useful in the differential diagnosis between severe dysplastic nevus and MIS. (Hematoxylin–eosin stain, original magnification 4×).

Histopathological evaluation of Melanoma In Situ (MIS) showing the presence of lymphocytic infiltrate, clusters of melanophages, lamellar fibroplasia, and neoangiogenesis. Notably, there is no visible invasive component of neoplastic cells. The histopathological evaluation of MIS can be very challenging, often requiring ancillary techniques such as immunohistochemistry (IHC) with markers like Melan-A, HMB-45, SOX-10, and PRAME to aid in the differential diagnosis between severe dysplastic nevus and MIS. The image is stained with hematoxylin–eosin (H&E) and viewed at an original magnification of 10×.

Histopathology of nodular melanoma, with a 1.47 mm Breslow index and a vertical growth phase. The image displays a densely cellular melanocytic tumor, consisting of round/oval cells and rare, elongated, bulky cells. Tumor cells present pleiomorphic, atypical, hyperchromatic nuclei, with rare mitoses and brown pigment within the cytoplasm. These cells are organized in nests at the dermo-epidermal junction or in islands within the dermis. Predominantly, lymphocytic infiltrates are present, and the lesion exhibits positive regression. Ulceration, lymphovascular, and perineural invasion were noted to be absent in the pathology report. The melanoma diagnosis was further confirmed by immunohistochemistry. Stained with Hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification: ×100.

Histopathology showing the tumor composed of hypercellular sheets, nests, and spindled cells after formalin fixation (H&E, ×100 magnification). The tumor cells display prominent nucleoli and a moderate amount of eosinophilic cytoplasm, and are associated with many melanic deposits.

Histopathology showing many melanic deposits observed (arrow) within the tumor, which is composed of hypercellular sheets, nests, and spindled cells after formalin fixation (H&E, ×100 magnification). The tumor cells also exhibit prominent nucleoli and a moderate amount of eosinophilic cytoplasm.

Histopathology at high magnification (H&E, ×400 magnification) showing tumor cells with enlarged oval-shaped nuclei and prominent nucleoli. The tumor cells also have a moderate amount of eosinophilic cytoplasm, without significant nuclear pleomorphism or numerous atypical mitoses.

Histopathology showing foci of necrosis (arrow) within the tumor (H&E, ×200 magnification). While foci of tumor necrosis were noted, significant nuclear pleomorphism or numerous atypical mitoses were not observed.
Histopathology of a tumor section showing sheets of clear cells with numerous branching capillaries between the tumor cells (hematoxylin and eosin stain, original magnification ×100).
Higher magnification image showing cellular atypia and atypical mitotic figures. This image was stained with hematoxylin and eosin (×400 magnification).

Histopathology of an ocular tumor showing differentiation. Differentiation is a pathological tissue image feature used to distinguish between benign and malignant ocular tumors. This feature was identified as an independent influencing factor in the diagnostic and differential diagnosis of ocular masses, with its presence or absence contributing to the characterization of the tumor's property. Image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at 200x magnification.

Histopathology of an ocular tumor showing structural atypia. Structural atypia is a pathological tissue image feature that helps differentiate between benign and malignant ocular tumors. This feature, characterized by organized or disorderly growth, was identified as an independent influencing factor in the diagnostic and differential diagnosis of ocular masses. Image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at 100x magnification.

Histopathology of an ocular tumor showing covering epithelium. The presence or absence of covering epithelium is a pathological tissue image feature used to distinguish between benign and malignant ocular tumors. This feature was identified as an independent influencing factor in the diagnostic and differential diagnosis of ocular masses. Image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at 40x magnification.

Histopathology of an ocular tumor showing keratosis. Keratosis is a pathological tissue image feature that aids in differentiating the properties of ocular tumor lesions, distinguishing between benign and malignant types. Its presence or absence contributes to the diagnostic evaluation of ocular tumors. Image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at 100x magnification.

Histopathology of an ocular tumor showing nest structure/distribution. The pattern of nest structure and distribution is a pathological tissue image feature utilized to distinguish between benign and malignant ocular tumors. This feature contributes to the diagnostic assessment of ocular tumor lesions. Image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at 100x magnification.

Histopathology of an ocular tumor showing nuclear atypia. Nuclear atypia is a significant pathological tissue image feature used for differentiating between benign and malignant ocular tumors. This characteristic was identified as an independent influencing factor in the diagnostic and differential diagnosis of ocular masses. Image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at 100x magnification.

Histopathology of an ocular tumor showing cytoplasmic change. Cytoplasmic change is a pathological tissue image feature that helps in differentiating the properties of ocular tumor lesions, distinguishing between benign and malignant types. This feature contributes to the diagnostic evaluation of ocular tumors. Image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at 100x magnification.

Histopathology of an ocular tumor showing nuclear division. Nuclear division, indicative of mitotic activity, is a critical pathological tissue image feature for differentiating between benign and malignant ocular tumors. This characteristic was identified as an independent influencing factor in the diagnostic and differential diagnosis of ocular masses. Image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at 200x magnification.
Histopathological findings showing the dermis expanded by a cellular substitution arranged in nests and cords. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, x 2 magnification.
Histopathological findings showing cells with nevic appearance and epithelioid morphology. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, x 40 magnification.
Histopathological findings showing on the base a focus with nests of a conventional nevus. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, x 20 magnification.

Histopathology illustrating the various morphologic appearances of neoplastic cells in anorectal melanoma. Panel A shows epithelioid melanoma cells characterized by roundish nuclei and wide eosinophilic cytoplasm. Epithelioid cells, either alone or in combination with other cell types, were a common finding in the systematically reviewed cases of anorectal melanoma in this study. The tumors frequently presented as polypoid (73%) and most (67%) demonstrated pigmentation. The mean tumor thickness across cases was 10.4 mm, and ulceration was observed in 80% of cases. (Hematoxylin & Eosin, x400 magnification).

Histopathology illustrating the various morphologic appearances of neoplastic cells in anorectal melanoma. Panel B displays lymphoma-like small neoplastic cells, which are admixed in a fibrous stroma and show crush artifact. Lymphoma-like cell types, either alone or combined with other morphologies, were observed in a notable percentage of the anorectal melanoma cases reviewed in this study. The tumors frequently presented as polypoid (73%) and most (67%) demonstrated pigmentation. The mean tumor thickness across cases was 10.4 mm, and ulceration was observed in 80% of cases. (Hematoxylin & Eosin, x400 magnification).

Histopathology illustrating the various morphologic appearances of neoplastic cells in anorectal melanoma. Panel C shows pleomorphic melanoma cells with huge, bizarre nuclei and prominent cytoplasm. Pleomorphic cell types, often in conjunction with epithelioid cells, were present in a subset of the anorectal melanoma cases reviewed in this study. The tumors frequently presented as polypoid (73%) and most (67%) demonstrated pigmentation. The mean tumor thickness across cases was 10.4 mm, and ulceration was observed in 80% of cases. (Hematoxylin & Eosin, x400 magnification).

Histopathology illustrating the various morphologic appearances of neoplastic cells in anorectal melanoma. Panel D shows spindle cells, characterized by elongated nuclei and sparse cytoplasm. Spindle cell types, either alone or in combination with other cell types, were a frequent finding in the systematically reviewed cases of anorectal melanoma in this study. The tumors frequently presented as polypoid (73%) and most (67%) demonstrated pigmentation. The mean tumor thickness across cases was 10.4 mm, and ulceration was observed in 80% of cases. (Hematoxylin & Eosin, x400 magnification).

Histopathology showing anorectal melanoma cells. This specific example demonstrates an amelanotic subtype, lacking melanin pigment, which accounted for 33% of the melanoma cases reviewed in the study. The image is stained with Hematoxylin&Eosin at x200 magnification.

Histopathology showing melanoma in situ, characterized by atypical melanocytes displaying continuous growth at the basal layer. In situ melanoma was detected in 33% of the cases reviewed in the study. The image is stained with Hematoxylin&Eosin at x400 magnification.
Histopathology showing nests of eosinophilic cells in the epidermis and basophilic area with high cell density in the dermis (H&E, ×12.5).
Histopathology showing nests of atypical keratinocytes in the epidermis (H&E, ×100).
Histopathology showing atypical spindle cells infiltrating the dermis in a storiform pattern (H&E, ×200).
Histopathology showing epidermal atrophy and dermal collagen thickening (H&E, ×40).
Histopathology showing atypical stellate fibroblasts in dermis (H&E, ×400).
Histopathology showing nests of melanocytes in subcutaneous fat tissue (H&E, ×40).
Photomicrograph showing unremarkable overlying stratified squamous epithelium with the presence of a tumor mass in the subepithelium. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), magnification ×40.

Photomicrograph showing the tumor mass arranged in diffuse sheets composed of epithelioid to spindle cells. No junctional activity was noted. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), magnification ×100.

Photomicrograph showing tumor cells displaying moderate nuclear pleomorphism, large prominent nucleoli, and moderate cytoplasm. Atypical mitosis was noted. Neither pigmentation nor squamous differentiation was seen. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), magnification ×400.

Histopathological examination, low magnification image, showing a diffuse infiltrative pattern of loose tumor mass in the deep dermis and subcutaneous fat along with scattered pigmented cells in the mid-upper dermis. (Hematoxylin-eosin stain; original magnification: ×10.)

Histopathological examination, medium magnification image, showing the junction of two lesions, where pigmented dendritic cells are scattered on the top and loose spindle cells are in a vortex growth pattern on the bottom. (Hematoxylin-eosin stain; original magnification: ×50.)

Histopathological examination, medium magnification image, showing the junction of two lesions, where pigmented dendritic cells are scattered on the top and loose spindle cells are in a vortex growth pattern on the bottom. (Hematoxylin-eosin stain; original magnification: ×100.)
Histopathological examination, high magnification image, showing pigmented, elongated, dendritic cells scattered among the collagen bundles. (Hematoxylin-eosin stain; original magnification: ×200.)

Histopathological examination, high magnification image, showing loose spindle cells with wavy nuclei in rich stromal components, with visible mast cells. (Hematoxylin-eosin stain; original magnification: ×200.)

Histopathology of invasive rectal melanoma arising in the rectal mucosa of a 60-year-old woman, showing eroded-rectal mucosa occupied by sheets of epithelioid, pleomorphic malignant cells growing in a solid pattern (H&E, 4X magnification). The tumor is typically composed of sheets or expansive nodules of large pleomorphic epithelioid cells.

High magnification histopathology of invasive rectal melanoma arising in the rectal mucosa of a 60-year-old woman. The lamina propria contains mucosal melanoma cells exhibiting a high nucleus-to-cytoplasm ratio, hyperchromatic nuclei, and prominent nucleoli (H&E, 40X magnification). The nuclei often have vesicular chromatin and prominent nucleoli.

Histopathology of the blue-greyish macule, revealing normal epidermis and scattered spindle cells containing melanin among collagen bundles in the dermis. These findings are consistent with the diagnosis of Acquired Dermal Melanocytosis (ADM). The image is stained with hematoxylin-eosin; original magnification ×200.

Histopathology of the black nodule showing an intradermal proliferation of pigmented dendritic melanocytes within a fibrotic stroma. The image reveals no features suggestive of malignancy, such as cytological or nuclear atypia, or mitotic activity. These findings are consistent with the diagnosis of common Blue Nevus (BN). (Hematoxylin-eosin stain; original magnification ×20).
Morphological aspects of a Tumor immunotype A, showing rare peri- and intratumoral inflammatory cells. The section is stained with hematoxylin-eosin. Original magnification 20×.

Morphological aspects of Tumor immunotype B, stained with hematoxylin-eosin. Immunotype B tumors exhibit predominantly perivascular and/or peritumoral stromal inflammatory infiltrate, with increased amounts of plasma cells and macrophages also observed. Observed at 20× magnification.

High-magnification histopathology image (H&E, 400x magnification) showing heavily pigmented tumor cells. These cells exhibit abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, vesicular nuclei, and prominent nucleoli. No cellular atypia or mitotic figures were observed, which are key features in the histopathological examination for diagnosing Pigmented Epithelioid Melanocytoma (PEM).

Histopathology image (H&E, 100x magnification) demonstrating the tumor cells extending from the superficial dermis into the subcutaneous fat, reaching the deep resected margin. This extent of invasion was noted during the histopathological examination for the diagnosis of Pigmented Epithelioid Melanocytoma (PEM).

High-magnification histopathology image (400x magnification) of melanin-bleached tissue, allowing clearer visualization of cell morphology under H&E staining. This image supports the observation of tumor cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, vesicular nuclei, and prominent nucleoli, which are characteristic features in the diagnosis of Pigmented Epithelioid Melanocytoma (PEM).

Histopathologic appearance of acral lentiginous melanoma in situ, specifically showing the normal appearance of palmar acral skin at low power. Stained with hematoxylin-eosin at 40× original magnification.
Histopathologic appearance of acral lentiginous melanoma in situ, showing increased single unit atypical melanocytes. Stained with hematoxylin-eosin at 400× original magnification.

Histopathologic appearance of acral lentiginous melanoma in situ, showing increased single unit atypical melanocytes with 3 mitoses in a high-power field. Stained with hematoxylin-eosin at 400× original magnification.
Microscopic examination of a Hematoxylin and Eosin stained nail bed biopsy from a subungual amelanotic melanoma shows nests of malignant tumor cells that fill the dermis. Original magnification ×200.
Microscopic examination of a Hematoxylin and Eosin stained nail bed biopsy from a subungual amelanotic melanoma shows nests of malignant tumor cells that fill the dermis. Original magnification ×400.

Histopathological photomicrograph stained with hematoxylin-eosin, showing an exophytic, extensively ulcerated neoplastic lesion diffusely infiltrating the superficial and deep dermis and associated with abundant necrosis. The tumor is constituted by two phenotypically distinct populations, intimately intermingled together and almost blending into each other at several points. Original magnification 4×, scale bar 1 mm.

Higher magnification histopathological photomicrograph stained with hematoxylin-eosin, showing the two distinct components of the neoplastic lesion. The melanocytic component consists of epithelioid, to a lesser extent spindle-shaped, melanocytes with markedly atypical nuclei, prominent nucleoli, eosinophilic cytoplasm, and significant melanin pigment deposition. The squamous component is made up of atypical squamous cells distributed in nests and cords, exhibiting true keratinization, dyskeratinocytes, and horny pearl formation, with focal clear cell changes. Both populations show brisk mitotic activity. Original magnification 10×, scale bar 250 µm.

Histopathological photomicrograph stained with hematoxylin-eosin, showing the neoplastic population composed of sheets of melanoma cells intermingled with islands of squamous cells. The melanoma cells are epithelioid to spindle-shaped, with markedly atypical nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and eosinophilic cytoplasm. The squamous cells are atypical and show central horn pearl formations, true keratinization, dyskeratinocytes, and focal clear cell changes. Significant melanin pigment deposition is observed throughout the lesion, and brisk mitotic activity is present in both components. Original magnification 10×, scale bar 250 µm.

Histopathological photomicrograph stained with hematoxylin-eosin, showing the neoplastic population composed of sheets of melanoma cells intermingled with islands of squamous cells. The melanoma cells are epithelioid to spindle-shaped, with markedly atypical nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and eosinophilic cytoplasm. The squamous cells are atypical and show central horn pearl formations, true keratinization, dyskeratinocytes, and focal clear cell changes. Significant melanin pigment deposition is observed throughout the lesion, and brisk mitotic activity is present in both components. Original magnification 10×, scale bar 250 µm.

Histopathology (H&E, x10 magnification) showing spindle cell proliferation, consistent with a peripheral nerve sheath tumor, originating in the reticular dermis and invading the hypodermis. The cells exhibit elongated, hyperchromatic nuclei, mild to moderate cytonuclear atypia, and scant eosinophilic cytoplasm. These cells are separated by thickened bands of collagen, with focal desmoplastic reaction.

Histopathology (H&E, x20 magnification) showing spindle cell proliferation, consistent with a peripheral nerve sheath tumor, originating in the reticular dermis and invading the hypodermis. The cells exhibit elongated, hyperchromatic nuclei, mild to moderate cytonuclear atypia, and scant eosinophilic cytoplasm. These cells are separated by thickened bands of collagen, with focal desmoplastic reaction. This panel provides a higher magnification view of the features described for panel A.
Histopathology showing a tumor mass consisting of a diffuse proliferation of neoplastic cells with dense melanin pigment deposition. H&E stain; 40× magnification.
Histopathology showing infiltrative tumor cells among the brain tissue. H&E stain; 100× magnification.

Histopathology showing tumor cells exhibiting round to oval, polygonal to spindle morphology, with partially extensive eosinophilic cytoplasm, an increased nuclear-to-cytoplasmic (N/C) ratio, and pleomorphic nuclei. H&E stain; 200× magnification.

Skin biopsy (10× magnification) stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin revealing epidermal malignant epithelial neoplasia. Tumor cells, which are large with abundant clear/pale cytoplasm, pleomorphic nuclei, and prominent nucleoli, are observed. These cells are arranged in small nests and isolated forms across all levels of the epidermis, exhibiting pagetoid migration. Histological sections also revealed dermal invasion by individual cells and glandular structures.

Dermal proliferation of large and atypical, some epithelioid cells, with hyperchromatic nuclei, and few scattered mitotic figures, some in cords and strands insinuating between collagen bundles (Hematoxylin-eosin stain; original magnification: ×20).

Histopathology of pigmented mammary Paget disease from a 52-year-old female presenting with an asymptomatic brown-black plaque on the left nipple. The image shows an intraepidermal pagetoid proliferation of large neoplastic cells, forming nests and cords. These neoplastic cells are interspersed with melanophages in the dermis. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification ×100. The punch biopsy revealed large neoplastic epithelial cells with pigmentation, exhibiting a pagetoid arrangement involving all epidermal layers, and infiltration of the dermis by cells forming nests and cords interspersed with melanophages, accompanied by mild inflammatory cell infiltration.

Higher magnification histopathology of pigmented mammary Paget disease from a 52-year-old female presenting with an asymptomatic brown-black plaque on the left nipple. The image shows tumor cells with enlarged nuclei and pale cytoplasm, some harboring granular brown melanin pigment. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification ×400. This is consistent with the histological features of pigmented mammary Paget disease, which involves large neoplastic epithelial cells with pigmentation.

Histopathology (H&E, ×20 magnification) from a 28-year-old man presenting with a superficial spreading invasive melanoma. The image shows atypical melanocytes arranged in irregular nests and single units within the epidermis, along with sheets of atypical melanocytes infiltrating the dermis. These features are accompanied by a prominent lymphohistiocytic infiltrate, consistent with the diagnosis of a superficial spreading invasive melanoma.

High-magnification histopathology (H&E, ×200 magnification) from a 28-year-old man diagnosed with superficial spreading invasive melanoma. This view shows atypical melanocytes present in irregular nests and as single units extending throughout all layers of the epidermis.

Histopathology (H&E, ×20 magnification) from a 28-year-old man presenting with a superficial spreading invasive melanoma. The image displays atypical melanocytes in irregular nests and single units within the epidermis and in sheets within the dermis, accompanied by a lymphohistiocytic infiltrate. Interestingly, a hair follicle with sebaceous glands (red arrow) is present in the upper part of the reticular dermis, representing hyperplastic sebaceous glands that were almost attached to the epidermis.

Histopathology showing moderate to severe dysplasia (KIN II–III) in an actinic keratosis (AK). In the study cohort, moderate dysplasia (KIN II) was the most common, accounting for 41.4% of cases, while severe dysplasia (KIN III) was present in 24.1% of cases. These findings highlight a significant proportion of lesions exhibiting moderate to advanced histopathological changes, emphasizing the importance of early recognition and appropriate management to prevent malignant progression. KIN grades, including KIN II and KIN III, showed significant associations with factors such as sex, cytonuclear pleomorphism, solar elastosis, and peritumoral inflammatory cell infiltrate severity. Magnification ×200; hematoxylin–eosin stain.

Histopathology showing severe dysplasia (KIN III) in an actinic keratosis (AK). In the study cohort, severe dysplasia (KIN III) was identified in 14 cases (24.1%) and predominantly affected male patients (78.6%). This grade of dysplasia was also more prevalent in the age group 70–79 years (42.9%). The presence of severe histopathological changes underscores the importance of early recognition and appropriate management of AK to prevent malignant progression. KIN grades, including KIN III, showed significant associations with factors such as sex, cytonuclear pleomorphism, solar elastosis, and peritumoral inflammatory cell infiltrate severity. Magnification ×200; hematoxylin–eosin stain.

Histopathological aspects of Actinic Keratosis (AK) with KIN I–II, representing mild to moderate dysplasia. The image, stained with hematoxylin–eosin at ×100 magnification, illustrates features characteristic of these grades of dysplasia. In the studied cohort, mild dysplasia (KIN I) accounted for 34.5% of cases and moderate dysplasia (KIN II) accounted for 41.4%. Such lesions are critical for early recognition and appropriate management to prevent malignant progression, often exhibiting cytonuclear pleomorphism, solar elastosis, and varying severity of peritumoral inflammatory cell infiltrate. Demographically, KIN I was more prevalent in patients aged 70–79 years and predominantly affected males (60%), while KIN II primarily affected patients between 80–89 years and predominantly affected females (62.5%).

Histopathological aspects of Actinic Keratosis (AK) with KIN III, representing severe dysplasia. The image, stained with hematoxylin–eosin at ×100 magnification, illustrates features characteristic of this grade of dysplasia. In the studied cohort, severe dysplasia (KIN III) accounted for 24.1% of cases. Early recognition and appropriate management of AKs, including severe forms like KIN III, are crucial to prevent malignant progression. These lesions often exhibit pronounced cytonuclear pleomorphism, solar elastosis, and varying severity of peritumoral inflammatory cell infiltrate. KIN III was found to be more prevalent in patients aged 70–79 years (42.9%) and predominantly affected male patients (78.6%).

High-power magnification of a mucosal fragment from a 49-year-old female patient presenting with a lesion on the upper adherent gingiva. The image shows a very thin squamous epithelium and a cyst in the subepithelial connective tissue covered by a cubic, stratified epithelium measuring 0.66 mm in size, leading to the diagnosis of gingival cyst (H&E, X10 magnification).

Histopathology of a mucosal fragment from a 49-year-old female patient who presented with a small, 3 mm, bluish nodular lesion on the upper adherent gingiva. Low-power magnification (X2) shows a gingival cyst located in the lamina propria (subepithelial connective tissue). The cyst, measuring 0.66 mm, is covered by a cubic, stratified epithelium, leading to a final diagnosis of gingival cyst. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Histopathology showing epidermis and dermis, with a tumor arising from the epidermis and growing down into the dermis in broad anastomosing fronds. Focal pigment is visible within the tumor. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification ×2.

Histopathology showing epidermis and dermis, with a tumor arising from the epidermis and growing down into the dermis in broad anastomosing fronds. Focal pigment is visible within the tumor. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification ×2.

Higher magnification histopathology showing the tumor, which is composed of poroma cells. These cells are monomorphic, small, and cuboidal, featuring basophilic nuclei, inconspicuous nucleoli, and compact eosinophilic cytoplasm. Focal areas of pigmentation are also present. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification ×10.

A histological section (Hematoxylin & eosin, ×40 magnification) shows the primary melanoma in vertical growth. The vertical growth phase is a characteristic feature of melanoma, and while the growth phase itself has been losing value as a mandatory reporting parameter in recent years, the overall histological type of melanoma is still crucial for assessment. This primary tumor is integral for determining key staging parameters such as the Breslow index (maximum tumor thickness) and the presence or absence of ulceration.

A histological section (Hematoxylin & eosin, ×40 magnification) shows a melanoma microsatellite in the dermis. This microsatellite is characterized by discontinuous tumor proliferation, located adjacent to the main tumor and permeated by normal tissue, without findings of inflammatory infiltrate or fibrosis that could suggest tumor regression. The presence or absence of satellitosis, which includes microsatellites, is a mandatory parameter that must be included in melanoma excision reports according to current international recommendations.

Histological section (Hematoxylin & eosin ×40) showing melanoma, characterized by nests of atypical melanocytic cells without signs of maturation and exhibiting moderate nuclear pleomorphism. This represents the primary tumor component in cases where melanoma is associated with an intradermal melanocytic nevus. The histological type and features like cellular atypia and pleomorphism are crucial for assessing parameters such as the Breslow index and mitotic index, which are mandatory for melanoma excision reports and anatomopathological staging, following current international recommendations.

Histological section (Hematoxylin & eosin ×40) showing an intradermal melanocytic nevus, associated with the melanoma shown in panel A. Small melanocytic cells can be observed, scattered throughout the dermis, exhibiting scarce cytoplasm and no cytological atypia. The presence of an associated nevus, as depicted here, is an important parameter that should be included in melanoma excision reports, as per current international recommendations which also detail other critical staging parameters like the Breslow index and presence of ulceration.

Panoramic view of an intradermal melanocytic nevus, removed for aesthetic purposes from a 14-year-old female patient. This case exemplifies the critical importance of anatomical-clinical correlation in diagnosis, as the interpretation of microscopic findings can be significantly influenced by the patient's age. The image is stained with Hematoxylin & eosin at ×40 magnification.

Histopathology of an intradermal melanocytic nevus, showing melanocytes arranged in nests with maturation to depth. This lesion was removed for aesthetic purposes from a 14-year-old female patient. Maturation to depth is a key feature indicating a benign melanocytic lesion, which is particularly relevant in pediatric patients where microscopic findings are carefully correlated with age for accurate diagnosis. The image is stained with Hematoxylin & eosin at ×100 magnification.

Histopathology of an intradermal melanocytic nevus, demonstrating no signs of atypia within the melanocytes. This finding supports the benign diagnosis of the lesion, which was removed for aesthetic purposes from a 14-year-old female patient. The absence of atypia, combined with the patient's age and clinical presentation, reinforces the importance of anatomical-clinical correlation in dermatopathology. The image is stained with Hematoxylin & eosin at ×200 magnification.

High magnification view showing the presence of atypical deep mitosis in the center of an intradermal melanocytic nevus. Despite this atypical finding, the overall diagnosis remains benign for this lesion, which was removed for aesthetic purposes from a 14-year-old female patient. This highlights the crucial role of anatomical-clinical correlation, especially in pediatric cases where certain microscopic features that might be concerning in an adult may not alter the benign diagnosis when correlated with the patient's age and clinical context. The image is stained with Hematoxylin & eosin at ×1000 magnification.

Panoramic image of a traumatized nevus located on the thigh of a 44-year-old female patient. The image shows the remaining nevus on the left, with central fibrosis and a dermal inflammatory infiltrate including melanophages on the right. This case exemplifies the importance of clinical-pathological correlation, as the patient's age (44 years old) and location of the lesion (thigh) are critical data points for interpreting microscopic findings, especially in the context of reported trauma to the lesion. The image is stained with Hematoxylin & eosin at ×40 magnification.

Detailed view of the remaining intradermal nevus and the fibrosis, which runs parallel to the direction of the epidermis. This image provides a higher magnification of features seen in the traumatized nevus from a 44-year-old female patient's thigh. The presence of fibrosis is consistent with a traumatized melanocytic lesion, highlighting the need for comprehensive clinical correlation, including patient age, lesion location, and any history of trauma, which can influence microscopic interpretation. The image is stained with Hematoxylin & eosin at ×200 magnification.

Detailed view of the inflammatory infiltrate, which includes melanophages. This image provides a higher magnification of features seen in the traumatized nevus from a 44-year-old female patient's thigh. An inflammatory infiltrate with melanophages is a common finding in traumatized melanocytic lesions, reinforcing the need for clinical-pathological correlation, where the clinical history of trauma helps in the accurate interpretation of these microscopic features. The image is stained with Hematoxylin & eosin at ×200 magnification.

Presence of atypical proliferated junctional melanocytes, a common finding in traumatized melanocytic lesions. This feature is observed in the context of a traumatized nevus from a 44-year-old female patient's thigh. The occurrence of trauma is a crucial piece of clinical information, as it can lead to microscopic changes like atypical junctional melanocytes that might simulate malignancy but are benign in the context of trauma. Such findings underscore the necessity of integrating clinical history (e.g., occurrence of trauma) with microscopic examination for accurate diagnosis. The image is stained with Hematoxylin & eosin at ×400 magnification.

Histopathological section from the excised parotid gland lesion, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 20× magnification. The image shows spindle-shaped malignant cells, consistent with spindle cell melanoma. Microscopic analysis further revealed nuclear pleomorphism and prominent nucleoli, characteristic features of the malignant neoplasm.

Histopathologic findings of cutaneous melanoma from an individual with a germline variant in POT1 (p.His226Asn). Low magnification shows spitzoid melanoma with epidermal and dermal nests, growing adjacent to a nevus, marked by the arrows. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification: X4.

Histopathologic findings of cutaneous melanoma from an individual with a germline variant in POT1 (p.His226Asn). The image shows spitzoid morphology consisting of atypical enlarged epithelioid melanocytes with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm. Some of the melanocytes are slightly pigmented. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification: X20.

Histopathologic findings of cutaneous melanoma from an individual with a germline variant in POT1 (p.His226Asn). The image displays superficial spreading melanoma with spitzoid features. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification: X4.

Histopathologic findings of cutaneous melanoma from an individual with a germline variant in POT1 (p.His226Asn). The image shows nests of enlarged spitzoid melanocytes including scattered multinucleated cells embedded in fibrosis. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, original magnification: X20.

Histopathology showing malignant melanoma with disorganized tissue architecture, neoplastic cells exhibiting enlarged, irregular nuclei, frequent mitotic figures, and uneven distribution, stained with Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at ×400 magnification.

Initial skin biopsy from the abdomen demonstrating a lymphocytic infiltrate in the upper dermis, basal cell vacuolar changes, prominent pigment incontinence with melanophages in the upper dermis, and atypical lymphocytes in the epidermis. The lymphocytic infiltrate obscures the dermoepidermal junction and includes migration of lymphocytes into the epidermis, raising suspicion of cutaneous lymphoma. (H&E, x200).

Initial skin biopsy from the abdomen demonstrating a lymphocytic infiltrate in the upper dermis, basal cell vacuolar changes, prominent pigment incontinence with melanophages in the upper dermis, and atypical lymphocytes in the epidermis. The lymphocytic infiltrate obscures the dermoepidermal junction and includes migration of lymphocytes into the epidermis, raising suspicion of cutaneous lymphoma. (H&E, x200).

Histopathology showing atypical lymphocytes aligned along the basal layer, perivascular spaces with melanophages in the dermis, and lymphocytes migrated into the epidermis with larger hyperchromatic nuclei. This abnormal lymphocyte migration into the epidermis contributes to the dermatopathological examination findings, raising suspicion of cutaneous lymphoma. (H&E, x200).

Histopathology showing atypical lymphocytes aligned along the basal layer, perivascular spaces with melanophages in the dermis, and lymphocytes migrated into the epidermis with larger hyperchromatic nuclei. This abnormal lymphocyte migration into the epidermis contributes to the dermatopathological examination findings, raising suspicion of cutaneous lymphoma. (H&E, x200).

Histopathological examination of skin lesions in a patient with generalized BD. This panel shows a Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) stain at ×20 magnification. The histopathological analysis revealed epidermal irregular hyperplasia and hyperkeratosis, along with hypertrophy of the spinous layer. The epidermal cells exhibited disorganization and variation in size, with heterogeneity evident and visible karyorrhexis. The basal cell layer remained intact, while inflammatory cells were observed infiltrating the dermis.

Histopathological examination of skin lesions in a patient with generalized BD. This panel shows a Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) stain at ×200 magnification. The histopathological analysis revealed epidermal irregular hyperplasia and hyperkeratosis, along with hypertrophy of the spinous layer. The epidermal cells exhibited disorganization and variation in size, with heterogeneity evident and visible karyorrhexis. The basal cell layer remained intact, while inflammatory cells were observed infiltrating the dermis.

Hematoxylin and eosin image showing marked solar elastosis with an overlying lentiginous proliferation of atypical melanocytes along the dermal-epidermal junction with areas of upward scatter, consistent with lentigo maligna.
Hematoxylin and eosin image following treatment showing no evidence of residual melanoma in situ.

Representative example of a breast carcinoma (×100 total magnification) exhibiting intratumoural desmoplastic stroma (IDS), corresponding to stroma Group 2. This Group 2 IDS demonstrates at least focally broader, greyish stroma on H&E, which in other organs or primary tumours corresponds to desmoplastic stroma, suggesting altered extracellular matrix. Typically grey-appearing areas in the broad stroma are highlighted by arrows.

Representative example of a breast carcinoma (×100 total magnification) exhibiting intratumoural desmoplastic stroma (IDS), corresponding to stroma Group 2. This Group 2 IDS demonstrates at least focally broader, greyish stroma on H&E, which in other organs or primary tumours corresponds to desmoplastic stroma, suggesting altered extracellular matrix. Typically grey-appearing areas in the broad stroma are highlighted by arrows.

Representative example of a colorectal adenocarcinoma with a tubular growth pattern (×100 total magnification) exhibiting intratumoural desmoplastic stroma (IDS), corresponding to stroma Group 2. This Group 2 IDS demonstrates at least focally broader, greyish stroma on H&E, which in other organs or primary tumours corresponds to desmoplastic stroma, suggesting altered extracellular matrix. Typically grey-appearing areas in the broad stroma are highlighted by arrows.

Representative example of a pulmonary squamous cell carcinoma (×100 total magnification) exhibiting intratumoural desmoplastic stroma (IDS), corresponding to stroma Group 2. This Group 2 IDS demonstrates at least focally broader, greyish stroma on H&E, which in other organs or primary tumours corresponds to desmoplastic stroma, suggesting altered extracellular matrix. Typically grey-appearing areas in the broad stroma are highlighted by arrows.

Representative example of a pulmonary adenocarcinoma (×100 total magnification) exhibiting intratumoural desmoplastic stroma (IDS), corresponding to stroma Group 2. This Group 2 IDS demonstrates at least focally broader, greyish stroma on H&E, which in other organs or primary tumours corresponds to desmoplastic stroma, suggesting altered extracellular matrix. Typically grey-appearing areas in the broad stroma are highlighted by arrows.

Representative example of a pulmonary adenocarcinoma (×100 total magnification) exhibiting intratumoural desmoplastic stroma (IDS), corresponding to stroma Group 2. This Group 2 IDS demonstrates at least focally broader, greyish stroma on H&E, which in other organs or primary tumours corresponds to desmoplastic stroma, suggesting altered extracellular matrix. Typically grey-appearing areas in the broad stroma are highlighted by arrows.

Histopathology image stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) showing tertiary lymphoid structures (TLSs) in melanoma. These TLSs are characterized by lymphocyte aggregation, which is defined as containing 50 or more lymphocytes, and are indicated by blue arrows. This panel contributes to the overall characterization of TLS and the tumor microenvironment (TME).

Microscopical appearance of the pigmented lesion showing features of a combined malignant naevus (blue naevus + melanoma). The lesion is composed of a malignant melanoma, with superficial Clark's level III invasion, arising in association with a blue naevus in the deep dermis (Haematoxylin and Eosin, original magnification × 5).
Microscopical appearance of the combined malignant naevus, showing the invasion of the epidermis by the neoplastic melanocytes (Haematoxylin and Eosin, original magnification × 20).

Histopathology of melanoacanthoma, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E). The image reveals stratified squamous non-keratinized epithelium exhibiting acanthosis, spongiosis, melanin pigmentation, inflammatory cell exocytosis, and numerous dendritic melanocytes distributed diffusely throughout the entire thickness of the epithelium, specifically in the suprabasal and spinous layers. A chronic inflammatory cell infiltrate is present in the subjacent connective tissue.

Histopathology of melanoacanthoma, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E). The image reveals stratified squamous non-keratinized epithelium exhibiting acanthosis, spongiosis, melanin pigmentation, inflammatory cell exocytosis, and numerous dendritic melanocytes distributed diffusely throughout the entire thickness of the epithelium, specifically in the suprabasal and spinous layers. A chronic inflammatory cell infiltrate is present in the subjacent connective tissue.

Histopathology of melanoacanthoma, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E). The image reveals stratified squamous non-keratinized epithelium exhibiting acanthosis, spongiosis, melanin pigmentation, inflammatory cell exocytosis, and numerous dendritic melanocytes distributed diffusely throughout the entire thickness of the epithelium, specifically in the suprabasal and spinous layers. A chronic inflammatory cell infiltrate is present in the subjacent connective tissue.
Histopathological findings of the enucleated eyeball, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), viewed at ×20 magnification.
Histopathological findings under high magnification (H&E, ×40).

Histopathology (H&E stain, 400× magnification) showing an acanthotic, slightly verrucous epidermis comprising both basaloid and spinous cells. The basaloid cells form well-defined islands, and numerous melanocytes are scattered throughout the lesion, extending deep into the tumor mass instead of being restricted to the basal layer. There is no evidence of cellular atypia or pagetoid upward extension of tumor cells. These histopathological features are characteristic of melanoacanthoma, a variant of seborrheic keratosis, and help to exclude a diagnosis of pigmented seborrheic keratosis or malignant melanoma.

Histopathology of the primary and recurrent tumor, stained with hematoxylin and eosin, showing a solid mass with nests of cells exhibiting an epithelioid appearance and eosinophilic cytoplasm (original magnification, × 400). These histopathological findings, along with immunohistochemical results, supported the diagnosis of non-pigmented melanoma.

Histopathology showing a cystic invagination extending downward from the epidermis, which was diagnosed as a syringocystadenoma papilliferum. Image taken at ×40 magnification with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) staining.

Histopathology showing a parakeratotic column overlying a trichoblastoma-like lesion, resembling the cornoid lamella of porokeratosis. Image taken at ×40 magnification with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) staining.
Histopathology showing fat cells present in the upper dermis. Image taken at ×40 magnification with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) staining.

Histopathology of the yellow, verrucous plaque, diagnosed as a nevus sebaceous (NS). The epidermis shows hyperkeratosis, irregular acanthosis, and papillomatosis. In the dermis, incompletely differentiated hair structures are observed, which are typical features of nevus sebaceous. (Hematoxylin and eosin, ×12.5).

Histopathology of a biopsy taken from a lesion on the patient's right femoral area, which led to a diagnosis of post-CT eruptive compound nevus. The image displays nest structures composed of nevus cells with oval nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm, originating from the dermoepidermal junction and extending toward the lower dermis. Hematoxylin and eosin stain, original magnification ×40.

Histopathology at scanning magnification, stained with hematoxylin-eosin, showing a sporadic melanoma (M) arising within a nevus (N). This image illustrates the progression of a nevus to melanoma, which is associated with the loss of BAP1.

High-magnification histopathology of the nevus component, likely stained with hematoxylin-eosin, showing bland melanocytes characterized by monomorphous round and oval-shaped nuclei. The scale bar represents 50 μm. This image provides a detailed view of the nevus component, which, in the context of the study, exhibits conspicuous nuclear staining for BAP1 and a BRAF V600E mutation, but no BAP1 mutation or chromosomal aberrations.

High-magnification histopathology of the melanoma component, likely stained with hematoxylin-eosin, showing melanocytes with large vesicular nuclei and prominent nucleoli. The scale bar represents 50 μm. This image highlights the distinct morphology of the melanoma component, which, in the context of the study, shows a high proliferation rate by MIB-1 immunohistochemistry, absent nuclear staining for BAP1, a BRAF V600E mutation, focal loss of chromosome region 3p21 spanning the BAP1-locus, and a frameshift mutation of the second BAP1 allele.

Histopathology of a biopsy taken from a violaceous papule showing orthokeratotic hyperkeratosis, wedge-shaped hypergranulosis, acanthosis, saw-toothing of rete ridges, basal cell vacuolization, and a dense, band-like, inflammatory infiltrate in the upper dermis. These histopathological features are consistent with a diagnosis of Lichen Planus (LP). The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and captured at 40x objective magnification.
Histopathology showing a verrucous lesion extending mainly on the left side of both the soft and hard palate. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and captured at 200x magnification.
Histopathology of a lesion, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), demonstrating acanthosis and papillomatosis.

Histological examination of a frozen section specimen stained with hematoxylin-eosin (H&E), showing a lesion located under the enteric mucosa. The tumor cells are diffusely infiltrative without obvious mucosal destruction, as observed at 4x objective magnification. The tumor was part of a 2.5 cm × 1.5 cm × 1 cm specimen that appeared gray-red without pigment on cut surfaces.

Histological examination of a frozen section specimen stained with hematoxylin-eosin (H&E) at 40x objective magnification, showing the morphology of the tumor cells. The cells are round, oval, or polygonal epithelioid, exhibiting markedly cytologic atypia with large eosinophilic nucleoli, abundant mitotic figures, and moderate cytoplasm. There is no obviously visible melanin pigment in the cytoplasm. These features led pathologists to consult on a malignant tumor, prone to lymphoma or undifferentiated carcinoma.

A biopsy specimen from the right calf shows hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, and hyperpigmentation of the basal layer. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at ×100 magnification.

Histology performed on a biopsy specimen from a keratotic lesion on the sole reveals verruciform epidermal changes, characterized by marked hyperkeratosis, parakeratosis, and acanthosis. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at ×100 magnification.
Histopathology (H&E stain, ×40 magnification) showing a tumor consisting of broad anastomosing bands extending from the epidermis to the dermis.
Histopathology (H&E stain, ×100 magnification) showing small, irregular ductal lumina within the tumor.

Histopathology (H&E stain, ×400 magnification) at higher magnification, revealing that the tumor cells are connected by intercellular bridges and have a uniform small cuboidal appearance and a round, deeply basophilic nucleus.

Photomicrograph of cervical spinal meningeal melanocytoma from a 37-year-old man. After melanin bleaching, microscopic examination with H&E stain (× 400) reveals spindle cells with minimal cytologic atypia.

Photomicrograph of a surgical specimen of a leptomeningeal seeding mass from a 37-year-old man with cervical meningeal melanocytoma. Microscopic examination with H&E stain (× 400) shows that the mass is composed of histologically benign cells.

This photomicrograph, taken at 100× magnification, shows a simulated acantholytic bullous lesion from the primary origin ulcerated site, viewed in a scanner perspective. The tissue is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

This photomicrograph, taken at 200× magnification, exhibits neutrophilic and fibrinous exudate directed toward the ulcerated surface (indicated by an arrow). Tumor cell nests are visible deep within the reticular dermis. The tissue is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

This photomicrograph, taken at 100× magnification, shows the proliferation of single atypical pigmented melanocytes and nests (indicated by a black arrow) within the epidermal layers. An increase in dermal blood vessels, including proliferating new vessels, is also present in the dermis (indicated by a blue arrow). The tissue is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

This photomicrograph, taken at 100× magnification, displays a dense infiltration of melanoma cells, with pigment visible in some areas. Atypical cells have descended deep into the reticular dermis. The tissue is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Photomicrograph from a metastatic site, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 100× magnification. The image displays a circumscribed tumour nodule of hyperchromatic tumour cells located within the dermis, notably without any junctional activity (indicated by a green arrow). Additionally, a small tumour nest (marked by a blue arrow) and a perineural tumour focus (indicated by a black arrow) are visible in the upper dermis.

Histopathology image showing primary dermal melanoma. The tumor is composed of a dermal and subcutaneous nodule, which is surrounded by fibrous tissue. The image also demonstrates extensive central necrosis and hemorrhaging within the lesion. The tissue section is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at ×10 magnification.

Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) stained punch biopsy (20× magnification) from the left neck of a 62-year-old male, showing involvement by Hodgkin Lymphoma (HL). The patient had a history of nodular sclerosis classical Hodgkin lymphoma and presented with a pink crusted plaque on the left neck. The image reveals an atypical mixed dermal inflammatory infiltrate with scattered larger atypical multinucleated and mononuclear cells, involving the entire dermis. A distinct grenz zone, indicating sparing of the epidermis, is visible between the infiltrate and the overlying epidermis. The histological features are consistent with a mixed cellularity variant of cutaneous Hodgkin Lymphoma.

Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) stained punch biopsy (100× magnification) from the left neck of a 62-year-old male, showing involvement by Hodgkin Lymphoma (HL). The patient had a history of nodular sclerosis classical Hodgkin lymphoma and presented with a pink crusted plaque on the left neck. The image highlights an atypical mixed dermal inflammatory infiltrate with scattered larger atypical multinucleated and mononuclear cells, involving the entire dermis. A distinct grenz zone, indicating sparing of the epidermis, is visible between the infiltrate and the overlying epidermis. The histological features are consistent with a mixed cellularity variant of cutaneous Hodgkin Lymphoma.

Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) stained punch biopsy (higher magnification, 200× or 400×) from the left neck of a 62-year-old male, showing involvement by Hodgkin Lymphoma (HL). The patient had a history of nodular sclerosis classical Hodgkin lymphoma and presented with a pink crusted plaque on the left neck. The image details the mixed dermal inflammatory infiltrate, which is composed predominantly of small lymphocytes and abundant histiocytes in the background. Prominently featured are several large atypical cells, including binucleated forms with prominent nucleoli, hyperchromatic nuclei, vesicular smudged chromatin, and prominent cherry red nucleoli, compatible with classic Reed-Sternberg cells and their variants. Scattered neutrophils, along with other mixed inflammatory cells such as plasma cells and rare eosinophils, are also present within the infiltrate. Atypical mitoses can be easily detected, consistent with a mixed cellularity variant of cutaneous Hodgkin Lymphoma.

Histopathology of superficial spreading melanoma in situ. Transverse section stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) showing atypical melanocytes protruding into the dermal papillae forming bridges (black arrows).
Microscopic image (40x magnification, H&E stain) showing the presence of large numbers of lipid-laden foamy histiocytes that are confined to the connective tissue papillae.

Histopathology showing epithelial hyperplasia characterized by parakeratosis and elongated rete pegs. The image also displays an abundance of foam cells within the connective tissue papilla. The tissue section is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at 10x magnification.

Histopathology showing an aggregate of nevus cells observed within a lymphatic vessel of the upper dermis. The lymphatic vessel, unlike adjacent small blood vessels (indicated by black arrowheads) which contain red blood cells and have small, round lumina, contained proteinaceous fluid without red blood cells and showed a large lumen. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin; original magnification, ×100.

Histopathology showing the lymphatic nevus cell embolus demonstrating characteristic morphological features of type A nevus cells. These features include a round to cuboidal shape, well-defined cell borders, abundant cytoplasm, and nest formation. Additionally, the embolus was lined by flattened endothelial cells, which are identical to the endothelial cells lining the lymphatic lumen. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin; original magnification, ×400.

Histopathology showing a clear distinction in morphology between a true lymphatic vessel, indicated by the black arrow, and pseudovascular spaces formed by nevus cells, which are visible in the right half of the image. The lumina of these pseudovascular spaces anastomosed irregularly with each other and were lined by nevus cells characterized by cuboidal contours and round-to-oval nuclei, rather than by the vascular endothelial cells which have flattened nuclei and greatly attenuated cytoplasm. Furthermore, the nevus cells formed intraluminal papillary projections, and specific floating individual nevus cells were also present. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin; original magnification, ×200.
Scanning view of a resected specimen, showing a lesion measuring 1 cm in diameter and 0.3 cm in height. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin at ×12.5 magnification.

Histopathology showing lesional cells in the upper dermis presenting characteristic morphological features of type A nevus cells. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin at ×200 magnification.

Histopathology showing lesional cells in the middle dermis presenting characteristic morphological features of type B nevus cells. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin at ×200 magnification.

Histopathology showing lesional cells in the lower dermis presenting characteristic morphological features of type C nevus cells. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin at ×200 magnification.

Digital image of H&E stained skin, acquired using a Zeiss AxioImager II system with MOSAIC tiling facility at x10 magnification, showing Grade I histological damage. This image displays a slight vacuolisation of epidermal basal cells. The epidermis tissue, which is to be segmented, is outlined in green. The dimensions of such tiled images varied, with heights ranging from 1047 to 4819 pixels and widths from 2676 to 5254 pixels.

Digital image of H&E stained skin, acquired using a Zeiss AxioImager II system with MOSAIC tiling facility at x10 magnification, showing Grade II histological damage. This image displays more diffuse vacuolisation and the presence of dyskeratotic bodies. The epidermis tissue, which is to be segmented, is outlined in green. The dimensions of such tiled images varied, with heights ranging from 1047 to 4819 pixels and widths from 2676 to 5254 pixels.

Digital image of H&E stained skin, acquired using a Zeiss AxioImager II system with MOSAIC tiling facility at x10 magnification, showing Grade III histological damage. This image displays sub-epidermal cleft formation in addition to Grade II changes, which include more diffuse vacuolisation and dyskeratotic bodies. The epidermis tissue, which is to be segmented, is outlined in green. The dimensions of such tiled images varied, with heights ranging from 1047 to 4819 pixels and widths from 2676 to 5254 pixels.

Digital image of H&E stained skin, acquired using a Zeiss AxioImager II system with MOSAIC tiling facility at x10 magnification, showing Grade IV histological damage. This image displays complete epidermal separation. The epidermis tissue, which is to be segmented, is outlined in green. The dimensions of such tiled images varied, with heights ranging from 1047 to 4819 pixels and widths from 2676 to 5254 pixels.

A typical tiled x10 magnification RGB image of an H&E stained skin sample, generated by the Zeiss AxioImager II system using its MOSAIC tiling and stitching facilities. The image shows black regions around the edges, which are added to form a rectangle after the tiling and stitching process. These black pixels at the image edge are subsequently replaced with a background threshold intensity to create a consistent background. The dimensions of such tiled images varied, with heights ranging from 1047 to 4819 pixels and widths from 2676 to 5254 pixels.

Conventional hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) histology showing a case of superficial spreading melanoma arising within a benign dermal nevus. This image is presented to illustrate the histological features of such a lesion, which serves as a benchmark for assessing the utility of 5-hydroxymethylcytosine (5hmC) as a marker. The black arrow highlights the nevic nests, while the red arrow indicates the larger melanoma cells surrounded by inflammation. The study aims to apply 5hmC to differentiate the benign nevus component from the malignant melanocytic component within the same lesion, assisting in accurate measurement of Breslow depth, where benign nevus components are expected to show strong 5hmC staining and melanoma components a loss of 5hmC.

Representative histopathologic features of patient 4 showing lentiginous melanocytic proliferation along the elongated epidermal rete ridges and rete fusion at the lower tip, with concentric and lamellar fibrosis in the papillary dermis. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification ×100.
Representative histopathologic features of patient 4 showing random mild to moderate cytological atypia in the basal layer. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification ×400.

Scanning view of a section from patient 3 showing both melanoma (indicated by a thick arrow) and dysplastic nevi (DN, indicated by a thin arrow). Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification ×40.
Magnifying view of the malignant melanoma from patient 3. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification ×100.
Magnifying view of the dysplastic nevus (DN) from patient 3. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), original magnification ×100.

Histopathology of a polypoid superficial spreading melanoma from a 58-year-old patient's left lumbar region, showing the polypoid melanoma pedicle at its insertion area. The adjacent skin surface exhibits slight proliferation of typical and atypical melanocytes in the basal layer, representing the predominant in situ component, along with a lymphocytic inflammatory infiltrate in the superficial dermis. The overall lesion, which had been progressively growing and recently ulcerated, had a Breslow thickness of 4.3 mm at the polypoid area. (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, 40x magnification).

Histopathology of a polypoid superficial spreading melanoma from a 58-year-old patient's left lumbar region, showing proliferation of atypical melanocytic cells with severe atypia and a pagetoid appearance. This lesion, which had been progressively growing and recently ulcerated, had a Breslow thickness of 4.3 mm at the polypoid area and demonstrated 8 mitoses in 10 high power fields. (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, 400x magnification).

Histopathology of a polypoid superficial spreading melanoma from a 58-year-old patient's left lumbar region, depicting the top of the polypoid area. It shows the epidermis and dermis with proliferation of atypical melanocytes and areas of necrosis, which clinically corresponded to an ulcerated, erythematous, and friable polypoid formation of approximately 1 cm, covered by a serohematic crust. The overall lesion had a Breslow thickness of 4.3 mm at the polypoid area. (Hematoxylin and Eosin stain, 100x magnification).
Photomicrograph from histopathological studies shows a highly cellular lesion composed of clusters of atypical cells with prominent nucleoli and marked eosinophilic cytoplasm (H&E, ×400).

Microscopic findings demonstrating tumor cells spreading through the submucosal layer of the stomach with a clear resection margin. The tumor cells exhibit atypical hyperchromatic nuclei and melanin distribution within the tumor nest. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×20 magnification.

Microscopic findings demonstrating tumor cells spreading through the submucosal layer of the stomach with a clear resection margin. The tumor cells exhibit atypical hyperchromatic nuclei and melanin distribution within the tumor nest. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×200 magnification.
Histopathology showing a tumor nest with accompanying melanin distribution. The tumor cells exhibit atypical hyperchromatic nuclei. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at 400x magnification.
Histopathology of tumor cells demonstrating atypical hyperchromatic nuclei. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) and viewed at ×400 magnification.

Histopathology of an HRAS-mutated spitzoid tumor from a 47-year-old female patient. The lesion, located on the right lower arm and measuring 0.8 cm in diameter, was initially diagnosed as Spitzoid Tumor of Uncertain Malignant Potential (STUMP). This image, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at 25× magnification, shows the lesion to be symmetrical, wedge-shaped, and primarily dermal-located. It is characterized by epithelioid spitzoid-looking cells embedded in an eosinophilic hyalinized stroma. A count revealed 2 mitoses present per 1 mm², with an absence of deep mitoses. HRAS-mutated spitzoid melanocytic tumors, like this one, have sometimes been initially misdiagnosed as melanoma based on histology alone, especially in adults displaying frequent or deep mitotic activity, though they typically show a good prognosis with no recurrences or metastases over long-term follow-up.

High-magnification histopathology of an HRAS-mutated spitzoid tumor from a 47-year-old female patient. The lesion, located on the right lower arm and measuring 0.8 cm in diameter, was initially diagnosed as Spitzoid Tumor of Uncertain Malignant Potential (STUMP). This image, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at 400× magnification, provides a detailed view of the epithelioid spitzoid-looking cells within the eosinophilic hyalinized stroma. The overall lesion was symmetrical and wedge-shaped, primarily dermal-located. A count revealed 2 mitoses present per 1 mm², with an absence of deep mitoses. HRAS-mutated spitzoid melanocytic tumors, like this one, have sometimes been initially misdiagnosed as melanoma based on histology alone, especially in adults displaying frequent or deep mitotic activity, though they typically show a good prognosis with no recurrences or metastases over long-term follow-up.

Histopathology of an ALK-positive spitzoid tumor, diagnosed as spitzoid tumor of uncertain malignant potential (STUMP), from a 4-year-old girl. This is an ALK-positive Spitz tumor. The lesion was clinically polypoid and presented on the arm. Hematoxylin and eosin (HE) stain, overview magnification (25×).

Histopathology of an ALK-positive spitzoid tumor, diagnosed as spitzoid tumor of uncertain malignant potential (STUMP), from a 4-year-old girl. This is an ALK-positive Spitz tumor. The lesion was clinically polypoid and presented on the arm. Hematoxylin and eosin (HE) stain at higher magnification (200×) showing spindle-shaped cells and some lymphocytes intermingled within the tumor.

Histopathology of an ALK-positive spitzoid tumor, diagnosed as spitzoid tumor of uncertain malignant potential (STUMP), from a 4-year-old girl. This is an ALK-positive Spitz tumor. The lesion was clinically polypoid and presented on the arm. Hematoxylin and eosin (HE) stain at higher magnification (400×) showing spindle-shaped cells and some lymphocytes intermingled within the tumor.

Histopathology of the primary cutaneous superficial spreading melanoma from the back of a 36-year-old female patient. This patient presented 16 years later with a lung mass. This overview shows an asymmetrical melanocytic lesion. (Hematoxylin and eosin stain, 25× magnification)

High-magnification histopathology of the primary cutaneous superficial spreading melanoma from the back of a 36-year-old female patient. This patient presented 16 years later with a lung mass. This image shows clear atypia of melanocytes with loss of maturation and ascension into the epidermis. (Hematoxylin and eosin stain, 100× magnification)

Low-magnification histopathology (25x) of the lung lesion, found in a 36-year-old female patient 16 years after her primary cutaneous melanoma. The lung mass was initially thought to be a non-small cell lesion (possibly squamous cell carcinoma) based on fine needle aspiration, with negative melanoma markers (HMB45, MART) and weakly positive p63. Evaluation of the pneumonectomy specimen, however, led to a differential diagnosis with metastatic melanoma, as some features were consistent with melanocytic differentiation (weakly positive Vimentin, tyrosinase, and mitf). This image shows a nodular proliferation of atypical, partly plasmacytoid cells resembling the primary cutaneous melanoma. (Hematoxylin and eosin stain)

High-magnification histopathology (100x) of the lung lesion, found in a 36-year-old female patient 16 years after her primary cutaneous melanoma. This image shows a nodular proliferation of atypical, partly plasmacytoid cells resembling the primary cutaneous melanoma. (Hematoxylin and eosin stain)

Histopathology (H&E, 25×) of a BRAF-mutated MBAIT lesion located on the posterior side of the ear in a 55-year-old female, showing an overview of a nodular dermal-based lesion with lymphocytes at the lateral margin. No common nevus component was present in this case.

Histopathology (H&E, 200×) of a BRAF-mutated MBAIT lesion located on the posterior side of the ear in a 55-year-old female, demonstrating a higher magnification of the large epithelioid aspect of the cells within the nodular dermal-based lesion.

Histopathology showing an overview of a BRAF-mutated Melanocytic BAP1-inactivated Tumor (MBAIT) found in a 31-year-old female, located on the lower back. The hematoxylin and eosin (HE) stained image at 25x magnification depicts a polypoid lesion protruding above the skin surface.

Histopathology of the central part of a BRAF-mutated Melanocytic BAP1-inactivated Tumor (MBAIT) from a 31-year-old female. The hematoxylin and eosin (HE) stained image at 400x magnification reveals large epithelioid cells intermingled with lymphocytes. These large epithelioid cells have demonstrated positive BRAF protein expression and loss of BAP1 protein expression by immunohistochemistry.

Histopathology of the margin of a BRAF-mutated Melanocytic BAP1-inactivated Tumor (MBAIT) from a 31-year-old female. The hematoxylin and eosin (HE) stained image at 100x magnification shows features consistent with a common compound nevus.

Histopathology showing a trichofolliculoma, characterized by a central cyst with multiple radiating hair follicles. This finding was observed in 4 out of 21 studied cases and is a diagnostic feature for trichofolliculoma. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 100x magnification.
Histopathology showing a cartilaginous component within adipose tissue. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at 100x magnification.
Histopathology showing a cartilaginous component within adipose tissue. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at 200x magnification.
Histopathology showing numerous, tiny, mature hair follicles. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at 100x magnification.
