Histopathology showing mature hair follicles located within the subcutaneous fat. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at 100x magnification.
Histopathology of subcutaneous fat, showing the connective tissue framework. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at 100x magnification.

Histopathologic examination of a biopsy specimen, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), showing a plate-like fenestrated subepidermal tumor extending horizontally under the epidermis with multiple cord-like connections to the overlying epidermis (original magnification ×20). These histologic findings are consistent with a Trichoblastoma-like follicular induction (TFI).

Histopathologic examination of a biopsy specimen, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), showing peripheral palisading of the basaloid cells (original magnification ×40). This feature, observed as part of the histopathologic findings, is consistent with a Trichoblastoma-like follicular induction (TFI).

Histopathology of an incisional biopsy specimen from the right temporal scalp of a 19-year-old Korean man with large, brownish infiltrated plaques and multiple subcutaneous cystic masses. The image shows variable-sized multifocal infundibular cysts packed with keratin and comedones. The cysts are lined by an infundibular epithelium, and comedones are plugged with keratin and sebum in the papillomatous epidermis (original magnification ×40). Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Histopathology of an incisional biopsy specimen from the right temporal scalp of a 19-year-old Korean man with large, brownish infiltrated plaques and multiple subcutaneous cystic masses. The image shows abundant, thick, hyalinized, eosinophilic collagen deposition in the dermis, which has increased markedly and extends into the subcutaneous fat layer as fibrous strands (original magnification ×40). Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Histopathology of an incisional biopsy specimen from the right temporal scalp of a 19-year-old Korean man with large, brownish infiltrated plaques and multiple subcutaneous cystic masses. The image shows perifollicular concentric fibrosis around hair follicles in the mid dermis (original magnification ×100). Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Histopathology of an incisional biopsy specimen from the right temporal scalp of a 19-year-old Korean man with large, brownish infiltrated plaques and multiple subcutaneous cystic masses. The image shows concentric fibrosis also involving some small and medium vessels in the surrounding tissue (original magnification ×100). Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).
Histopathology of an excision specimen, showing a scanning view. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Histopathology of a biopsy specimen, revealing well-circumscribed, various-sized dermal tumor lobules. Adjacent to the tumor nodule, prominent hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, papillomatosis, and pseudohorn cysts are observed. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and captured at ×20 magnification.

Histopathology showing a lobular aggregation composed of numerous basaloid epithelial nests and multiple primitive papillary structures. Distinct peripheral palisading of nuclei is evident. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and captured at ×200 magnification.

Histopathology of the epidermis, demonstrating marked hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, papillomatosis, several horn cysts, and mild basal hyperpigmentation. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and captured at ×100 magnification.

Histopathology showing nevus sebaceous, characterized by multiple immature sebaceous glands located in the upper dermis. Image captured at 10x magnification using Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) staining.
Histopathology showing a multiloculated cystic lesion located in the dermis, which is lined by epithelium. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and captured at 10× magnification.
Histopathology showing a double layer of columnar cells with decapitation secretions, viewed at 40x magnification, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin.

Histopathology image stained with Hematoxylin and eosin (original magnification 200×), showing dispersed spindle-shaped malignant melanocytes within a dense and diffuse fibrotic stroma in the dermis. Lymphoid aggregates are visible at the periphery.

Histopathological examination showing sheets and nests of atypical melanocytes located in the corium. The overlying epithelium was atrophic and not pigmented. Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) stain, final magnification ×100.

Histopathological examination showing atypical melanocytes arranged in an alveolar pattern. Some cells present round nuclei of various sizes, occupying nearly the entire cell cytoplasm and prominent nucleoli. A few tumor cells contain dense cytoplasmic melanin pigment (arrow). Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) stain, final magnification ×400.

Histopathology of mucosal melanoma, part of the concurrent mucosal melanoma and angiofibroma. The image demonstrates tumor cells containing intracytoplasmic melanic pigment, representing the mucosal melanoma component of the excised mass. (H&E, ×400).

This image, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), illustrates histological features of congenital melanocytic naevus (CMN) in the nervous system, specifically depicting leptomeningeal disease. It shows a biopsy with a cellular collection of melanocytes that exhibit minimal atypia and no significant proliferation, consistent with typical benign leptomeningeal lesions. The histopathological examination of these lesions can be challenging, but they generally present a variety of morphological features without invading the CNS parenchyma. The minimal proliferation was further confirmed by Ki67 labelling shown in panel (b) for patient 3.

This hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained image highlights a stark contrast to the benign features seen in panels (a) and (b), presenting histological evidence of proliferation of markedly atypical cells with frequent mitotic figures within a congenital melanocytic naevus (CMN) of the nervous system. Such pronounced cytological atypia and increased cellular proliferation are key histological indicators of transformation to malignancy, a definition that also includes unequivocal invasion of the CNS parenchyma. This lesion expresses markers typical of melanocytes, such as HMB 45, and exhibits a high Ki67 labelling index, as further shown in panel (e).

This hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained image displays an area within a proliferative nodule of a cutaneous congenital melanocytic naevus (CMN). It features typical small deep melanocytes intermixed with expansile regions composed of spindled cells and areas containing larger cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm. Crucially, there is no significant atypia and an absence of mitoses, which is characteristic of benign proliferative nodules in CMN. Such nodules are generally defined histopathologically by a mixture of morphological cell types and a pushing border that may distort surrounding structures. In contrast to melanoma, they typically lack necrosis, significant cytological atypia, or high proliferative activity, and documented progression of a clearly benign nodule to malignancy is difficult to find.

This hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained image shows a section of a proliferative nodule within a cutaneous congenital melanocytic naevus (CMN). The image reveals typical small deep melanocytes alongside expansile areas formed by spindled cells and regions with larger cells possessing eosinophilic cytoplasm. Notably, no significant cytological atypia and no mitotic figures are observed. These features are consistent with a benign proliferative nodule, which is characterized by a diverse mix of cell types and a pushing border, and typically lacks the necrosis, marked atypia, or high proliferative activity associated with melanoma. Although these nodules can be quite proliferative, cases of benign nodules transforming into malignancy are rarely documented.

This hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained image illustrates the histological characteristics of a proliferative nodule found within a cutaneous congenital melanocytic naevus (CMN). It demonstrates areas composed of typical small deep melanocytes, admixed with expansile zones of spindled cells, and regions of larger cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm. Importantly, there is an absence of significant cytological atypia and no mitoses are seen, indicating its benign nature. Benign proliferative nodules typically feature a diverse cellular composition and a pushing border, and, unlike melanoma, generally do not exhibit necrosis, marked cytological atypia, or increased proliferative activity. Despite suggestions that these nodules might be precursors to melanoma, convincing documentation of such progression is uncommon in the literature.
Histopathology showing a pigmented Kinetochore body (KB) at 400x magnification. KBs were found in evaluated lesions, with some lesions containing only pigmented KBs. Stained with Hematoxylin & eosin.

Histopathology showing a lightly pigmented Kinetochore body (KB) at 400x magnification. KBs were found in evaluated lesions, with some lesions containing non-pigmented or lightly pigmented KBs. Stained with Hematoxylin & eosin.

Histopathological analysis of an incisional skin biopsy, stained with Hematoxylin & eosin (X20), shows aggregates of mature, ectopic adipocytes diffusely scattered and interposed among collagen bundles in the reticular dermis. These adipocytes are present without connection to the subcutaneous fat, a finding supporting the clinical diagnosis of Nevus lipomatosus superficialis (NLCS).

Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain at 200× magnification, showing the histopathology of the excised lesion. The image reveals a stratum corneum with basked wave hyperkeratosis interrupted by irregular islands of hyper- and parakeratosis. The epidermis exhibits acanthosis with irregular scattered melanocytes arranged in nests of different sizes and as single cells at all levels of the epidermis. Single cells and nests are also seen erupting into the stratum corneum.

Histopathologic appearance of the complex choristoma, which was initially described as diffuse and partially excised one month after presentation from the left eye of the 3-month-old Saudi boy with Linear nevus sebaceous syndrome (LNSS) described in Panel A. The image reveals glandular acini, smooth muscle, and cartilage, all embedded within prominent wavy collagen fibers and adipose tissue. This represents the microscopic structure of the epibulbar complex choristoma associated with LNSS. Original magnification X100, Hematoxylin and eosin stain.

Histopathology of a skin biopsy from a rash, representing the general findings of a cutaneous adverse event (CAE). The image shows slight basal layer vacuolization, dermal edema, and a superficial dermal perivascular lymphocyte and eosinophil infiltrate. These pathologic findings are considered relatively mild, despite the often extensive nature of the rash clinically, and are primarily characterized by a lympho-eosinophilic infiltrate. No necrosis is present, and there is an overall scarcity of inflammatory cells with a lack of toxic or necrotizing changes in the cutaneous vessels and epithelium. This pattern of inflammation suggests a delayed hypersensitivity type reaction, rather than features of Stevens-Johnson syndrome/toxic epidermal necrolysis (SJS/TEN), erythema multiforme-like drug reactions, or vasculitis. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at 200X magnification.

High magnification histopathology of a skin biopsy from a rash, showing eosinophils (indicated by arrows) prominently present alongside lymphocytes, concentrated around the superficial dermal capillaries. This image further highlights the primary lympho-eosinophilic infiltrate characteristic of the cutaneous adverse event (CAE) rashes. Critically, fibrinoid necrosis of capillary walls, which would be a sign of vasculitis, is not present. This observation reinforces the general finding across these biopsies that there is a lack of toxic epithelial changes, interface alterations, or necrotizing changes in the cutaneous vessels and epithelium. The mild inflammatory pattern observed is consistent with a delayed hypersensitivity type reaction. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at 400X magnification.

Histopathology of a biopsy from the mastoid showing a tumour, consistent with foetal metastases of a melanocytic tumour, exhibiting features of intermediate to high-level malignancy. The tumour consists of nests of small-sized and medium-sized cells, with oval to round nuclei and poorly defined eosinophilic cytoplasms. The examined tissue originated from multiple fragments of dark-coloured tissue sent for histological examination. Molecular analysis, using real-time PCR-HRM, detected a p.V600E mutation in exon 15 of the BRAF gene. (Hematoxylin-eosin stain, original magnification 200x).
Histopathology showing sharp demarcation in a focal atypical cell nodule of a congenital melanocytic nevus. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification ×40.
Histopathology showing cellular pleomorphism in a focal atypical cell nodule of a congenital melanocytic nevus. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, original magnification ×200.

Histopathology photomicrograph, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (HE) at 100X magnification, showing a biopsy from the maxillary right gingival mucosa of a 53-year-old woman with oral dark stains. The image exhibits parakeratinized stratified pavimentous epithelium with evident acanthosis and elongated epithelial projections. Melanocytic cells, containing brownish cytoplasmic pigments compatible with melanin, are localized throughout the entire basal extension of the epithelium. These microscopic findings are consistent with oral melanotic macule (OMA).

Histopathology photomicrograph, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (HE) at 400X magnification, showing a biopsy from the maxillary right gingival mucosa of a 53-year-old woman with oral dark stains. The image provides higher magnification evidence of brownish cytoplasmic pigments, compatible with melanin, specifically restricted to the melanocytic cells within the parakeratinized stratified pavimentous epithelium. These microscopic findings are consistent with oral melanotic macule (OMA).

Histopathology photomicrograph, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (HE) at 400X magnification, showing a biopsy from the maxillary right gingival mucosa of a 53-year-old woman with oral dark stains. The image exhibits spongy focal areas and the presence of numerous dendritic cells, containing brownish cytoplasmic pigments compatible with melanin, dispersed throughout the entire extension of the parakeratinized stratified pavimentous epithelial tissue. These microscopic findings are consistent with oral melanotic macule (OMA).
Microphotograph showing acanthotic epidermis with pigmentation and a horn cyst. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and captured at ×40 magnification.

Histopathologic findings of recurrent dysplastic nevus, specifically its third recurrence, showing melanocytes that are round, regular cells with moderate amounts of cytoplasm. No nuclear atypia, pleiomorphism, or mitosis are visible (H&E stain, ×400 magnification).

Histopathologic findings of malignant melanoma after repeated recurrent dysplastic nevi. The tumor cells show round to oval nuclei with mild nuclear pleomorphism, small nucleoli, and an irregular nuclear membrane. The cytoplasm contains melanin pigmentation. No mitosis is evident (Hematoxylin and Eosin, ×400 magnification).

Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) stained section of a CSF-470 VAC-SITE tissue from Patient #045, a 51-year-old Caucasian man treated with the CSF-470 vaccine for melanoma. This panel shows numerous Large Multi-nucleated Giant Cells (LMGC) within the vaccination site (indicated by arrows). Original magnification: 100X. Scale bar: 100 μm.

Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) stained section of a CSF-470 VAC-SITE tissue from Patient #045, a 51-year-old Caucasian man treated with the CSF-470 vaccine for melanoma. This panel shows numerous Large Multi-nucleated Giant Cells (LMGC) within the vaccination site (indicated by arrows). Original magnification: 1000X. Scale bar: 20 μm.

Histopathology showing a very abundant inflammatory infiltrate, composed of lymphocytes and plasma cells, at the level of the invasion front and deep limit of the tissue fragment. Additionally, there is dermis edema and dilated, tortuous blood vessels within the dermal papillae. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at objective magnification 5x.

Histopathology of Acral verrucous carcinoma, showing a solid invasion front and parakeratosis centers. Histopathological examination reveals foci of a well-differentiated squamous carcinoma with minimal atypia and rare atypical mitosis. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin, objective magnification X5.

Histopathology of the basal cell carcinoma (BCC) from the nasal lesion, confirmed by incisional biopsy as ulcerated nodular BCC. The image shows clusters of basaloid cells. Stained with Hematoxylin & eosin, original magnification ×10.

Histopathology of the basal cell carcinoma (BCC) from the nasal lesion, confirmed by incisional biopsy as ulcerated nodular BCC. The image demonstrates peripheral palisading of cells, a characteristic feature of BCC. Stained with Hematoxylin & eosin, original magnification ×100.

Histopathology of the melanoma from the right temporal region, confirmed by incisional biopsy. The image displays nests of atypical melanocytes and pagetoid spread. Histologic analysis of this melanoma demonstrated a vertical growth phase, with a Breslow thickness of 1.2 mm and Clark level IV. Stained with Hematoxylin & eosin, original magnification ×200.

Histopathology of the “dog ear” fragment, which was obtained during the resection of a sternal lesion. This fragment showed alterations leading to a diagnosis of multibacillary leprosy. Panel A shows an inflammatory infiltrate in the peri-adnexal superficial and deep dermis, composed of lymphocytes and macrophages with vacuolated cytoplasm. Stained with Hematoxylin & eosin, ×400 magnification.

Histopathology of the “dog ear” fragment, which was obtained during the resection of a sternal lesion. This fragment showed alterations leading to a diagnosis of multibacillary leprosy. Panel B shows perineurium delamination and infiltration by lymphocytes and macrophages. Stained with Hematoxylin & eosin, ×400 magnification.

Histopathology with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining (original magnification, ×400). This high-magnification view shows detail of the dermal infiltrate with infiltration of the follicular epithelium by large atypical lymphocytes. These predominantly medium-sized to large atypical cells, including those with hyperchromatic and cerebriform nuclei, and blast cells, are a feature observed in a subset of cases (seven cases, all belonging to the P-FMF group). In contrast, most cases (83%) of FMF show predominantly small to medium-sized atypical cells.
Histopathology showing prominent perifollicular infiltrates. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin.
Histopathology showing a detailed view of the perifollicular infiltrate, revealing infiltration by small atypical T-cells. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at ×400 magnification.

Histopathology showing a detail of diffuse dermal infiltrate, specifically a dense infiltrate of small atypical T-cells infiltrating follicular epithelium. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) and captured at ×400 magnification.

Histopathologic examination of skin lesions, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) at ×40 magnification, shows sparse intrafollicular and perifollicular infiltrates and extensive follicular mucinosis. These findings may explain the induration of the skin lesions.

Histopathology showing Spitz nevus without cytological atypia. The image reveals epidermal hyperplasia, lengthening of epidermal ridges, transepidermal elimination of moderately pigmented epithelioid melanocytic nests, and numerous melanophages in the papillary dermis (H&E, original magnification ×4).

Histopathology showing Spitz nevus without cytological atypia. The image reveals epidermal hyperplasia, lengthening of epidermal ridges, transepidermal elimination of moderately pigmented epithelioid melanocytic nests, and numerous melanophages in the papillary dermis (H&E, original magnification ×20).

Histopathologic findings of a biopsy specimen from the abdomen, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×40 magnification, showing an epidermal change. The study analyzed major histologic items such as hyperkeratosis, parakeratosis, acanthosis, papillomatosis, and dermal inflammatory cell infiltrates, which contribute to such epidermal changes. Hyperkeratosis, for instance, was observed in 38 specimens, predominantly presenting as mild to moderate grades, and papillomatosis was also a significant finding in the analysis of pathologic features.

Histopathologic findings of a biopsy specimen, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×100 magnification, remarkably showing hyperkeratosis and papillomatosis. Hyperkeratosis was a common finding across the specimens, detected in 38 cases, with most (37 specimens) showing a mild to moderate grade, and only one showing severe hyperkeratosis. Papillomatosis was also identified as a major histologic item analyzed in the study, contributing to the observed epidermal changes.
Histological analysis of the tumor tissue. Hematoxylin and eosin staining showing the tumor cells at × 200 magnification.

Histopathology after H&E staining showing interlacing fascicles of spindle-shaped cells with oval, round, and tapering nuclei, exhibiting pale eosinophilic cytoplasm. These spindle cells are part of a biphasic pattern, alternating with closely packed cells that have small rounded nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm, all set within a collagenous stroma. Foci of forming bone are evident, characteristic of an osteoblastic variety of tumor consisting of tumor osteoid surrounded by bizarrely arranged fibroblast-like cells (original magnification ×10).

Histopathology after H&E staining showing interlacing fascicles of spindle-shaped cells with oval, round, and tapering nuclei, exhibiting pale eosinophilic cytoplasm. These cells alternate with closely packed small round nuclei cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm, arranged in a biphasic pattern set within a collagenous stroma. Foci of bone formation are evident, characteristic of an osteoblastic variety of tumor consisting of tumor osteoid surrounded by bizarrely arranged fibroblast-like cells (original magnification ×10).

Histopathology after H&E staining showing interlacing fascicles of spindle-shaped cells with oval, round, and tapering nuclei, exhibiting pale eosinophilic cytoplasm. These spindle cells alternate with closely packed small round nuclei cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm, arranged in a biphasic pattern. This pattern is typically set within a collagenous stroma and represents an osteoblastic variety of tumor, consisting of tumor osteoid surrounded by bizarrely arranged fibroblast-like cells (original magnification ×10).

Histopathology showing a collision tumor consisting of keratoacanthoma and melanoma, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). The overall histological picture reveals an invaginating squamous proliferation consistent with keratoacanthoma/well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, keratoacanthoma type. This squamous lesion exhibits characteristic lipping of the edges, large pale keratinocytes, and micro abscesses in epithelial nests at the bottom. The image also depicts a melanoma component, initially suspicious for melanoma in situ as a junctional spindle cell proliferation, which subsequent immunohistochemical analysis (not shown) confirmed to have an invasive spindle cell component positive for melanocytic markers (Melan-A, HMB45, SOX10, S100). The melanoma had a Breslow thickness of 4.6 mm. The small insert on the upper right side specifically highlights the edge of the keratoacanthoma, demonstrating its characteristic architecture and the presence of large pale keratinocytes.

Histopathology showing a detailed view of the invasion front, characterized by large pale keratinocytes and epithelial nests with micro abscesses. These squamous features are consistent with an invaginating squamous proliferation identified as keratoacanthoma/well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, keratoacanthoma type. These squamous elements are observed in a background of diffuse spindle-shaped cells, which were confirmed to be melanoma cells through subsequent immunohistochemical analysis, showing positive staining for melanocytic markers (Melan-A, HMB45, SOX10, S100) and negative staining for epithelial markers. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E).

Hematoxylin and eosin stained photomicrograph of cutaneous tumors from TN and TB mice, showing variable proportions of spindle (left, cellular) and myxoid (right, spaces) morphologies, regardless of UV exposure history. The scale bar represents 200 μm.

Hematoxylin and eosin stained photomicrograph of cutaneous tumors from TN and TB mice, showing a higher magnification image of the myxoid morphology depicted in panel A. The scale bar represents 20 μm.

Hematoxylin and eosin stained photomicrograph of cutaneous tumors from TN and TB mice, showing a higher magnification image of the spindle morphology depicted in panel A, with arrows indicating mitotic figures. The scale bar represents 20 μm.

Hematoxylin and eosin stained photomicrograph of a cutaneous tumor from a TN mouse, showing neoplastic cells with plasmacytoid features (indicated by circles) seen in most of the TN tumors evaluated. The scale bar represents 20 μm.

Hematoxylin and eosin stained photomicrograph of a cutaneous tumor from a UVA-treated TN mouse, exhibiting a fibroblastic phenotype with abundant collagen (indicated by an asterisk). This phenotype was observed in half of the tumors from UVA-treated TN mice. The scale bar represents 20 μm.

Hematoxylin and eosin stained photomicrograph of a cutaneous tumor sample from a TB mouse, containing areas of pigmentation, typically appearing as clusters of melanophages at the dermal–hypodermal interface (indicated by boxes). The scale bar represents 200 μm.
Histopathology showing a benign macule in the gingiva, corresponding to the macroscopic lesion in Panel A, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE).
Histopathology showing a benign macule in the gingiva, corresponding to the macroscopic lesion in Panel A, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE).
Histopathology showing a benign intramucosal nevus on the hard palate, corresponding to the macroscopic lesion in Panel B, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE).
Histopathology showing a benign intramucosal nevus on the hard palate, corresponding to the macroscopic lesion in Panel B, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE).
Histopathology showing a blue nevus, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE).
Histopathology showing a blue nevus, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE).
Histopathology showing a junctional nevus, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE).
Histopathology showing a junctional nevus, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE).

Histopathology showing a lentigo maligna melanoma on the mandibular gingiva, corresponding to the malignant oral mucosal melanoma (OMM) in situ shown in Panel C, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE).

Histopathology showing a lentigo maligna melanoma on the mandibular gingiva, corresponding to the malignant oral mucosal melanoma (OMM) in situ shown in Panel C, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE).

Histopathology showing an ulcerated malignant melanoma on the hard palate, corresponding to the malignant oral mucosal melanoma (OMM) in situ shown in Panel D, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE).

Histopathology showing an ulcerated malignant melanoma on the hard palate, corresponding to the malignant oral mucosal melanoma (OMM) in situ shown in Panel D, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE).

Histological examination (H&E, ×40) of a slightly elevated, brownish, oval papule from the right shoulder of a 22-year-old woman, revealing an epithelial tumor. The tumor is characterized by psoriasiform hyperplasia, parakeratosis, and large keratinocytes with pale cytoplasm. These features are consistent with a clear cell acanthoma (CCA).

Histological examination (H&E, ×100) of a slightly elevated, brownish, oval papule from the right shoulder of a 22-year-old woman, showing the presence of melanophages in the superficial dermis. The overall histological findings, including these melanophages, led to the diagnosis of a clear cell acanthoma (CCA) with melanophages.

Histopathology of Lentigo maligna on the left temporal region of a 77-year-old man, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at 400× magnification. The image shows atypical melanocytes and irregular nests at the dermoepidermal junction (DEJ) and in the epidermis, with involvement of the hair follicles. This follicular involvement correlates with the asymmetric pigmentation of the hair follicles observed clinically and dermoscopically. In the dermis, there is prominent solar elastosis, melanophages, and a discrete lymphohistiocytic infiltrate. The presence of melanophages in the upper dermis correlates with the blue-gray granularity seen in the annular-granular pattern on dermoscopy. The irregular nests at the DEJ and aggregates of melanocytes also correlate with the brown dots observed on dermoscopy.

Histopathology of Lentigo maligna on the left temporal region of a 77-year-old man, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at 400× magnification. The image shows atypical melanocytes and irregular nests at the dermoepidermal junction (DEJ) and in the epidermis, with involvement of the hair follicles. This follicular involvement correlates with the asymmetric pigmentation of the hair follicles observed clinically and dermoscopically. In the dermis, there is prominent solar elastosis, melanophages, and a discrete lymphohistiocytic infiltrate. The presence of melanophages in the upper dermis correlates with the blue-gray granularity seen in the annular-granular pattern on dermoscopy. The irregular nests at the DEJ and aggregates of melanocytes also correlate with the brown dots observed on dermoscopy.

Histopathology image of a superficial spreading melanoma (T1a, Breslow 0.5 mm) on the abdomen of an 82-year-old man, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at 40× original magnification. This image shows fibrosis with a lymphohistiocytic infiltrate in the dermis, which correlates with an area of regression (labeled *). Superficial spreading melanoma is a slow-growing melanoma, and regression (white areas) and inflammation may be present at any stage. Atypical melanocytes in single units and irregular nests mostly arranged at the dermo-epidermal junction (DEJ), along with melanophages in the dermis, correlate with structureless bichromatic brown-blue areas (labeled +).

Histopathology image of a superficial spreading melanoma (T1a, Breslow 0.5 mm) on the abdomen of an 82-year-old man, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at 40× original magnification. The image shows hyperpigmented rete ridges with atypical melanocytes in single units and irregular nests mostly arranged at the dermo-epidermal junction (DEJ) (labeled ^), which correlates with the atypical network observed in dermoscopy. A heavy lymphohistiocytic infiltrate with melanophages, acanthosis of the epidermis, and heavily pigmented atypical nests and melanocytes in the epidermis are present, responsible for the structureless blue pigmentation (labeled °). Superficial spreading melanoma is a slow-growing melanoma characterized by an initial radial growth phase (RGP) with epidermal involvement, followed by a vertical growth phase.

Histopathology image of a superficial spreading melanoma (T1a, Breslow 0.5 mm) on the abdomen of an 82-year-old man, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) at 100× original magnification. This higher magnification image shows atypical melanocytes in single units and irregular nests mostly arranged at the dermo-epidermal junction (DEJ), along with melanophages in the dermis. These features correlate with the structureless bichromatic brown-blue areas (labeled +) seen in dermoscopy. Superficial spreading melanoma is a biologically slow-growing melanoma, typically showing an initial radial growth phase involving the epidermis and DEJ, followed by a vertical growth phase (VGP) with invasion into the dermis.

Histopathology (Hematoxylin and Eosin, HE, ×100) of melanoma in situ on the left flank of a 62-year-old man. The image shows a proliferation of atypical melanocytes, present in single units and nests, extending through all layers of the epidermis. Additionally, a dense lymphohistiocytic infiltrate with melanophages is visible in the dermis.

Histopathology (×200) showing the correlation of dermoscopic features with histological findings in melanoma in situ. The image displays irregular pigmented areas that correlate with clumps of melanin and pigmented parakeratosis. Irregular hyperpigmented areas are among the most prevalent dermatoscopic features in small diameter melanoma (<5 mm) and typically correlate with clumps of melanin or hyperpigmented atypical melanocytes in the epidermis or stratum corneum. The structureless brown areas observed dermoscopically correlate with a dense lymphohistiocytic infiltrate with melanophages in the dermis. The staining is likely Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), given the context of the overall histological analysis.

Histopathology (hematoxylin and eosin stain, 20× magnification) of a nevus-associated melanoma from a 76-year-old woman. The image shows an asymmetric melanocytic lesion composed on the left side by a dermal proliferation of monomorphous melanocytes with maturation, which corresponds to the central hypopigmented-brown structureless areas observed dermoscopically. On the right shoulder, elongated rete-ridges are present with atypical melanocytes in single units and irregular nests throughout all epidermal layers, correlating to the atypical network seen in the dermoscopic image.

Histopathology of a superficial spreading melanoma (T1a, Breslow 0.53 mm) from the left chest of a 44-year-old man. Superficial spreading melanoma is characterized by an initial radial growth phase (RGP) with atypical melanocytes. This hematoxylin and eosin (HE) stained image (100× magnification) shows peripheral, confluent, and heavily pigmented atypical junctional nests of melanocytes. These nests correlate with pseudopods observed in dermoscopy. Additionally, structureless black and blue areas seen in dermoscopy are typically related to a heavy band-like lymphohistiocytic infiltrate with melanophages in the dermis.

Histopathology of a superficial spreading melanoma (T1a, Breslow 0.53 mm) from the left chest of a 44-year-old man. Superficial spreading melanoma is characterized by an initial radial growth phase (RGP) with atypical melanocytes at the dermoepidermal junction. This hematoxylin and eosin (HE) stained image (100× magnification) reveals irregularly large atypical nests of melanocytes at the dermoepidermal junction (DEJ), which correspond to irregular globules observed in dermoscopy.

Histopathology of a superficial spreading melanoma (T1a, Breslow 0.53 mm) from the left chest of a 44-year-old man. Superficial spreading melanoma is characterized by an initial radial growth phase (RGP) with atypical melanocytes proliferating in the epidermis. This hematoxylin and eosin (HE) stained image (100× magnification) demonstrates small atypical nests of melanocytes or irregular clumps of melanin within the epidermis. These histological features correlate with irregular dots observed in dermoscopy.

Histopathological analysis of an incisional biopsy from the right buttocks of a 58-year-old man, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). The image shows cysts within the dermis. The wall of the cyst is lined with stratified squamous epithelium exhibiting keratinization similar to the epidermis and is partially replaced by basaloid malignant cells. The cyst is filled with horny material and malignant tumor cells. The tumor extends through the dermis down to the subcutaneous tissue in a solid pattern. These findings are consistent with basal cell carcinoma (BCC) originating from an epidermal cyst. Scale bar = 600 μm, original magnification: ×20.

Histopathological analysis of an incisional biopsy from the right buttocks of a 58-year-old man, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). The image shows cysts within the dermis. The wall of the cyst is lined with stratified squamous epithelium exhibiting keratinization similar to the epidermis and is partially replaced by basaloid malignant cells. The cyst is filled with horny material and malignant tumor cells. The tumor extends through the dermis down to the subcutaneous tissue in a solid pattern. These findings are consistent with basal cell carcinoma (BCC) originating from an epidermal cyst. Scale bar = 500 μm.

High-magnification histopathological analysis of an incisional biopsy from the right buttocks of a 58-year-old man, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). The image displays characteristic features of basal cell carcinoma, including a palisading arrangement of the nuclei in the peripheral cell layer of the tumor nests and a clefting artifact between the epithelium and the stroma. The tumor cells are basaloid and fill portions of the cyst. This further supports the diagnosis of basal cell carcinoma (BCC) originating from an epidermal cyst. Original magnification: ×400; scale bar = 20 μm.

Histopathology of a punch biopsy sample, stained with hematoxylin-eosin, shown at 10× magnification. The biopsy reveals a slightly increased density of eccrine glands within the dermis, with no other abnormalities.

Histopathology of a punch biopsy sample, stained with hematoxylin-eosin, shown at 40× magnification. The biopsy reveals a slightly increased density of eccrine glands within the dermis, with no other abnormalities.

Histopathology showing atypical melanocytes forming the “shoulder” of a malignant melanoma lesion. The atypical melanocytes ascend to the level of the dermoepidermal junction and show a tendency to invade the superficial and middle dermis. These elements are frankly of a melanocytic nature, with occasional pigment. This “junctional” component is also characterized by being strongly positive for S-100 protein, Melan-A, and HMB-45, but negative for CD10, as determined by immunohistochemical examination. (Hematoxylin-Eosin, Original Magnification: 10×).

Histological micrograph highlighting the two morphologically different components of dedifferentiated melanoma. These include elements of a melanocytic nature, which invade the superficial and middle dermis, and an exophytic polypoid nodule consisting of pleomorphic, atypical elements. On immunohistochemical examination, the melanocytic component (the “shoulder” of the lesion) is strongly positive for S-100 protein, Melan-A, and HMB-45, but negative for CD10. In contrast, the nodular component is almost entirely negative for S-100, Melan-A, and HMB-45, only focally positive for SOX-10, and strongly positive for CD10. (Hematoxylin–Eosin, original magnification: 20×).
Histopathology showing melanoma in situ. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and eosin at 20x magnification.
Microsatellite Stable (MSS) tissue, stained with Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), viewed at 20x magnification.
NM (Nevus Melanocytic/Melanoma), visualized with Hematoxylin and eosin staining at 100x magnification.
Histopathology showing NM, stained with Hematoxylin and eosin at 20x magnification.
Histopathology showing both dysplastic nevus and melanoma in situ, stained with Hematoxylin and eosin, at 20x magnification.
AM (specific condition or sample type, as described in the paper), observed under Hematoxylin and eosin staining at 100x magnification.

Microscopic examination of hematoxylin and eosin stained sections shows squamous cell carcinoma in situ. This low magnification view (x4) illustrates hyperkeratosis (thickened stratum corneum; green brackets), acanthosis (thickened epidermis; blue brackets), and a pseudohorn cyst (red arrow). Lymphocytic inflammation (white circle) and melanophages (black arrows) are also noted in the papillary dermis. The biopsy tissue specimen showed hyperpigmentation. The yellow circle indicates an area of higher magnification shown in Panel D, where atypical nuclear features are present in keratinocytes.

Microscopic examination of hematoxylin and eosin stained sections shows squamous cell carcinoma in situ. This higher magnification view (x10) illustrates hyperkeratosis (thickened stratum corneum; green brackets), acanthosis (thickened epidermis; blue brackets), and a pseudohorn cyst (red arrow). Lymphocytic inflammation (white circle) and melanophages (black arrows) are also noted in the papillary dermis. The biopsy tissue specimen showed hyperpigmentation. Atypical nuclear features are present in keratinocytes throughout the epidermis.

Microscopic examination of hematoxylin and eosin stained sections shows squamous cell carcinoma in situ. This higher magnification view (x20) illustrates hyperkeratosis (thickened stratum corneum; green brackets), acanthosis (thickened epidermis; blue brackets), and a pseudohorn cyst (red arrow). Lymphocytic inflammation (white circle) and melanophages (black arrows) are also noted in the papillary dermis. The biopsy tissue specimen showed hyperpigmentation. Atypical nuclear features are present in keratinocytes throughout the epidermis.

Microscopic examination of hematoxylin and eosin stained sections shows squamous cell carcinoma in situ. This higher magnification view (x40) of the epidermis (corresponding to the yellow circle in Panel A) demonstrates several atypical keratinocytes (yellow arrows). Atypical nuclear features were present in keratinocytes throughout the epidermis. The biopsy tissue specimen also showed hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, pseudohorn cysts, lymphocytic inflammation, melanophages, and hyperpigmentation.
Histopathology showing hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, and mild perivascular lymphohistiocytic infiltration. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×100 magnification.
Histopathology showing tiny brown-pigmented particles present at the lower level of the corneal layer. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×400 magnification.
Histopathology showing tiny brown-pigmented particles present at the mid-level of the corneal layer. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at ×400 magnification.
Photomicrograph of the incisional biopsy from Patient #1, stained with hematoxylin and eosin. Scale bar 500 μm.
Photomicrograph from the resection specimen of Patient #1, stained with hematoxylin and eosin. Scale bar 1 mm.
Photomicrograph of the incisional biopsy from Patient #3, stained with hematoxylin and eosin. Scale bar represents 100 μm.
Photomicrograph from the resection specimen from Patient #3, stained with hematoxylin and eosin. Scale bar represents 200 μm.
Photomicrograph of the incisional biopsy specimen from Patient #2, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E). Scale bar: 100 μm.
Photomicrograph of the resection specimen from Patient #2, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E). Scale bar: 200 μm.
Histopathology showing dermal proliferation of heavily pigmented epithelioid cells. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) and captured at 400x magnification.

Histopathology showing spindle cells with an additional junctional dendritic component, highlighted by an arrow and further detailed in the inset. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE) and captured at 200x magnification.

Histopathological examination showing epidermal hyperplasia with parakeratosis and pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia (PEH). There is a symmetric proliferation of variable-sized nests of melanocytes at the dermoepidermal junction, accompanied by shrinkage artifacts around the nests. The nests are vertically oriented along rete, and melanocytes within the nests also share this vertical orientation. (hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, scale bar = 200 μm).

Histopathological examination showing Kamino bodies, which are rounded, dull pink areas composed of trapped basement membrane material within the epidermis. Melanocyte nests diminish in size and transition to single cells with increasing depth. There is diminished cellular and nuclear size with depth, indicative of maturation. Melanocytes are dispersed at the base of the lesion. (hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, scale bar = 50 μm).

Histopathological examination revealing clefts between melanocyte aggregates and adjacent keratinocytes. There is also central pagetoid scatter. The melanin pigment is absent in the majority of the melanocytes, except for those located superficially. (hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, scale bar = 50 μm).

Histopathological examination showing that the melanocyte nests are composed of spindled cells and epithelioid cells. These cells exhibit abundant amphophilic cytoplasm and large but relatively uniform vesicular nuclei. Cellular shrinkage is observed, and multinuclear cells are also noticed. No mitoses were found. (hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain, scale bar = 25 μm).

Histopathology showing full thickness atypia/dysplasia in the epidermis. The keratinocytes show atypia that spans the entire epidermis, not breaching the dermo-epidermal junction. This image illustrates key diagnostic features confirmed by histopathology, which is the gold standard diagnostic modality. The epidermis may also exhibit hyperkeratosis, parakeratosis, marked acanthosis with elongation and thickening of rete ridges, and loss of maturity and polarity giving a “windblown” appearance. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 10x magnification.

Histopathology showing areas of hyperchromasia, pleomorphism, and atypical mitosis. The keratinocytes demonstrate intense mitotic activity and pleomorphism, often with very large nuclei, which are characteristic features confirmed by histopathology, the gold standard diagnostic modality. The accompanying loss of maturity and polarity gives the epidermis a “windblown” appearance. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 40x magnification.

Histopathology of a conventional deep penetrating nevus. A wedge-shaped (inverted triangle) proliferation of enlarged fusiform, spindled, and/or epithelioid melanocytes is observed extending into the deep dermis and subcutis, with an overlying grenz zone. The lesion is typically small, well-circumscribed, and symmetrical. (Hematoxylin and eosin, 20× magnification).

Histopathology of a conventional deep penetrating nevus. The lesional melanocytes, which are typically enlarged fusiform, spindled, and/or epithelioid, are arranged in characteristic fascicles, cords, and nests. These bundles of melanocytes may be associated with neurovascular and adnexal structures, giving a plexiform appearance. (Hematoxylin and eosin, 100× magnification).

Histopathology of a conventional deep penetrating nevus. The melanocytes are epithelioid and spindled, possessing amphophilic cytoplasm. Admixed are scattered, often sparse to abundant, heavily pigmented melanophages. A lymphocytic infiltrate may also be present. There is no associated necrosis or loss or invasion of adnexal structures. (Hematoxylin and eosin, 100× magnification).

Histopathology showing a deep penetrating nevus associated with a predominantly intradermal melanocytic nevus, presented as part of a combined nevus. Deep penetrating nevi often exist in this combined form, frequently associated with other nevoid subtypes like conventional, blue, or Spitz nevi. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, 40× magnification.

Histopathology showing a deep penetrating nevus associated with a predominantly intradermal melanocytic nevus, presented as part of a combined nevus. Deep penetrating nevi often exist in this combined form, frequently associated with other nevoid subtypes like conventional, blue, or Spitz nevi. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin, 100× magnification.

Histopathology of an atypical deep penetrating nevus originating from the eyelid margin, stained with Hematoxylin and eosin at 40× magnification. This panel provides an overview of the lesion, which exhibits features consistent with atypical deep penetrating nevi.

Histopathology of an atypical deep penetrating nevus from the eyelid margin, stained with Hematoxylin and eosin at 200× magnification. The image reveals moderate cytologic atypia and rare mitotic figures, which are characteristic findings in atypical deep penetrating nevi.

Histopathology of an atypical deep penetrating nevus (DPN) at 40x magnification, stained with hematoxylin and eosin. This image demonstrates atypical architectural and cytological features that exceed those typically seen in conventional DPN. Atypical DPNs are characterized by increased architectural and cytologic atypia compared to conventional DPN, although these features fall short of those diagnostic of melanoma. Atypical architectural features, which may be visible at this magnification, include asymmetry, hypercellularity often with expansile nodular or diffuse sheet-like architecture, and infiltrative borders.

Histopathology of an atypical deep penetrating nevus (DPN) at 200x magnification, stained with hematoxylin and eosin. This panel highlights the junctional component, which is predominantly nested and epithelioid. Occasional pagetoid upward migration of atypical single melanocytes is present. The atypical cells within the junctional component are cytologically similar to those seen in the dermis and may exhibit moderate to severe cytologic atypia, including pleomorphism, high nuclear to cytoplasmic ratios, and conspicuous cherry-red nucleoli.

Histopathology of an atypical deep penetrating nevus (DPN) at 200x magnification, stained with hematoxylin and eosin. This panel shows the dermal component where melanocytes are spindled and admixed with melanophages. Scattered cells within the dermis exhibit severe cytologic atypia, consistent with the increased and more than random atypia found in atypical DPN. These cells may display features such as pleomorphism, high nuclear to cytoplasmic ratios, conspicuous cherry-red nucleoli, variable cytoplasmic melanin pigment, amphophilic cytoplasm, and rare multinucleation. In this specific case, findings on fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) with probes for RREB1, CCND1, MYC, and CDKN2A were within normal limits.

Histopathology of sentinel lymph node deposits from a patient with an atypical deep penetrating nevus, stained with Hematoxylin and eosin at 40× magnification. Atypical deep penetrating nevi may show nodal deposits on sentinel lymph node biopsy.

Histopathology of sentinel lymph node deposits from a patient with an atypical deep penetrating nevus, stained with Hematoxylin and eosin at 200× magnification. Multiple clusters of coarsely and densely pigmented epithelioid cells are noted within the lymph node parenchyma and subcapsular space. Atypical deep penetrating nevi may show nodal deposits on sentinel lymph node biopsy.

Histopathology image showing a deep penetrating nevus-like melanoma with a compound, asymmetric melanocytic proliferation. DPN-like melanoma typically exhibits histomorphologic features reminiscent of conventional deep penetrating nevus but may demonstrate an atypical junctional component with pagetoid upward migration of melanocytes, irregular epidermal hyperplasia or atrophy, infiltrative growth patterns or nodular growth at the base, increased depth, ulceration, necrosis, inflammatory reaction, perineural invasion, lymphovascular invasion, increased cellularity, significant cytologic atypia, prominent mitotic activity, and atypical mitotic figures. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin at 20× magnification.

Histopathology image showing a deep penetrating nevus-like melanoma with a compound, asymmetric melanocytic proliferation. DPN-like melanoma typically exhibits histomorphologic features reminiscent of conventional deep penetrating nevus but may demonstrate an atypical junctional component with pagetoid upward migration of melanocytes, irregular epidermal hyperplasia or atrophy, infiltrative growth patterns or nodular growth at the base, increased depth, ulceration, necrosis, inflammatory reaction, perineural invasion, lymphovascular invasion, increased cellularity, significant cytologic atypia, prominent mitotic activity, and atypical mitotic figures. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin at 40× magnification.

Histopathology image of a deep penetrating nevus-like melanoma, highlighting lesional cells that share cytomorphologic similarity with conventional deep penetrating nevus. DPN-like melanoma typically has histomorphologic features reminiscent of conventional DPN, but can also be characterized by features such as an atypical junctional component, pagetoid upward migration of melanocytes, irregular epidermal hyperplasia or atrophy, and various infiltrative growth patterns. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin at 200× magnification.

Histopathology image of a deep penetrating nevus-like melanoma, showing increased cytologic atypia. DPN-like melanoma often demonstrates significant cytologic atypia, which may include marked pleomorphism, prominent pseudo-nuclear inclusions, abundant pale cytoplasm, and an irregular pattern of dusty cytoplasmic melanization (pulverocytes). These atypical features are typically found throughout the lesion and are nonrandom, supporting the diagnosis of melanoma. Additionally, immunohistochemical studies showed diffuse loss of p16, and the MyPath Myriad score (from qRT-PCR-based molecular analysis) was 2.0 (malignant range: 0 to 10), further supporting the interpretation of melanoma. Stained with hematoxylin and eosin at 400× magnification.

Low magnification histopathology showing an ovoidal-shaped, poorly-pigmented choroidal tumor with sharply circumscribed margins. This tumor is located in the posterior ocular chamber, protruding into the posterior segment of the eye, and is consistent with a 'balloon cell melanoma of the choroid'. The surgical sample was fixed in neutral-buffered 10% formalin and submitted for histologic examination. Staining is hematoxylin and eosin (original magnification 25×).

Low magnification histopathology showing that the choroidal tumor, due to its mass effect, induces a massive retinal detachment in the posterior segment of the eye. This feature is consistent with a 'balloon cell melanoma of the choroid'. Staining is hematoxylin and eosin (original magnification 50×).

High magnification histopathology of the choroidal tumor, exhibiting a diffuse ballooning morphology. The tumor is mainly composed (90%) of small- to medium-sized, ovoidal cells with rounded to oval-shaped hyperchromatic nuclei, dispersed chromatin, inconspicuous nucleoli, and abundant clear or weakly eosinophilic granular cytoplasm. Few inflammatory cells, including lymphocytes and melanin-laden macrophages, are admixed with the neoplastic cells. These morphological features support the diagnosis of 'balloon cell melanoma of the choroid'. Staining is hematoxylin and eosin (original magnification 400×).

Histopathology showing a small portion (10%) of the choroidal neoplasm composed of more pigmented spindle-shaped cells. These neoplastic cells have elongated nuclei and conspicuous (evident) nucleoli, representing a conventional spindle-cell morphology, which is a component of 'balloon cell melanoma of the choroid'. Staining is hematoxylin and eosin (original magnification 150×).

Histopathology showing the left half of a lesion. The nests within the lesion are heterogeneous, differing from one another in shape and dimension. They display an asymmetric disposition and an uneven distribution of pigment. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at 40x magnification.
Histopathology showing an asymmetric, not sharply circumscribed, mostly junctional melanocytic proliferation. Image captured at 20x magnification using Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) stain.
Histopathology image showing atypical melanocytes present in single units within the stratum spinosum, observed at one edge of the lesion. (Hematoxylin and eosin stain; 100x magnification).
Histopathology showing irregular nests with cohesive melanocytes pushing the epidermis from the bottom, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 200x magnification.

Histopathology of the right half of a lesion, showing nests that are distinct from one another, varying in shape and dimension. The nests exhibit an asymmetric disposition and an uneven distribution of pigment. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) and captured at 40x magnification.

Histopathology showing expansile nests pushing the epidermis from the bottom and squeezing the stratum spinosum. The epidermis also exhibits focal pigmented parakeratosis and pigmentation of basal keratinocytes (H&E; 100x magnification).

Histopathology image showing irregular nests and single melanocytes present in the epidermis, including areas above the dermoepidermal junction. In the superficial dermis, there are melanophages, a few dendritic melanocytes, and lymphocytes. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) and viewed at 100x magnification.

Photomicrograph of balloon cell melanoma from the first case (female, 76 years old), showing the pseudolipoblastic/balloon cell aspects of the melanocytes, characterized by a swollen histological appearance and the disintegration of disordered and abundant melanic pigment. The lesion consists of more than 50% “balloon-shaped” melanocytes, featuring abundant and finely vacuolized cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei generally located in the periphery of the cell, but not pycnotic. Melanin is quantitatively reduced within the cell, with a disordered dispersion within the lesion itself and in numerous melanophages. Architecturally, the cells are organized in large pale masses that replace the dermis and thin the epidermis, forming large solid sheets of “ballooniform” melanocytes divided into irregular aggregates by thin collagenous septa, with no clear signs of activity at the dermo-epidermal junction or pagetoid spreading. Very rare mitoses were observed. Hematoxylin-Eosin stain, Original Magnification 4×.

Histological micrograph of balloon cell melanoma from patient number two (male, 75 years old), showing two different neoplastic parts: on the right, the characteristic “balloon cell” part, while in the center and on the left, a component of spindle cells of malignant melanoma is present. Additionally, in this case, there was an abundant and irregular presence of melanic pigment. The lesion consists of more than 50% “balloon-shaped” melanocytes, featuring abundant and finely vacuolized cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei generally located in the periphery of the cell, but not pycnotic. Melanin is quantitatively reduced within the cell, with a disordered dispersion within the lesion itself and in numerous melanophages. Architecturally, the cells are organized in large pale masses that replace the dermis and thin the epidermis, forming large solid sheets of “ballooniform” melanocytes divided into irregular aggregates by thin collagenous septa, with no clear signs of activity at the dermo-epidermal junction or pagetoid spreading. Very rare mitoses were observed. Hematoxylin-Eosin stain, Original Magnification 4×.

Histological preparation of sections from balloon cell melanoma in the third patient (female, 36 years old), displaying both balloon cell morphology and potentially a spindle cell component similar to what was observed in case number two. The lesion consists of more than 50% “balloon-shaped” melanocytes, featuring abundant and finely vacuolized cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei generally located in the periphery of the cell, but not pycnotic. Melanin is quantitatively reduced within the cell, with a disordered dispersion within the lesion itself and in numerous melanophages. Architecturally, the cells are organized in large pale masses that replace the dermis and thin the epidermis, forming large solid sheets of “ballooniform” melanocytes divided into irregular aggregates by thin collagenous septa, with no clear signs of activity at the dermo-epidermal junction or pagetoid spreading. Very rare mitoses were observed. Hematoxylin-Eosin stain, Original Magnification: 10×.

Photomicrograph of balloon cell melanoma of the lesion in patient number four (male, 51 years old), displaying the characteristic balloon-shaped appearance of melanocytes with histological features that sometimes resemble pseudolipoblasts. The lesion consists of more than 50% “balloon-shaped” melanocytes, which specifically feature an abundant and finely vacuolized cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei generally located in the periphery of the cell, but not pycnotic. Very rare mitoses are observed, and melanin is quantitatively reduced within the cell, with a disordered dispersion within the lesion itself and in numerous melanophages. Architecturally, the cells are organized in large pale masses that replace the dermis and thin the epidermis, forming large solid sheets of “ballooniform” melanocytes divided into irregular aggregates by thin collagenous septa, with no clear signs of activity at the dermo-epidermal junction or pagetoid spreading. Hematoxylin-Eosin stain, Original Magnification: 20×.

Histological micrograph showing the cytological detail of melanocytes with balloon cell characteristics of the cytoplasm, from a patient with balloon cell melanoma. The lesion consists of more than 50% “balloon-shaped” melanocytes, featuring an abundant and finely vacuolized cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei generally located in the periphery of the cell, but not pycnotic. Melanin is quantitatively reduced within the cell, with a disordered dispersion within the lesion itself and in numerous melanophages. Architecturally, the cells are organized in large pale masses that replace the dermis and thin the epidermis, forming large solid sheets of “ballooniform” melanocytes divided into irregular aggregates by thin collagenous septa, with no clear signs of activity at the dermo-epidermal junction or pagetoid spreading. Very rare mitoses were observed. Hematoxylin-Eosin stain, Original Magnification: 40×.
Histopathological analysis of uveal melanoma stained with haematoxylin-eosin.

Histopathology from a shave biopsy of the lesion showing a cup-shaped lesion with hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, and papillomatosis. Vacuolation of keratinocytes is observed within the granular layer. These features are consistent with a diagnosis of epidermolytic hyperkeratosis (EH, acanthoma). (Hematoxylin and eosin stain, 40× magnification).

Histopathology showing large basophilic granules present in the granular layer and fine eosinophilic granules present in both the granular and spinous layers, representing epidermolysis. These findings are characteristic of epidermolytic hyperkeratosis (EH, acanthoma). (Hematoxylin and eosin stain, 200× magnification).

Microscopic examination of the resected well-circumscribed, dermal-based neoplasm, showing a central dilated, pore-like, keratin-filled cystic structure with an opening to the skin surface. The tumor also features emanating lobules of basaloid cells and lobular dermal aggregates of basaloid cells with multiple connections to the epidermis. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 10× magnification.

High magnification microscopic view of the cystic wall, which is composed of epithelial buddings of basaloid cells, hair-follicle-like structures (black arrows), and occasional microcysts (white arrows). The intervening stroma shows fibroblast-like cells and lymphocyte infiltrates. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 40× magnification.

Microscopic detail within the wall of the main cystic structure, showing microcysts encircled by squamous epithelium with keratohyalin granules and corneocytes in a laminated and basket-weave array (black arrows), representing infundibular differentiation. Also visible are solid aggregates of follicular germinative cells with peripheral palisading (white arrows). Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 200× magnification.

Microscopic detail within the wall of the main cystic structure, demonstrating findings of hair follicle differentiation. Areas show cells with eosinophilic trichohyalin granules (black arrows) and associated blue-gray corneocytes (white arrow heads), indicating inner root sheath differentiation. Layers of clear cells (white arrows) are present at the periphery of the trichohyalin-rich cells, resembling outer root sheath differentiation. Eosinophilic shadow cells (black arrow heads), resembling hair differentiation, are also noted. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 200× magnification.

Low-power histopathology (H&E) of an incisional biopsy from the tongue of a 30-year-old male, presenting with extensive brownish-black pigmentation of the lingual dorsum. The image shows globally preserved tissue architecture with no signs of malignancy, consistent with physiologic pigmentation of the tongue.

Higher-power histopathology (H&E) of an incisional biopsy from the tongue of a 30-year-old male, presenting with extensive brownish-black pigmentation of the lingual dorsum. Melanin pigment (arrowheads) is noted both at the basal cells of the epithelium and in the superficial connective tissue (lamina propria). There are no signs of malignancy, supporting the diagnosis of physiologic pigmentation of the tongue.

Histopathology showing submucosal melanoma (blue star). The biopsy confirmed a malignant proliferation of atypical pleomorphic cells with cherry-red macronuclei and amphophilic cytoplasm containing pigment, ultimately diagnosed as malignant melanoma, further confirmed by positive Sox10 and S100 staining. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at × 200 magnification.

Histopathology showing the proliferation of markedly atypical melanocytes with prominent macronuclei (blue arrow) and cytoplasmic pigment (red arrow). These cells are part of a malignant proliferation of atypical pleomorphic cells, characterized by cherry-red macronuclei and amphophilic cytoplasm containing pigment, confirming the diagnosis of malignant melanoma, which was also positive for Sox10 and S100. The image is stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at × 400 magnification.

Histopathology of a pigmented eccrine poroma, stained with Hematoxylin & eosin at ×10 magnification. This comparative image of the neoplasm demonstrates the absence of cytological atypia, cellular pleomorphism, increased mitotic activity, and foci of necrosis, which corroborates the exclusion of porocarcinoma as a diagnostic possibility.

Pigmented eccrine poroma, showing an area with evident intratumoral melanocytes. The histopathological examination reveals a well-defined nodular neoplasm, connected with the epidermis, consisting of small, monomorphic, cuboidal cells, with ample, eosinophilic cytoplasm and well-defined borders. Melanin deposits are diffusely distributed inside the neoplasm. (Hematoxylin & eosin, ×100 magnification).

Pigmented eccrine poroma, showing a detail of the formation of incipient intracytoplasmic lumens inside the tumor. The histopathological examination reveals intracytoplasmic lumens and ductular formations delineated by cuticles observed in some tumor cuboidal cells. The neoplasm consists of small, monomorphic, cuboidal cells, with ample, eosinophilic cytoplasm and well-defined borders. (Hematoxylin & eosin, ×400 magnification).

Histopathology of a pigmented eccrine poroma, stained with Hematoxylin & eosin (×100 magnification). The image displays a well-defined nodular neoplasm connected to the epidermis, composed of small, monomorphic cuboidal cells. These cells possess ample, eosinophilic cytoplasm and well-defined borders, exhibiting conspicuous intercellular bridges. Melanin deposition is diffusely distributed within the neoplasm. The tumor lobules do not show stromal retraction or peripheral nuclear palisading.

Histopathology at 20x magnification, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE), showing epidermal hyperplasia and cystic invaginations extending into the dermis. Numerous papillary projections (black arrow) are visible, along with hyperplastic sebaceous glands in the dermis (red arrow). The stroma is rich in plasma cells.

Histopathology at 100x magnification, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE), detailing the cellular composition of the papillary projections. These projections are covered by double layers of cells, with columnar cells forming the luminal layer and smaller cuboidal cells with larger nuclei and comparatively meager cytoplasm making up the outer layer. The stroma is rich in plasma cells.

Histopathology at 100x magnification, stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (HE), showing multiple basaloid cells in the dermis, presented in the form of a lump or cord. Characteristic features include peripheral palisading, focal retraction from the stroma, and increased pigment. A rich lymphocytic infiltrate is present in the stroma. These findings are consistent with basal cell carcinoma (BCC) in a patient diagnosed with SCAP and BCC associated with NS.

Histopathology of the anorectal tumor from a 63-year-old woman who underwent surgical resection, revealing anorectal malignant melanoma. The image shows smaller tumor cells with a diffuse distribution. Stained with hematoxylin-eosin.

Histopathological examination (hematoxylin–eosin stain) of the metastatic tumor from a modified radical mastectomy in the outer upper quadrant of the right breast. The morphological findings are consistent with metastatic malignant melanoma, which was histologically confirmed and is believed to have originated from the anorectal region. Core needle biopsy of the suspicious mass in the right breast had previously revealed a malignant tumor.

Histopathology showing dermal melanoma, epithelioid subtype, from a 77-year-old male patient who presented with a giant oozing, necrotic tumor on the scalp. Histological analysis of a biopsy sample (collected before the tumor reached nodular shape) revealed BRAF-mutant melanoma with isolated neoplastic infiltration under the epidermis, lacking an epidermal component and evidence of regression. Breslow thickness and Clark level could not be assessed. The tumor exhibits a high proliferation index of Ki-67 80% and non-brisk tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes (TILs). Epithelioid polygonal cells show mitotic activity of 15/1 mm², and the neoplastic mass has focal necrosis. (hematoxylin–eosin staining, magnification 50-fold).

Histopathology showing nodular melanoma (NM), epithelioid subtype, from a 23-year-old male patient who was admitted with a large (5 × 4 cm), firm, black, necrotic tumor on the parietal scalp. The histopathologic report indicated a Breslow thickness of 12 mm and Clark level V, with the presence of ulceration and microsatellites. (hematoxylin–eosin staining, magnification 50-fold).

Histopathology of nodular melanoma (NM) from the same 23-year-old male patient described in panel C. The image demonstrates signs of neuro-invasion, where melanoma cells infiltrated dermal nerve fibers, and angio-invasion, with clusters of melanoma cells found in the lumen of small blood vessels in the tumor front. (hematoxylin–eosin staining, magnification 280-fold).

Histopathology image of a nodular melanoma (NM) biopsy, showing significant deposits of melanin within some of the tumor cells, which is a significant feature for this tumor type. The primary tumor was composed of atypical epithelioid cells and also exhibited strong immune positivity for SOX10, HMB-45, and Melan-A. (hematoxylin–eosin staining, magnification 130-fold).

Histopathology image showing nodular melanoma (NM) with prominent nuclear inclusions in atypical epithelioid cells. The primary tumor biopsy for this case also presented strong immune positivity for SOX10, HMB-45, and Melan-A. (hematoxylin–eosin staining, magnification 380-fold).

Histopathology image of nodular melanoma (NM), epithelioid subtype, from a 67-year-old male patient who presented with a rapidly growing, bleeding melanoma tumor measuring 5 cm in the right heel region. The tumor has a Breslow depth of 10 mm and is Clark level V, with the presence of microsatellites, absent tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes (TILs), and a radial growth pattern. There is no evidence of angio- or neuro-invasions. (hematoxylin–eosin staining, magnification 30-fold).

Histopathology (H&E stain) revealing melanoma in situ, lentigo maligna type, on shave biopsy from the 5 cm ovoid pink-white plaque on the arm of a 69-year-old female patient. The patient had a five-year history of an enlarging lesion that was unresponsive to previous treatments for tinea corporis, nummular dermatitis, and actinic keratosis. Microscopy is performed at 100x total magnification.

Histopathology (H&E stain) revealing invasive lentigo maligna melanoma with a Breslow depth of 0.3 mm. This finding is associated with the 5 cm ovoid pink-white plaque on the arm of a 69-year-old female patient, who presented with an asymptomatic growth that had enlarged over five years and was unresponsive to various prior treatments. Microscopy is performed at 100x total magnification.

Histopathology of nevus pathology. A low-power view shows two foci of pigmented cells within a collagenous stroma in the superficial dermis, which is suggestive of a benign blue nevus. The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin; original magnification: ×10.

Histopathology of nevus pathology. A high-power view reveals two distinct cell types: spindled-to-dendritic melanocytes (indicated by a blue arrow) and melanophages (indicated by a red arrow). The image is stained with hematoxylin and eosin; original magnification: ×40.

Histopathological examination showing solitary nodules, representing dermal separated nodes of a relapsed cell-rich blue nevus, located in close vicinity to the scar. The nodules are constituted by a nodular dermal proliferation of ovoid melanocytes with monomorphous nuclei and inconspicuous cytoplasm, intermingled with dendritic pigmented melanocytes. Nevus cells of the nodules are dispersed in the dermis and hyperpigmented, spindle-shaped melanocytes infiltrate among the collagen bundles. No features suggestive of malignancy, such as cytological atypia, atypical mitoses, or necrosis, are observed. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) at 40× magnification. Inset shows a higher magnification view (H&E, 400×).

Histopathological examination showing recurrent cellular blue cell nevus (also referred to as relapsed cellular blue nevus). The image displays solitary nodules in close vicinity to a scar, constituted by a nodular dermal proliferation of ovoid melanocytes with monomorphous nuclei and inconspicuous cytoplasm, intermingled with dendritic pigmented melanocytes. Strongly pigmented oval-shaped, spindle-shaped, and dendritic melanocytes and melanophages occupy the upper and mid dermis. Nevus cells are dispersed in the dermis, with hyperpigmented, spindle-shaped melanocytes infiltrating among the collagen bundles. No features suggestive of malignancy, such as cytological atypia, atypical mitoses, or necrosis, are present. Stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E), 200× magnification.

Hematoxylin-eosin staining of the right buccal mucosa from the proband’s father, revealing histological features consistent with White Spongy Nevus (WSN). Panel (a) shows enlarged spinous cells and well-differentiated basal cells with an increased number of layers, as indicated by the red frame. These findings, including the significant thickening of the epithelium and hyperplasia of well-differentiated basal cells, conform to the conventional pathological manifestations of WSN. Original magnification: 40×.

Hematoxylin-eosin staining of the right buccal mucosa from the proband’s father, revealing histological features consistent with White Spongy Nevus (WSN). Panel (b) illustrates incomplete keratinization of surface cells and uneven epithelial tissue with no inflammatory infiltration, as indicated by the red frame. These characteristics, particularly incomplete keratinization of surface cells and the absence of significant inflammatory infiltration, are key pathological findings in WSN. Original magnification: 100×.

Hematoxylin-eosin staining of the right buccal mucosa from the proband’s father, revealing histological features consistent with White Spongy Nevus (WSN). Panel (c) highlights vacuolar change of spinous cells, indicated by the red arrow. The presence of enlarged and vacuolated spiny cells is a characteristic pathological manifestation of WSN. Original magnification: 200×.

Hematoxylin-eosin staining of the right buccal mucosa from the proband’s father, revealing histological features consistent with White Spongy Nevus (WSN). Panel (d) shows spinous cells with nuclear pyknosis (top arrow) and cell edema (bottom arrow). These findings, including nuclei consolidation and edematous spiny cells, are characteristic pathological manifestations of WSN. Original magnification: 400×.
